description:
I recently had the pleasure of winning (best price ever) a free dinner here thanks to a professional event.

We were seated in the private room next to the main area of the restaurant. This area lends itself very well to groups of 20ish people. Upon entering the room, I was immediately greeted by friendly staff asking me what I'd like to drink. I asked what they were offering and got the reply "we can make you anything you'd like". I was tempted, but felt like wine so went with a Cabernet Sauvignon, which was brought swiftly. I took a sip and was thoroughly impressed, this was a great wine. 

After networking, we were all seated at a large table. We each received a menu, which was completely tailored to the event (custom made with logo) and offered a list of appetizers and entrees. We learned we would receive all appetizers to share (hooray, an opportunity to taste everything!) and could pick one entree.

The appetizers did not disappoint. My personal favorite was the stuffed pepper with goat cheese (I'm sure there is a nicer description for it on the menu, but that's what it comes down to). Very satisfying. For an entree, I had the opportunity to pick between 2 meat options, 2 fish/seafood options and 1 vegetarian dish. They lose one star because the vegetarian dish did look pretty sad among their steak and seafood counterparts. I feel like they can up their game here, but granted I did not taste it. 

I went for the New York steak and it was delicious. I am not a big steak eater, but figured now was the time as I was confident this restaurant would nail it, and they did. Solid dish. This was a class act, even more so because they managed to get everyone's entree out at the same time while respecting everyone's cooking time preference (mine was spot on medium well). 

And then...they brought out a whole arrangement of tiny desserts. Oh my heavens. I was so stuffed that I only tried one and a half but they were superb. 

Top-notch experience.
author: Ellen H.

description:
Pacific Calamari "a la Plancha," Garlic + Lemon Confit $14- this was probably my favorite calamari I've ever had in my life. It was not fried, see my picture so that you realize you're not getting a large portion, but the portion you do receive is extraordinary. The sauce is also excellent for dipping with the complementary bread.  5/5

Tuna Steak Sandwich, Onion Marmalade, Arugula
$16. This was also excellent although not a large portion the quality was superb. I wanted a light lunch so this was exactly the right size and it came with a very small mixed green salad on the side with a light dressing.   It comes seared and the quality of tuna is really the star of the show although the marmalade and sourdough bread are also contributors to the overall deliciousness.  5/5

The location is very convenient right alongside the bay and the restaurant itself is actually pretty spacious and has very attractive lighting although the decor is not as Basque as I would have hoped on the interior. There is also an outdoor seating area that also would be nice on a warmer afternoon.  Complementary crusty sourdough bread is served at the table with a very nice olive oil and I also requested balsamic vinegar for dipping.
author: Ariana N.

description:
Came here for a work dinner and the service was great. 

We got a few starters including the strip steak crudo, thinly sliced ham, and the special which was octopus. Oh I loved the octopus dish.

I think what I was bummed about was the entree options. They were pretty meat heavy and there weren't a lot of solid vegetarian options or "light meat" options.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Food is great and so is the ambiance, so what's not to like?

The overzealousness of the waiters and busboys.  They want to clear your plates before you finish your food.  They also constantly interrupt your conversation with "how is everything?"

Everything is great so please leave us alone.
author: V L.

description: We just loved our dinner at this cozy beautiful restaurant. They have a nice bar too, but we decided to take a table in a very good spot. The food is very good. I would really recommend the squash soup, octuplets and even the fries there were very good. The service was excellent !!! Our waitress was so polite and helpfull! I will definitely come back!!
author: Marina B.

description:
The food was excellent and the service top-notch on our dinner visit last night. I had the toy box tomato tartlet, new york steak and the potato-manchego gratin side, and my friend had the butter lettuce salad and seafood stew. We were bowled over by the outstanding quality of everything. I'd asked for the steak to be done just under medium, and it was perfect; my friend's sea scallops and prawns were sweet and delicious with no metallic unpleasantness. 

Our server wasn't familiar with the Vesper cocktail that I asked if the bartender could make, but she queried me about the ingredients and ensured I had an wonderful rendition of that drink in front of me in just a few minutes. I really appreciated that. And she recommended a glass of the Miura 1842 Tempranillo when I asked for her opinion on a pairing for my steak -- what a great find!

I hadn't been to Piperade in a few years, and I'm so glad to see they haven't lost a step since.
author: Teresa D.

description:
This place was so hyped up, and I expected unique, quality food. Although nothing was bad, nothing really WOW-ed me. 

Dinner was perfectly average. I personally had the Piperade to start (a sort of veggie stew with bacon and a poached egg). This had really nice flavors, but there was no attention to detail here. All the veggies were cut in very different shapes and sizes, so it wasn't consistent. The egg, however, was cooked to perfection and the bacon was really good.

Other appetizer favorites included the Piquillo pepper with goat cheese (they loved this), Foie Grois, the Bacon Wrapped Dates were amazing, and the mushroom tart was well-liked.

The entrees were decent. I personally was not a huge fan of the New York Strip. I ordered it medium rare, it looked medium rare, and yet it tasted tough. It honestly tasted like steak I attempt to make for myself at home. It really needed a sauce!!! I was craving some extra flavor. The sides were good, but the steak was flavorless and tough. Not great!

Everyone else really liked their entrees. The Duck Confit was excellent. Crispy, good lentils, nice addition of carrots. Others got the special fish, the Cod, the Sea Bass, and the Pork Cheeks (nice dish, but nothing special). We felt that the Sea Bass was completely ruined by the addition of spinach. It took away from the vinegar flavor. It was a tasty fish, but the spinach made the flavor watery.

Dessert was okay. We ordered the Orange Blossom Beignets- these are NOT Beignets! They were pretty flavorless, non-stuffed profiteroles. I was almost insulted that they called these Beignets.... No. Apple tart was enjoyed.

Service was also nothing to rave about. It took ages to find someone for more water. They were not around very much.

Definitely an average meal at what was supposed to be an above par restaurant. Would not return at these prices.
author: Hannah S.

description: Brick walls, white tables clothes, the aroma of a sweet old Spanish man smoking a cigar on a beautiful evening in Basque. This place will take your tastebuds for an elegant ride in a Maserati with your top off. Eat here. Live here. You won't regret it.
author: Mcknzie R.

description:
Piperade hits all the notes.

My second visit to Piperade -- this time for lunch. A nice, lazy afternoon. Piperade was not overly busy -- just a nice relaxed 2 hour lunch. We started with the serano and pain tomate; perfect thin. My friend had the garlic soup and the Petrale. Judging by his plate they were both good. 

I went for the pig-trifecta with the sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine -- crispy and succulent, followed by the braised pork cheeks -- kind of a boeuf bourguignon alla pig thing. Add to that plenty of excellent bread to sop up the luscious sauce and a couple of glasses of Rioja, a decadent chocolate mousse and excellent coffee and I was more than happy.

Nice service, never rushed but attentive. A great way to spend a Friday afternoon.
author: John C.

description: Very nice looking restaurant, good service and just average food. When you walk into this place it has a great look, from the cute outdoor seating at the front to the vibrant set up indoors. We ordered lunch, a burger and a vegetable risotto type dish. The burger was ok and the rice was completely flavorless. Tried and done.
author: Sabrina D.

description: A solid place for lunch. Atmosphere, great attitudes and my dish was what I needed after a long week. I ordered the hamburger medium well. I believe it was served on a fluffy but perfect density brioche bun with Swiss cheese, fresh tomatoes and lettuce and a smattering of mayo. Fries were one of the best I've had and served with a side of a spicy-fancy ketchup concoction.
author: Danielle Y.

description:
Nice looking restaurant with solid food, about a 3.5.  Great service, as they split every dish into two servings for us.  We had:
- Beet salad (3/5) - Pretty tasty but basic.
- Bacon wrapped dates (3/5)
- Piperade (4/5) - Interesting stew of peppers and onions with nice runny poached egg.  Definitely the best dish of the night.
- Pork cheeks (3/5)
author: Simon L.

description: Ahi mahi mahi salad has quality sashimi grade fish and  fresh vegetables and hard boiled eggs in a light vinaigrette dressing. I only wish there was a bit more in quantity. Elegant restaurant and good professional service. I would happily come here again. Next time I will make time for an appetizer and dessert as well. Prices are not cheap but also not the highest. Quality food is what you get here. Very good Basque food.
author: Lucy L.

description: Excellent service, perfectly executed pintxos and appetizers, warm, inviting and comfortable dining room featuring exposed brick and attractive artwork.  Highly recommend.
author: Matthew G.

description:
5/5: food
5/5: ambiance 
5/5: service

Hard to come by but we enjoyed every dish we got. The asparagus soup, sea bass, mushroom tart, and calamari. Probably the best calamari I've had in San Francisco - super tender, juicy, and flavorful. The dessert was also delightful. The sea bass came with this sour-ish soupy sauce and it was totally different and refreshing. 

Our server was also so knowledgeable and gave us good recommendations especially on wine choices.
author: Terrie C.

description:
I've been a fan of Gerald Hirigoyen's going back to the opening of Fringale back in the early '90s. When a friend suggested we go to Piperade and told me it was Gerald's place, my expectations were high to say the least. I was not disappointed by our dinner. Nuanced, layered flavors with the Basque "comfort food" feel made for a perfect evening.

The wine list was imaginative and our time at the bar while waiting for our table was fun. 

Highly recommended!
author: Brian B.

description: Food was great, service was good. Very pricey. I'm Basque and wanted to try it. Glad I did. I would go back
author: John E.

description:
What a wonderful restaurant! The perfect spot to take your date to for a special date night. Given it's so close to Embarcadero, if you don't mind the wind it's also great to walk by the bay afterwards.

I have to start with the bread. My god, consuming carbs never felt this right and wrong at the same time. A bit of olive oil, balsamic and seasoning the only thing you have to worry about is leaving enough room for the actual dishes. 

We have ordered two appetizers. The calamari and Piperade. I have to be honest, Piperade wasn't really $18 worthy but it was still a nice dish. Calamari though, was incredible! The citrusy flavor and the fact that it wasn't fried made everything much more flavorsome!

For the main dish we have ordered the seafood stew and the fact that they've separated the dish onto two plates because we were sharing made me realize how much this restaurant cared about their customers. The flavor? Again, just fantastic.

Meanwhile we were ordering our wine and usually I hope the wine is average but god no, it was also quite good! Hats off to you guys!

At the end, after having so many wonderful dishes and having a great time we wanted indulge ourselves with dessert. Decided on the Hazelnut dish, we told them we would share and again they've amazed us by cutting the dessert right in the middle and serving on two plates. Dessert? Yup, it was fascinating.

So please, please give this place a try. They will live up to all the expectations you have.
author: Ali O.

description:
This is a MealPal review:

The Chicken Mandarin salad on offer was very solid. Fresh vibrant greens and frisee, delicious panko encrusted chicken with shaved parmesan and walnuts. Quite a treat! Great value. I would've rated it a 5 if the dressing was better, there wasnt enough and not much flavor. I added salt, pepper, a splash of soy sauce on the chicken before devouring. I need to come back for dinner.
author: jacob m.

description:
After going on a trip to Spain last year, I have never been the same. So when I can get to a restaurant that helps bring me back, to that magical experience, even if it's only through food, wine and a waiter with a slight accent, it's a wonderful gift. 

Piperade is small. The menu isn't too extensive, but it's alluring enough to go back for more. There is something for everyone, the pescadarian, the vegetarian, the vegan and the full fledged carnivore. They will even modify happily to cater to the dairy or gluten free person as well. 

We had the Dungeness Crab Cake Special, Gem Lettuce Salad, Warm Olives for starters. The Crab special was light with tangy fruit and greens mixed to make a pleasureful mouthful in each bite. 

I went for another appetizer The Calamari with lemon and garlic as my main course while my dates opted for the special and the Sea Bass. Our table hardly spoke a word, while we dug into our entrees. 

Don't skip the traditional basque cake, with a side of Tawny Port. It's small in proportion and just enough to wet your desert quench without filling you up. And oh, those fresh black cherries on top were splendid.. 

It's so close to home, I must return! Enjoy!
author: Cassandra E.

description:
Two stars because I had a meeting there and the outcome was good. Don't go here expecting basquaise food.

Service: very rude and brusque. I was greeted by a portly older man in a chefs jacket. I told him I'm meeting two people and they have made a reservation, I'm early. Gave him the name of one of the ladies and clarified that I'm not the one that made the reservation so I'd wait till the others arrived. He said, "Well I can tell you're obviously not (American name). So okay." How utterly uncouth and typical sexist racist old fogey behaviour.

Food: How on earth is a bloody tuna melt a basquaise "chef's special" for lunch?! Do these people think their patrons are stupid?
Service: awful. My plate was cleared with no warning while I was eating. Apparently, if you put your fork and knife down between bites, your plate will be removed.
Manners: zero. The waiters were grouchy and kept hitting the back of my head without even an apology.

Pretty sure the kitchen atmosphere is dreadful and that's the reason for the nasty negative vibe here.
author: Mick J.

description: The chef is perfection here.  Hands down one of my favorites in SF.  I can not pick a favorite as I try something new each time.  Excellent dessert choices and I always order the orange blossom beignets to take home.  The service is very professional and this place is reserved for special occasions or holiday season.
author: David W.

description:
Overall I had a good experience. 

First off I like the location, because it's an area in the city you can actually drive to and find free parking for dinner, which is pretty rare.

The ambience inside is nice. Service was average not great but not bad. 

Now diving into the food - I ordered the calamari, the sea bass and the chocolate cake. I really enjoyed the calamari it was cooked really well and had nice flavor but wasn't overpowering. I was disappointed in the sea bass, it was overcooked. I know fish can get overcooked easily but at least it was only slightly overcooked so it wasn't dry it was just a bit chewy. Another person I was dining with had the braised pork cheeks and those were delicious, very tender! Lastly for dessert I had the chocolate cake which was decadent and had creme fraiche on the side, it was good and pretty much what you'd think for a chocolate cake. It tasted like a chocolate lava cake minus the melted chocolate lava center. 

I had a nice dinner here and I'd come again in the future but i guess there wasn't anything that particularly stood out to me that was something I could only get here. For that I'm giving it 3.5 stars.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
It must be very hard to successfully run a restaurant.  Economics and all.  Recently, I've been to a number of places and the serving sizes go down as the pricing goes up.  That isn't necessarily meant as a criticism, just a statement of the facts of life.  

This past Saturday I dined at Piperade.  Some things hadn't changed at all.  My server was a somewhat pushy salesman who, after I declined his suggestions for add ons, was distant and disinterested in checking up on me.

Nevertheless the dungeness crab Txangurro was a lovely if pricey appetizer.  The crab was sweet and as abundant as it should have been in a $20 appetizer.

The rack of lamb main course was actually two lamb chops accompanied by a sausage.  That's hardly a rack.  The chops were nicely prepared but in no way better or less expensive than one might get at nearby Kokkari, and at least at Kokkari some potatoes accompany the lamb.  

Slowly but surely places like The Slanted Door and now Piperade and becoming special occasion places as prices aim towards the stratosphere.
author: David D.

description: Pretty mediocre all the way around.  Their signature Piperade dish was rather bland.  Seafood stew was fine, unmemorable.  Service, while friendly, was slow beyond belief.  The setting is quite lovely. Parking is relatively easy for SF.
author: Eric C.

description:
Love the entrance to Piperade, you have big sofa's and very comfortable seating and you can actually sit there, and wait for your table to be ready, or even have drinks or food on the warmer days.
This place feels really great, the second you walk in. Simple, but great decoration, and always friendly hostess.
Great big bar.
After coming here for a few times, I still didn't find my favorite dish, but everything tastes good and everything is done and presented well.
This restaurant is at the perfect location, at the Battery street, there is always parking spaces in the evening, which make life so much easier if you are driving.
A place that we will be visiting over and over, because of great food and great service that we received every single time that we come here.
author: Bianca G.

description:
$26.00 for a three course meal during lunch?? YESS!!
(Prix Fixe: Includes Soup or Green Salad / Chef's Entrée / Choice of Dessert)

Came here twice so far and I must say this place has not disappointed me - service was great, dishes were well prepared and presented. 

Some dishes I've tried:
Pacific Calamari "a la Plancha," Garlic + Lemon Confit -- Must order!
Baby Gem Lettuce, Fresh Herb Vinaigrette -- the lettuce is soooo fresh! 
Blue Nose Sea Bass, Spinach, Fried Garlic Vinaigrette -- loved the combo of ingredients

Can't wait to come back to try more dishes!
author: Leilani Y.

description: My mother-in-law and I had a lovely Friday night dinner here. We split three small plates (calamari, tomatoes tart, and a salad) and one main entree (lamb). All the food was fresh, high quality, and prepared with care. The service was attentive without feeling smothering.
author: Tara T.

description:
Many restaurants are labeled fine french cuisine but that's not the reality. With the Piperade restaurant you will find a REAL French Basque restaurant with a truly incredible quality of food, an incomparable flavor. The service is just as impeccable. The cost for this type of restaurant AND this quality is reasonable. It was a no-fault, I would have liked to meet the owner to congratulate him unfortunately he was gone when we paid our bill.

Beaucoup de restaurants sont étiquetés fine cuisine francaise mais ce nest pas la realité. Avec le restaurant Piperade vous trouverez un VRAI restaurant de cuisine francaise basque avec une qualité des mets vraiment incroyable, une saveur incomparable. le service y est tout aussi impeccable. Le coût pour ce type de restaurant ET cette qualité est raisonnable. Cela a ete un sans faute, j'aurais juste aimé rencontrer le proprietaire pour le féliciter malheureusement il etait parti quand nous avons payé notre facture.
author: Jean-François H.

description: I ordered the Piperade appetizer and was pleasantly surprised. I wasn't expecting to enjoy the dish but after 1 bite I was taken aback and had a flashback to the dinner scene in the movie Ratatouille( the scene where the restaurant critic was taken back by the simplicity of the dish and the sophistication of its flavors). It was kind of like that. I would definitely come back again to try their entrees and desserts. 5 stars all the way!!!
author: Chinere M.

description:
Popped into Piperade yesterday for a quick business lunch. I'd never eaten there but, only ever been once before for a Burgundy tasting, and that was a number of years ago. Needless to say, I was excited about the food because I love all things Spanish/Basque. We were kindly greeted at the door by the chef/owner and seated at a nice white table clothed window table. The servers were prompt but, not invasive of our time and space. The mark of great customer service. 

Anyway, on to the food...

They are known for their "Stuffed Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pistachios, Golden Raisins", so we started with that and boy was it delicious. The richness from the cheese and the basil spread below worked in perfect harmony. They had a special running which was the dungeness crab salad, so why the heck not?! I love all things crab and this salad was essentially a heaping pile of pulled dungeness with a a few greens on top. For my main, I was feelin' some fish so opted for the "Blue Nose Sea Bass, Spinach, Fried Garlic Vinaigrette". The level of acid on this dish was heavenly and super sophisticated. Order this if you're a fan of spinach and the "irony" feel it leaves in your mouth for hours afterwards :) 

A solid lunch spot and meal no doubt. I'll surely be back for dinner, armed with wines that will be on the same level.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Very disappointed by the sea bass, which was swimming in vinegar. I could only eat 2 bites (but was not offered a replacement).
author: Mary F.

description:
Took my boyfriend here for his birthday dinner with a Travelzoo dinner in hand. $79 for two appetizers, two entrees, and two desserts but I did not actually end up saving that much money in the end. 

Made reservations via phone and let them know we were celebrating a birthday. Arrived at 6:30 on a Friday to a nearly dead restaurant. Told our waiter we had a Travelzoo deal and he said it had to be printed out. This has never happened to me before and I told him I only had it on my phone. The hostess came over and apologized for our waiter not knowing we could have it on our phone. She took down the voucher number. All set right? 

Our waiter goes through the appetizers. My bf wants the foie gras. Its a $10 additional charge because its a special item. Okay cool. No problem. Time for the entrees. BF wants the steak, its $32. Voucher says entrees up to $30. Thought we would just pay the difference but nope, another $10 fee. What? Waiter starts raging out of NOWHERE. Straight up all IT SAYS ON THE VOUCHER I'M JUST THE MESSENGER THATS WHAT IT SAYS WHAT DO YOU WANT ME TO DO?! Literally yelling at this point. I am high so I am unfazed. Cool as a cucumber. The voucher does not say anything about a $10 charge. I ask the hostess, she confirms it says the $10 fee on the voucher. It literally says nowhere on it but okay fine. 

Appetizers come. Mushroom tart is amazing. BF hates the foie gras he insisted on. He took one bite and would not take another. I end up eating 1000 calories worth of foie gras too myself. Feel sick. Give him death glare. Time for the entrees. Mashed corn the best thing I've ever eaten. Salmon is crispy but too salty in some parts. BF couldn't finish his steak. Didn't pack it to go. Goodbye leftover steak. 

Dessert time. Got the flan and the beignets. Beignets were whatever, flan blew my mind. BF eats all the flan even though he ordered the beignets. No candles. I noticed someone else had a candle in their dessert. Down my cocktail. 

Waiter comes by and apologizes for being a dick and forgetting birthday candle. Gives us another dessert with candle. Stuffed. Hide the rest of the dessert in a napkin in my purse. BF eats the cake out of the napkin while still at the restaurant. Classy.

Go to party next day. Tell everyone about dinner at Piperade. No one has heard of it.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
"Piperade," my coworker texted. Sounds like "haterade," I said, as I walked over to her desk. Not feeling like any one particular cuisine / being sad that I was going to work until midnight on a Friday, we quickly decided on piperade (the restaurant's namesake), the mushroom tartlet, and the piquillo peppers.

^(Actually, we just ordered delivery via Postmates and I am procrastinating by writing this intro. Will be back with the food commentary momentarily!)

Our piperade was dropped from our order without explanation. 

As for the rest: the piquillo peppers had light goat cheese, with hydrated (by the cheese) nuts and raisins. I've always like hydrated raisins. Red peppers that are preserved, however, have never been my thing. I've always found them to be kind of slimy. My coworker liked it though. 3/5.

The mushroom tart was a fine choice-- flaky, buttery rust. The mushrooms were quite al dente. The cheesy sauce on the tart complemented things well. 3.25/5.
author: Nicole H.

description: Very disturbing experience. A 38 dollar bottle of wine was charged as 85 dollar on the bill. They tried to convince us that this was correct and only after repeated assertions did they acknowledge that their calculation was WRONG. No apologies, no attempts to compensate such an embarrassing mistake. I recommend that you avoid this restaurant, but if you really want to go, check your bill carefully before you offer your credit card
author: carla m.

description:
Dinner review. 

Mushroom tartlet - 7x7 - 5/5
Roasted rack of lamb - 5/5 
Braised pork cheeks - 4/5
Gateau basque - 7x7 - 3/5
Peanut Butter chocolate rocher - 4/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
I bought a Travelzoo coupon for $80 which included 2 sets of appetizer + entree + dessert and used it with my parents for dinner last Thursday.

I made a reservation beforehand because it was so easy to do so, but I don't think I really needed to. There were some empty tables when we arrived a little bit before 6.

We ordered (* marks recommended):

Appetizer
*Seasonal mushroom tartlet (on the 7x7 list): LOVED this dish!! I love mushrooms, so the combination of the different types of mushrooms on top of a soft buttery tart was absolutely divine.

Piperade: had to order the namesake of this restaurant! The soup was a little bit on the salty side but otherwise it was pretty tasty especially with the bacon strips and the poached egg. Tip: Save some of the bread you get at the beginning to dip into and eat with the piperade.

Entree
Bizkaiko (braised seafood and shellfish stew): I was impressed with how much seafood came with this dish. My parents and I all tried this, and even split between 3 people, there was plenty of seafood to go around. There were scallops, salmon, some other types of fish, shrimp, and squid cooked together in a tasty sweet pepper-based sauce.

Braised pork cheeks: the meat was fall-off-the-bone tender (though there wasn't actually a bone). I really enjoyed cutting off small pieces and dipping it into the gravy for some additional flavor.

Dessert
*Dark chocolate cake: this ties with the mushroom tart for my most enjoyable dish at this restaurant. I don't like the bitterness of dark chocolate, but this cake was the right amount of sweetness, not too much and not too little! And the best part was that it's served warm (maybe straight from the oven?) so each bite you take is a soft warm piece of chocolate-y wonderfulness. My parents aren't huge fans of American desserts normally, but even they really enjoyed this cake.

French apple tart: this was an okay dessert. It was already sweet enough without the caramel sauce, so the sauce felt like it was too much.

On top of the $80 I had already bought, I paid another $32 for tax and tip. Not bad for a nice enjoyable meal out with my parents!

Note: the environment felt pretty formal. Most of the diners were pretty dressed up, though there were some more casually dressed patrons as well. Would be a nice spot for a date (in fact I saw multiple couples there), especially if the weather cooperates and you can sit outside in their patio area.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Looking for tapas? 
Want to swoon someone?
Dinner date?
Hidden in the North beach area
Ambiance: chic and modern
Service: great

What's hot on the menu?
Twice cooked Oxtail, Napa cabbage pickled pepper
Stripped Steak Crudo
Chilled Foie Gras
Stuffed Piquillo Peppers
Dungeness Crab salad
Blue nose Seabass
Braised Duck confit 
Lamb shank

Dessert 
Dark Chocolate Cake
Orange blossom beignets-i didn't like
author: Kathy V.

description:
We had a reception in the private room for $4,000. They promised and forgot candles there was no music. Butter was broken and cold. The food was a let-down, plain and simple.  The vegan food had tomato in every course, seems like they were running out of options - no creativity for a vegan guest of honor they knew about in advance. My one and only appetizer was a skewer of half a grape, half of a cherry tomato and small piece of beet.  I was starving for salad that came as a butter leaf lettuce with only dressing and my entree was bland rice with corn and the same cherry tomato from the appetizer.
 
We had to wait over 15 minutes after all but 3 guests had dinner for steaks to cook instead of putting them on sooner so the steaks finished off together. This is not how a fine dining establishment handles a Wednesday night party of $4k.  I am very disappointed that the Chef only defended himself when he messaged the Event Manager. Very sad won't be back.
author: Nadine G.

description: Pricey but exquisite food, amazingly delicious. Great and elegant
author: Melissa R.

description: Fine cuisine from Basque Country, with the most fresh and carefully selected ingredients, and great attention to detail. Loved that they went out of their way to set a special table for us. And they made my dishes with low sodium / no salt added which tells me that they truly made it from scratch. Ate calamari and octopus (special of the day) and chicken as the main course. Had their gateaux basque, and they even added some sour cherries for me... special treat and impeccable service.
author: Stefan D.

description: The best Basque food I've had outside of Spain. The food is both French and Spanish Basque, but seems to be more focused on the Spain side of Basque food. First the vibe: the restaurant and bar both have a warm and comfortable feel, but with a lot of energy coming from not only the customers, but the servers, as well. The cocktails are excellent and the wine list is phenomenal. The food is outstanding, and everything from the Pintxos to the Main Courses are delicious. Everything I've had during my four visits to this restaurant has been incredible, with a few memorable standouts: Calamari "a la Plancha", Almond Stuffed Medjool Dates, and Stuffed Piquillo Peppers. But, the star of any meal I've had at Piperade is the Braised Seafood  and Shellfish Stew-this is a top five meal I've had anywhere. Bottom line: if you are anywhere near this restaurant, work it into your schedule and GO!
author: Carlos D.

description: I was a bit nervous based on some mixed reviews but this place was honestly amazing. Definitely a spurge and treat yourself dinner, but nothing left us unsatisfied. The mushroom tarts pastry was incredible!! The Piperade appetizer was delicious but not as impressive. My fiancé had the pork cheeks and they were tender and savory, but my entree was my favorite; it was a seafood stew special (different to their usual) with clams, prawns, scallops and muscles. The sauce was so savory and just spot on, and perfect for dipping their sourdough in. To finish we had the chocolate cake for our birthday celebration, and they split it down the middle with a candle which was very sweet. The desert itself was the perfect balance of rich chocolate and refreshing creme. Will definitely be back!
author: Liz H.

description:
Ordered soup, calamari, and salad to get started.

Duck and pork entrees.  

Almond cake and apple tarts for desert.

Everything was totally amazing, wonderful flavors.  The salad was simple, but the more you eat, the more you appreciate it.  Pacing of meal was nice, not too fast, not too slow.

Owner stopped by.  All in all, an incredible and unforgettable dining experience.  Merci!
author: R H.

description: This is a charming, cozy place tucked in a off the beaten path at the foot of the hill between Russian and Telegraph Hills.  It has a very comfortable ambiance and atmosphere and nice for a casual dinner.  The appetizers were quite good, fresh and tasty with a Basque flair.  I had the lamb for my main course and it was exceptional.  Although a bit salty on the edges the overall preparation and taste was spot on.  It came with some wonderfully good accompaniments, including a small sausage, and I would gladly order this again.  Wine, dessert (especially the beignets!) and everything about the experience was worthwhile. Service seemed a bit harried and overwhelmed, but didn't detract much from the entire time.  This is the place to go if you want a cozy San Francisco restaurant not innundated by the tourist crowd.
author: Tom B.

description: This is probably on top of my best of the best restaurants in San Francisco. It was exceptionally delicious the wine, food, dessert and the ambience very romantic I highly recommend it. Gus and I will definitely be back soon!
author: Ericka C.

description:
Had a delightful meal at Piperade; a Basque restaurant with both folksy charm and polished sophistication. We started with cocktails from the cocktail menu and the fried Manchego cheese with pickled vegetables. The cocktails were incredible and the cheese was quite good too.

Next, we had two appetizers -- the Basque salad and the grilled calamari. They split both for us without us even asking, which was nice. The calamari was some of the best I've had. Very tender and the sauce was so delicious that I had to sop it up with bread.

We ordered glasses of red wine, both of which were excellent, with our dinner. The lamb chops and the swordfish. The lamb was perfectly done and the swordfish also was very tasty. Everything was perfectly prepared and presented.

For dessert, we shared the dark chocolate cake (more or less a lava cake) and the lemon roll (which was not very lemony and a bit dense for sponge). I wish we would have ordered the beignets. Maybe next time!

Lovely service, very nice pace, fantastic food and a cozy yet upscale environment. Cost including tip was $225 for two.
author: Angelique L.

description:
Piperade exquisitely prepared for and hosted a 30-year reunion event of 28 people on a Saturday night.  The Lauburu room was a perfect fit for our group.
Its artistic ambiance and backdrop contributed to an upbeat feeling during the dinner
and helped folks feel comfortable to stand up and share stories.
The staff was outstanding and spot on.  The food and drinks were excellent.
It was a great foundation for a memorable evening!
author: Robert G.

description:
My friend and I came here for dinner before watching If/Then at the Orpheum. She wanted to cross something off her 7x7 list, and I was pleasantly surprised when I realized that Piperade was one of the restaurants I regularly pass by but had never been to.

We started with the Mushroom Tartlet, which was her 7x7 item, along with the Serrano Ham accompanied by EVOO and tomato compote. Both were delicious! The Mushroom Tarlet was perfectly flaky and had a wide array of different mushroom varieties. I LOVE MUSHROOMS. The Serrano Ham was also tasty and went well with the complimentary bread at our table. 

Our tiny two-person table got a little crowded with two appetizers, bread, and our glasses of wine... but we managed. For our main courses, we shared the New York Steak and Duck Confit. Personally I liked the steak. The fact that it had black pepper sauce immediately caught my eye. It was served with a side of super buttery garlic broccoli rabe. YUM!! Would come back here specifically for this dish again. The Duck Confit was delicious as well. Was not quite in the mood for something so greasy but it's a good dish. Both portions were huge and very filling.

We enjoyed our meal with a few glasses of Syrah before heading out to the musical. I'm thinking about taking my boyfriend here for an anniversary dinner. Perfect place for that! Professional service with a classy ambiance. Love Piperade.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Came here for my fiancé's birthday and although we were definitely the youngest ones in the place, we really enjoyed the atmosphere and service. 
Food was good portion sized and delicious!
author: Hannah H.

description:
A nice, big restaurant serving Basque food in North Beach. I had a delight time with my friend here. The decoration inside is very classic and European-style, which I would see as a nice break from hipster and trendy places I frequent mostly. Most customers were dressing up and with their colleagues/partners from business. But I didn't feel very uncomfortable in my casual normcore-style clothes. 

We shared 5 appetizers and 2 desserts, which was a lot for 2 girls. 3 dishes stand out the most - stuffed pepper with goat cheese, pistachios, and raisins, grilled calamari, and mushroom tartlet. 
Stuffed pepper looks really fluffy and adorable - pink-red pepper skin is paired with cream-white filling, which looks more like a dessert than an appetizer. And the taste lives up to the look! The goat cheese filled my mouth with crunchy pistachio pieces and sweet raisins. Simple yet sophisticated taste and texture. Love it!

Grilled calamari is very fresh and with great texture - not too dry and over-cooked, and not too raw and chewy. The sauce itself has a nice sour taste, and could be easily sopped up with bread.

We also tried Orange Blossom Beignets. While I think it does smell like blossom and spring, the taste is not as vibrant. And would be nice if it's softer and more fluffy. 

Overall, if you want an adventure for Spanish food in the city, this one should be on your list!
author: Yuhuan T.

description: Felt the appetizers were more inventive than the entree.  Not much on the plate for the price, although the Sea Bass was tasty.  Staff was very attentive!
author: Randy M.

description:
Piperade offers original and authentic Basque dishes in a cozy, warm environment.
We enjoyed the sautéed calamari, beans, oxtail, and pizza as well as a scrumptious dessert. The portions are large and can be easily shared. Our waitress was exuberant and engaging, making our experience special. Everything is made fresh, in house.   Piperade deserves to be on the Chronicle top 100 list.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Came here for an office dinner once and it blew me away. I had never had basque cuisine before, and I'm glad I got to here (..and on the company card). I remember we split a few appetizers and they were all great. I ordered the Basque Rice as the main dish, a great vegetarian option, and nearly licked my plate clean. We also had the desserts and they were fabulous as well. The restaurant itself is very nice- a bit far from Market Street and the middle of financial district though- and would be a great date spot.
author: Alka M.

description:
Returned here for the 1st time in a few years and was disappointed.  
They ruined and misrepresented an octopus appetizer, explained as "ceviche style".  It wasn't.  It was a couple pieces of octopus and about a half a box of croutons plus some potatoes.  The worst octopus appetizer I've ever had bar none and I order it in various styles frequently
The duck confit was fine but ordinary.
They brought food before brining the wine that was ordered in time to be delivered before the food, hence a demerit for the service.
The noise was oppressive and much much noisier than I remember.
The one big plus - street parking is easy.
author: S K.

description: This is one of our "go to " places.  The reservations are always honored in a timely fashion, service is very professional without being hovering, the food is delicious, the wine selection is good. This could have been a 5* rating except that the gluten free options are very limited. I  had few choices but the stuffed pepper appetizer is excellent and the halibut special was very good. I loved their flan for dessert and my husband had the apple tartin.  All very good.
author: Marianne K.

description: Good expirience, nice food , the service was ok, and the environment was good...like the dessert
author: Andrea R.

description: Bought the travel zoo deal but it didn't really save us much. The decor is nice and service is attentive. Great wine selection and list. I ordered the rack of lamb which was cooked perfectly and was good. We also Had the sea bass which was also good. To finish off I had the custard which was good.
author: Andrew M.

description: We found this deal on travelzoo for dinner for 2 and we were so happy with not just the deal but the food, service and the whole ambiance of the place was worth a lot more than what we paid for. Service was always friendly and attentive. The food was amazing especially the stuffed pepper. And the deserts were a wonderful way to end the night. And they had a nice wine list by the glass as well a giant wine list by the bottle. We would definitely return even without another travelzoo deal.
author: L T.

description: Excellent food, the service is wonderful. It is pricey but that's the SF pricing nowadays. As french, I appreciate the basque flavors and the calamari dish as well as the carpaccio are my favorite! I wish the size of these plates was a bit bigger. Not a fan of the dessert menu, I was expecting more in pastries coming from a french restaurant. Overall very fine and cozy atmosphere, love this place! Thanks.
author: Claire M.

description:
My friend and I came here before our date for If/Then at the Orpheum.  We needed to finish up my list and since we were in the area for work and figured I should check another thing off the list! 

I ended up getting there a bit earlier than my friend so I ordered a glass of Syrah - it's basically the only red I like other than red blends.  

We started off with the mushroom tartlet (on the 7x7 list) and the serrano ham with tomato compote.  The mushroom tartlet was delicious. The pastry was very well made and the mushrooms were really good too. I'm not a big mushroom fan before, but these were very well made and had a great flavors to it too.  The serrano ham was also great. I paired mine with some of the tomato compote and the free bread they gave us. 

We also ordered the duck confit and the steak. The steak came with this great black pepper sauce and it made the steak so much better.  It also came with these REALLY buttery broccoli rabe too - good though.  The duck confit came with these great lentils that were good, but not amazing.  Definitely the steak was a great order option. 

Protip: mushroom tarlet and the steak!
author: Nina Y.

description: Honestly, I was pleasantly surprised! I had eaten at Piperade at least a decade ago, and now I'm left thinking, Why did I wait so long to go back? Our meal was lovely. Service was extremely knowledgeable about appropriate bottles of wine and the promptness was appreciated, and it was a nice atmosphere. Everything from the bread at the beginning to dessert. A very solid restaurant to add to your rotation.
author: jamie h.

description:
This place is ok... just had lunch with 3 customers and the setting is nice, but food and service is just ok. This place serves Spanish/French small plate dishes and I expected to be pretty fancy and upscale, but it isn't for my taste. The staff are pretty slow for service and it took 45 mins into our lunch to get my ice tea and sparkling water. Also the server came every 10 mins to ask us if the food is finished.... when the place isn't really busy. Over all, the place looks nice but everything is pretty average. Not sure why it shows $$$ for pricing when four of us only had a $200 bill for lunch and we ordered lots stuff. 

We had the tuna salad, the tuna is very thick and fresh but the salad is very plain, not taste.

The bacon, egg shrimp soup is ok.

The calamari- didn't know it was t deep fried... it tasted strange...

The oxtail - pretty good, my fav. out of everything.

The New York steak canes super thin sliced... which was strange and don't have anything to go with it.

We also had a pre-fix: don't remember the dishs name, but it's mix of pork belly, duck feet and sausage baked together in some sort of sauce... looks too heavy. 

Not sure if I will come back again...
author: Mingge L.

description:
Disappointing, for an upscale establishment in the Financial District. I have the sense that they often do better than they did last night, but last night was "off" in a few important ways.

I arrived quite early, at 6:45pm for a 7:15pm reservation; and as such, had absolutely no expectation that I would be seated early. My expectation was to have a cocktail at the bar and await my friend's arrival. However, since I was there anyway, I figured I'd announce myself to the Maître d so they would know I was present. So I did, then I went to take a seat at the bar, however there weren't any seats. So I walked outside and took a seat on the stairs of the chiropractor's office nextdoor and waited a bit. Understandable, so far everything was as one would expect.

My friend arrived and we announced ourselves at 7:10pm for our 7:15pm reservation. We were told that our table wasn't ready yet, but that there were two seats at the bar, and we were welcome to sit there until they were ready for us. So we walked through the crowded restaurant to the two seats at the back of the bar, to be informed by someone that they were "saved" for his two friends who were in the restroom. So we cancelled our order with the bartender and walked BACK to the front of the restaurant to wait again.

At 7:30pm we were told our table (7:15 reservation) was almost ready. And again at 7:45pm. At 7:50pm we were offered complimentary cocktails since we had to wait so long. At 8:00pm we were finally seated. In the meantime, I had to call and cancel an appointment I had made for after dinner; there was no way I could make it on time. That appointment had to be rescheduled for next Friday, as they had no other openings beforehand... so now my schedule for the week is skewed and my weekend plans have to be adjusted. Really annoying.

The food was fairly hit-or-miss. Credit where credit is due; the stuffed piquillo pepper was flavorful and delicious. Though the menu said peppers and it was, in reality, one small pepper (for $14). It was fantastic and totally worth getting, even at that price, but a bit misleading and I was already cranky at this point.
We ordered the pommes frites as well, and they were amongst the best shoestring french fries I've ever had. The Calamari Txipiroa, however, which was their special of the night, was really not a dish I enjoyed at all. I don't know what "ink sauce" is supposed to taste like, and perhaps the dish was prepared flawlessly and I simply have a peasant's palate, but to me the entire dish tasted like smoke and rice. I actually left it mostly unfinished on my plate. The orange blossom beignets somewhat made up for this, as they were perfection.

In summary, a delightful aesthetic, poor organization and time management, cursory efforts to compensate us for a fairly ridiculous wait, some really good dishes, some really unpleasant dishes, and pricey.

I probably wouldn't return; in a city with so many high-end restaurants, I suspect that there's just better out there.
author: Sean B.

description:
This place is very hard to find. I've lived in the Levi's Plaza neighborhood for 6 months now and had it not been for yelp I never would've known it existed. It's in an alley southwest of the Pottery Barn headquarters. (Mad props to the chef inside of the main Piperade for giving me directions)

I haven't been to the sit down establishment yet (it's bookmarked for sure!), so I can't compare this to-go stand location to it. 

I had the yelp-recommended Mr. Williams. The sandwich took a bit of time to make, so be prepared to wait. There are plenty of pre-made sandwich, wrap, and spring roll options if you need a quick grab and go option. 

The chewy, crusty bread was excellent!-- totally worth the carbs. The breaded chicken was crispy and perfectly complimented with cheese, avocado, and roasted red peppers. The lightly dressed small salad of mixed greens was simple and a nice sidekick to the sandwich. 

I will certainly be back to try the turkey and Brie sandwich and a wrap when I need a quick lunch near my home
author: Andrea H.

description: We ate there for the 1st (and not last) time 3 nights ago. Terrific menu along with an excellent wine list with lots of interesting Basque wines. Welcoming and capable staff. Just a very, very good restaurant.
author: Rex S.

description: We had a great experience with a party of 13.  Service was attentive and efficient.  We enjoyed a variety of dishes, including beet salad, calamari, duck, steak, and many more.  The old-fashioned cocktail was sub-par, as it was served on the rocks and tasted weak.  Where were those large, single ice cubes?
author: Myles L.

description: Well - this is NOT the place to go if you're lookin' to "cut-up, get funky and get loose." Piperade is a bit buttoned-up. But it is EXCELLENT for a business lunch (never too noisy, moderately priced and wide menu selection).  It's a bit off of the beaten path - but service is solid and the food NEVER disappoints.
author: Nick S.

description:
I always think of Piperade as a nice hidden gem. Close to a lot, yet on its own quiet litle street. Romantic, lively but not noisy, but a little overpriced.

THE COST
We got a TravelZoo deal: $79 for 2 glasses of wine, 2 starters, 2 entrees, & 2 desserts. It was worth it, though I would've found it a little much at full price ($148 value).

SERVICE
The hostess was great: friendly, came around often to fill water & other little things. Our server, however, didn't show up at our table for a good 10 minutes, even after we were looking around the restaurant quite obviously. He acted a little too suave & could've been more apologetic about (or even just acknowledged) ignoring us for so long. He did let me upgrade my glass of wine (part of our TravelZoo deal) to a cocktail for free.

COCKTAILS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=KoYaJDlobS-3wt7udyCg3Q#KoYaJDlobS-3wt7udyCg3Q
* Elkano (Botran Reserva Rum, King GInger, Pineapple, Peach Bitters. $10) - 4 stars
This was light & refreshing, just like I asked our server to recommend me, quite boozy yet well-balanced. My bf usually doesn't like the cocktails I get but was floored by this one.

TTIPIAK (Small): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#UinIriSngshUjphtMN9F2A
* Stuffed Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pistachios, Golden Raisins ($14) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#lRyC9u_fWrR_WBkMpy71GA
The thick sweet cheese inside was the best part. I'm not sure what the green streak on the plate was, & it didn't have too much flavor.

* Warm Sheep's Milk Cheese + Ham Terrine, Aged Sherry ($15) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#ZeljWHl_gQ18Pj7BR5NLxw
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#M_weTOlpY9xoG0lG96QfIQ
Like the last time I had this, it was very salty, but this was countered well by the greens in balsamic. Unlike last time, I did notice the the layers of cheese in the ham, but the meat was definitely much more prominent. It was lightly breaded & crisped - great texture!

EUSKALDUNENAK (Traditional Basque Specials): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#0Q2Zn1SCEMl5zHkc-nlxoQ
* Veal Stew "Axoa," Braised Peppers (Saturdays. $26) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#ew7oTmHG79o_1ooqlss5FA
This had very very hearty & moist chunks of meat. Good flavor to the soup, too.

HAUNDIAK ("Larger things"): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=zOGrylgtKmplZAODw9EQpQ#zOGrylgtKmplZAODw9EQpQ
* Rack of Lamb, Merguez, Fennel, Breadcrumb, Pecan, Cumin + Date Relish ($32) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#bnObyzJgnW1wuFocUreRUw
Very rare, mostly pink. I had very high expectations & found the meat, despite being so rare, to be surprisingly tough to cut through. This wasn't bad by any stretch, but I've just had way better cuts of meat as well as flavor of lamb.

DESSERT: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=1QOsrStL7C16F94Xz1qfhA#1QOsrStL7C16F94Xz1qfhA
* Milk Chocolate + Hazelnut "Biarritz Rocher" ($9) - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#gfNhG0QZYs1SyOoTosMpbw
I didn't think I would really like this, but OMG the crust at the bottom - we both went CRAZY for this! It was thick, had a wafer-like crunch to it, but was a little more dense than you'd imagine. This perfect crisp when you chewed into it, coupled with a burst of flavor, made this fantastic.

* Yogurt Cake, Honey, Apricots ($9) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA#HXkzPVUZulffieOfbHIIqA
This was good to balance with the intense chocolate dessert above. The yogurt itself was really great w/ a thick texture, & the honey went well. The cake was like a light cheesecake, & came together well with the honey & apricots.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Nom nom nom. It wasn't what I was expecting, which was traditional tapas/paella/sangria, etc., but it was still delicious. For four of us, we got stuffed peppers, warm sheep's milk cheese & ham terrine, grilled calamari, oxtail, potatoes gratin, and two orders of the braised pork cheeks. The only thing that was disappointing was the terrine; the taste and texture was just like cold cheese and ham squished together. We snagged the last gratin of the night, but I wish we could have ordered one each. The oxtail was also a tad dry but delicious none the less. The braised pork cheeks exceeded expectations--it came with a temperanillo sauce which had me like YAAAAS. 

They also have an extensive selection of wine. There were a ton of Spanish wines, but we ultimately decided on a cab from Napa. Thankfully the three other people in my party can't handle that much wine (amateurs) so guess who got to drink about half the bottle? MEEEEEEE!!!
author: Christina D.

description:
Had a wonderful dinner at Piperade! Generous portions. Terrific service! Save room for the heavenly chocolate dessert!!
Added bonus, no background music, able to hold a conversation. 
Only reason not 5*s, even with a Travelzoo offer, pricey!
author: Janice K.

description: Yum! This place is great. Really enjoyed my meal here. The waitstaff was lovely, the ambiance was warm and the food was just delicious! I'll be back for sure.
author: Roz B.

description:
I wish I could give 3.5 stars.  My friend and I were at the Exploratorium, but realized that the lecture we wanted to attend wasn't until 9pm.  Since we were 3 hours early, we decided to find a place nearby to eat.

I really like the decor of this restaurant, especially on the outside.  It's intimate with low lighting.  Basque food is the specialty, and we ordered fried manchego cheese, sauteed green beans, a tomato tart, and chicken with corn and chorizo.  The fried cheese was good, but it was lacking acidity for me.. It had to be eaten with the pickled vegetables for a more robust flavor.  The green beans were okay too.  They had to be eaten with the marinated pluots to compliment the dressing.

The stars of the meal were the tomato tart and the chicken.  The tart had simple ingredients: cherry tomatoes, a flaky crust, basil, garlic, balsamic, and thyme.  And together was an explosion of flavor!  I wish it was bigger because I could've eaten more.  My friend ordered the chicken, and she devoured it.  I got to try the corn and the chorizo, which were fantastic.

We weren't thinking of ordering dessert, but we got the menu, so we decided to treat ourselves.  The orange blossom beignets caught our attention, so we ordered one to share.  They were okay.  I'm assume it's not a traditional beignet, but I wish it had more of sweetness to it.  And it was a little dry to me, but if it was drenched with sauce, it would've been more of a Greek dessert.

There were some hits and misses, but overall it was a good meal with friendly service, and I would definitely come back again for the tomato tart.
author: Vira P.

description:
Went to Piperade with some coworkers for dinner before heading to the Exploratorium on a Thursday night. They have seating outside which we chose since it was a nice evening. I give Piperade 4 stars for ambiance!

I ordered the garlic soup with egg, bacon, and shrimp but it wasn't what I expected. Anything with bacon and shrimp must be good?! The soup was just ok but the texture and taste seemed more like a watery egg drop soup. I was expecting something a little heavier, maybe cream based.

I had the duck confit for my main entree and I thought the duck was a little on the over cooked side.

Overall I give Piperade a 3 star. I'm not sure if I would go there again since there are so many other dining options in the area.
author: Scott L.

description:
Piperade is secluded from the main streets, tucked in a quaint neighborhood surrounding and exudes a form of shared intimacy when dining.  

What drew me in to want to dine here one day, you may ask? Their delectable and deliciously good looking, small dishes!

Starting out with their Dungeness Crab, presentation was splendid and the grapefruit pieces, added a nice tangy complimentary taste.  Next up, their Sheep's Milk Cheese mixed in with Ham Terrine and Aged Sherry, was phenomenal!  I am already a sucker when it comes to aged cheese!  Add the gamey taste to the cheese and salted ham with the whole sha-bang, we have a winner on this tapa dish!  I liked their Piquillo Peppers filled with Goat Cheese, topped with golden raisins and sprinkled with pistachio crumbs!  You can't go wrong with their unique, small tapas!

Onto their main dishes!  Their Braised Seafood in Shellfish Stew was rich on the variety from the sea, but the salmon was plain dry.  Too overcooked. Their House Special of the Day, mango slices topped on a medium rare thick pork chop, was not to my liking.  I have to commend on their Rack of Lamb, however.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly!

Their small dishes are preferred over the main plates!  Dishes were served out fast.  The staff was accommodating and polite. 

There is an outdoor patio area - great to lounge at on a light, breezy day!

I love this desolate, but charming tapa place!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
It has probably been 10 years since I last ate at Piperade. My memories were that of a dark cozy restaurant buzzing with people and plates of comfort food. A wonderful experience.

It was with some trepidation that I returned: I mean you read the Yelp reviews that give one or two stars  and the complaints of indifferent service and long waits.

Well my friends those reviews, Imho, are greatly exaggerated and unfounded from my experience.

Piperade still has that certain charm and warmth that is exemplified in the Basque culture. First of all when we arrived there was Chef Hirigoyen, outside, enjoying a glass of wine after a long afternoon of work. He is a very approachable guy and it was fun to chat with him.

The service was really nice. My friend asked, after we had been seated for a while, if we could move and they did it quickly without any hassle. The waiters are warm and friendly but they arent in a hurry to get you in and out.....and I really appreciated this.

The food was really good. It is pretty pricey but the quality is pretty stellar. The crab appetizer was amazing. Nothing but chunks of light, fluffy, fresh crab. Lightly dressed with some blood oranges and vinaigrette. Seriously I could have eaten three of these.

The other appetizers were the mushroom tart which was a great flaky pastry with loads of very fresh and flavorful shrooms.

The salad was boring and I would skip.

The mains were the shinning star of this place. My duck was cooked to perfection. Light crunchy skin, succulent meat that was not dry at all. The seafood stew was also amazing: chalked full of mussles, calamari, and prawns....it was good. The steak was also very nice albeit boring. We oredered two sides and they were amazing. The gratan was lovely potatoes and cheese. The lentils were lovely.

The surprise of the meal were the desserts. They were lackluster and basically boring. The beignets  were cold and paled in comparison to spruce's. The apple tart was so so. The chocolate cake was another boring production.

Finally the wine list is impressive and you can find good wines at pretty reasonable prices. We ordered a bottle of 2007 Clarendelle Bordeaux..... a really really nice wine at 40 dollars.

For a special occasion I think Piperade hits all the right notes.
author: David G.

description: I went there with three friends and dinner was lovely. Food was very good, staff was very friendly, and nobody rushed us out even when we stayed there for hours. I'll come here again.
author: Marta F.

description:
had a great experience here a week ago. Spanish food doesn't always mean tapas :)

as soon as you walk in, you'll know the service will be exceptional. we were meeting friends there and they had problems getting in and were going to be 1/2 hour late but we were seated immediately, which was greatly appreciated. our waitress was very helpful and super friendly without being annoying. 

with four people we were all able to taste a good variety. one of our group was a non-meat eater and there were plenty of veggie and fish options.

everyone love the stuffed peppers. they're not fried, but sautéed nicely with a goat cheese and pistachio filling. so good. the mushroom tart was also a favorite. they had a special seafood stew, almost a bouillabaisse that was fantastic. the duck confit was a little dry for my taste. the dark chocolate cake was also everyone's favorite. 

corkage is a reasonable $25 and they were very happy to open and serve the wine. a great option for casual, but gourmet, dining in SF
author: Bob U.

description:
Disappointing, given price point and ambiance expectations.

I come from France, so I was happy to try out some theoretically basque cuisine. My girlfriend and I chose this place for our 2 year anniversary dinner. When we got to our reservation at 7, it was rather full and they tried to place us on a table so close to two other ones that it felt like we were at McDonalds. I had to negotiate with the host to be able to switch, and he was nice about it. Even so, I was paying attention to the other people they tried to place there and no one seemed happy about it, they should really space out their arrangement given the price of the food.

They were also using their side room for a private party where lots of noise was erupting, regularly. This was not terrible but once again a small annoyance that was unwelcome.

As for the good, I ordered the duck and lentilles and my girlfriend the mushroom tartelette appetizer. It wasn't bad but the duck and lentils was not worth 28$. The duck was overcooked and the lentils undercooked, and they both were served it too hot, which led to me burning my tongue.
 The mushroom tartelette was better, but my girlfriend also thought it probably wasn't worth its price.

All in all I wasn't impressed. The food did not match the decor and the price point I was expecting. I may have simply ordered the wrong thing, but I don't recommend this place.
author: Nicholas C.

description:
I had a work lunch here and was really looking forward to trying the seasonal mushroom tart and the Gateau Basque.  I wasn't really concerned about my main, I figured I'd game it and see what happens.  After walking in to a completely empty restaurant, my co-worker and I got settled in and ordered the mushroom tartlet, which they graciously split for the two of us! The tartlet, which appears on 7x7's Big Eat list, is definitely worthwhile.  The flaky tartlet crust with some seriously savory mushrooms is definitely a great starter.  It's not big either, so sharing it between two people was idea.  I had their special shrimp salad, which in all honesty, was not that special.  In fact, it was a borderline rip off.  I should have stuck with the tuna.  Alas, lesson learned I guess.  My co-worker had the tuna steak sandwich and absolutely loved the onion marmalade that came garnished with it. We then split the Gateau Basque and I appreciated the not-so sweet taste that came out from it.  It was also split for the two of us, but the slice was incredibly small.  The photos from Yelp seem to indicate that the actual slice is bigger, but given that I'm trying to be better about what I'm eating, I guess this was a way of them helping me with portion control.

The total bill came out to around $80 after gratuity, and I honestly was a little disappointed that I wasn't a) more full and b) more satisfied with my experience. That salad was easily the biggest disappointment, and while I loved the mushroom tartlet and the dessert, it wasn't enough to overtake my disappointment in my entree. Meh.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I came here with my coworkers for lunch and had a really good experience. The restaurant was really nice and the service was on point. However, the ambiance was a little weird when we came for lunch at noon.

Everyone in my group enjoyed their meal. They bring out bread and olive oil at the beginning of the meal which was a nice touch. I ordered the Tuna Steak Sandwich which was so delicious. The flavors were amazing together and the tuna steak was so tender. You could tell it was great quality. A couple of other people in my group got the Seared Tuna Salad which looked pretty good except it was more expensive and had less tuna than the Tuna Steak Sandwich. Finally, the chicken sandwich looked a little sad. The meat was really thin but I didn't try it, so it might have been good. It just didn't look like you got a lot.
author: Jane H.

description: The Basque cuisine at Piperade is delicious and they have a great selection of Spanish wines. This restaurant is good for groups because you can share the dishes and enjoy different flavors.
author: Molly P.

description:
The five stars may be a bit biased. Perhaps it was only four and a half stars? About five years ago I attended the Basque Festival in Elko, NV, and found out about Chef Gerald Hirigoyen by purchasing Pintxos and The Basque Kitchen, two incredible Basque cookbooks. A couple of my favorite recipes are from these books - so yes, I might be a little biased to have finally attended his restaurant.

The boyfriend felt bad rolling up in jeans, and I in leggings, but the hostess assured us that it would be fine - however, just keep in mind this place is a bit dressy. We just didn't want to pack anything fancy for a 36 hour SF trip - :\

The service here is wonderful. The ambience is quaint, and beautiful. Soft, romantic lighting, cool decor, minimalist but still fancy. We were seated and immediately ordered a Picon Punch (Basque tradition, usually cheap red wine and coca cola, or is that just done in Elko? - because this one was WAY better), and a blood orange and vanilla cocktail for me. I'd order the Picon Punch again.

We had a sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine - split for us - and it was divine. I mean, literally divine. It was perfect. I wanted like, eight more. But alas, we had to eat the main courses, so I enjoyed it while I could, savoring each bite to the fullest. Grand.

Usually I stay away from seafood unless it's sushi or Plouf (mussels). However, since the Basque are well known for their seafood dishes, Ryan suggested I try the stew - and it was amazing. Seriously, it was. The mussels were perfect, the scallops were so good, whatever fish was in there I savored, all in this magnificent stew sauce. I mean, I was amazed. And Ryan's steak - buttery, cooked perfectly - he was incredibly satiated.

Save the best for last: dessert. We ordered two, the almond mousse and the orange blossom beignets, accompanied by a 20 year Tawny.

In August 2010, I had dinner at Ad Hoc with my cousins. Afterward we walked to a ridiculously fancy hotel in Yountville for drinks, and I passed by the most fragrant bushes - orange blossoms. I could have stood there for hours just breathing deeply, and to my companions, it felt like I did.

The orange blossom beignets ignited that peaceful memory of a perfect night. The beignets themselves, hallowed and crunchy, could not have possibly been made any better. Their orange blossom scent lifted through the back of the throat and back down the nose, in a fragrant cycle. I was almost afraid of tasting the mousse - how could anything live up to the beignets? Surprisingly, it did. The almond mousse was perfect. Everything was perfect. The whole thing.

I want to come back here. Forever and ever.
author: Jaime L.

description:
I buy a lot of groupons, bloomspots, yelp deals, etc Basically if it is a deal I'll consider it. BUT I am picky. I first look at the Yelp reviews - anything over 3.5 stars I'll consider, but I also look at the amount (sometimes too much money for a meal for 2, sometimes just an awkward denomination for a meal, sometimes limitations on WHEN it can be used, really I do my research.

Anyway I have not been to this restaurant, but it had 4 stars and the deal from TravelZoo looked great - 2 glasses of champagne, 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts - all for $69. (the deal said they add 18% tip and tax, and was worth about $140).  I LOVE that they included the champagne, and that there were TWO desserts and TWO apps- often these deals only include 1 to share, and I love my man, but I'll rock paper scissor him for the 3rd beignet every time, and if I lose, he often lets me have it any way. - what can I say? I'm a lucky gal.  (FYI so is he, I'm the one who buys ll these groupons - he just has to leave the tip!)

Now I NEVER let a groupon expire, and I never lose them, I have a system,  I print them out right away, highlight the expire date and stack them in expiration date order.  This one was coming up and so I called on Friday for a reservation for the following Thursday the deal was set to expire on Sunday.  They said they had 9pm...not really my style.  Then they said they were "extending the expire date"  FANTASTIC, the following Thursday was great with me, 6:30 please.

We arrive into a beautiful space, and are seated against the wall with a nice view of the dining room (well I had a nice view of the dining room). Our sweet waiter Jean (something) was very gracious about the voucher and asked if we would like our champagne - INDEED.  

I ordered the ham terrine, and let me tell ya, I am still dreaming about it, hard to describe, check out the photos and what looks like potatoes on top is really sliced serrano ham fried up like crispy bacon, and blew my mind  - on top of a frisee salad. You had me at "ham".  

in order to maximize the voucher's deal, we ordered the 2 most expensive entrees, the steak and the rack of lamb with sausage.  I cook a mean rack of lamb, and while this was cooked to a perfect med rare, I think I do a better job of seasoning on the grill, but the mergeuz sausage was awesome, and the figgy/fruit sauce was quite nice. The steak was actually better than the lamb, and I almost NEVER order steak in a restaurant, why bother, you can get it anywhere and cook it yourself if you are so inspired, but the steak was better than the lamb. Again cooked perfectly and the size of my foot - HUGE.  (we had leftovers enough for a steak egg taco for breakfast for my man and a petite lunch sammy for me.)

I think we fumbled a bit on our dessert selection - the orange beignets were great, but we ordered the almond cake - which was good, but I could have used some chocolate and there were a few selections.

Like I said we did not finish our steak, so I asked the nice waiter to package it up WITH the delish bread we had leftover - YUP, I'm exactly that cheap, but they were gonna just throw it away anyway right?

I wanna go back, sit at the bar and get a big glass of red wine and that crispy ham terrine...drool
author: Amy W.

description: We had a late night dinner here. Overall, thought the food and drinks was average. It's a cute spot and our waitress was very nice.
author: L B.

description: Food is absolutely phenomenal here and is truly authentic. We had the foie gras, piquillo peppers and rack of lamb and all were superb. I can't wait to revisit this great restaurant!
author: Jennifer N.

description: I had an extended lunch here the other day and was pleasantly surprised! Definitely more of an upscale lunch option - great for business meetings. Server/service was very friendly and accommodating. Not too busy or noisy. The food was all very tasty, no major complaints, except there is a lot of bread that comes with every dish. I personally try to avoid stuffing myself with bread and there are more creative options(!) but I doubt most people would notice or care. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Definitely will be back to try dinner.
author: Christopher J.

description:
I was really excited for Piperade for two reasons. I've had this restaurant on a list for some time now - the menu is so interesting. And then I recently got the Travelzoo voucher for 2 glasses of cava, 2 apps, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts for $69 - what a steal! I saved this for a special occasion, but sadly, the dinner was pretty disappointing.

1. They lost our reservation. I made the reso on Seatme, and changed the date once. When I got to the restaurant, they didn't have my name down for the evening. In the end we were seated, but I still thought it was unprofessional to not have the updated reservation information. What if they were completely booked? I made the reservation specifically for a special occasion.

2. They ran out of the calamari appetizer, which we were really looking forward to.

3. We ended up getting the mushroom tart and stuffed piquillo peppers. They were pretty lackluster and small for sharing.

4. The steak was overcooked. That was probably the worst thing that happened. The lamb was great, but the steak was pretty egregious. Not sure what happened there. I also thought that the accompaniments with the meat were mediocre - didn't really add to the dish at all.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Still a perfect spot for a low key date night.

The warm ambiance with the excellent Basque cuisine is what keeps me coming back here. Service is uneven sometimes, but we've never had a really bad experience.

The calamari a la pancha is a delicious starter made with fennel, capers, olive and lemon.  The calamari is rendered soft but not too chewy and the brightness of the flavors are a delight. The seafood stew is a winner, generously filled with scallops, prawns, mussels, clams and halibut.  While you can't go wrong with the seafood items, the NY steak is well executed too. 

Chef Gerald Hirigoyen started his career as a pastry chef in France, so don't miss dessert: we went for a classic tarte tatin topped with soft apples and drizzled with caramel sauce. Divine!

On a recent visit, we shared the app and dessert and the kitchen already split the dishes for us, so that's why the portions look small. Although I prefer to have the dish come as a whole, it just looks better for my pictures ;-)  

Piperade is a bustling spot for lunch, but I like coming here at night because of the readily available street parking! And in SF, that's a big deal.
author: Janice C.

description: Refreshments Viva Piperade GinTonics so Espana, Indi and Wint new friends in Gege's Nightcap cocktail orange peppercorn star anise.  Viva S.F.
author: johnathon c.

description:
Beautiful is the best word to describe pretty much anything and everything about Piperade. 

The interior is dimly and is very lounge like, making you feel so much more relaxed. We were seated in a smaller dining room off to the left of the host stand and for the first half of our meal we were alone. Separating our dining room with the other, more full dining room, is a wine cooler.

I was here for a business meeting with five other people, so a variety of different food was tried and enjoyed. The very first thing we enjoyed was the bread. Even though the bread was cold, it still tasted good and instead of serving it with butter, bottles of olive oil are placed on the table. 

We shared plates of the sea scallops, the four cheese plate, a crab cake, and bowls of tomato puree bisque. The scallops come with parsnip puree and a shaved apple salad. 

The scallops were cooked beautifully, so I didn't have to pull a Gordan Ramsey and smash them against the table. The parsnip puree I couldn't taste much of but the shaved apple salad paired very well with the scallops. 

The four cheese plate was minimal in quantity, but all four had amazing flavor. My favorites would have to be both the blue cheese, and the goat cheese that was served. The cheese is served with a Spanish fig cake that was very delicious and paired great with every piece of cheese on the plate. 

The only "cake" like about the crab cake, was the shape. The circle of crab was very easy to pull apart with your fork for bite after bite of deliciousness. 

Three of us ordered the tomato bisque, which were then passed around so all could try. It tasted pretty good, but nothing too special. 

For my entree I ordered the blue nose sea bass, which was served with sautéed spinach and fried garlic vinaigrette.
