My first time having bass, and I must say I am now a fan: Very flaky, and with marvelous flavor. The bass was great but the spinach with the garlic vinaigrette was spectacular. I could have probably eaten plate after plate of just that. 

I was able to sample a bite of both the pork cheeks and the prunes they are served with. Both are excellent. The cheeks are tender, and the prunes are just delicious. 

Also must have are the potato and manchego gratin. We had four orders of this, and all four orders were completly emply by the time we left. I would say this dish was probably the star of the night. 

Four of us ordered the same cocktail. The Elkano: Two of us hated it. The other two LOVED it. I fall into the "Love" column. Being that I love rum and being that this drink really packs the rum into it, plus adding all the fruity flavors to it, the drink was pretty damn good. 

The service was pretty OK and average. Everyone who waited on us, seemed to be in such a hurry to the point where I for one felt a little rushed. No orders were served wrong and everyone was happy with their meals.

Piperade is for lack of a better word, PHENOMENAL.
author: Jonathan R.

description:
Great place to share a fancy meal with a small group or a larger group. The space is somewhat loud so consider if intimate dining for two. There is a mastermind chef or two in the kitchen that created wonderful dishes that were both a work of [subtle] art and an absolute delight to the palate. The wait staff cared about our dining experience through their willingness to serve, handling awkward responses, their appearance.

The table was a solid and trendy stylish. Tables were set generously apart from one another. Low table turn is okay, i.e. you will not feel rushed. Enjoy the wonder albeit limited desserts. The experience was luxurious. Even if paying $100 per person after all was said and done, it would feel like a great value. (we paid less than $70 pp, no bottle of wine).  It has to be an old-world spirit of hospitality that drives everything else in this establishment. You will recognize it if you have been dining out for decades or you have dined in other parts of the world.
author: Mike F.

description:
We were on a lucky night, I guess? The chef and owner was the one cooking. 
We ordered the warm sheep milk and ham appetizer along with the pacific calamari. The first was a little on the salty side for my taste but the calamari were perfect! 
As entrees, we both ordered rack of lamb and were very pleased with the cooking and flavoring: it tasted deliciously fresh and didn't have that "goaty" smell / after taste. Definitely had a unique citrusy flavor without comprising the texture. 
We also had several desserts:
- bignets, which to my disappointment had no filling (never heard of that before)
- a typical gateau cake, which had again orangey-floral aroma (delicious!)
- a typical well executed chocolate cake. 

The service was outstanding (one of the waiter also escorted us to our cab, because it was dark and were two women) and I felt overall the price points reflected the quality and preparation time required for the food. 

All flavors were subtle and unique, so if you are looking for the Barbeque ribs or greasy ribeye this is not the place.
author: Fe A.

description:
Have enjoyed the restaurant before, brought friends for a 6:45 pm reservation again, arrived on time and saw many open tables for four but were seated at a table right at the kitchen door with two of the four seats facing right into the kitchen.

Food is fine; our tab was $400. Our server was very charming and professional, but the owner?made the decision about where we were seated. Certainly felt that we were not treated as welcomed guests. Lots of other excellent restaurants in San Francisco.  We'll go elsewhere and be better treated.
author: Anne L.

description: After dinner waiter stopped us and complained that we didn't give him enough tip. It's the first time we had such unpleasant experience in a restaurant.
author: Yuliya H.

description: We loved it!! Had a superb dinner there with our friends,  we had a variety of different foods and everything was delicious, loved the lamb and dessert. Service was great. Loved the interior as well
author: Ivy A.

description:
Dang it, I didn't know there was a living social coupon for Piperade!  Good thing it was a company expense to wat here because I don't think it was worth it.  My friend and I had the shrimp appetizer with baby gem lettuce.  It was ok, nothing special.  I had the seafood stew and she had the lamb shank special for the night.  Stew again was nothing too special, could have been found at an Italian or seafood restaurant.  My friend's lamp shank was a bit dry on the inside.  

I was looking for a great Spanish basque restaurant and I'll have to keep looking.
author: Yun C.

description:
Good San Francisco classic.  It has fallen a bit behind in terms of name recognition, but the food here has always been good.

The cheeses and pastries here are typically very good.  So if they are available on the menu, definitely get them.

They also are very good with seafood, particularly fish.  One of my favorite dishes here is the Mediterranean bass, when is generally crispy on one size and moist on the other.  Almost always very well executed.

Class European service here too.  And they do a mean coffee, and chocolate cakes.  Highly recommended local classic, without too much frills or being overpriced for what you get.
author: Mark M.

description:
The staff were super flexible with the Bloomspot deal, instead of 1 app, 2 entrees and 1 dessert, they allowed us 2 apps, 1 entree and 2 desserts.  More variety is always better. Really nice how the kitchen split our seafood stew into two bowls without our prompting.  

Standout favorite of the evening: mushroom tartlet.  Earthy, meaty mushrooms, creamy cheese on a flaky crust.  LOVED!!!  Must get.  

Calamari done perfectly.  I would say lighter on the olives?!?!?  So salty.  Stew was okay, I have had better, the white fish was bone dry, mussels, small, but perfect.  I have never eaten three pieces of bread during a meal in my life, these two dishes needed the bread for sopping and to tone down the sodium.

Desserts were a letdown.  The apple tart was a soggy version of the mushroom tart and seemed reheated to me.  The orange blossom beignets had a lovely essence, but the batter was heavy tasting.

Try a nice glass of the tempranillo.

Service is top notch at the front of the house and especially at our table.  He represented the region of the food well.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Went there for a date night. Ambience is nice, I had a reservation so they were able to seat us as soon as we got in. The place was packed and noisy- so definitely not a best option for a date night! Staff were okay, not great!

Food was pretty good! I liked the appetizers that we had ordered - toy box tomato tartlet  and stuffed piquillo peppers were pretty good! Main course didn't impress me that much! From cocktail, I tried Elkano which wasn't bad but made me peek into their wine list!
author: Roshni G.

description: Dinner was very good. Unfortunately, small portions and a bit pricey. Thankfully, cousin paid for it. :-)
author: Al C.

description:
I can't say the food is amazing or anything worse than average but the choices are always different and selected based on the day.  The chef cooks up some tasty treats along with some not-so-wonderful.  I think the thing that gives this little window it's charm is the man behind the counter. He's always friendly, upbeat, outgoing and there to please.

Check it out for yourself some time and maybe you'll fall into an easy morning routine.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Beef cheeks, the beef cheeks are wonderful.  I took the first bite and it was like Helen Mirren in "A Hundred Foot Journey".  One taste and she knew if the chef was going to make it or not.  This dish is only offered on Saturdays and is worth a trip to Piperade.
Everyone at our table had a bite and commented it was "really good". 

The bread basket of slices of bread came with olive oil and was OK.  We started off with some appetizers.
Raw beef slices were topped with tiny potato chips and was quite good. My mushroom tart was OK. Full of slivers of mushrooms but I probably wouldn't order again. 
The meat was tender. 2 of us had the beef cheeks and 2 tried the rack of lamb.  Hubby likes rack of lamb no matter who makes it. The meat was tender. 
The beef cheeks had a robust beefy flavor, as if it was marinated in beef demi-glace'. 

The drinks were strong and pretty good.
The desserts didn't impress me much.  I tried the orange blossom beignets, you can taste the orange blossom flavor filling.  I took 2 of the round beignets home and Jr. Yelpers said it just tasted like a fried oily ball.  BFF had this dessert which looked like a panna cotta.  It was on the bland side.  

We saw the chef come out to talk to customers at a couple of tables.  Wait staff was good, the bus boy seemed a bit rush and at one point I was afraid our water glasses would never get filled but the lady who seated us, came over with the water pitcher to fill our glasses.  That's good team work far as I'm concerned. 
The great thing about this place is that there was a ton of parking spaces on the street.
author: Ry T.

description: Just finished lunch their with some co-workers, The service was not very pleasant, even sat at the bar and 10 minutes went by before we were even asked if we wanted something to drink, and the food was very bland to me, I have had much better food and service at lower priced restaurant.
author: Anthony J.

description:
Used to love Piperade and have dined and recommended the restaurant many times in the last 10+ years.... Tonight's dinner/experience was definitely not a good one :-( 

Tonight I decided to sit at at the bar and ordered the side of haricots vert to start & the blue nose sea-bass for my dinner.... After a couple of minutes bartender comes back: I'm so sorry but we are out of that, hands me the menu and I decide to order the grilled calamari. Bartender again says: I'm so sorry but we are out of that also! I ended up ordering the cornish hen.

Having been in the restaurant business myself, I do understand that kitchens might run out of stuff but where I got frustrated was that I wasn't told about it when I was making my choices but after placing the order, twice.....

I did mention to the bartender that I wished he had informed me ahead of time! I guess he didn't like my comment and after that moment service was no longer an option....

The haricots vert came and they were quite greasy and looked tired but tasted OK. The portion was also very small and it's price definitely not at $12.00.
The 1/2 cornish hen came swimming in oil and (would have liked to ask for a strainer and a new plate but thought better of it); the 1/2 hen consisted in about 4-5 morsels in total and the menu didn't mention it was going to be only half the little bird.... $26.00

I am very disappointed as I really used to love this place!
author: Claudio A.

description:
Past Saturday invited friends from LA for dinner with us. 
This place has a nice homey feel when you walk in from the street.  The brick wall makes it feel warm and welcoming. 
However after that it was downhill like a steep ski hill!

The duck special entree was inedible . It was chewy and tasteless.  My wife's seafood stew was mediocre.

And to top that off it seemed our waiter graduated from the Tadich Grill school !!

What a waste of our time and money !
author: Rashid I.

description:
Booked marked this place over a year ago mainly for their mushroom tart..finally had a chance to dine here!! Took mom on Wednesday for an early birthday celebration and we had an amazing time!! Mom was pleased with the entire dining experience! (my mom's a chef and most of the time very hard to please!) You guys get an A+!

We started with the mushroom tart, which they split for us! Delicious flaky crust, mushrooms were very well seasoned! A must try! Also had their foie gras special that was served with bread, salt, pepper and a chutney..so good! I probably shouldn't have eaten so much of it! 
Next we shared the rack of lamb and the halibut. Both were cooked to PERFECTION!!! We asked for rare for the lamb and the halibut to be cook m/rare....both came out so beautifully plated and the flavors were fantastic! 
DESSERT!!! Apple tart and they brought out a complimentary chocolate cake....ok YUMMY!!! 
Great wine list as well!!! 

Our server was so wonderful and showed us a really great time! SO happy I finally had a chance to try this place, will definitely go back!!!
author: Vi N.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday - we had reservations, but this place has been around for a while so it wasn't too crowded.  Ambiance is upscale and classy, but not stuffy.  Good spot for a fancier date or more formal business meeting.

We had the Butter Lettuce (average), Strip Steak Crudo (very good - the fingerling potato chips were a nice touch), Stuffed Piquillo Peppers (yummy combination of flavors), Warm Sheep's Milk + Ham Terrine (very good, though a tad salty), and the Seasonal Mushroom Tartlet (not my flavor - but I don't like creme fraiche).

A bit pricey but I would come again for a special occasion.
author: Emily W.

description:
If you come here with Travelzoo deal, note that they added tax from the full price bill + 18% tip. So after the voucher, we still had to pay around $40. Food is so-so. The calamari appetizer is amazing! The rack of lamb and duck are tasteless. The orange beignets dessert that everyone is raving about is overhype. I much prefer the milk chocolate hazelnut cake! Service is not that great either. Once our server knows we are using Travelzoo voucher he took away the wine menu and said "Only house wine is included". What if we hate those house wine and want to order something else and actually pay for it?!?! Parking is relatively easy. There are some street parking in front of the restaurants on Saturday for dinner. 

Recommended: No. I am definitely not coming back.
author: Prisilia P.

description: Went here tonight for dinner just for two. The restaurant definitely has a romantic aura as there are many candles and I noticed there were a lot of couples that were already eating when we got there. For appetizers, we ordered the Piperade and the oxtail. They were both delicious as the Piperade was very eggy with just the right amount of spice and sweetness. The oxtail was perfectly cooked and tender. For the main course, I had the duck breast which also was perfectly cooked and tender. My friend had the sea bass with spinach and it was absolutely perfect - not salty or overlooked. Overall, fabulous food and attentive staff!
author: Lanai L.

description:
Visits: 5+
Rating: 4*
Service: Excellent
Dishes: Garlic Soup; Prawns; Braised Seafood; Veal Stew (Special); Warm French Apple Tart; Biarritz Rocher

Piperade has been our favorite go to place for tapas for years. It hasn't disappointed yet.

¤ Garlic Soup (4*). Very subtle flavors. You can taste the garlic but subtly. Goes great with the shrimp, bacon & eggs. Refreshing, delicious & a great start to dinner.

¤ Prawns (3*), from the Txikitos menu. They swim in a bath of Basque Ketchup & Lemon Confit. Almost reminds me of shrimp cocktail but without the horse radish burn. It's good.

¤ Braised Seafood (5*). This tomatoe based sauce is devine. The seafood is delicious & I can lick this dish dry. Yum yum.

¤ Veal Stew (4*). This was the days special. Another great broth/sauce. Veal stock to be exact. Glad we went with the special. The Veal was fall apart tender, juicy & so flavorful.

¤ Warm French Apple Tart (4*). If you're into warm Apple pie or fruit tarts then you'll love this. A thin crispy crust, sliced apple filling & caramel drizzle. Mmm mm.

¤ Biarritz Rocher (5*), this is the Milk Chocolate + Hazelnut dessert. Chocolatey, creamy mouse with a crunchy bottom crust. Loved the texture & loved the taste. Not too sweet, just right. Wifey being the chocolate lover she is loves this dessert.
author: Daniel T.

description:
We came here with some older, more "prim and proper" kind of family who chose the restaurant. The setting matched the company for sure. The service was very friendly, but the vibe, menu and atmosphere feels very outdated and I'd guess it hasn't changed much in the last 15 years or so.

- Stuffed Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pistachios, Golden Raisins: 
This was VERY creamy, as the goat cheese was large and in charge. It was a bit overwhelming, and we didn't finish it. (And I LOVE goat cheese)

- Pacific Calamari "a la Plancha," Garlic + Lemon Confit: 
The calamari was cooked very well. The portion was pretty substantial for an appetizer. Other than that, it was pretty simple and standard. I'll write this up as a dish that focused on simple, well cooked seafood.

- Alaskan Halibut, Corn Pudding, Toy Box Tomatoes, Olive Salpicon: 
This was probably the most interesting of the dishes we tried. The tomatos were bright and added a nice fruity balance to the heavy corn putting. The olive added a good amount of salt to tone down the fresh tomatoes. I felt like the fish was lost a bit, which was a shame because it was executed very well.

- Blue Nose Sea Bass, Spinach, Fried Garlic Vinaigrette: 
Very very boring. My fiance was very disappointed with this. It was bland and unimaginative.

Overall, we were pretty disappointed, as this was our first time trying Basque cuisine.

I did end up getting stomach cramps and very very sick throughout the night (my hunch is from the calamari), so I will definitely not be back for that reason mainly.
author: Haley J.

description:
Five stars!  My husband and I were looking for a place to begin celebrating our anniversary a day early and decided to go to Piperade for lunch.  We were looking for something different and we definitely got it.  Everything we ordered was delicious, starting with the BIARRITZ, a cocktail made with Maestro Dobel Tequila and White Peach juice ($10), and some good bread with olive oil.  

The restaurant was not very busy because we came in before noon.  The service was perfect, even though more patrons began to come in.
  
We decided to share three appetizers one entree:  calamari ($14), Basquaise salad ($14), twice cooked oxtail ($15), and rice Gazuxa ($20).  

The calamari was split into two small bowls without our asking, which made it easier to eat because it was saucy.  The flavor of the garlic and lemon zest went nicely with the calamari.  
Next we had the Basquaise Salad, with frisée, serrano peppers, Ossau-Iraty cheese, apples, pine nuts, and sherry vinaigrette.  The salad was full of flavors and we both enjoyed it, moving back and forth between that and the oxtail, which was really yummy.  We finished our lunch with the rice dish, which was also split without us asking (so nice).  It was like a risotto with small tomatoes, roasted corn, arugula, peppers, and more of the delicious Ossau-Iraty cheese.  Even though we could not finish all the rice, we ordered dessert (why not?!).  We had the apple tart and dark chocolate cake.  The chocolate cake was the better of the two, only because the tart was a bit hard to cut with a fork, but still the flavor was good and the pastry on top was flaky.  

Overall, a really nice experience.
author: Kelcie T.

description:
We a splendid meal at Piperade, an elegant but comfortable Basque restaurant while on vacation in San Francisco.
The dining room was nicely laid out and the service was outstanding. We sampled a number of dishes, all excellent. Pork cheek. Garlic soup. Plum gateau. And more.
Highly recommended, particularly for a group.
author: Jeffrey R.

description:
I had lunch today at Piperade. My first time dining here. I was very impressed! They had a great and extensive menu. Many different appetizers and many different entrees. We started with Stuffed Piquillo Peppers...stuff with goat cheese, pistachios and golden raisins...yum!
Another starter was the Basquaise Salad, Frisée, Serrano, Ossau-Iraty, Green Apple, Pine Nuts, Cider Vinaigrette...yum #2.

For my entree I had the Seared Tuna Salad, Arugula, Fingerling Potatoes, Fennel, Egg. It was delicious and just the right size.

NOW...I would like try it for dinner.

Oh, and the atmosphere is really pleasant, brick walls, wood floors, spacious.
author: Rob F.

description: Quite disappointing given its location, price, and ambiance. My boyfriend and I celebrated our 8th anniversary here and had high expectations. They prepped our table perfectly with preordered champagne and a good seating location. But the food was sub par. The raved about piquillo peppers appetizer was nothing special. The garlic soup my boyfriend had was basically water and egg combined with no flavor. My seabass was overcooked and so bland. I think I could've went to a cheap diner and it would've been better. We had to continue our dinner and drinks at Roka Akor nearby which exceeded our expectations.
author: Felicia F.

description:
This is one of my better meals in the city. We got a Boomspot coupon for it so it was also a great deal, although it's certainly a bit on the pricey side without the discount. They also have $20 corkage, which is pretty good. The servers at Piperade were also nice enough to split the shared plates for us (at no charge! and we didn't even have to ask!!).

We shared the stuffed peppers for appetizer, had the lamb and the steak for entrees and the apple tart for dessert.

The stuffed peppers weren't too heavy even though it was filled to the gills with goat cheese. The sweetness of the peppers married well with the tartness of the cheese. It was simple and not over done. A must order!

The rack of lamb is arguably the best that I've ever experience. It was perfectly medium rare -- great flavor and tender as butter. It would use a bit more of that delicious sauce, but the meat was amazing on its own. I also adored the poached fennel. Compliments to the chef.

The steak was slightly overcooked, more like medium than medium rare. Nevertheless, the beef had great flavor and a nice crust from the sear. The polenta fries were crispy on the outside and cheesy/tender on the insider. The watercress salad was slight overdressed and probably the heaviest tasting item on the plate, but the acidity cut through some of the richness of the dressing. The sauce was nutty and complex. It certainly helped out with the slightly overcooked meat. Maybe we'll order it rare next time.

The apple tart was very thin with slivers of overlapping apple slices. There's a nice crust from the caramelized sugar. The star of the show is definitely the caramel sauce. I overheard another table order their apple tart with extra caramel -- they probably are repeat customers and know how great the sauce is.

Overall, I highly recommend the place. The service is efficient without being intrusive or too chatty. The noise level is low so a good place for date night.
author: Alice W.

description:
Please read my last review, this is just an update. 

Six years later and this classic but quiet SF institution has only improved with time. This is one of the very best restaurants in the city, but hardly the most famous or expensive or anything else.

Nominally Basque, this is basically a serious but somewhat informal French restaurant owned and overseen by a very serious chef. Typical restaurant service. You come, you're seated, they ask for a drink order, wine bla bla, appetizers, main entree, desert, or you could ask them otherwise. 

Service is a little weird at times, a cast of fairly experienced but personality-rich characters dealing with dinner service. 

The food is at times transcendent. That is the highest praise of food. Not just good, or filling, or a good value, or whatever. Out of 7 dishes in my last visit, two of them took me to another planet where Yelp reviews, the existence of restaurants, or the American economy did not matter. You forget yourself, it was that good. It is like going to see a music event and you are in shock.

Specifically, one dish, an oxtail appetizer, was the gateway. Always on the menu, the lamb chop was also amazing. A seasonal simple chanterelle mushroom side dish was also a gatewy to a better place.

The weak point as it has always been is the dessert, kind of desultory, overly sweet, not fresh, and I wonder what they're thinking. Minus one star for that, but otherwise I would give them six stars so it comes out to five.

Seriously, if the oxtail is on the menu you have to try it.
author: Gil S.

description: Fantastic wine list. The food was rich and authentic. The seasonal mushroom tart was amazing! Definitely save room for dessert.
author: Johanna M.

description:
Took my mom here because there was an amazing deal that I got off Travelzoo (dinner for two-- comes with wine, two appetizers, two entrees, two desserts). Didn't know what to expect really because I don't know if I've ever had Basque-specific food (thought I've been to restaurants that have dishes from the region). Everything was very tasty!! Had great grilled calamari (though it is rolled in a somewhat lemon juice/sauce, so if you're sensitive to lemon... and a really good albacore (?) spread for appetizers. I got the duck confit while mom got the rack of lamb. Both were cooked to perfection and served with some pretty tasty sides (lentils for me, veggies for her). We also got a side of summer vegetables which was surprisingly expensive ($10) but was actually a huge portion and very good, so that was fine. 

Dessert was Gateaux Basque (basically a million layer cake-- whatever I don't remember the french term for it huckleberries) and an apple tart. Apple tart had caramel sauce (which is awesome for those of us who are not pro-chocolate) and was served warm. Noms. 

Good atmosphere, seems like it could be good for a (small) family dinner or a fancier date night. Without the coupon would probably be about
author: Lai-Nin W.

description:
We've eaten dinner a few times at Piperade on special occasions, but I tried it for the first time for lunch the other day.  I'm happy to report that all is shipshape during the lunch hour, with the menu modified to include a few sandwich items and simpler dishes.  

My friend ordered a chicken sandwich with avocado, red peppers, and cheese, which was accompanied on the plate by a simple green salad.  He devoured it and said it was excellent.  

I ordered the Bizkaiko, a fish and shellfish stew in a red pepper infused sauce.  From what I could tell, beneath the sauce were cod, tuna, salmon or char, shrimp, clams, and mussels.  The fish was cooked absolutely perfectly, poached to a buttery consistency, and was clearly fresh as could be.  While the sauce was very simple and almost bland, this was a wonderful dish, especially when accompanied by the restaurant's signature bread, a sourdough with wonderfully coarse texture.

We also split an order of frites, which I remembered from previous dinners as being amazing.  Either the memory was flawed or the product isn't always the same.  We got a generous portion of shoestring potatoes that we enjoyed eating and that weren't awful by any means, but they weren't "special" and they hardly justified a $10 price tag.

Even without appetizers, drinks, or dessert, but with Cafe Americanos and SF Health Mandate surcharge, the bill came to more than what most people spend for lunches in a week, but it was a very enjoyable meal for us.  An added benefit was that the restaurant let us sit where we were for an extra couple of hours after lunch, which allowed two old chums to catch up on bygones and gossip.  

All told, I probably prefer Piperade for dinner, when the menu is larger, more complex, and worthy of elevated pricing.  However, I wouldn't hesitate to come back for lunch if the circumstances called for a splurge.
author: Mike R.

description:
Absolutely  wonderful. I loved our waiter, who was very funny and attentive. They were out of the manchego gratin potatos  (I'll be back) but had the seafood stew, grilled calamari, fried manchego with pickled veggies.  I had the apple tart which was to die for.
My fiance had lamb which was cooked perfectly and the orange beignets. My mother in law had the flan like dessert which was very rich but wonderful.
author: Annie J.

description: Nice place, food is pretty good and creative, service is good. And the acoustics are good - even when busy you can hear people
author: Shannon D.

description: We have been coming to Piperade for years, but haven't been in a while so decided to give it a try, as it had always been great. I'm not sure what has happened to the service, but it has certainly gone downhill. Our waiter couldn't have cared less about us. There were a few large tables filled with business people that seemed to be pulling our waiter's attention. The waiter came and was so brisk with us, took one cocktail order and left. We all looked at each other confused. I got his attention and I said, "Can everyone order their cocktails now?" He took the orders but I tried to order some appetizers as well (since I guessed it would take him a while to come back), but he left again without asking if we would like anything else! It was horrible. He brought our cocktails at all different times, then we tried to order the appetizers, and we only ordered ONE and he ran away again! (it was the fish appetizer on toast, and I thought it was going to be individual small fish but it was just tuna and mayo with spices, so was not very good.) Anyway, the entire evening went on like this. Waiter would come and take one part of our order, not ask if we wanted anything else, then leave. It was so frustrating. The food that came for our entrees was very good, nothing crazy, but it was good. The mushroom tart was the best thing (appetizer). The waiter brought a huge basket of bread with our entrees (shouldn't that have come with the appetizers)? We finish our entrees and the waiter comes and says he is leaving, and someone else will take over. So he left and another waiter brought us our dessert... it was one of the stranger dining experiences.
author: K S.

description:
We went here as a family to celebrate Mother's Day. Overall my biggest disappointment was the wait staff (in particular our main waiter). 

I came with my child so I entered just after he brought drinks, but it would be twenty more minutes before I could get his attention long enough to order a drink for my husband or me. From here on out nothing was once assumed or offered. Everything had to be requested and begrudgingly given to us. This was extra annoying when it turned out they were out of so many things. Such as having only Diet Pepsi for soda. But rather than say that you had to go down the list of sodas first. 

For the price most of the food was bland and much to small a portion for the cost. Of the things we enjoyed were the braised pork cheek. Otherwise I would not order anything again...

I don't plan to return here.
author: Sarah F.

description: My husband had my 60th birthday surprise party in the private dining room. I got nothing but rave reviews from my guests as well as my own experience with our private waiter. It was one of the best experiences I've had of this caliber. Ask about The special drink that is named after the owner.  It is awesome!
author: Elpie K.

description:
Nice quiet location on Battery with both indoor and outdoor seating.  Indoors has a nice long bar with about 10 seats.   Outdoor tables have heaters to keep the chill down.  

Took the travelzoo deal which included 2 apps, 2 entrees, 2 deserts, and 2 drinks.  The food was all very good.  For wine we got red or white.  Limited choice but wine was good.  For apps we had the mussel salad and sardines over garbanzos.  Both were very very good.  

Then on to the main dish.  Had the duck confit served with lentils.   Also tried the seafood medley which came with shrimp, scallops, also with several other kinds of fish.  It was served on a tomato base.  Delicious.   

Final course were 2 desserts.  They were good but i honestly don't recall what I had.  My only beef with them was that on checking out they already added a tip.  Never had that happen before and it was a little off putting.
author: Marcus K.

description:
I found Piperade when driving around FinDi (do not ask me why).  I had the fois gras and their green salad.  Both were great!

I would definitely go again!
author: Mark M.

description:
We came here to celebrate a new member of our team at work and to welcome back a coworker from his long vacation. We started a few appetizers: Pacific Calamari, Toy Box Tomato Tartlet, Piperade, and Twice Cooked Oxtail. The appetizers were pretty good, i didn't try the calamari tho. The Tartlet was delicious and had a wonderful flaky crust to it. The piperade was amazing, especially with the bread that they served. The twice cooked oxtail was also flavorful and amazing. For my entree I ordered their lunch special which was the Lamb Shank over pasta. The Lamb was well cooked and tender but the dish as a whole could have used a little more flavor. From the looks of it, I thought sure thing the sauce mixed with the pasta would be quite flavorful but it was a little more on the blander side. At least the lamb was tender and didn't have that strong lamb taste (that I don't mind) but it was cooked well. Overall it was ok, i'd give it a 3.5.

And of course at a place like this portions are smaller.

Other than that, the dining environment is gorgeous. It's quite spacious and comfortable. Something I'm not used to seeing in SF when dining. Love the ambiance and comfort.
author: Rehana K.

description:
Restaurants are like theaters, each with directors (chefs) and actors (waitstaff) who work in concert to provide a memorable experience for its patrons.  

Travel Zoo offered a 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and 2 desserts voucher for $79, a good price for a fair amount of food.  We sat near the rear against a wall. Our view was of the main dining room.

Part of why we loved our last experience here is the setting but also the waitstaff.  Last time, our waiter was extraordinary, one of a kind, old school, incredibly patient, knew where the prepared food were from, had an air of reassurance, and knew when we needed something.  

That wasn't the case this time. We were underwhelmed and disappointed.  Although nice and efficient, our waitstaff struggled to tell us how the food was prepared, could  not tell us where it was from or describe its tastes and had to be flagged down numerous times for ordering, getting the check, etc.. This person also always seemed rushed, running from the kitchen to various tables, not checking in on us.  The restaurant was busy, but I can't remember seeing waiters running around at other fine dining places.  Also, when we asked for water, this person gave bottled water which she didn't mention the $8 charge.  Uncool.

Restaurant owners and managers: your waitstaff needs BETTER TRAINING to describe the amazing food you cook and how to better anticipate the needs of diners, and disclose any costs. Your patrons are intelligent and savvy, and many of us want to know where your food is from and descriptions of their tastes so that we can make good meal decisions and come back again.  

So while the choices we made were delicious  (beet and argula salad, calamari a a la plancha, steak and mushrooms, halibut and tomato, corn puree, beignets and warm chocolate late), what was sorely missing was the calm, knowledgeable waitstaff.  I've had better service at take out restaurants and cafes.

In addition, Travel Zoo's mandatory 18% gratuity was not fair based on our lack of service.   Patrons should be able to control how much we pay for the service.  Giving the same tip to all servers is a dis-service to patrons who expect good fine dining service and to servers who don't know they need better training.

Again, disappointed. No plans to return.
author: Jen L.

description:
The chilled mussel salad is a great appetizer and the dish that I would go back for over any other. 

The swordfish was extremely disappointing; tasting more like a premium fish stick than anything else. 

The NY Steak was actually really good. Seasoned simply with salt and pepper and cooked exactly to order.

The service had a lot to be desired though. Issues we had were treated like an inconvenience (flickering lights, lack of candles, incorrect bill was fixed but without even a perfunctory apology, etc) and the waiter gave off a general air of annoyance. 

Also a note to the wise. The ambiance is a little weird. The place was filled with a strange mix of 50-60 year olds in suits, 20 somethings in nice but casual, and 40 year olds getting loud, drunk, and annoying.  

tl;dr

*mussel salad is a win
*service (and ambiance in general) was weird
*the hostess was awesome!
author: Boris K.

description: Still wonderful.  There are not enough accolades in the English language to describe how wonderful this place is.  David, our water, was spectacular.  Attentive w/o being overbearing.  The food was over the top fantastic.  The Calimari a la Plancha was to die for.  With so many places coming and going here in SF, it's nice that the truly great restaurants remain. Also understands gluten free and servers are knowledgeable about what GF diners can have.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in SF! Worth every penny and believe all the favorable reviews. I've been here half a dozen times from romantic nights with the husband, birthday parties, and tonight's celebration with my interns.  I've never seen anyone so happy about a rib!  I always get the fried Manchego, the potato gratin, and the mushroom tartan. David always get the goat cheese and ham taurine.  Then we share what everyone else wants.  Today the meat eaters got the fois gras and were not disappointed.  For dessert everyone's favorite was the dark chocolate cake, chocolate peanut butter mouse, and orange beignets.  Man what a great night!  Thank you again to Chef!
author: R B.

description:
I love the food at Piperade. I get takeout from here regularly even though they are an up-market spanish restaurant better suited for dining in. 

The last time I actually dined at the restaurant, I was disappointed. The service was very slow and my favorite fish dish that has always been cooked to perfection for take out was bone dry.

My take is they have a great kitchen, but the front of the house seems to be easily overwhelmed at busy times. I guess if you eat at off times of day like me, when no one else is hungry, you won't have any problems.

My favorites here are:

Piquillo Peppers with goat cheese, pistachios and golden raisins. These are really good.

Seasonal Mushroom Tart-let - Light flaky pastry, nice selection of mushroom types, great taste. Fungus heaven. 

Pacific Snapper Spinach and fried garlic vinaigrette. If they don't overcook it, this is a wonderfully light and tasty dish.

Dungeness crab with orange , grapefruit, basil and aioli. Simple but good.
author: David T.

description:
You know, we just weren't "wowed" by the food. I guess there are some signature plates, but others aren't that well-executed. 

The prawns, calamari, and friend Manchego were excellent, but the garlic shrimp soup and butter lettuce salad were just okay. My lamb was fantastic, but my other two guests weren't happy with the duck confit or the mussels. I guess you should stick with the regional specialties even though there's a decent amount of French influence in the menu. 

Fortunately, the beignets were a great end to a somewhat mediocre meal. I COULD be persuaded to try this again since it is rated so highly, but I'm not itching for it.
author: Dylan T.

description: Top notch dining experience. I took my boyfriend here for his birthday and we really enjoyed ourselves! We tried the strip steak crudo, basque rice and the daily special of roasted duck. All the dishes were interesting, nicely played and flavorful. Our server was excellent and we left feeling satisfied. Leave room for dessert!!
author: Brigette A.

description:
Went in with the Travel Zoo voucher and was pleased with the deal and the food.  My wife and I brought in our 3 y.o. daughter and although we were 15 minutes late, they seated us within 10 minutes.  This place isn't really kid friendly, since they have no high chairs, boosters or even a kid's menu.  They couldn't even do a special request of spaghetti but did offer pasta with butter.

The ambiance of this place is awesome as it is dark wood floors, ceiling and a cool ass wine chandelier in the center of the room.  We started off with the 2 glasses of champagne and some bread, and then had the calamari app and some crispy fries for the little one.  Next course for me was the rack of lamb which was delicious and a nice size portion.  The flavors of the food were really nice and not something I am accustomed to.  It really felt like I was transported to Spain in a tiny village along a rural street.

The waiter didn't seem to pleased that we had a toddler with us, but this could have just been the way he is with all guests.  They added a travelzoo tax of $12.60 which I think is 8.5% of $148.00 and a service gratuity of $29 which is 20% of what the total would be.  I wasn't about to get out my iphone and start calculating what these charges were.  I was just glad they didn't tell us they lost our rsvp when they saw us show up with a kid.  Overall I was pleased with the TZ coupon of $69 +$50 for the fries,tax and tip.
author: James H.

description: Meh.... place for older folks I guess. I ordered  a 32 rack of lamb and got 2 pieces of lamb. My husband order the steak and it was not as good as we grill at home and they don't cost 32... his came with a side of broccolini and he got over garlicky green beans instead.  by the time we were done eating we just wanted to get out of there. I don't recommend.
author: Diana J.

description:
I don't know what bothers me the most: the bad service or the food. 
When I walk into a place and wait for someone to seat me, and multiple waiters pass by me without a word or a "we will be with you shortly", it's not a good thing. 
The server was limit rude, not caring for our table at all. The appetizers were the two stars of this review. A little on the salty side but tasty. The main meals took half an hour to get out and nobody cared to appologize or check with us. 
When the food was dropped on our table, no one cared to explain what was in the plate or even just name the meals. My hen had one potatoe and a few mushrooms to share the over salted sauce. 
Very disappointed to have spent 200$+ at this place.
author: Lanéa P.

description:
4.5 STARS

Mr. NSS: "Wow, this would make a great first date place!"

*Looks at menu prices*

Mr. NSS: "Ummm, I meant 20th date place."
Me: "20th date place?!?!"

Mr. NSS: "Yah, you know...once you've secured the goods." *Wink Wink*
Me: "No, I don't know what you mean *Wink Wink*...women are NOT cargo on a ship, you know!"

Mr. NSS: "Geesus, is it that time of the month again?"

Whether it's the 1st or 20th date, Piperade is definitely a solid choice for date night. Fantastic food and strong cocktails in a sexy yet rustic ambiance with dim lighting, exposed red brick walls and wooden furnishings with crisp white linen clothed tables. They also have an outdoor dining area which is perfect for those rare warm city nights and a private room to accommodate larger parties (up to 30). Piperade is nestled in a more desolate area between North Beach and the Embarcadero which makes finding free street parking after 6 pm a breeze. 

Acclaimed as the top basque chef in America, Chef Hirigoyen's menu focuses on Californian influenced Spanish and French Basque dishes. Every dish we had was very well-executed and packed a big punch of flavor which justified the high prices for the portion sizes. For a less spendy meal, try his other nearby restaurant, Bocadillos (next door to Bubble Lounge) which focuses more on Spanish Tapas.  

We started with the Dungeness Crab "Txangurro" w/ Orange, Grapefruit, Basil & Aioli ($16): http://bit.ly/12J1KCr which was a tower of freshly shredded sweetly tender crab. It was a very light and refreshing way to start a meal. While Mr. NSS grappled the crab appetizer, I lusted over our second appetizer, the Piquillo Pepper Stuffed w/ Goat Cheese Topped w/ Pistachios, Golden Raisins ($14): http://bit.ly/140RAZI. An absolute must order, the goat cheese was like devouring creamy, fluffy clouds with a nice textural contrast from the crunchy pistachios. The golden raisins gave it a lovely pop of sweetness. 

For our mains, Mr. NSS had the Roasted Rack of Lamb w/ Merguez Sausage, Fennel, Cumin & Date Relish ($32): http://bit.ly/1600lUZ. The lamb was succulently tender but the date relish was what made the dish; it was like a savory and tart honey glaze. I was delighted with my Seared Duck Filet w/ Braised Carrots, Coriander, Orange & Green Olives ($29): http://bit.ly/14yZ87Z.. One of the best duck dishes I've had,  the breast was perfectly rendered and seared leaving a deliciously crunchy skin atop. The breast was lean yet had a luxurious fatty flavor. Loved the accompanying sweetly crisp braised carrot as well. The better half grappled half of my duck breast because yes, it was THAT good. I didn't mind because I had dessert all to myself (Mr. NSS doesn't eat sweets). The Biarritz Rocher ($9) was calling my name on the menu and it was a wise choice: http://bit.ly/12qa1tF. A Ferrero Rocher in dessert form, this was THE best dessert I've ever had. The chocolate mousse was divinely light and airy while the hazelnut crust was chock-full of crunchy hazelnut bits. Words can't describe how heavenly this dessert. GET THIS!

Service was friendly and very timely though not very polished. Dishes were abruptly plopped on our table without any explanation by the food runner while our waiter was stretched thin. He had to tend to our section and the outdoor dining area which understandably lowered the attentiveness. Had service been a tad better, this would definitely be a solid 5 star review. 

Piperade is easily one of my top picks for date night especially if you want to "secure the goods" as Mr. NSS so eloquently put it. 

Oh yah, no date is complete with starting with one or two...ok, three cocktails. I had the tequila based Spring in Biarritz ($10): http://bit.ly/11inn6s. And, you know how Mr. Tequila and I roll. *Wink Wink*
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Always wanted to check out Piperade since it's perennially listed on by SF Chronicle's Michael Bauer as a Top 100 Bay Area restaurant.  We were able to secure a 5:30pm on a Thursday to finally check out Piperade's Basque cuisine.

Though arriving ten minutes early, the host seated us at a quite table on the side, as requested. The waiter came by and took our drink orders.  After bringing the drinks, we place our orders.

The bread basket consisted of tasty ACME bread with a delicious olive oil for dipping.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=B21lxoY9LatoGvz8VerGVw#B21lxoY9LatoGvz8VerGVw)

Starter:
Seasonal Mushroom Tartlet with thyme and garlic.  Nicely flavored mushrooms on a tart.  Delicious.

Entrees:
Roasted Rack of Lamb with Merguez sausage, fennel, cumin and date relish.  The lamb was cooked perfectly medium rare and was nicely browned on the outside.  The lamb and the Merguez sausage went well with the date relish. Dish also included some cut pieces of potatoes and a fennel bulb, which I initially thought was an onion.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=B21lxoY9LatoGvz8VerGVw#C7KerDnykgDEK-uZxdOp7g)

New York Steak with Romesco, broccoli rabe, garlic, Ossau-Iraty.  Steak had a nice sear and was perfectly cooked medium rare.  It went well with the Romesco sauce.  The entrée had broccoli rabe as a veggie, but it was lacking something.  Oh, a starch.  Maybe they forgot to put some potatoes on the dish.  It would have rounded out the dish.
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=B21lxoY9LatoGvz8VerGVw#3TxjDWeU44vYBGIEOu-ZEQ)

Dessert: 
Orange Blossom Beignet.  Thinking that these would be similar to the traditional Southern beignets, these were similar to the Chinese sugar puffs.  There were four small "beignets" to the order.  It had a nice orange flavor, but at $9, this is pricey.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=B21lxoY9LatoGvz8VerGVw#pa6V7jVfrQRI8DmTl47u4w)

Overall, nice atmosphere with very attentive service.  The customers were mostly middle aged clientele with a couple of business dinners. Prices are on the expensive side.  Food was delicious, but given the prices, the lamb and steak doesn't stand out to what I've experience at other establishments at more reasonable prices.
author: Al L.

description:
3.5 stars for a nice weekend dinner recently. First off, the place has been well established for many years. The decor and the vibe overall speaks older crowd and "old soul"-inviting.....uh...that would be us:)!

Ambiance was muted. Just the exact shade of lighting that I prefer---romantic, but dont need cell phone light to make out all the verbiage on the menu:) Viognier wine was great.....sweet and nice balance.

Veal cheeks could have had a bit more depth in flavor.....to be honest, it was ehh for me. His halibut was lovely and light, subtle flavors. Seared asparagus stems grilled just right, nice flavor.

Our bread was KICKIN---that's the way I like my carbs...Olde World recipes with nice crunch, and chew, light on the interior. Some ratio of wheat..yum!!! The dip was an Arbequina olive oil that was SOOO good and awesome, I asked where to buy it (Berk Bowl).

Our calamari starter was wonderful. Loved the Basque flavors of olive oil, tapenade, etc

Dessert was the best, with a milk chocolate hazel nutty, rice crispy layer, with large shavings of more chocolate to cover. Deeelish.
author: Jana C.

description:
Last time I had dinner here was a couple month ago, and I really wanted to try the mushroom tartlet as an appetizer, but they are out of it since our reservation was 8:30pm.
This time again, our reservation was 8:30pm.  I called them in advance to save the mushroom tartlet if possible. 
We walked in the restaurant and the host welcomed us with a very nice smile telling us that they saved the mushroom tartlet for us!  Delightful!  


And here is my review for it:

I got so excited to see the plentiful mushrooms when the dish came to our table.
Oh my god, it is FANTASTIC!!!  It is full of flavors with the very flaky piecrust.  Yes, I would say it is more like a pie.
It is the best mushroom pie I have ever had.  
I forgot to ask them what kind of mushrooms they have in it, but definitely there were King Oyster mushrooms and Maitake mushrooms at least.
Definitely it gets 6 stars!  It is a MUST-TRY!  


Let me move to other dishes here:

- Warm Sheep's Milk Cheese + Ham Terrine, Aged Sherry = 3.5 stars 
I love how crispy it is, but it is too salty for me. 

- Rack of lamb, Merguez, Fennel, Cumin Date Relish = 4 stars
Lamb is tasty and tender. Sausage is delicious and spicy. Fennel is so sweet.

- Braised Veal Cheeks with Peppers = 4.5 stars
Soup has a rich taste of peppers.  Veal is melting tender.


Overall, I would give them 4.5 stars.
Piperade is a wonderful restaurant with a lot of flavorful dishes and pleasant service.

Mmm, mushroom tartlet.... cannot wait to come back.
author: Tomomi K.

description:
Interior: 10/10, Food: 9/10, Service: 9/10 

Yummy! Food is fantastic. Price is decent ... for San Francisco.

I will look forward to my next visit.
author: Ionakana H.

description: Great atmosphere, tasty food and friendly service here.  We were on a double date here with another couple and had several orders of the stuffed peppers appetizer as they were amazing and reminded us of spanish tapas, lamb chops, and a few other items I can't remember. But do I remember having a good experience from start to finish.  I was in town for a few days and this was a good choice for after work dinner with another couple.  Would definitely repeat.
author: Maksim S.

description:
Gateau Basque- #10 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Piperade is on SF Gate's 2012 100 Best Restaurants list, and also had a dish on the 7x7 list, so I was happy to finally dine here and be able to multi-task lists. Sweetening the deal was my Bloomspot for a 3 courses for 2 (1 appetizer, 2 entrees, 1 dessert). I called to make reservations a week ahead of time and had no problems, but we did have an early dinner (5:30pm) since we were meeting up with friends after. We arrived a little early, and saw that they were allowing patrons in before they technically opened at 5:30pm. We were greeted at the door by the host, and sat promptly. Our server was very attentive and came over right away. We ordered:

-Calamari "a la Plancha" (Fennel, Olive, Caper, Coriander, Lemon, $15, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=hkCrWTX-aPee07XTHMFi4g#hkCrWTX-aPee07XTHMFi4g): Good. The calamari was cooked very well, and they very nicely split the plate without us asking. Although, I felt the olives and capers overpowered the subtle taste of the calamari a bit, I would still recommend this dish.
-Veal Cheeks (Roasted Red Peppers, Fingerling Potatoes, $29, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=hkCrWTX-aPee07XTHMFi4g#sne9CJ87yEziFM7M2TIYlQ): The veal cheeks were fork tender, but the dish overall was very bland! They definitely need to add more salt/seasoning, since it was hard to eat the tasteless red peppers and potatoes. This dish was also too watery for my liking, and I'm not sure I would order it again.
-New York Steak (Romesco, Broccoli Rabe, Garlic, Ossau-Iraty, $32, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=hkCrWTX-aPee07XTHMFi4g#Q_zAwzRySo-At4j0AfLSiw): The steak was cooked a perfect medium rare, and I loved the sear on the steak. However, the NY cut was too lean for my preference, and it got a little boring to chew after a while, even with the romesco sauce. My favorite part of the meal was actually the broccoli rabe that accompanied this dish, since it was topped with shaved parmesan pieces.
-Gâteau Basque (Cherry Preserves, $9, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/piperade-san-francisco?select=hkCrWTX-aPee07XTHMFi4g#zxBcqT2sxr48omcfufRR1w): Eh.. just ok. The custard filling was good, but the crust of the basque was too dry. I liked the version I had at a bakery in Portland a lot more. This version wasn't worth the $9- Skip!

I mostly enjoyed my dinner at Piperade, but I'm glad I had my Bloomspot deal, and am not sure I would return and pay full price for a meal here. The ingredients seemed quality and were cooked well, and they gave you a good sized portion, but I just didn't love any of the dishes for some reason. For the prices, I would rather dine at a number of nearby restaurants in the Financial District where I've had tastier food. I agree with Marisa G. that the other diners were considerably older (I'm in my late twenties), and it seems like they have a lot of regulars. At least the service was attentive, and our server made sure the pace of our meal was pretty brisk since we had to head out. Parking was easy to find since we came early, but there is a good amount of street parking spots available around this area.
author: Amy D.

description: This was the best meal I've had in a while. The prawns basquaise - a little sweet, a little salty - and braised pork cheeks were fantastic, and my dinner companions raved about their basque rice and NY steak.  Next time I'll come hungrier and make a point of exploring more of the menu.
author: Cathleen T.

description: Decent restaurant but definitely not a SF staple as some may claim. The food lacks personality and did not make for a memorable meal. The meal did not do much to differentiate itself from other similarly-priced restaurants.
author: Derrick W.

description:
I've been here for lunch a few times. Always leave happy. 
The space is bigger than you expect when you walk in, they also have a cute outdoor patio area. 
I really enjoy the calamari a la plancha, it's tender and the sauce is a great match. 
The rack of lamb, the steak and the duck confit are all really tasty entree options. 
And for dessert, I love The orange blossom beignets; they are delightful and subtle. 

They also used to have a lunch window in the back alley, which had great to-go salads and sandwiches, but they've sold it and the new menu is not as good. I might still be bitter about it...
author: Lacy S.

description:
Decided to get a little fancy for lunch and in retrospect, it was a good move!

Came here with a coworker mid-day sans reservation. We were seated promptly and well taken care of through and through. We split the calamari and mushroom tart which was ridiculously good. One would think, how great can an arguably dinky-sized vegetarian tart be? The answer: mind blowing good. I'd go back just to nosh on that tartlet alone. 

I also had the chicken sandwich and was pleasantly surprised - loved that they took it up a notch by panko-ifying the chicken. Yum!

Yes it was more than I planned on spending for an impromptu lunch but do I regret it? Not in the least.
author: Brianna M.

description: Fabulous meal  - the pork cheeks were delicious.  The ham and cheese terrine was a tad salty but my husband loved it.  He ordered the French apple tart for dessert and was pleased.  The waiter was fantastic-  did not mind the Travelzoo coupon - it was a terrific meal.  I had the seafood stew - not too sure what to expect and it was perfectly cooked but I expected more complex flavor as. Still, would order  again.
author: Angela B.

description:
Gora Euskadi!  Long live the Basque!

I am simply in love with Basque cuisine and this place was awesome.  Came here with Yelper Gloria C. and four other people and enjoyed a night of fine wine & food.  I had never heard of this place before until someone in the group had suggested the place, and I'm glad we went there because the food was superb, exquisite, and most of all--TASTY.

Our party ordered and shared the following tapas, all of which were really good and tasty, and made we want to have more...but sadly, I could only get a little bite of each: 
* Warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine with aged sherry
* Thinly sliced serrano ham
* Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts, and gold raisins, 
* Calamari a la plancha
* Dungness crab with basil, roasted pepper, and mango
* Endive salad with pomegranate seeds and persimmons

Of all the appetizers, my favorite was the warm sheep's milk cheese.  It was just so creamy and delicious.  It's definitely something you should try.  Probably my least favorite was the serrano ham, due to its simplicity.  I had made the choice to order it to share only because it's a staple in the Iberian diet (well, ham).

For the entrees, I ordered the "Seared Filet Of Duck with braised romaine, cippolinis, cherries & pork wine sauce" which was very well done.  I had it done medium-rare (consistency of steak) since that's the best way to have game meat... if duck is cooked too well prepared, then the meat is dry and unpalatable.   It was rich with flavor and the texture was great, and the romaine, small onions, and cherries complimented the complex flavors of the seared duck.  Absolutely delicious.  I had it paired with a Basque red wine, which I cannot remember the name, but they went together VERY well.

Lastly for dessert, we all ordered our own separate things, but I had the turron mousse cake with roasted almonds.  If you are a big fan of turron, what Spaniards and Italians have during the Christmas season, then you'll love this cake. It tasted like eating turron but in a soft, cake form...delicious.  It was paired with a glass of their sparkling moscato, which wasn't too sweet or too dry--so the two went together perfectly.  

If you look at the menu online, there aren't any prices listed.. usually that means $$$.  And with no exception, this place is actually kind of expensive.  Each of us ate about $60 or more worth of food... but it was well worth every penny.  This place is really cozy, so it's a definite great place to bring someone on a date to!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Lovely ambience & not a bad table in the house. Easy neighborhood to find parking in (although meters run till 11pm - oops!).

We started with the Dungeness salad & seared scallops. Both were extremely tasty & I recommend each. I went with the Basque rice (risotto) as my entree & my fiancé had the New York steak. My dish was  rich in flavor, & cooked to perfection. My fiancé was not blown away by his steak, unfortunately. We shared the dark chocolate cake (gluten free!!!) for dessert. It was sublime. I only wished we'd each gotten our own! Yum. 

I will certainly be back. I'd love to dine at their outdoor tables (great outdoor space), or one of their window tables. 

Only negatives - we weren't informed of the night's specials. Once I heard our neighbors being told of them, I realized my dinner order would've likely been different. Additionally, they should provide a water vase for the table - I was often without water & thirsty (they only fill your glass 3/4 of the way, even if it's the 4th time you've requested more water).
author: Cara C.

description:
The fact that Piperade is in a location that gets little to no foot traffic during dinner hours, yet is consistently busy but not overly crowded says a lot to me. It is worth traveling a few blocks outside the Financial to come here. I have been for both lunch and dinner and Piperade delivered on both occasions.

The menu offers a great selection of Basque-like dishes and everything that I have tried here has been a great experience to eat. They actually have an item on their menu that I would place on my "greatest things I have ever eaten" list - you must try the stuffed Piquillo Pepper, it is unbelievably good!
author: Frank J.

description:
We used a TravelZoo coupon and were just amazed with the flavors we experienced.  Never went to a Basque restaurant before, but will be back.  
Started with the twice cooked oxtail, wonderful with the pickled relish.  The serrano ham with the tomato compote a must have with bread.  Cant wait to return and try other appetizers on the menu.  I had the Alaskan halibut on a bed of corn pudding which I loved.  Honey had the rack of lamb, which I was lucky to get a taste.  Desserts  were delicious, she had the chocolate flourless cake, I had the almond mousse.  I think I won with the candied almonds topping the wonderfully smooth almond mousse.  I taste treat to remember, and so looking forward to a return trip.
author: Jeff L.

description: Terrific food and atmosphere!  Service was attentive and informed. A little pricey, but certainly in range of SF restaurant prices.
author: Dean N.

description: Great introductory course to Basque cuisine.  I've got to find a way to make the stuffed piquillo peppers and serrano ham a part of my regular diet.  The big down side is the private room.  The acoustics in there create decibel levels that will rival a recent One Direction concert.
author: Ryan J.

description: Everything was perfect!  We went for lunch at 1 PM on a weekday.  My first course,  Garlic Soup, Rock Shrimp, Bacon, Egg, Toasted Levain, was beautifully prepared.  Not over the top, but I could smell the garlic, which was sliced into paper thin strips.  My second course was Blue Nose Sea Bass, Spinach, Fried Garlic Vinaigrette.  The delicately cooked fish was perfect with the vinaigrette.  The coffee was excellent.  The waiter was pleasant and efficient.  We will definitely go there again.
author: Jean S.

description:
Still a really solid place after many years, occasionally having dinner since they opened.  Recently went to a birthday dinner, the birthday gal is indecisive and is generally a curious person (read: asks a lot of questions). Server was patient and pleasant, answering all the questions, and we all felt rewarded when she made her decision (lamb chops). 

Not copying her ( I felt comfortable with this since after the 20 questions, I knew everything about this dish but the name of the farm the lamb came from), ordering lamb chops as well, it was 3 perfectly prepared, tasty and an accurate "medium rare"... fantastico. Shared the calamari w/ fennel, capers, olives, lemon... a rendition that may be "as good as it gets". At our table were Halibut we're a friendly bunch, with an invite I grabbed a bite. Delicious with a capital D.  

Gerald Hirigoyen, the owner/chef is a seasoned (pun intented) culinary star of SF. Serving what he calls "West Coast Basque" cuisine. A few years ago, I wanted to tell him how happy we were with the dinner, and noting his last name I thought he might be Japanese (not that it would matter...just check out my name), well, he is surprise, surprise, surprise......Basque. 

Piperade is very consistent w/ great service, perfectly prepared dishes, and welcoming ambiance & decor. Keeps me coming back....for more.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
I wanted to like you, I really did...
I was pretty disappointed all around.  I've heard and read good things but everything lacked - service and food.  The restaurant was nearly empty then again it was early in the weekday for dinner in what I'm sure is a bustling area during the work hours.  

We shared a bunch of plates: Fried Manchego, Beef Crudo, Calamari "a la Plancha", 
Stuffed Piquillo Peppers, Steamed White Sea Bass, Duck Confit, Pommes Frites, and Potato + Manchego Gratin (probably the best dish we had).

All in all it was just ok.  Our server must have been anxious to leave since she was pushy about collecting the bill.  There was one point she was staring at our table while my gf was sobbing telling us a story of her dad w/ cancer.  I never need to come back here.
author: Meredith K.

description: The ambiance is really nice and cozy, the restaurant has wooden tables and dim lights. However, the food is average. Nothing too special. We ordered the piquillo pepper, the mushroom tart, the shrimp with lemon confit and a seafood stew. Portions were small for what it was worth. The shrimp seemed to be taken out of a Safeway frozen bag of shrimp ... Tasteless. Sadly we are not coming back.
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description: Good atmosphere; great drink selection including cocktails and wine, excellent food and good service. Service was a bit slow, but not terrible. Great place to dine with a client.
author: Nick R.

description: A wonderful and accommodating setting for a big dinner party. Our group had our nye dinner here and the restaurant was very helpful with our requests even when the restaurant was very crowded that night. The food and wine pairing was delicious. The nye decorations, hats, etc. added a fun, festive touch to our night.
author: Akina L.

description: This place has the perfect combination of great food, service, and atmosphere. Super tasty tapas dishes, friendly service from the owner himself, and a great, covered  outdoor patio with heating lamps.
author: Peter J.

description: After barely surviving being crushed to death leaving NFL city, prior to the free Alecia Keys concert, we looked up restaurants in walking distance from Embarcadero.  Piperade had good reviews, so I was surprised when we got lucky by quickly snagging a table.  Nice place.  We were the only one with kids.  Food was quite good.  The kids split a Cornish hen.  Rabia had the lamb rack.  My New York streak was thick and juicy.  Desert was good too.
author: Iftikhar K.

description:
I ate at many different and new (for me) places during my bday month...Piperade was one. We had a 8pm reservation on a Friday. The place was semi full, didn't recall seeing a hostess but since our party was the large round table dead center, didn't really need someone to walk me over. Some of us ordered the NY steak (scrumptious and rare to the touch!), some ordered the duck filet...i don't usually like eating duck but this was very tender and tasty and a couple ordered the lamb and i was in heaven! i DON'T like lamb at all, the after taste usually forces me to gag (but) a few years back at GDanko i tried their lamb and was in-luv. That same feeling surfaced this evening for me, at Piperade. i was so happy....Maybe i am ready to venture out.

We did order some appetizers but i can't for-the-life-of-me remember any of them...so i am only yelping the main entrees.

They also gave me the birthday Dark Chocolate Cake & Creme Fraiche and sang me a song. It was yummy...indeed.
author: Vee V.

description: I agree with others that the stuffed piquillo peppers were amazing! The NY steak was well prepared and the beignets literally melted in my mouth. The setting was perfect for my big group. Enjoy!
author: Claude G.

description:
Came here with the bloomspot deal with my girlfriend. Did not know what to expect because I didn't research anything before eating here. 

I was pleasantly surprised with the food (bloomspot deal limited us on a few appetizers). We started out with the grilled calamari, and had the lamb chop and New York strip entrees. All were well cooked and tasted very good. As for desert, I would pass on the orange blossom beignets ... They had a taste that reminded me of perfume or potpourri.

Parking is easy around the neighborhood at night.
author: Daniel K.

description:
This is the first Basque place I have been to since moving up to the bay area.  It turned out to be the best Basque place I have ever been to in the states.  Having a little Basque blood in me, this occasion felt a little more personally intimate for me.  The ambiance and the decor was fantastic with touches of Basque decor.  The selection of dishes are plentiful which was great to see.  The head chef even came out to my table and asked "Who has the Basque name here?" since the reservation was under my last name and chatted us up.  Very pleasant fellow.  Now on to the food.  I was not alone in this dinner endeavor so i will give a list of things I remember us ordering.  

For the Tipiak's:
  - Calamari
  - Mushroom tartlet
  - Foie Gras
For the Haundiak's:
  - Piperade
For the Euskaldunak's:
  - Seafood & Shellfish Soup "Ttoro"
For the Goxoak's:
  - Orange Blossom Beignets
  - Warm Apple Tart
  - Gateau Basque

I cannot tell you how much I enjoyed my meal.  Every dish was a homerun and wish my stomach was bottomless.  I particularly loved the mushroom tartlet, the Piperade, and the three desserts were phenomenal.  My dad was here from out of town and got to partake in this experience and he was impressed with the food and wished they served something even remotely close to this back home.  I am definitely going back here as this place was right for me in every way.  Even if you have no idea what Basque food is like, there is stuff on the menu for everyone with taste buds from all walks of life.  I encourage you to give this a try and further your own individual conquest to be a "cultured" person.  This quiet place is great for intimate parties and romantic evenings.
author: David A.

description:
What a sad experience....
My boyfriend and I walked in after work on a Thursday night for a new cuisine. As soon as we were seated our elderly waiter came immediately and asked us if we had a travelzoo coupon? Yes indeed I answered - "please write the voucher and PIN number "he asked .. even before bringing us a menu or water. While I struggled to recall my password he dropped off a pen and piece of scrap paper for the voucher no. 

Eventually after I gave him the information he wanted our app order before even asking if we would like something to drink. 

The apps were okay. The waiter never checked in to inquire about anything until he wanted our entree order. The duck confit was really good but could have been better with a glass of wine- which we had to ask for twice, and when it finally arrived, was the wrong glass... And to add insult to injury the waiter insinuated that I had been in the wrong when ordering! Meanwhile the water glasses were empty and the drought continued until I asked for more- please! 

Lastly dessert was nothing memorable.

What is and always will be is the 18 percent gratuity that the waiter added when he dropped off the check! He had nothing vested in ensuring good service because he already knew that he was going to make that percentage regardless of his inexcusable horrible service. 

I will never recommend this restaurant to anyone I know simply based on the service.
author: Mayu D.

description:
What a great evening with great food!

We tried the garlic and egg soup along ($8) with the fried manchego for our appetizer.

Then, we ordered rack of lamb, seafood stew, and the NY steak as our entrees with a half bottle of the Banshee Cabernet ($40)..The entrees were all around $29-$32

Everything tasted great and the service was on point.

For dessert, we had the chocolate cake with creme fraiche and the orange blossom beignets with two glasses of moscatel (moscato).


I would definitely come back..
author: Elaine H.

description: Came here once for lunch, and once for dinner. I like the atmosphere, it is an upscale place, but relaxed. Quiet, but not boring. Waiters are attentive, but not pushy. Recently, I had the tomato tartlet (delicious; flavors and texture were absolutely wonderful!), and the Basque rice, which I also enjoyed very much. A while back, I had the fried Manchego (it was decent, but I had better), and the Alaskan halibut (perfection). The Gateau Basque is delightful; I would have preferred the crust a tad more flaky, but that's simply a matter of taste, and I would order it again anytime. Ingredients were fresh (both times I visited), and prices are commensurate with the quality of the food. I will be back for sure.
author: H. W.

description: I'm a big fan of this place - especially for lunch. it's excellent - everything he makes is outstanding (The Chef) tough name to say, but a really good guy and I like his wine selection.
author: Rew C.

description:
Haven't been to Piperade in a few years (that's what happens when you retire and aren't in SF every day).  It was as wonderful as we recalled.  We shared the Pacific Calamari "a la Plancha" and the Toy Box Tomato Tartlet.  I didn't realize the calamari would have a sauce, I thought it would be simply grilled, but it was very good.  The Tartlet, especially since it's the height of tomato season, was outstanding and left us wanting more.  We also had the Shellfish Stew that had 2 or 3 types of fish, clams, mussels, shrimps and scallops - make sure you use the bread to sop up the sauce.  Hubs wanted the New York Steak w/Black Pepper Sauce and Sautéed Broccolini.  Wouldn't have been my choice, but wow was it cooked perfectly (med-rare) as was the broccolini, and the sauce was velvety.  We also had a glass of port for dessert, the chocolate cake (great with the port) and the beignets which were just ok.  

We like Tempranillo wines but aren't familiar with Basque wines so had help with the selection.  Had a delicious Muga, Reserva, Rioja 2011 (listed as a 2010 on the wine list - these things matter to the Hubs).
author: Joli W.

description:
I came here for Valentine's day one year and it was not worth it (as most V-day prix fixe menus are).  To be fair the $70-80 pp price tag was reasonable considering that the portions were a good size. 

The appetizers were delicious!  We had the crab salad and mushroom pie and both were some of the best tapas I've ever had.  The main course on the other hand was very disappointing.  I ordered a fish dish (well I tried 2 of them because they gave me the wrong one first) and they were nothing special.  My boyfriend ordered the lamb and it was dry.  

I would definitely still come back to Piperade, but only for the apps.
author: Leanne J.

description:
I have given Piperade 5 stars in the past.  I wouldn't do it again. 
The food from my past experience has been good.  I went this week and wanted to eat at the bar.   I was seated rather promptly---off to a good start I thought.  I then waited and waited and waited some more.  I made I contact hoping to get the bar tender who looked like they were having a terrible day or perhaps that was this person's every day look.  

After looking at the menu and wine list and having memorized everything I threw in the towel and gave up.  I went to the host stand to let them know I was leaving not because I didn't find anything I wanted but because of not being served.  The man that was there didn't say sorry or seem to care.

I am sure there might be an excuse like "it's Dreamforce week" but in my book an open seat is a reason to serve every customer.  I won't visit again.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Great food, service and menu.  Lovely atmosphere and lots of street parking available.  I would go back.
author: Sandra W.

description:
Piperade has been around in the relatively quiet Levi Straus North Waterfront neighborhood for a long time.  Consistently delivering great food and attentive professional service is the hallmark of any great restaurant.   Piperade fulfills these expectations day in and day out.   

Piperade is about two blocks from my office and I feel really lucky that no matter how often I go for lunch they never disappoint.

The fish (sea bass or halibut) is excellent, as are the lamb chops, hamburger and even the signature Piperade.   Gerald, the owner, has assembled a great team that quickly both takes your order as well as delivers food that answers very high expectations.

The restaurant also built a private dining room and spruced up its outside areas recently.  Both are worth visiting.
author: Eric M.

description:
So much of the magic of dining out on a special occasion rests in the hands of the server assigned to your table. That of course and the quality of the food,  and the ambience in music, lighting and comfort supporting the cuisine on the menu. 

Our first experience at Piperade one year ago was perfect in every way, even if the professionalism of the waiter could have been a little more generous with an occasional smile and appreciation of our family as his customers. But our experience last evening, New Year's Eve, was lukewarm, and our server though mildly accommodating of my food allergy/sensitivity concerns, was a dud. I can't help but wonder whether my not imbibing in any alcoholic beverages, and therefore our not ordering champagne or a bottle of wine, made our potential check less than he hoped. 

The food was delicious, the spirit of the place and fellow diners festive ... but I am doubting we'll choose Piperade again for a romantic dinner for two.
author: Dawna F.

description:
came here with a travelzoo deal but ended up spending about the same amount as having come w/o it... we spent $80 for the deal + $40 at the restaurant for one $5 beer, ~$11 tax and they tacked on $23 service charge for our party of 2. 

food was mediocre.. nothing special and overpriced
service was mediocre, our waiter was not very friendly (the hostess was super nice though). everyone that works there just looks miserable

won't be coming back!
author: Elyse R.

description: This is - quite simply - one of the finest restaurants in the Bay Area.  Gerald - the chef/owner - has created a warm, elegant venue with excellent food.
