The restaurant has maintained its impeccable standards since its opening. Join the fiercely devoted patrons who have savored this fine establishment for the last decade.
author: David S.

description: We had an excellent time celebrating our wedding at Piperaid! The dinner was delicious and the service couldn't have been better! Thank you for making our evening so special!
author: Whitney B.

description: I took my date here for her birthday and thanks to our waiter, Ramond and hostess, Elena, the experience could not have been better. They accommodated my requests for flowers at the table, birthday cakes, and being very friendly and helpful through the entire night. The food was delicious and the wine was excellent too. I'm very happy with the whole experience and would recommend anyone come here looking for great food with a beautiful ambiance that's easy to converse in too. There was also easy and free parking nearby, which is a big advantage over other restaurants.
author: Josh F.

description:
Wonderful place, quiet and out of the huddle of SF, that has become so noisy. Nice evening meal with my 2 foodie friends. Stuffed peppers, calamari... Steak .mmmm just wonderful 
. David our server was so informed of the meals offered. A wonderful bday dinner for me. 
Thank you Karen & Stacy & Piperade
.
author: DC C.

description:
I am torn between a 3 and 4 star rating -- here's why:  I came here Wednesday night for a business dinner with 3 couples.  We were seated timely, but that was the only thing timely.  The entire time we had a hard time finding someone to take our order.  The time between each course was too long, and in each case, we seemed to have to flag down the server.  We would have ordered another bottle of wine, since the first bottle was empty just before our entrees arrived, but no one ever came to say, "would you like another bottle"?  Overall length of dinner was 2 hours, 45 minutes, and although we were enjoying each other's company, I could tell my guests were getting antsy.  Ok, that's the negative. 

On the positive side, when the server arrived, she was pleasant.  I asked her for a Spanish wine recommendation, and she immediately recommended a Rioja Reserva I hadn't heard of, but it seemed moderately priced (by restaurant standards), and it turned out to be awesome.  I later found out it had been rated 94 by Wine Spectator, and was in their Top 100 wines of 2013.  Great choice and a good find.  They sell it at K&L for $30, and I will buy some.

The food was also excellent.  We had several appetizers, including a cold crab salad, calamari (not fried) and stuffed peppers -- all very good.  For entrees, most got either the lamb chops or the steak.  Speaking for the lamb chops -- really good.

Anyway, 4.5 stars for the food, 1.5 stars for the service, so you can decide which is most important to you!
author: Fred E.

description:
A bit off the beaten path, but in a good way. Host was pleasant and accommodating. Bartender was snarky and uninviting. Gave sarcastic responses that bordered on rude. My drink was terrible, flavor of vanilla bean was ridiculously overpowering. Girlfriend's drink was crafted well and tasted great.

Dinner - waiter has no clue about wine. We asked for a recommendation and be combed the menu with us to find one in our price range (don't you think I could do that myself...?). We ordered the cheese plate, which was delicious.  Only problem is that they insisted on using the table bread with it. No crackers or anything with complimentary flavor a (there was dig jam on the board). Wine was exceptional, through no help of the staff... 

We ordered the red snapper and NY strip. Both were absolutely out of the this world. Honestly, the red snapper may have been the best tasting fish I've ever had. Steak was cooked well, little overcooked for me liking, but I was too busy eating off my girlfriends plate to take notice.

One more thing, the waiter never once came over to table the entire time we were eating to check on us. He didn't bring the food, didn't pour the bottle of wine, didn't even ask how the food was.  He gave short, again, bordering on rude responses.

The skinny: if you want a really delicious meal that includes pretty terrible service.. Go here.
author: James G.

description: I have eaten at Piperade before. The food is fine.  This review has to do with their very poor customer service.  I purchased a Travelzoo offer and have attempted to use it many, many times. The restaurant hours and policy make it nearly impossible to do so.   I tried to make reservations on several dates, and all that they would offer me is 3pm or 9pm.  Really?  The grand finale came on the weekend before the offer expired, when the restaurant decided to close down entirely for a private party -- completely closed on both Saturday and Sunday.  Again, REALLY??!! Isn't the goal of these offers to attract new customers, who will return to your restautant again and again? I do not understand why they would even make this offer, if all it achieves is to frustrate and annoy people who are trying to come and eat in your restaurant? I certainly won't be eating at Piperade again -- ever.
author: moe v.

description: Always a good meal here.  I've brought several people here and haven't ever had a bad review just yet.  I usually come here for the carpaccio with the apples and the duck.  For the sweets I'd say between the creme caramel and the dark chocolate cake (beware...it's very rich).
author: Spencer Q.

description:
55%
Pretty good Basque.

***Short Review

Came here for dinner with a small group of four in Sep '11

Although I tried their prix fixe, some of my dining companions ordered of the 'a la carte' menu, so I got to try more dishes.
My prix fix included a butter lettuce salad, veal & red pepper stew, and an orange beignet dessert, all for around $38-ish.

Food here is fairly hit & miss, but the experience wasn't bad overall.  
Dishes rate from pretty good (although not quite great), to mediocre.
The 'Roasted Lamb' was probably the best dish we had.
I also enjoyed their roasted their Piquillo peppers.
Their 'Bacao' of raw cod & oysters over creme fraiche is a bit of an acquired taste, and probably too briny for some.
Avoid their NY Steak, the quality is comparable to what you'd might expect at Sizzler.

I feel that the prix fixe presents the best value.
Other menu items are reasonably priced.
Portion sizes are reasonable.

Ambiance is a pleasant, rustic and comfortable.
Service was personable and more attentive than average.

Detailed review will go into the dishes with further info.
I'll also add some thoughts about the general experience.

****Detailed Review

Cooking style here I feel is not really that different from Spanish, although it refers to itself as Basque.  Although you are not having tapas, the flavors aren't too different.  The preparation here isn't complex, and the approach in cooking is relatively conservative.  The quality of ingredients can be hit & miss.  While I enjoyed their veggies and lamb, I felt their NY steak was unforgivably poor.  Ordering the right dishes here, or at least one that fits your preference will make a considerable difference.  

On to the food;

-'Butter Lettuce + Fresh Herb Salad' ($10 or part of prix fixe)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eG5VcB6XuSp-C1mAggD_Cg?select=lYW2-NnVpPFjTheytHdD9w

I had this as part of my prix fixe.  Salad itself is quite fresh, and a generous portion is offered.  I like butter lettuce, because I feel (as the name implies) it has a more buttery texture and it one of my favorite greens.  Ultimately it wasn't a bad dish, but the use of the herb (I'm guessing vinaigrette) dressing really didn't add much to the greens.  I don't think there would be much difference if they served the greens as is.  Dish rating, 45% (two and a half stars).

-Haricots Vert Salad, Black Mission Fig, Perfect Blondes ($13)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eG5VcB6XuSp-C1mAggD_Cg?select=Rbdo67vnABZOVLH3xEqGAQ

This was dessert of string beans with fig and various spices, the most notable being (what I would guess as) mint.  Walnuts were a nice touch.  It's a nice simple appetizer, and the ingredients hold their own.  I felt it was a bit overpriced, but a good dish nonetheless.  Would have also be a fairly solid side dish for an entree.  65%

-Cherry Tomato Tartlet, Basil, Balsamic ($13)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eG5VcB6XuSp-C1mAggD_Cg?select=ddqVs0X5FNEVq8uMBcy6Zg

One of the better appetizers of the evening.  This was a simple tomato tart, but executed well on every level, albeit the concept was more on the conservative side.  Tomatoes & basil were fresh.  Just the right amount of basil & balsamic were used.  The pastry crust has a nice tender texture to it.  temperature was perfectly warm. Good execution and good balance of pronounced flavors.  81%  (four and a half stars).

-Cold Poached Foie Gras, Black Pepper, Sea Salt + Rhubarb Compote ($20)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eG5VcB6XuSp-C1mAggD_Cg?select=KS0m6WkOtGa3gJMUUcVAnw

Not a bad foie gras dish, although short of exceptional.  This was similar to some of the foie gras torchons that I've had prior.  Texture is rather dense, and it is predictably heavier.  Unfortunately the flavor of the foie was a bit more muted than I would have preferred.  I felt the flavors of the dish were brought out more by the pepper, salt, & rhubarb jam.  I can't remember what bread was used, but I don't recall it being any better than the usual choice of brioche.  Portion size is reasonable however.  50%

-Balcao of Raw Cod & Oysters with Creme Fraiche
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eG5VcB6XuSp-C1mAggD_Cg?select=npaw3jwOfv4lK8t6rrHC2A

The raw fish here isn't similar to Japanese Sashimi, Italian Crudo, or Ceviche.  It was too briney for my palate, and so are raw oysters.  One bite of this was already more than enough for me.  Just not my thing, but some of my dining companions enjoyed it more.  I'm not going to rate this because it's not something I would appreciate even if executed well.

Continued, please refer to 'earlier review'
author: Adrian Robert H.

description:
Love the ambiance of this restaurant, but I've always been a bit unsure about it. The food is usually quite nice, but there's just something,,,not right. Last night I figured out what it is.

Went in with a TravelZoo voucher for the 2 glasses of sparkling wine, 2 apps, 2 entrees and 2 dessert menu ($79). Not a bad deal. Were were seated right away, the waiter came over, took the voucher and immediately returned with the wine. If he had waited to talk to us, I would have said, bring one now and one later (for my SO), since I didn't plan on having the sparkling wine at all. The waiter seemed somewhat distracted when he took our order. Perhaps he wanted a different set of diners.

Food was excellent, though. I had the smoked herring salad, husband had the cheese plate; I had the lamb rack (done perfectly), husband the seafood stew (served somewhat cool). We would have asked for a warmer stew IF THE WAITER HAD STOPPED TO ASK US HOW ANYTHING WAS. But he didn't. We were seated in a spot where he had to pass us constantly and he seemed purposely not to look at us.

We had to flag someone down to ask for pepper and more water. Who has to ask for water in a restaurant of this caliber?  

During the meal, the bus boy would stop by and remove something from the table that needed removing, but not everything. We spent the meal looking at 2 olive oil dispensers (why 2? I surely don't know) and dirty wine glasses and flutes. But the waiter NEVER returned to the table. Except to throw, and I do mean throw, down the dessert menus.

My orange blossom honey beignets were outstanding and hubby enjoyed his apple tart. Time for the check. Where did our waiter go? Hmmmm. He finally did drop, and I do mean drop, the bill on the table on one of his fly bys. No smile. No thanks. No looking directly at us.

Unfortunately the Travelzoo voucher requires an 18% tip, otherwise we would have made an adjustment.

So, what I figured out about Piperade is that they concentrate on the food and only the food, but that is not the only reason we go to a restaurant. We like to have a comfortable time in a welcoming environment. It will be a long while before we return to Piperade, if ever. And we live only 3 blocks away.
author: Diane K.

description:
Food was amazing, service was perfect - not overbearing, true basque cuisine, romantic ambiance, reservation time with no wait, and the food is absolutely reasonably priced, and the meats were PERFECT.

We ate at another - more popular and hard to get reservation - restaurant the night after, and kept saying we wish we had just come back to Piperade as the service was terrible, food overpriced, meats tough, an
d we weren't VIPs, so we didn't get much attention after we waited 35 min past our reservation for a table..

All of that said, if you want quality and respect, consider Piperade, we would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Brooke B.

description:
I enjoy bocadillos quite a bit so I knew I'd like Piperade off the bat.  To begin with, our group shared these apps:

Calamari "a la Plancha," Asian Pear, Mint
Terrine of Warm Sheep's Milk Cheese + Ham
Piquillo Peppers stuffed with  Goat Cheese, Pistachios and Raisins

Their apps and desserts are hands down the best part of the meal.  The calamari was grilled and refreshing, the terrine was UBER salty but so fatty that little bites were still foodgasmic, and the piquillo peppers were stuffed with heavenly creamy goat cheese.  Honestly, I wished I had ordered two more apps for myself as my entree.  Here were the reasons why I didn't like the entrees:  

- I thought the roast chicken was pretty boring, as well as the steamed rockfish.  I just wish there was a little more umph to it.  It was fine quality, but I like the rockfish I steam at home better (or perhaps its just I don't like the subtlety of the basque style fish/chicken?

-My husband's new york steak came out medium to medium well, which is truly upsetting when you expect a medium rare.  He had to sit there while we all ate and by the time he got his food back, he wasn't hungry. This definitely ruined it for him. 

+ On the plus side, my friend got the rack of lamb and he loved it.  We all agreed we should have gotten his dish instead. 

For the desserts:
* Dark Chocolate Cake "Amatxi" & Crème Fraîche
* Milk Chocolate & Hazelnut "Biarritz Rocher"
* Orange Blossom Beignets

I loved the airy and chewy texture of the beignets, but felt they lacked something; whether it was a creme to dip in the beignets or more flavor in general.  I didn't like rocher, since the botttom crispy part had tasted like it was previously frozen, and maybe even had frost bite on it at one point.  Definitely the Dark Chocolate Cake was the winner, and I would be happy to get this every time.
author: Hannah W.

description:
Service was abysmal but I guess they don't need to provide good service since they tack on an 18% service charge (for a party of 3).  I can't comment too much on the food because it was not a great choice for a vegetarian, which I knew. The vegetarian entree was "Basque Rice "Gaxuxa," Seasonal Vegetables, Sheep's Milk Cheese, Espelette," the espelette being the only thing that sets this dish apart from every other mediocre risotto in town. But hey, the kitchen even forgot to add the espelette. Nice quality control. 

The dark chocolate dessert was great.
author: Kirsten N.

description: we stopped here before dinner time, to fortify ourselves before an evening meeting, so we ate off the appetizer and side dish menu. The dishes we had were exceptionally good, especially the lentil soup. Really great flavors and equally exceptional service. We intend to come back for the monthly prix fixe basque dinner. Even though the food was so tasty, it was not overly salty, as is often the case. We are very sensitive to salt and had no swelling the next day.
author: MJ L.

description:
We had a Travelzoo voucher and never would have tried this place otherwise.  A+ for service.  I was a little worried the wait staff would give us the cold shoulder based on some of the negative reviews from other Tzoo members, but we had a lovely experience.  
Salmon was delicious and the hubs enjoyed the lamb.  We both rolled out of the restaurant full and happy.
author: Ever L.

description:
Very disappointed with this place. I feel like every time I buy a restaurant coupon I have high expectations, only to be let down. I will say we got a *good* deal, as in we paid $69 for the Travelzoo voucher and food alone regular price would have been $114 (plus 2 glasses of champagne with the deal). Then again, they add tax + 18% mandatory tip on top of that, so you end up paying way more than intended. 

Great rustic atmosphere with outdoor seating area, although it's definitely an older crowd, potentially because it's in a back alley/warehousey section of North Beach. No problem getting an online reservation for a Thursday night, and we were seated right away. We were pretty close to the 2 tables beside us, like when we stopped talking we could hear every word of both their conversations. Not quite ideal. Our server definitely took her time getting to our table, and was rushed, rude, and inattentive the entire night. We heard her say to the couple beside us how completely swamped she was ("sigh"), and how she had too many tables, but honestly she just seemed to hate her job. We actually had to ask for ice for our water, and I had to request salt & pepper shakers from the bus boy. I guess I get the whole European authenticity thing, but we're in America here ...

They were out of the cheese plate, which I was most excited about ordering, and so we ended up with the serrano ham and crab txangurro appetizers, which admittedly were both excellent. I had the halibut entree which was tasty, but my bf's steak was way overcooked when he had specified medium rare. The spectacular desserts would have partially made up for the poor service, if only our waitress hadn't forgotten to bring us our leftovers after we asked her to bag them. (????!!) I swear, expensive underwhelming restaurant experiences like this make me thankful for Thai food and pizza.
author: Natalie H.

description:
FANTASTIC meal. Came here with a Bloomspot offer (win) but every dish we had was a total success. Consistency is key, people!

The menu mentions that the appetizers are small but the appetizer portions to me were pretty generous in comparison to other restaurants. 

Dungeness Crab "txangurro"  - Best dish here. They split the appetizer into two plates for us and I was surprised that they gave so much. I was all prepared for this expensive appetizer to be super small but it wasn't. AND it was delicious
Beef Crudo, Chile - TIP: If you order both this and the crab, eat this one first. Solid appetizer but definitely a more subtle flavor than the crab (which is not a bad thing at all)
Seared Duck Filet - Duck was cooked so perfectly. And the carrots and sauce were surprisingly just as good as the duck itself!
Caramel Custard "koka" - Basically, it's a flan dish. It's basically a really, really good flan.

Consistently great dishes. Would highly recommend for either a date or group of friends. It's surprisingly in a really quiet part of SF which is nice so it's relatively easy to find parking.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I pretty much come here only because I work right next to "the Window" and it's one of a handful of options close to work. The food is decent, but sooo overpriced. The staff is super nice.

Breakfast can easily run $5 - a coffee, a hard boiled egg, and a small fruit salad. On days that I'm not too concerned about carbs, I'll get a toasted sesame bagel with cream cheese, tomato, and pesto. Pass on the baked egg whites - the whites are overdone and bland. Frittatas are tastier but heavy, and I've found egg shells more than a few times in mine. Lunch runs around $8+. The chicken mandarin salad ($7.95) is my go-to salad, although I'm usually hungry again by 4pm. I also like the side tuna & black rice salad, but it's so small that I usually get a soup along with it.   

On rainy days, the lines are ridiculous and you're better off walking in the rain a few blocks away cause you'll get your food faster than the suckers staying in line. (Tip: if you're just getting a salad, drop by around 11am. They'll be ready and can hold until you're ready to eat).
author: Judy C.

description: The food was pretty good, maybe a little overpriced, but it was the wines by the glass that really perplexed us.  At a restaurant of this level, you'd expect to have lots of decent wines by the glass, but we didn't like any of them.  Wine prices were VERY high for the quality of wines offered.  The service was decent, but not stellar. Maybe we were expecting more from this restaurant as it is very cute and fancy looking...
author: john s.

description:
Great for a special occasion or power dinner.  It's pricey for sure, but delicious food, nice ambiance, good service, so I'd say it's worth it.  We had a nice older gentleman serving us that was Basque, he was super awesome! 

We had:

APP:
(1) warm sheep milk + ham terrine.  SO GOOD!  Crispy on the outside, melty on the inside.  It looks a bit funky but just cut it up and eat it with bread.  It's very salty but sooo good.  
(2) serrano ham - delicious if you're a ham fan, which I am!

ENTREE:
(3) rack of lamb - so tender and juicy and perfectly medium rare.  I ate it separately from the cumin fig sauce so I could just enjoy the lamb flavor.  decent portion considering it's rack of lamb.
(4) snapper with spinach - so soft and moist, really well cooked.  loved the garlic chips on top. 

DESSERT:
(5) orange blossom bignets.  A delicious surprise.  Orange blossom fragrance was so subtle and wonderful.  As some other reviewers said, they're more akin to the Chinese egg puff pastries rather than a really doughy ball.  I love both, and I loved this airy light texture.  
(6) Basque tart with cherries -- really good, although this wasn't the stand out dish, but that's probably b/c everything else was so good!

WINE: 
(7) the cote de provence rose is delicious (I think there's only one by the glass).  So light, perfumy, and perfect with the snapper.
(8) garnatxa- went really well with the lamb.
(9) white dessert wine - can't remember the name but man it was soo good!  

Wine list is great.  We had a fabulous time and I would definitely recommend it.  Enjoy!
author: A L.

description:
Great restaurant for a quiet lunch at 12 noon.  We (3 guests) all chose the Chef's Special Prix Fixe lunch; the main plate was a filet of sole which was superbly cooked.  It began with a choice of soup of the day or a salad and included a dessert; choice of one of 6/8 selections.

Service was marvelous and we were not rushed.  We had a nice visit chatting long after our table was cleared.  Best of all, we could converse without resorting to raising our voices.  Street parking at lunch time was ample; this being a Tuesday, Dec. 1.

We would return again soon for a relaxing lunch!
author: Tony T.

description: Really great place for a special date.  If you can't find a table sit at the bar with Zach, he's awesome!
author: Becky B.

description:
I honestly don't understand the appeal of fancy restaurants with tiny, overpriced portions. And unfortunately, this place is one of them. Of course, if the food was good, I wouldn't complain, but it really didn't deliver; I was truly hoping that Piperade would have amazing food with all the decorative hype. 

The service was cordial and the restaurant is quite nice. A bit on the fancy side, which is perfect for a business luncheon when the food is only secondary to the conversational transaction. 

I do like the originality of the Piquillo peppers. It's stuffed with goat cheese with pistachios and golden raisins on the side. For an appetizer, it's delicious! The goat cheese was slightly warmed and melted inside the peppers, and the sweet taste of the raisins added a nice touch to lighten the flavor. Piquillo peppers: 5/5!

The tuna sandwich I ordered turned out cold and dry, so I don't recommend it. It's actually a real tuna sandwich, where a thick piece of tuna fish is stuck in the middle of two pieces of bread. The tuna was seared well, such that the middle was still half raw, like how one would cook medium-well steak... but it came out cold! Also, because the tuna was so healthy, it lacked any flavor to help take down the bread. I was so disappointed, that I actually wished I had a normal tuna sandwich. At that point I didn't mind having just pieces of tuna marinated in mayo...I just wanted SOMETHING that had SOME flavor! I think the dish would have been better if the tuna wasn't in a sandwich form. Tuna sandwich= 2/5.
author: Rose W.

description:
4.5 stars.

Perfect execution. That's what I kept saying after the meal. Nothing was especially unique, but every dish was executed to perfection.

The food enjoyed included:
- Mushroom tartlet. VERY RICH, creamy and probably 1000 calories. Good, but thank goodness I only had 1/2 of one.

- Rack of lamb with cumin-date sauce, veggies and fennel bulb. For the longest time, we couldn't figure out what the mystery white vegetable was --- cabbage? onion? artichoke? --- No, apparently it's fennel. Ok, moving on the meat. The lamb was cooked exactly as we requested with a charred outside. The veggies were also very well seasoned.

- Steak with a small sauce-platter of romesco and broccoli rabe. I've never had romesco with steak and it was brilliant. Need to try that at home next time. The broccoli rabe had parmesan cheese melted on top which really hid the bitterness of the rabe well. Delicious! And of course, the steak was PERFECTLY cooked with a crusty, grilled outside.

- Dessert: Dark chocolate cake with crème fraiche. It was like a dark chocolate flourless cake. Good, but nothing special.

The restaurant doesn't have anything that you probably haven't had at other restaurants, but it's probably cooked better at Piperade. 

Service was also very attentive even though we were probably the youngest people there that night. Also loved the décor including the wine bottle chandelier, although the round table that seats 10 under it was unusually large, which made it difficult for people to talk to anyone other than the people directly next to them.
author: Angela S.

description:
I used the travelzoo coupon and it was a preety good deal although they do add tax and an 18% tip on what the regualr price would have been.

I had the Dungeness Crab "Txangurro as an appetizer which was very good and the gf had a calamari dish which was too spicy for me.

Dinner was lamb chops and a side sausage served with something.

Dessert was good.
author: Mark M.

description:
Wow. The crab appetizer was one of the best things I have ever eaten. The squids were very good. 

Their house Cava is actually good, which is rare.

The steak was properly cooked and the romesco sauce was killer.  Dessert was good.

Not the greatest service in the world, but overall an EXCELLENT experience. The food was truly phenomenal.
author: Wade C.

description:
My husband and I went to Piperade based on a Bloomspot deal that I had purchased.  Making reservations through the website was not a problem, and the host was understanding when we called to explain we would be late due to the bad traffic along the Embarcadero.  Our table was still waiting for us when we arrived and by this time I was starving and ready to get my grub on!

Ambiance: The restaurant itself is a very nice, large space but it's located in a very non-descript area of the city.  This is totally fine with me, as long as the experience is good.  The patrons were all noticeably older.  In our mid-thirties, I think we were by far the youngest people in the restaurant!  As others have mentioned on Yelp, you are sitting very close to other tables so it's hard to not to eavesdrop on people's conversations.

Food:  for appetizers we ordered the grilled calamari and the Serrano ham, which were both quite tasty.  The Serrano ham was very overpriced though, considering how much you get.  The grilled calamari was probably my favorite part of the dinner, very tender and perfectly seasoned.  For entrees we split the Cornish game hen and the New York steak.  The Cornish game hen was good, but the New York steak was even better!  The steak was perfectly cooked medium-rare and came with a yummy sauce for dipping.  Since we got two appetizers we didn't order dessert.

Service:  We had to wait over 20 minutes for our appetizers because of a large, private party that was in the restaurant. Once the waiter noticed he did apologize and our appetizers eventually came.  We had to ask for our waters to be refilled and I also had to ask for another glass of wine, which was a bit annoying (even more so because I was starving and irritated from waiting).  Our waiter was nice enough to comp my second glass of wine because of the wait, which was a nice touch.

Overall, the food was pretty good but I don't think we'll be back anytime soon unless there's another Bloomspot deal because it's not worth their price point when there are so many other restaurants to choose from in the city.
author: Marisa G.

description:
So cool - entrance, space, service, food, wine. Highly recommended. Dinner on a Monday night with my gf's mom and stepfather. Despite the post-modern architecture, the staff kindly found us a four-top which assisted her parents in hearing everyone. 

Honestly, my only concern with the entire meal was finding a wine to pair well with the diverse flavors represented in our orders. What a great problem to have! Piperade's tone was convivial, though not exuberant. As proof: every party, seated at tables or at the bar, was smiling and laughing. I've never seen such a large group of random restaurant patrons, on a Monday night no less, in such a pleasant mood.

Returning to this restaurant will be a pleasure, and likely another excellent experience, thanks to the superior execution in so many facets. 

BTW, parking nearby at night isn't too difficult. Plenty of spaces on the streets.
author: Mike H.

description:
This place is truly a hidden gem! Friendly staff, great food - perfect for a work lunch/dinner or a date! 

I needed a place for a work dinner near North Beach & Financial District. Had great reviews but I didn't realize what a treat I was in for. 

For starters, we  split the Piquillo Peppers w/ Goat Cheese, Pistachios and Golden Raisins & the seasonal mushroom tartlet. We split the rack of lamb entree -- delicious! Loved the date relish! 

I ordered the pinot noir by the glass and the pour was generous. Thrilled with the whole experience, can't wait to go back!
author: Liz O.

description:
As 1/2 spaniard, I was underwhelmed on my 2nd visit (3-4 years later).  Piperade no longer feels Basque... just has basque touches to an otherwise generically-upscale menu.

Example: There is no sidra (dry cider) on the drink menu!  Are you kidding me?  That is the basque way, tio!

Example 2:  There is barely any cod dishes on the menu.  Cod is the basque hallmark.

Perhaps there is new management in town.
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Disappointing.  The food was fine but nothing was memorable (and we even had the calamari, which was an incredibly small portion and just okay).  The service was pretty horrible.  At $30+ per entree in an international restaurant, I would appreciate an overview of the menu as opposed to just sauntering up to our table 20 minutes later to ask us what our order is.  We had to request the bread plate.  I had to track down our waitress when I wanted another glass of wine.  We ordered the lamb rack and the duck, which were large portions.  The best thing we ate was probably the duck or the lamb sausage (was a side to one of the dishes).  So, $185 later I would have much preferred to have gone to Kokkari, La Mar or Spruce (the list goes on) for a special evening with amazing food. 

The atmosphere was very quiet on a Friday evening.  We are 30 and were the youngest people there by about 20 years (it was full though, so they must be appealing to someone).  The tables were very, very close to one another so that I had a hard time NOT eavesdropping on our neighbors.  And, I had the pleasure of sitting next to a 300 pound 60 year old man eating with his hand down his pants.

Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else for a great meal!
author: Tami S.

description: When I first sat down and looked at the menu, I thought to myself that I had either just become dyslexic or that I truly just was stupid.  Turns out that many of the things on the menu are super fancy and have super fancy lingo to go with it.  I ended up opting for the steak and I was happy with my choice!  Also, not sure why the cuisine type says Spanish as our waiter said it was French...
author: Courtney S.

description: It was a little bit of a walk, but my friend and I completely enjoyed catching up over a lovely Spanish meal at Piperade.  We shared the Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pistachios, Golden Raisins appetizer (creamy, lovely combination of flavors) along with the bread and tasty olive oil.  I had the Monday Classic: Albacore "Marmitako," Saffron, Potatoes (loved the saffron flavor with the albcacore), and then we shared the Gâteau Basque with Cherry Preserves (nice light cake with sweet cherry preserves, loved this combination).  Piperade also a nice wine selection, and the cocktails looked interesting too.  Service was helpful in making recommendations, pleasant dining environment with lovely decor.  I would come back!
author: Maile N.

description:
It has been two years since my first and only visit here, and while I didn't remember many specifics from the first time, I remembered that I loved it. Round two did not disappoint. Heading here with another traveling colleague, we both thought it was a great meal. 

We began with the Dungeness Crab "Txangurro," which was light and flavorful, and paired very nicely with the Beef Crudo. The Fingerling chips with the crudo were a really nice touch. I chose the Alaskan Halibut for my meal. It was perfect cooked, seasoned beautifully and the roasted corn relish added a great dimension. Meanwhile, the green and yellow zucchini medley that supported it left me pleasantly surprised by its grilled flavor and nothing like the soggy mess that often characterizes zucchini dishes.

We finished off the meal by splitting the orange blossom beignets (which were good - but I would have like a little more of the orange flavor to come through) and the "Milk Chocolate & Hazelnut 'Biarritz Rocher'", which pleasantly surprised me. The waitress described as something like a Ferrero Rocher concoction, whereas this was a delicious mousse-like centerpiece, on top of a crumbly and crusty chocolate base.

Can't wait to head back on my next trip in town.
author: David B.

description: Definitely try the crab app.  Snapper entree is also good.  Nice atmosphere and is tucked away near local channel 5 (KPIX) station office.
author: Mitzi A.

description:
This review is for the Piperade Window in the Ice House alley (Pip-to-Go)

This review is mostly for the SERVICE. The food here is GREAT, which is why it makes it so frustrating!!! My main complaint is the short girl with the dark hair. She came on as soon as Zach left and the service has gone WAY DOWN HILL since then. She moves at a snails pace and it usually seems like she is half asleep. She knows nothing about any of the menu items if you ask her and she is just plain stupid and unfriendly. Sorry to be so harsh but this is a daily occurrence and I see others EVERY DAY storming off with their orders.

It doesn't take a rocket scientist to ring up orders and hand people food but this just not seem to be getting any better and it has been months now since she has been there. I work across the street and a lot of people in our office are aware of the same problem and some say they won't even go over there anymore.

To the Management: PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE fix this problem!!!
author: Randall F.

description: I just love this place!  Been coming here for years.  Kind of hidden away between Kokkari and Fog City but consistently excellent, friendly, non-threatening.
author: Greg N.

description:
This place is great!   

Matthew L. and I came here with four other people to enjoy an "all-out no turning back night full of deliciousness" sort of meal.   I felt like I could reward myself with a night out and I was ready to eat up a storm and not feel guilty about overdoing it. 

I believe that first impressions are important and I loved this place from the start.  It's tucked away on a corner, subtle but classy.  I was looking forward to trying Basque food.

Matt and I were fashionably early and the waiters offered us a seat at the bar.  The bartender didn't glare at us when we both just asked for waters. 

Eventually, the rest of our party arrived and we proceeded to our table and started admiring the menu. :)  This is what we ended up trying:

Tipiak small plates: 
Dungeness crab with basil, roasted pepper and mango
Warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine
Calamari "a la plancha"
Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts and golden raisins
Thinly sliced serrano ham
Endive salad with pomegranate seeds and persimmon 

For big plates, I ordered the braised seafood and shellfish stew in red pepper sauce.  My dining companions tried the lamb chop, roast duck, sea bass and another fish dish that I can't remember the name of now.  I loved the stew that I had.  For the price, I felt like it was very worth it.  The portion was perfect and the sauce that coated all the seafood was really flavorful. 

Their menu has seasonal features so if you go on the website, you won't always be able to see the full selection of what they currently have.

On top of all the food (Hey, I said all-out-no turning back right?), we started the night off with two bottles of Basque wine at the recommendation of our server.  Both of the wines were wonderful.  We tried one white, one red.  The white wine was really fantastic.  It was on the dry side, very light and refreshing, with a taste of apple mixed in.  I'm by no means a wine expert so this is just what my elementary palate remembers from last night. 

Out of all the small plates, my favorite was the piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese and the calamari.  Both were really well done and I'd definitely get them again.  For some reason, the sheep's milk ham and cheese terrine didn't leave a big impression on me but if you go there, you should still try it.

Oh! I almost forgot about the desserts!!!  I had the cornmeal cake with strawberry compote and creme fraiche and also tried some of the orange blossom beignet as well as the kefir cheese yogurt with seasonal berries and honey.  I also tried a glass of their moscato to go along with dessert.   The cornmeal cake was a bit dry and hard.  Not sure if that is how Basque cornmeal cake is supposed to be, but it was worth a try, although I don't think I would get it again. The orange blossom beignets were delicious though.

If you're ever looking for an intimate classy restaurant to enjoy a night of great food (and spend some $$) , Piperade is the place to go!
author: Gloria C.

description:
I hadn't heard of Piperade until I picked up a recent Bloomspot promotion and boy oh boy am I glad I did! The food was hands down some of the best I've had in the city and the presentation was equally as impressive. The last time I had basque food was in a casual environment with heaping family style portions so I wasn't sure what to expect with a higher end establishment. 

Starters:
We started with the Picquillo Peppers and the Sheep's Milk Cheese + Ham and both were amazing, packed with tons of unique flavors--nothing like I've experienced before. I also tried the split pea soup with ham, which was very fresh and tasty, and unlike your traditional green gooey split pea soup (which I also very much enjoy). And like most restaurants, they provided bread and olive oil. The bread was pretty average but the olive oil was very tasty and had a strong olive flavoring. I probably should have stopped after my 5th piece of bread... 

Entrees:
I ordered the Roasted Rack of Lamb, which was cooked to order (medium-rare) with a charred outter layer. The lamb was packed with flavor and was very tender, and was not too gamey. My dish also came with braised fennel and a sausage which complimented the lamb very well! My fiance ordered the Pacific Petrale Sole over a bed of spinach and fried garlic. Mmmm-mmmm that combination makes my mouth water just thinking about it. I think I enjoyed her dish more than mine!

Dessert:
By this time, we were pretty stuffed but we decided to split a dessert: the Gateau Basque. This was a nice dessert given our level of stuffedness because it was very light and not overly sweet. There was a very subtle hint of almond which I loved. All in all, a great choice.

Service:
We were sat immediately per our reservation. Our server was very nice and informative. She didn't come by often, but she also didn't neglect us. My fiance and I had time to chat without being interrupted every 5 minutes, so that was nice.

Overall, my fiance and I were pleasantly surprised at this restaurant and will 100% be returning, next time with friends and family to help spread the word!
author: Eric C.

description:
I really like the food at Piperade but I must admit that I was fairly disappointed with the To-Go outpost. Perhaps it's unfair to compare the two but if you see the Piperade name, you expect a certain standard. 

The Basque influence of the mother-ship does not fully transfer over to the pick-up lunch spot. On that note, Piperade To-Go doesn't actually cook anything. Everything's done at Piperade's kitchen (the server said so himself) then brought to this little nook. Some of the quality must have fallen off the trolley along the way I guess. Not that it's inedible by any means but the fried chicken in a Mr. Williams sandwich for example, has long lost its crunch by the time you put it in you mouth. 

With that said though, I really like the folks who work here. Upbeat and friendly, they kept conversations going plus they also take cards which is nice. I can see how having a salad here is the thing to do since they don't really make anything in-house but for a lunch time spot, I think there are better options around.
author: Jon L.

description:
The service was good. The place isn't suitable for girls night out, too conservative. 

We didn't like the menu options either. I like small plates, but had a hard time to find items I liked. Entree options are better.  It says this is a Spanish restsurant on yelp, but it's not at all.
author: Danielle W.

description:
Went to dinner with better half. We had a reservation but they still didn't have out table ready so we sat at the bar for a while. The table was pretty small (uncomfortable for my boyfriend's long legs). So much so that he knocked wine on the table (still his fault). But the waiter was nice about it so we left a hefty tip.  Wine list was long and had many good choices!

Food: boyfriend ordered lamb chops which were delicious. I ordered the chicken breast but wasn't as good as the chops
author: Japna S.

description: I've eaten here two more times since my first visit.  Trying the burger, famous chicken sandwich, and a seafood stew.  I thought all of the items were OK, not spectacular.  Service has always been on the edge.  They're really nice people but you have to work for their attention.  And you know...I don't like working during work hours.  I'm not bumping it down to a 3 completely, more like a 3.5 stars.
author: Shannon L.

description:
YUM. I have been a loyal Piperade guest since probably 2006. It is consistently an enjoyable spot, whether you're just popping in for a drink (or 3) at the bar, indulging in a few apps, or sitting down to a full-fledged dinner.

I must start off with what I consider the beacon of their menu, which is the Calamari a la Plancha. If you are someone who only enjoys calamari when it is battered and fried to death, then this is not for you. What it is, in all of its tasty glory, is a perfectly cooked squid (not battered or fried) drizzled with a red wine-type of sauce that is melt-in-your-mouth delicious. Don't skip the bread basket as you'll want to use a piece or two to sop up any remaining sauce after you've thoroughly enjoyed the calamari itself.

Although the menu changes seasonally, I think I have tried almost everything or at least a version of what is on the current menu. Honestly, I don't think I've ever had anything I didn't enjoy. I generally change up my order depending on what I am in the mood for that day. If you happen to pop in on a Tuesday, don't skip the Calamari with Ink Sauce (if two calamari dishes are too much for you, might I suggest starting with the Crab Tower or Piquillo Peppers instead?). If it's not Tuesday, my go-to entree is probably the Duck; my best girlfriend alternates between the Lamb and the Shellfish Stew.

If there are at least two of you, be sure to get the manchego gratin as a side. You won't be disappointed.

Lastly, don't forget to finish off with some dessert. Although I tend to be a chocolate fanatic (and their dark choc cake is fantastic), I usually end up getting the almond mousse cake. It is a little more unique and is a great, light-ish way to finish off such a tasty meal.

Now I may need to visit Piperade tonight now that I've relived all of these dishes in my mind while writing this review...
author: Nicole A.

description:
Two of us went to dinner here Mon 7/17/06.  I made reservations over the phone in the morning around 10am and the lady said I had the last reservation!!  

We showed up about 7am about 30 minutes before our reservation but we were seated anyways.  It wasn't busy yet.  B. got a glass of wine and then we got bread which was good which we dipped w/ the slightly spicy olive oil.  Later we noticed there was a red pepper floating above the olive oil.  

Everything sounded good on the menu so it was a tough decision.  Dishes we tried: garlic soup w/ rock shrimp, bacon, bread & egg $10-was good but I was expecting a creamy soup--it was too watery for me and didn't come with any bacon that I could see or taste.  

Warm Piquillo peppers w/ goat cheese, Calif raisins & moscated vinaigrette $10 was good, but for the price I'll skip it next time.

B. got a cod dish appetizer that he really liked.  $10-$12 can't remember.

Main dishes:
Marinated lamb chops w/ a potato gratin $23-Excellent.  Very tender and juicy, ask for it medium rare!  Potato gratin was delicious.

I got the veal cheeks comes w/ peas and corn and some brown sauce. $23.  I liked the veal cheeks-which was very tender but I didn't like the peas-too hard, corn was just ok--maybe from a can.

Dessert-we tried the turron mouse cake w/ roasted almonds. $7.  It was very light tasting and the almonds were crunchy reminding me of corn flakes a bit.  

Total was around $90 after tax but before tip.  I'd go back to try other dishes such as the warm sheep's milk cheese & ham terrine $12, steamed pacific snapper $19, Biarritz chocolate rocher dessert $7; or the chocolate cake "amatxi" $7.   Portions are good size and we left really full, but we also had no leftovers.

On OpenTable they only have one seating at 6pm.  They have two unisex bathrooms.
author: Ann L.

description:
This is our most favorite restaurant in SF.  The service is always great and the food is wonderful. Last night my husband had a perfectly dressed butter lettuce salad and I had a wonderful tomato tart as our first course. Then we had lamb....three distinct ways....and steak; both were excellent.we finished up with a almond gateau and an apple tart. Throughout the meal Daniel, our favorite waiter, matched wine pourings with each dish. Perfect, always perfect. It was an anniversary celebration and we did feel special! 
This is not just reliable but the secret find not to be missed.
author: Lynn E.

description:
Hidden Jem
Steve was our waiter very knowable and gave us great service 
The food was very good I had sea base and burgers are great
author: Spike 2.

description: My friends recommended this restaurant.  We sat at the bar and our bartender/waiter,John, was rude and indifferent. We ordered 3 appetizers and they were all terrible.
author: Alison J.

description:
Piperade, was my first experience at "West Coast Basque Cuisine", but the menu didn't seem to have anything unfamiliar when I first glanced at it. 

Parking was easy, there was ample street parking and the restaurant was busy for a Saturday night. It's a cosy little restaurant. The staff was prompt and welcoming, we were seated right away. 

The wine list is pretty impressive, from the finest Basque wines to wines from France, Spain and then, our very own California wines. We got served with some fresh bread and delicious olive oil to compliment our wine/bubbles.

We had a bunch of appetizers, and here is what I would recommend:
    - Dungeness Crab "Txangurro," Mango, Peppers, Basil : Served cold and absolutely incredible in flavor. I was enjoying the chunks of mango and pepper. 
   - Piquillo Peppers, Goat Cheese, Pistachios, Golden Raisins : Being not such a big fan of cheese, in general, I'm skeptical trying it. But this was a perfect 10 for me, absolutely delicious and the texture was firm yet smooth. I happily went for a round two.

What I didn't enjoy was the Cold Poached Foie Gras, Sea Salt, Black Pepper, Fruit Compote, it was my first experience with Cold Poached Foie Gras and the after taste it left me with, didn't make me happy. People in the party seemed to enjoy it but it did make me loose my appetite for a few. 
 
I had the Black Cod, Broccolini, Baby Leeks, Pil-pil Aioli. An absolutely well done, well presented and delectable item. Cod was mild and tender, the portion is small. I did sample some Lamp chops and NY steak, but the tenderness of the Cod beats all the other sampling I indulged in that night.

Out of the desserts, what stands out was, The Dark Chocolate Cake "Amatxi" & Crème Fraîche. 

I would like to try Bocadillos Tapas+ Wines, since Chef Gerald Hirigoyen owns that as well.
author: En J.

description:
The meals were okay. The salads were usual, and the four cheese plate appetizer carried the expected selection of cheeses. The corkage on the champagne we brought was $25.  No where does the restaurant post the $25 corkage, accept when it appears on the bill.  $25 amounts to punishment , and so I was duly disciplined for not purchasing one of the Piperade's mediocre, over priced sparkling wines. Neither the food, nor the atmosphere, nor the service compensates for the price exacted for not buying into their sad, pricey champagne offerings.  Next time, I will sacrifice an evening at Piperade. The $25 penalty sends just the right message: if you don't like our wuss wines, don't bother to come in.

Message received.
author: Jamie M.

description: Great menu. Top notch service. The location was off the beaten path but the good news was street parking, which was a breeze (and free on Sat night!). Had calamari and oxtail for apps which were outstanding. Sea bass and short ribs for main dish - both were excellent. Lots of restaurant choices in SF, but would definitely recommend checking these guys out too!
author: Dave M.

description: So. Good. I went here on a recommendation from people who know... I started with a cheese plate that had a bleu to die for- creamy with the perfect amount of smoky/salty flavor. Followed up with sea bass on a bed of spinach. The server recommended a rose from Provence which did not disappoint. You won't regret the price tag .
author: Amanda S.

description:
Having walked by this place many times over the years, I'm surprised that I never actually made it until now. But strangely enough, it was now that I would only truly discover and appreciate what the food is about. I've recently returned from Spain and spent a significant time in the Basque country which is where the chef and our server hailed. Now unfortunately the many dishes that I really loved just arent available here as the nature of seafood,produce, etc are just too wildly different. However we still found many things to be attractive and went as follows:

-Warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine with aged sherry
-Calamari a la plancha with fennel, olive, caper and coriander salpicon
-Cold poached foie gras with black pepper, sea salt and apple compote
-Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts, and golden raisins
-Lamb basquaise chops with gigante beans and zikiro vinaigrette
-Gateau basque with cherry preserves

They were out of the Axoa special and they didnt have things like pil-pil, caillos, kokotxa, txipirones, or bacalao/hake which I was really looking forward to, but all the familiar basque flavors were there. I had ordered a glass of Txakoli which kind of perked our servers attention. As we spoke further I found out that she was from a village outside of Lasarte which houses one of the most famous Basque restaurants Martin Berasategui. I then started talking about all the places throughout San Sebastian/Donostia  that I had been and she said I made her homesick! It was very cool to be able to relate to someone who grew up on the other side of the world. I always say that the easiest way to be accepted by another's culture is to eat their food and it sure held true here. At the end of our meal I was asking about dessert wines and was offered some complementary Patxaran, which is a specific Basque digestif. The same thing happened to me at Arzak in San Sebastian. It's true the hospitality of the Basque people! They are so damn friendly!

In normal form, we closed the place down and I'm excited to go back. I now have a Basque connection and I'm going to lobby for some of those dishes that opened my eyes to the Euskadi cuisine . 4.5 stars

Fuerte!
author: Kim N.

description:
What happenned to Piperade?  Our previous expriences here have been great.  Tonight wasn't so much.

The food:
I had the Piperade for appertizer and it was quite bland.  The halibut was not bad but also bland and a little dry.  My wife had the cornish hen and it was extremely dry. The accompanied corn cake was burned. The dessert was meh.
Service:
It took a while for the entrees to come. Perhaps because it took a while to over cooked everything.  The waitress took 15 minutes to come back and take our dessert order after dropping off the menu, then another 15 minutes for the dessert, then another 10 minutes after clearing the table to bring the check.  We had of of these vouchers so tip is included.  Is that why service was so bad, they were getting their tip regardless?

I'm hoping this is just one of their off night. Previous experiences have been great.
author: Yo Yo M.

description:
Our waiter tonight was very abrupt and rushed thru any interaction with us and therefore our order was messed up a few times.

But the food was so great we might still come back despite the service!

We loved the mushroom tart....the crab appetizer was tasty and generous portion.

The lamb main course was wonderful (the lamb sausage was amazing)  and the duck dish was spectacular

We had the cherry gateau for dessert and enjoyed it.
author: Foodlover B.

description: We stopped in for lunch on a Friday afternoon and it was not crowded. The food was great- I had the tomato tart and a basic herb salad. For dessert three of us shared the yogurt cake and apple tart. Both were excellent. The server was knowledgeable about the menu and took great care of us. He even made a special fruit juice soda for my daughter.
author: Aimee L.

description:
Piperade rocks!! The food is amazing. However, the waiter needs a bit fitness.
We had a bloomspot certificate to try out the place.  I have been there few times, my friends and I have always enjoyed this Restaurant.
author: bonnie c.

description: It was a first time experience and I must say everything from the atmosphere, to the wine, desserts and main course was excellent. Looking forward to another visit.
author: Tee Z.

description:
The location is somewhat hidden away.  We came upon this place on our route home and after looking the place up, we decided to try it out.

We are not big on making reservation and just try our luck.  With the dining room half empty, the hostess told us she won't be able to accommodate us without prior reservation as they were completely booked.  Before we turned away, the owner/chef came over and told us he'll get a table for us while having a word with the hostess.

We were sat at a table near the window.  For the records, the place never became full while we dined.  To think the hostess always gave away business and how many more she turned away.

Our waiter, Daniel, was very friendly and helpful with the menu.  We ordered a bottle of Cahors ($36) and had the following:

bacalao salad -$13 - house cured bacalao w/ oyster tartare & lemon creme fraiche - DELICIOUS!  so delicate, fresh and flavorful.

txangurro - $14 - dungeness crab "txangurro" w/ basil, roasted pepper & mango - yum, melt in the mouth!

A La plancha - $13 - calamari "a la plancha" w/ fennel, olive, caper and coriander salpicon - another winner

sheeps mik - $13 - warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine w/ aged sherry - slightly on the salty side.

orange  blossom beignet - $8 - very good

turron mousse cake w/ roasted almonds - $8 - so happy Daniel recommended this - LOVE it!

I personally love this place and it's my favorite place to enjoy small plates.
author: Gloria H.

description: okay... I was here with a customer during oracle open world. The food was good, the soup was to die for. However I would have expected better service and the steak was a little tough for medium rare... I will still recommend this place for lunch for about party size of 5.
author: Prateek B.

description:
Got the seared duck entree. The stuff around the duck was pretty tasty (sauce, citrus, carrots, but the meat itself was only alright. There was plenty of flavor.

There were five pieces of duck loin, each with a good amount of skin on it, fairly thick skin too. The meat wasn't as tender as it could have been. I asked for it done medium but it tasted a bit too rough for medium.
author: Haitao M.

description: Might be my favorite restaurant in SF. Like the location, ease of parking, atmosphere of the restaurant. The servers are friendly and attentive. Drinks, food are excellent. Piperade is the real thing in all ways. Give it a try...
author: Dan S.

description:
It was expensive for what it was. Small portions, even the "big plates" were small. There were 3 of us and we ordered 4 small plates, 2 large plates and 3 desserts. We ate everything, including the bread and we did not come out full. The food was good. The calamari and mushroom open pie were the standouts of the night. The duck and seafood stew were ok. The garlic soup and the stuffed piquillo peppers are totally overrated. I would not order the peppers again. The duck and seafood stew were good but not special. The beignets tasted like jasmine tea donuts which was really good. The $8 caramel custard "koka" tasted exactly like flan that you can get at Chevy's for $3 and it's twice the size. The creme fraiche chocolate cake was just chocolate cake.  

The service was ok. It was not warm and friendly but they did their job. I made a note on Open Table when I made our reservation that we were celebrating a birthday, they never acknowledged it in any form.

The place is pretty casual, we would have felt more comfortable in jeans. Street parking was really easy. We had 2 cocktails and a (really sour) lemonade. The bill came out to $160. We didn't feel that we got what we paid for.
author: Andy W.

description:
I though the most food was excellent but the service was very poor for that type of restaurant. Food 5 stars Service 3 stars

For example, we had to ask for water about 3 times despite the waitress walking past us on many occasions. We even saw her hanging out at the bar talking to other staff rather than pay attention to the tables. 

Perhaps if we had had a different waiter it may have been different but you've got to blame the management for either poor training or attention. 

In a lesser restaurant it wouldn't have mattered but Piperade is not cheap and I would expect better. The problem it's things like this that make you think twice about coming back!
author: Brian W.

description:
This is definitely a fine dining restaurant.  My husband & I came with another couple.  We each ordered a small plate, an entree, a dessert, and wine.  Each couple paid $145.00 inc. tax & tip.

Our small plates included the serrano ham, the garlic soup, the calamari, and the tuna.  If you love Spanish serrano ham, order it here.  The ham is piled high on the plate. The ahi tuna was seared just right and comes in a soup bowl with sliced potatoes.  Our friends liked the flavors in the garlic soup and calamari, but both felt their dishes were somewhat salty.

Everyone enjoyed the entrees.  We ordered the lamb chops, the seafood stew, and the locally caught halibut.  Everything was cooked perfectly, and each entree was very generous.  Definitely order the lamb chops if you love lamb.

The noteworthy dessert was the orange blossom beignets.  Came 4 in a bowl, and was very hot.  Sure the inside was a little doughy as noted by another Yelper, but not uncooked.  More like a custard texture.

Our server was very reserved, but efficient.
author: Shirley N.

description:
My first meal at Piperade was well over 5 years ago, so I can't possibly comment on that dining experience.   Obviously it was good enough that I was happy to return, which I did earlier this week.   A friend of mine drove up from the South Bay and I suggested we revisit this restaurant for lunch.   Him being Basque, I thought he might enjoy a taste from home.

My friend ordered the fish stew, which he enjoyed.   I for one tried to be a little adventurous and decided to go with 2 appetizers.  I had the Foie Gras and the Piquillo Peppers stuffed with goat cheese.   The portion of Foie was quite generous though I thought it was served a little too cold and hard for my taste.  While the piquillo pepper dish was lovely and tasted good, I couldn't help but compare it to the same dish I had at Julian Serrano in Las Vegas last month.   Obviously the dish paled compared to Serrano's masterful creation.    Nevertheless, all in all it was a nice dining experience and I definitely recommend you check out Piperade.
author: David O.

description: It worths 4 stars. This means I will come again some time.
author: Herman K.

description:
A fun to-go counter where the staff is always friendly.
They have a great mix of sandwiches, soups salads and quick grab and go items like yogurts, parfaits, chips, & wraps. I also appreciate that they'll let you sample the soup before committing to buy the soup of the day. 

My favorite salad is the curried chicken salad: it's chunks of chicken, grapes, almonds, celery, dried cranberries and the serve it with pita and butter lettuce so you can make lettuce cups, or a pita  sandwich.
If you want a salad I recommend getting the the Mr. Williams but ask for it as the "Mrs. Williams" it's the same sandwich but it comes with a spicy aioli that takes the sandwich to the next level.
author: Amy L.

description:
One of the best meals I have ever had.  I sat outside on the patio out front and had a terrific meal and great service.
I started with a Dungeness crab salad appetizer that was out of this world!  The portion size was more than I thought it would be which was a great surprise.  It was perfectly made with the perfect amount of spices.  The blood oranges went perfectly with the crab meat.
I then had the Calamari "a la Plancha," Fennel, Olive, Caper, Mint, Lemon, what a great dish!
For the final dish I had the Roasted Rack of Lamb, Merguez, Fennel, Breadcrumb, Pecan, Cumin,  with Date Relish.  Everything went perfect together.  The lamb chops were so tender so juicy so good!
Finished it all off with the warm apple tart.
author: Jim S.

description:
Piperade was recommended to me by a coworker and being a "finger on the pulse" kind of woman, I was surprised I hadn't heard about it based on the 4 star review. I immediately made plans to get my grub on seeing as how it was not too far from my work, anyway. 

Having now dined here, I'm not surprised I hadn't heard of it. Piperade is one of these random restaurants that seem to get decent reviews but don't really deserve it. I imagine a lot of bridge and tunnels rave about it; folks who haven't experienced the scope of what really amazing food is here in SF, hence the generous 4-star review rating.

The butter lettuce was boring, boring, BORING. The dressing had zero flavor and it came garnished with pretty much nothing. If I wanted a bland bowl of lettuce leaves I would go to the grocery store and throw some olive oil on it. The pork shank was bland too...the meat itself was well prepared - it fell off the bone quite beautifully - but there was no depth or strong flavor to the sauce it came with. There was just nothing special about this meal and it certainly wasn't worth spending good money on.

If it weren't for the delicious dessert, this probably would have been a 2-star meal. The dark chocolate cake and orange beignets saved the evening.
author: Julia N.

description:
I recently met a friend here for dinner. We started this lovely meal by sharing the following apps: 
* Calamari (a must if you go)
* Mushroom Tart 

When it came to picking an entree to share it was a bit more challenging.  Due to an allergy I don't eat beef so many of their menu items were out.  I'd usually go for tuna or halibut, but that's out due to future Baby R. And so we ended up ordering the char, which I wasn't sure if I would like. Our waiter was sweet enough to split it among 2 plates and it turned out to be really good. Apparently I do like char!

No dessert since we'd be drinking our "dessert" elsewhere, although non-alcoholic cocktails for me of course.  Yet another delish meal in SF...
author: Andrea R.

description:
I had been wanting to try Piperade ever since we got back from Spain a couple of years ago.  A coupon on Bloomspot finally gave me an excuse to go.  The ambiance is warm, the service was both friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  The seasonal cocktail list was full of tempting options.

To start, we split the dungeness crab, with blood oranges, basil, and grapefruit.  The lumps of crab were generous and tasty, and the citrusy fruit complimented it quite well.  We also tried the gigante beans with bacalao and caviar, which was quite good.  It wasn't the heavily salted bacalao of Spain, but a fresher-tasting version (it nearly reminded me of ceviche).  

For dinner, I had the seared duck filet and my husband had the lamb.  Both were cooked perfectly.  I don't think I had enough entrees when I was in San Sebastien to really speak to the food's authenticity (we primarily ate at pintxo bars), but my impression is that this food is California Spanish Basque.  What seemed to be fresh, local ingredients inspired by Basque cooking.

For dessert, we split the milk chocolate and hazelnut "biarritz rocher," which was an amazing pastry that, as the named suggests, tasted like a Ferrero Rocher (but better).  Everything was wonderful and there were many items on the menu that I would love to go back to try.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: We have dined here 4 times. No fail the food is delish every time !! If you are into seafood, try the  squid ala plancha & seafood stew in red pepper sauce.. Yummy
author: Beth P.

description:
2nd time here but the first time was years ago and I attended a private party in their side room.  I remembered I enjoyed the food and saw a Bloomspot voucher so I jumped on a chance to revisit this restaurant.  

It's a very cozy, and warm feeling restaurant, not small but like you're eating with good friends and family.  We shared the mushroom tart which was excellent!  Try it!  I had the Sole which I thought had too much vinegar and not enough flavor.  The fish was cooked well though.  BF got the steak which we both thought was very good.  It came with a chipotle sauce which he poured on without tasting first but ended up enjoying it.  The steak was cooked well but shouldn't have been cooked a second longer for medium.  We then shared the mousse cake with almonds.  My bf who is French said it reminded him of something he used to eat in France.  It was delicious and not something you normally see on the menu.  

Food, 4 stars but the service 2 stars.  Our server was a very nice lady who just had too many tables that night.  I had my back to the room but my bf said she pretty much had to handle the whole room and some people who sat outside.  Everything took a little too long to get which ended up being frustrating.  We also ran out of water multiple times.  Other than that, we enjoyed our dinner there.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
We visited Piperade with the TravelZoo deal and were very happy to have this introduction. We were pleased with the service and found the range of options on the menu presented a good exposure to the cuisine. 

We enjoyed the tomato tart and stuffed pepper appetizers. The rack of lamb with merguez was an ample portion and well prepared. They were very accommodating for me as a vegetarian and allowed me a variety of option. I selected three of the sides manchego and potatoes gratin, spinach with raisins and pine nuts, and lentils. They worked well together and made a nice main dish.

We felt that the 18% service that was included because we had the voucher was appropriate and look forward to dining at Piperade again.
author: David W.

description: Both my date and I thought the food here was good, but not spectacular. A bit stuffy, but good for the business dinner occasions.
author: Will D.

description:
Five stars because I'm still dreaming about the arugula salad I had as a starter.  It tasted, honest to God, like Spring in the country when everything is that new delicate green you can hardly believe exists.  Ethereal. 

The food was excellent.  My asparagus side was lovely and my halibut cooked to perfection, but that arugula salad cast a heavenly halo over everything.  My host, visiting from out-of-town, insisted on Piperade when he usually defers to me on SF restaurants.   He reported his meal excellent, too, but I was in raptures and didn't pay much attention (maybe the seafood stew).  Sorry.

I'm not a cocktail drinker.  Give me a straight 15-20 year old single malt with a side of water and I'm a happy girl.  My host ordered a Grey Goose martini and reported it, "Perfect!"  He was very, very happy.  We had a Molinari chardonnay, he being a reformed wine collector and still wine lover, that he was very pleased to find on the wine list.

 I'm glad we went as the decor while simple had an elegance that welcomed and enfolded us.  We talked and caught up with service that supported the food and our conversation without intruding.

If you you're looking for a romantic spot, Piperade has all you need.  We weren't looking for that and yet I couldn't help imagine the simple elegance lending itself to a grand romantic gesture.  The wait staff controls the room well, but as in all high-end SF restaurants these days, the tables of shall we say self-involved "entrepreneurs"  trying to work business deals can be distracting.  If romance is on your mind, cue the staff when you make your reservation.
author: Julia C.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by our meal at Piperade. The restaurant has been around for so long that I have forgotten about it but I'm totally happy for my last visit.

We ordered the stuffed peppers, halibut, and the calamari with squid ink rice. I probably wouldn't get the peppers again, the whole nuts just didn't do it for me. Our calamari dish was so good that I'm hungry again thinking about it. I had black squid in all over my mouth. We had a good laugh.

Desserts could use a modern touch and their drinks need help. I suggest hiring a new mixologist to spice things up and bring in a younger crowd.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I'm a fan of this place.  I came with a Bloomspot deal.  Here's what we ordered:

Appetizer/Side: 
- Calamari: grilled and the sauce it was in was sooo bombdiggity.  It was drenched in a lime/chili oil type thing that gave it so much flavor.
- Frittes: these taste like McDonald's french fries!! If you like that, then you should order for sure.

Main:
- Duck: this had a really interesting sweet flavor from the pear and sauce.  The duck was pretty tender, but not the best duck I've had in SF.  Jardiniere still takes the cake for the best duck in the city.
- Sole: BF ordered the sole because he wanted something lighter, and he definitely got it.  It wasn't anything extraordinary in my opinion - it was actually pretty  simple... a piece of fish on top of some sauteed spinach.

Dessert:
- Orange Blossom Beignets: MAN i am so glad we ordered this.  We thought it was going to be like an orange blossom flavoring syrup or filling, but the beignets were actually flavored this way! It was SO good.

Overall, the place was pretty good.  It was kind of in a random area, and nothing else was around it, but it was a cute quiet place.  I don't think I'd come back here without some sort of deal, but it was still good.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The food is definitely 3 stars but the service is not or at least it was not on the night we were there.
Granted there were 2 big parties seated next to us and since we were the last reservation of the night(nobody came after us AT 8:30) , we were kind of forgotten.
Even though when service came it was friendly but not efficient. Food runner was not friendly and did not look whether we had all or the right utensils.He needed to be told Waitress friendly but distracted, at the end of the evening she clearly wanted to be done.Herring,crab salad,garlic soup,lamb rack and salmon all were excellent.
Looking at the bill now again,I am noticing that there was 1 cocktail  charged extra!
Well, I should have seen it before.
If it wasn't for the food, only 1 star here. Too bad.
Have been  here many times but not for a while and this left us disappointed.
author: Maria C.

description: I had the scallops for an app and braised pork cheeks for the main. I finished off with the apple tart for dessert. Everything was spot on except for the dessert it was a little dry and seemed like it was over cooked or from yesterday. Other than that the food was spot on, I am excited to try lunch here next as the menu differs. The wine selection was also good and was able to pair my main with the same wine used in the dish.
author: Ribec F.

description:
Got in on a Bloomspot deal from a friend whose coupon was expiring.  Birthday dinner for $39 bucks - yeah!

What we had:
* Calamari appetizer (I wasn't really a fan.  It was too fishy, for some reason.)
* Duck entree
* Shellfish and fish stew (There was a lot in there and was really tasty.  The "stew" part was super duper thick - like the consistency of baked potato soup.  Great flavor.)
* Warm apple tart w/ caramel sauce for dessert (which I also requested creme fraiche to be added.  SO delicious.)

I think this would be avery nice date spot, and look forward to returning.
author: Tamar D.

description:
I really wanted to go to the Gold Club to sample the five-dollar buffet, however the friend I was visiting for lunch felt like that would be a poor idea if he was seen visiting that establishment during a work day.

Instead, he suggested Piperade. Apparently this is a Basque restaurant. There only four things I vaguely know about the 'Basque' is that its an area that straddles France and Spain, there is a separatist movement including a militant faction, the roots of the Basque language predate Western Europe, and they were historically renown as cod fishermen. I know nothing about the food.

I had the house sandwich, which is good and bad. It was good because it was something easily recognizable, but it was bad because it still gave me no idea about Basque food. The house sandwich, known as Mister Williams, is a panko encrusted chicken cutlet served with thinly sliced avocado, Manchego cheese, and a roasted red pepper. 

I'm pretty sure 'Mister Williams' is not a Basque name, but Hell, it was a damn fine sandwich anyways.

Pro-tip: There is a backdoor take-out if you don't have time to sit down.
author: .Alan Y.

description:
Eh..... I've experienced better.  This place does NOT deserve the average 4 star rating (out of 400+ reviews).   It also does NOT deserve to be on the Big Eat SF list.  

I have to admit, the ambiance and deco was nice.  I loved the brick walls and comfy and yet elegant decor.  The food however was mediocre at best.  The description of the dishes sounded delicious on the menu but the final product was far from impressive.  In fact, the rack of lamb was a salty and disappointing mess.  Presentation was good.... quality and taste however was a severe disappointment.  In fact, that seemed to be a common theme.  Everything looked great but the quality was severely lacking.  

And the service?!... I guess my group was lucky to get the absolute WORST server in SF?  The other servers, waiters, etc. were all very friendly and pleasant.  Our server, however, was an absolute mess full of excuses and lies.  She told our group, that she can do separate orders.  Up to 10 orders in fact which was not needed.  Then, when it came to order, she stated that she couldn't do separate orders.  Then, she said she can but won't.  Then, she told us of an incident when she served a large group and they came up short?  What does that have to do with us?  Are you stating that we are going to come up short?  WTF?!  Then, she says, she is not supposed to do it but will do it anyways....  Seriously?!  How many lies can you spit out of your mouth in less than a minute?

I haven't been offended and angered by a server in a very long time.  In fact, it has happened less than 3 times in my entire life.  

 I guess this place was in fact memorable.... for all the wrong reasons.
author: Danny L.

description:
Went here for my birthday dinner with a bloomspot deal and nice bottle of Syrah (was charged corkage, not comped!).

Have to say the food was great, server very friendly, quite / upscale ambience.

The highlight of my meal was the lamb chops. They were really delish!

Its not the best place in town to dine at, but you can definitely do worse!
author: Sumit C.

description: Came here twice, once for a bloomspot deal and the other for a pre med school formal feast where we rented out a private room. The Basque tapas here are quite interesting and different, definitely not my usual meal. I've tried the appetizers calamari (not fried! grilled in a lemony sauce), piquillo peppers with goat cheese, and the dungeness crab. Entrees I tried were the sole with fried garlic and spinach and the braised seafood and shellfish stew. My favorite out of everything was the sole. The meat was really buttery and soft and the fried garlic and spinach complemented the fish well. Everything else was average. I had the orange blossom beignets for dessert which were great.
