It was such an intense flavor that even a dab of this stuff on your burger will mask the burger taste in its entirety, leaving you to taste nothing but piperade.  

I will definitely come here again with the swain to conduct a more thorough taste test.  The workers here are very accommodating and genuine and this place just has a very classy feel to it.  By the time we finished lunch, this place was jam packed with an assemblage of white collars in tunnel and peripheral vision.  The Basque burger left something to be desired, however, the sheep milk cheese more than compensated.  The flavours are extremely robust and I would like to see how they incorporate piperade in other dishes like fish.  

ps...i relinquished my coat during our seating.  when i went to retrieve it, i was intercepted by a garcon who took my coat, and held it open for me to slip my arms through.  not fond of being served in this manner, i motioned for him to desist and hand the coat over.  he stoutly refused, not budging, ever smiling.  god lam him.  it nearly brought tears to my eyes.  may the fates' spindle break on his thread of life, rendering him an immortal.  bless up.
author: Brian V.

description:
VERY POOR COMMUNICATION!
I called ahead to Piperade to let them  know I was coming in
With my husband for his birthday. The hostess even let me select
The dessert I wanted them to bring out ahead of time. When we arrived I even
Pulled a waiter aside to RE ITERATE it was my husbands birthday etc. The waiter
Simply said it would be taken care of. And low and behold after lunch, the waiter brought the bill. NO CAKE, NO DESSERT, NO NOTHING! I excused myself for the second time and asked what happened??!! The waiter simply said he didn't get the message (don't know HOW he couldn't have) and then brought out a lame dessert and charged me for it on top of everything!
Very disappointing experience because of the attitude and unhelpful staff.
author: lisa g.

description:
After being told about how wonderful this restaurant is, I was surprised to be very disappointed by my experience at Piperade. 

Our party chose to try Piperade for lunch, and upon arriving at the restaurant we noticed that we were a bit underdressed in comparison to the professional looking patrons. After noticing this, we requested to be seated outside in attempts to respect the establishment - you would've thought we had personally insulted the host's mother! 

The food and wine were both enjoyable. However, the service was terrible, and our waiter was horribly rude. I would suggest trying somewhere else, unless you wish to be treated like gum on the bottom of a French waiter's shoe.
author: Annie H.

description: I came here for dinner with my husband. It has been one of our favorite restaurants, but we haven't been there in a while. It didn't disappoint. The food was delicious, the service was great and the staff was friendly but not intrusive.
author: J I.

description: No way this is any higher than 3! Food is only ok. I have been to Spain, this is a disappointment! Not kid friendly either. Bar is ok
author: Aleksey L.

description: Tasty but notably expensive food and drinks, in a snobby ambient and not very friendly waiters. Definitely, there are better places to go in SFO than this one that calls to be Spanish when it is not.
author: Ana M.

description:
The Three Stooges (CM and Peg S and me) met for a wonderful meal... I had trouble opening and finding the front door but stumbled in to a warm restaurant with a lively crowd.
The food as Peg S described was wonderful but I would probably not order the cocktails and stick to beer and wine.
I really liked that we arrived early for a table and even at its most crowded we could still easily talk with each other without having to yell.
Great place for meeting friends.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
A little bright spot in my office neighborhood. I haven't ordered anything I haven't liked. The soup and salad special changes daily, which keeps their small menu fresh. The soup isn't always vegetarian, even the cream of broccoli, which is disappointing, but there's always a grilled cheese or Italian veggie sandwich and their cute snack-sized hummus and pretzels [who knew those went together?]. 

The staff is always super friendly and have clearly posted their payment preferences. On days when I've met the min. requirement for a credit card and am short on cash, I haven't experienced even the slightest bit of attitude.
author: Angela N.

description:
3 couples, $115 each couple, and that included wine!... 12 courses that we all shared. 

crab and green apple salad, mussel bread salad, ham terrine, grilled octopus with some kind of rich sherry demi? sauce..

chicken with pistachio and shittake (juicy and flavorful), duck breast (perfectly perfect), braised seafood in some kind of lobster tomato cream, pork shank with star anise-

lemon curd roll, chocolate mousse cake, cream caramel? or flan.. and the best of all, the gateau basque cake with glazed cherries!! 

I spent many summers in the south west coast of France(Hossegor/ Biarritz)..Basque country and all I ate was roast chickens, tomatoes, peppers, pomme frites AND that freakin to die for amazing cake/tart..

here's the kicker. One of our dinner guests looked at the cake when it was dropped and said "boy, wouldn't it be nice to have 6 cherries on the plate for all of us?" and nothing out of disappointment mind you. 
The waitress over heard her and VOILA! a second slice arrived with.. oh yes, 6 cherries. 
A french laundry experience for sure. maybe a bit messy because we shared and not with all the fan fare- an amazing array of flavors and textures for a fraction of the cost! great value!! 
only suggestion is to maybe skip the crab and mussel salad. a little flat- the service was tops!
author: Stephen G.

description:
Piperade is located on a perennially sleepy section of Battery street, skirting the base of Telegraph Hill and the long buried line of the Gold Rush waterfront;  in an area of warehouses that have long been transformed into chichi offices.  Just off Broadway, but well removed from the Barbary Coast atmosphere there, the biggest threat to the pedestrian is dying of boredom before reaching the restaurant.

Fortunately for the diner, Piperade has a lot more going on than the unfortunate street upon which it sits.  If you have weekdays off and don't feel compelled to eat at 11 in the morning, you can walk in to what is essentially your own private restaurant, sharing a large space with only a few other people.  The setting is of a recent modernism aging to classic---clearly not cutting edge, but not dated, either.  Nice, warm, yet elegant.

We confined ourselves to small plates, sharing the piquillo peppers;  calamari a la plancha;  Dungeness crab txangurro;  and the beans gigante---the menu changes daily and I notice that today it's mussels a la plancha and no beans gigante, with other stuff added that wasn't on the menu the day we dropped in.

Everything was well prepared, tasty, well presented.  There were no "Wow!" moments of culinary discovery, or bliss, but if we had a complaint, it never found words to express itself.

The hands-down favorite was the Dungeness crab, in a simple preparation that allowed the sweet marine flavor and silky texture of the crab to shine through, with added tropical notes, and a light crunch from the fresh, julienned escarole that topped the dish.  The grilled calamari (a la plancha=grilled) was basically the cone and tentacles of baby squid separated but cooked otherwise intact.  Fresh, soft, and slightly smoky, this is a far cry from the fried variety I love, and I didn't care.  Seafood polyamory!  It's San Francisco!  The beans gigante were O.K.;  a cold preparation as I remember, with a small number of the big flat beans beneath what looked like slices of pickled herring (a delicate white fish, in any case), but tasted better.  Not the most impressive dish that day, but still decent.  The piquillo peppers were the Basque equivalent of Mac n Cheese:  You'd be a real sour puss not to like something with this much goat cheese stuffed into it.  The flavor burst of the creamy cheese preparation were an hard to resist delight.

The lunch ended with the dark chocolate cake amaxti with creme fraiche;  a near molten (and very warm) chocolate  cake cooled by a generous dollop of the creme fraiche, which also tempered the bitter of the chocolate itself.   The espressos coming out ahead of the cake, to be mostly consumed by the time it arrived, was the only gaffe in service we experienced.

Portions are not generous but appropriate for this level of dining establishment and I'd heartily recommend eating here.
author: Paul T.

description:
My girl friend and I went here for dinner last night to mark our anniversary of our friendship, a toast to the New Year and to celebrate a new journey for the both of us. She had such an amazing time with her family at this restaurant that she decided to take me here. It was a short walking distance from her apartment and so, we didn't need to take my car. (Perfect!) 

We walked in and was seated right away by the exposed brick wall. Prime table location. We were greeted by a really nice gentleman who became our server for the night. She quickly ordered a bottle of their red, a Spanish 2008 El Chapparal, de Vega Garnacia. It was a light bodied red with full flavor. It really went well with our meal which consisted of the following:

-Calamari a la plancha (TASTY)

-Butter lettuce salad 

-Manchego gratin

-Steamed rockfish with a garlic vinagerette and spinach (STELLAR) 

Because our server found us quite the "charmers," he brought two glasses of dessert moscato, on the house to go with our Milk Chocolate and Hazelnut Biarritz "Rocher" dessert for our finale. Simply poetic justice. 

I think I may have found a restaurant where to take my parents for a special occassion, or at least someone who will appreciate impeccable service and the Spanish Basque cusine. 

I am a fan, and will be back!
author: Mika D.

description: Came her for a Prix Fixe Menu deal on Travelocity. The deal is dinner for 2 includes; 2 glasses if champagine, 2 appetizers, 2 dinner entres, and 2 desserts.  There are a few restrictions on what we can and cannot order.  The minus 1 star was because I ordered the New York steak medium rare it was cooked medium.  I sent it back and the second steak was rare plus (cooked outside and deep purple in the middle.) Minus a star for the 2nd steak and the steak knife was so dull I really had to work hard just to get a cut.  I didn't even finish my steak because my arm and wrist was too tired.  I could have asked for a sharper steak knife but decided to just fill up on the veggies and move on to dessert.  I had the hazel chocolate it was very good.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Ever walk into a place and just feel all warm and cozy. That's the feeling I got when we walked into Piperade. It had the feeling of a place you would go with your grandparents when they visit and where all dishes should always be shared. 

Is it cutting edge locavore cuisine? no. Is it cheap American comfort food? no. They don't list the farms they use, nor do they add on the SF health tax on afterwards to your bill instead everything is done with class and a manner that lets the history of the food speak for itself.

There were so many smaller plates that looked interesting that we decided to get lots of them and just split a larger plate. We both started with soups, my spouse got the soup of the day which was a pea soup unfortunatly she realized after it came and she tried it that it had bacon in it and had to return it as she doesn't eat land animals. They were nice about it and removed it from our bill. I had the garlic soup which was wonderful, it has the lovely bouquet of garlic while not being bitter or too strong, there was egg and croutons floating in the broth as well as perfectly cooked prawns.

Seafood is really where Piperade shines. All the seafood dishes were spot on in terms of cooking and seasoning. We had the calamari which my spouse really liked and I thought was pretty good. We both really enjoyed one of the vegetarian dishes which was a mushsroom pie which was so rich and creamy and the staff brought it out already cut in two and on two plates for us. I order the cold poached foie gras which was pricey at 20 dollars but when I saw the huge portions I understood why. This is a dish for 4 people to share. they brought out two huge torchons of foie gras with salt, pepper and quince compote. quince compote plus foie gras on toast is truly a marvelous thing. There was no way I could eat all the dish though and I brought one torchon home with me for midnight snacking.

The large entree we did share was basque stew of seafood with the wonderful pepper sauce that is used so often and it was all cooked beautifully. I really liked it while the French wife liked it but clearly since she has spent far more time eating Basque cooking at the source didn't find it so amazing.

We finished off the meal with a play on the Ferraro Rocher  with a dense chocolate mousse on top of a bed of hazelnut "rocher". It was one of many tempting desserts on the dessert menu and it was really lovely and one of the standouts of the evening.

The archicture may harkens back to a basque farmstead with rough brick walls, low timbered ceilings and distressed wood floors. What was lovely was how quite it was with an almost full dining room and how relaxed it felt.

There servers were almost all older men and our server was a nice uncle type who was present without being overbearing. With a spouse a with a mohawk and uniform of combat boots and cut off cargos I'm never quite sure how the service will be although usually in San Francisco we haven't had too many issues and this place followed that pattern with the staff being surprised but amused at her giant furry animal hat. The clientele does range from early 30 through older than they will admit.

It would be very easy to spend a 100 dollars on a meal for two but you could also spend around 45 for a meal for two. It's not a cheap restaurant yet everything was worth the price we paid.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
In SF solo on business, I wandered in here after reading about Piperade in the Chronicle's Top 100 Restaurants in SF Bay Area 2011. Man, did they get this one right!

A warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine, perfectly salted, over a balancing slightly bitter frissee and tangy shredded green apple salad drizzled with aged sweet sherry. Oh my. I had to restrain myself from licking the plate. When the bartender turned his back, I mopped my plate with the crusty-on-the-outside, chewy soft-on-the-inside  bread.

Then, I moved on to the Calamari a la Plancha. Perfectly cooked fresh squid tentacles and full pieces. The seafood was slightly sweet with a tomato-y broth that was a perfect tangy counterpoint. Again, not inhaling was  a struggle. 

Top off the night with a caramel custard "koka" (aka creme caramel). Light and luscious. Perfect with the glass of muscato gifted to me by the bartender.

Oh, and did I mention the lovely setting, the superb and genial waitstaff who treated a solo diner like a star, and the perfectly suggested pinot noir?

I immediately recommended Piperade to all my co-conference attendees!
author: Leigh W.

description:
Yes I am on a rampage. Yes this is not an emotionally objective review. BUT. I can absolutely say that I will no longer return! 

I've always had issues with the menu items tasting like processed foods churned into charming brown-boxed goods: The orange cheese in their sandwiches is pretty much Velveeta; the Mr. Williams "fried chicken" looks and tastes like it came out of a supermarket freezer; mandarin oranges in a popular salad clearly come from a can. However, given the close proximity and the FRIENDLINESS/ sheer EXUBERANCE of the people there--seriously, what are they on?!--made me a regular customer, and hey, their sandwiches are decent enough. 

Usually the wait is rather long, but today, they neglected my order completely. As I watched entire lines exhaust and dwindle down to the last stragglers, I inquired about my order. The buoyant cashier keeps referring to some other sandwich I did not order, but never mind that, because they never made a sandwich period! She talks to the guy manning the kitchen, and instead of taking care of my order from at least 20 customers ago, he fills incoming orders until he feels my order is fit enough for his time. In my opinion, he should've made me his priority customer instead of taking his sweet a$$ time.

Now, I mentioned service is usually slow, but slow meaning a total wait time of no more than 10 minutes of standing around the little window. Grilled cheese is no mad science, and half the cheese isn't even melted. I can see the beveled edges where they were sliced at the factory.

What irritated me further was how, of course, they handed me my sandwich unapologetically and with that HAPPINESS of theirs, and then I realized that they are not "on" anything...they are happy out of sheer ignorance!! If I had run this window, I would've not only made my order as quickly as possible, but I would've refunded my money. But nope! Instead they've lost a customer.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I went here with my wife for our sixth anniversary and we LOVED it. So much so that I went out and bought one of Chef Hirigoyen's cookbooks. We had the Piquillo Peppers stuffed with Goat Cheese, Pine Nuts and Golden Raisins and the Calamari "A La Plancha" with cantaloupe, mint and lemon confit. Both were Fantastic! The atmosphere was warm and inviting and the waiter was attentive and polite. I wrote a full review of the restaurant, how I found it and a little about the cookbook I bought on my local food blog:

http://thegreenecook.blogspot.com/2011/01/piperade-my-restaurant-review-and.html

I also had the Sea Bass with the frothed butter, which melted in my mouth like lobster and the Orange Blossom Beignets for dessert, which were perfect. 

Next time I go, I will try out one of the Basque classics offered on the menu. 

I took photos of everything and put them on there as well. I will be returning soon.
author: Michael G.

description: A great restaurant the first time... Underwhelming experience on 2013 New Year's Eve.
author: James F.

description:
Perfectly positioned in a small little alley surrounded by william sonoma buildings, this is the perfect little spot for good salads, sandwiches, and any type of lunch fare.  I personally recommend the Mr. Williams Sandwich, which I seem to always tend to get.  The quesadillas and grilled cheese sandwiches are also really good.  Most items (if not all) come with some greens.  

Tip: Go there early by 12:30 they are usually sold out of most of the salads.
author: Eric A.

description:
My wife and i went to Piperade with 2 other couples for lunch to celebrate of the friend's birthday.  The restaurant has a relaxed and elegant ambiance, perfect for a special occasion lunch.

The waiter, a gentleman in his 50's, was attentive and friendly without being intrusive.  He made a few recommendations for dishes and all were excellent, especially the daily special.  We ordered a bunch of appetizers ,a couple of main dishes, including the daily special, and a bottle of Rhone wine and we had a great time!

Incidentally, in our local public library I saw a cookbook by the owner of the restaurant and checked it out to try a few dishes at home.  The instructions are often very easy, a few are more complicated and require 2 days in preparation, but all the dishes are delicious, perhaps not as much as at the restaurant....

Piperade is a restaurant I will definitely go again.  Next time I will try dinner!
author: Lawrence L.

description: One thing I like is fine dining, one thing I don't like is eating in the dark, but these two go together no matter where you fine dine. I really don't remember what I ate, but I do remember that it wasn't bad. So try it, stop reading reviews! ;)
author: Troy V.

description:
I was a little self conscious coming to Piperade because the average customer is quite different from myself. But either way the servers were attentive and very very helpful when making decisions about the menu. 

For appetizers we tried the calamari, peppers, and terrine. The terrine was my favorite of the three because even though it was on the salty side the flavor was delicious and the crispy texture and savory flavor paired well with the bed of julienned green apple. The calamari pieces were very sour and chewy and not really to my liking. The peppers were tasty though, with goat cheese oozing out of the grilled piquillo peppers.

For the main course I chose the strip steak with shallots, thick sliced potatoes, and portobello mushrooms. The steak was DELICIOUS. Perfectly cooked medium and juicy. Definitely my favorite compared to the lamb chops (though also very flavorful) and steamed pacific snapper. A very solid steak dish.

And of course we had to try the beignets for dessert! These were orange blossom flavored so they had a light floral taste that wasn't too overpowering. YUM.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Pretty amazing.

I was told about this place by a FoaF as a place to go for a good business lunch. Gave it a shot... and I am desperately looking to go back. Aside from the atmosphere (how can you beat a great street view looking out onto Battery?), the service was impeccable, as was the wine selection.

Anyone reading me for any length of time knows I love my cheese plates - the selection of Spanish cheeses here was amazing, and getting a side order of serano ham didn't hurt, either. 

Anyway, I was only there for lunch, and I had to pay attention to the vendor I was taking out for lunch, so I didn't get to savor this place as much as I would have liked. (I did have a bitchin' tuna sandwich, tho.) 

So...next time: dinner.
author: Rob D.

description:
Yum, yum, yum! What a lovely little spot with a great menu and staff. 

We went out for a quick bite after a cocktail party (so no one was very hungry) and ordered a number of small things - mussels, grilled calimari, etc - all of which were delicious. 

My favorite part, though, was definitely dessert. The chilled white dessert wine with the almond paste cake.... I think I'm in heaven. It might be the best thing I've ever had. The cornmeal (I think) dessert was also fantastic. 

Even though I didn't order a main course, the dessert, atmosphere, and excellent service definitely merit 5 stars in my book.
author: Stephanie W.

description: I forgot how delicious the basque gateau is. If you like marzipan, you will love this cake. The food really is wonderful here.
author: Leah L.

description:
seriously delicious.  we bought a daily deal that got us a 3 course dinner for 2 for a great price and we really were not let down.  to start, we shared the calamari a la plancha- it was definitely tasty, but i didnt think it was anything special. the calamari was definitely cooked well and seasoned well, but the dish itself wasn't anything to write home about.

for dinner we got the rack of lamb and the new york strip.  both cuts of meat were excellent and cooked perfectly.  the sides on the plate were also delicious- especially the polenta fries with the steak!

we had the dark chocolate cake for dessert and it was delicious.  the cake was warm and still a little gooey in the middle and came with some creme fraiche along the top.  yum, i'm still dreaming about it.

i think the normal menu here is pretty pricey, but for the deal we got it was absolutely phenomenal.  service was excellent, atmosphere was intimate and classy.  excellent experience, hands down.
author: Lisa C.

description:
3.5 stars, nice decor, fairly quiet for a Friday night, good service.
We shared one appetizer which was very good, each ordered a big plate and tasted each other's. They were good, but not mind blowing.
Overall, the food was good, dessert was just ok, probably picked the wrong one.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Okay this is the first time ever that I've been influenced by other reviews into ALMOST changing my review to a Meh-I've Experienced Better. I would have never found this little window in a wall lunch spot if my coworkers had not shown it to me and since I'm new to the office, I wouldn't have known where else to eat except de Stijl or the Safeway deli up the street. 

I agree with everyone that the workers are REALLY REALLY REALLY cheerful and that's okay, but it's not really okay when you spend a long while cheerfully chatting up a customer when the line is 17 deep. I definitely don't want a "No soup for you!" attitude but I need to get back to work and I'm usually starving. I do think it's expensive definitely, and therefore, I can't go more than once every couple weeks I guess.

I do feel that I have to wait a weirdly long time for my food as it seems to come from the nether-worlds when I order it and the several times I've been there I've inadvertently tried to take someone else's food as it's being handed out the window! Awkward!

Sigh. I loved my chicken curry but yeah, my teeny weeny salad was too teeny and on my Mr. Williams sandwich the toasted bread almost broke a $1000 crown on my tooth so that's not gonna work. Can't have no $7 sandwich getting bad ass with my way too expensive mouth! :) 

I don't know. I'm on the fence. If they improved a few things it would be great and yeah, it's really close. I'm going to be walking up to the Safeway deli from now on and I  can whittle my backside down while getting my food at the same time.
author: Melisa B.

description:
Aloha-Flagging also, altho doesn't look like tapas-ville of "sister" Bocadillos/ q.v.

thx again, Randall-of-Millbrae, and Mark Y. -of-Nolulu.

check out those photos - Hunnnn/coveting 
                                 l am having serious Pavlovian Moement,

C
author: Clifford L.

description:
I had high hopes for this place.  I booked reservations 3 weeks in advance and was counting down the days.

I've never had food from the Basque region of France. I left a bit underwhelmed.  Everything sounds great on paper but I was not entirely blown away by the food I received.

The warm sheep's milk and ham terrine was delicious!  My dinner companion and I couldnt stop talking about it.

We both agreed that the cold poached foie gras would probably taste better if it were a warm dish.

The grilled calamari was addictive! I almost didnt want to share it with my friend.  It paired well with our glasses of white that our lovely server recommended.  I'm such a rookie when it comes to wine.  I have to remind myself that its not about getting sloshed (haha).

I love lamb chops and was glad that it was on the menu.  The lamb was cooked perfectly and there was no gaminess which would be indicative of old meat.  

My friend had the NY steak.  She offered me a nice portion of her steak but fessed up after the fact that it was only so I would do the same with my lamb chop!  Ugh!!  Conniving b*tch!   Anyway, the steak was ok and funny enough it was the portabellos that stood out the most in this dish.

I dont have much of a sweet tooth so our server recommended the orange blossom beignets . Light and airy with nice hint of orange.  The smell reminded me of a winter themed Thomas Kincade print I saw at Walgreens when I was a little kid.  The orange was due to the fact that I was eating an orange creamsicle (LoL).  cold and warm.  

Gosh I miss the good ol' days. =(
author: Sun T.

description:
I was not going to write about this place because I found it not so worthy of my time, but I change my mind to let others know not to make the same mistake we did. It is an over priced and  not so memorable place to eat,  when there is so many other great places to eat while in San Francisco.
This was our first experience at Piperade and we were looking forward for a nice relaxing and tasty meal with a good glass of wine. We end up ordering a couple of appetizers and a bottle of Rioja and we so disappointed we decided to cut our losses and ask for the check.  An overly-salty Serrano-Sheep's milk cheese dish and a rather bland goat-cheese stuffed pepper was our starter. Not bad, just not great and not what we expected from such a well reviewed restaurant. 
They have an amazing wine list, but when we asked for some guidance, our server went right to the cheapest wine on the list. Why would they do that? We know Cali wines but just wanted some good advice for Spanish wines. They brag everywhere that they have a "master sommolier," but it turns out he doesn't actually work in the restaurant. In the end we paid over $100, left hungry, and went to our neighborhood restaurant for a much better meal.
My advice to "PIPERADE" if you are so willing to charge the prices that you have in the menu the least you can do is use the best and freshest ingredients and this includes a real olive oil not your Bertoli-esque cooking olive oil mix that you have on the table for the bread ( bread was the best thing on the table) You are in California where you can get the best of the best ingredients. Remember you are so willing to charge us the customers for it. A real disappointment.
author: Luz Q.

description:
This place is somewhere you go out of convenience because you work in the dreaded Telegraph Hill area: a vaccuum for crappy food options that are always (at least!) a 10 minute walk away.

The Piperade To-Go Cafe has a specific name, but I coudn't find it anywhere on Yelp or Google. It's basically a little window in the back of Piperade that faces the alley between Battery and Green - called "Icehouse Alley." Look for all the Williams-Sonoma employees unloading boxes and you're getting closer.

Their sandwiches and salads are a bit pricey for what they are, but they are damn good. The cafe just introduced a new sandwich that I seriously can't get enough of - the Black & Blue: steak, onions, and blue cheese grilled panini-style with a side of salad.

Any of their paninis are good (grilled cheese, roasted pork) and their quesadillas are surprisingly flavorful and filling, but a little messy. 

Unlike other Yelpers, I've never had any issues with rudeness. They recently made an "order line" and "pay line" to curb confusion during the lunch rush, which is helpful.

And for those complaining about running out of food - they are a small cafe. I'm glad they don't over order and throw out good food. Go early if you're worried about them not having what you want.
author: Hannah L.

description:
From the moment we walked in, the staff and the Chef made us feel special.  To be truthful, I've been a fan of this chef since the Fringale day's.
Service was perfect, knowledgeable waiter who guided us perfectly.  Food, outstanding, Tuna seared to perfection and lightly seasoned, salad the same, perfectly dressed.  Friend had daily special of squid, outstanding.  

Chef came out, talked to us and shared the secret code to WIFI, we were early for our lunch but we talked and it made the meal all that much better.  The discussion that is, not the WIFI....ha

Love his food!
author: Skip L.

description: We had a fabulous evening - the hostess was especially considerate, since part of my party arrived very late and with a snafu in the reservations. She found us a table and was very kind. This wasn't my first time, so I knew the food would be delicious - the frisee salad, the spicy carpaccio, the duck confit and the seafood stew were all wonderful. We had the sinful chocolate Rocher for dessert, together with the nougat mousse - new and very very good. It was a great evening and the hostess, bar tenders and waitstaff made it even better.
author: molly c.

description:
i've had the takeout from here while recording nearby, but finally went into the restaurant for a birthday.  MUCH different, not that the food was bad by any means on these takeouts...

the restaurant itself is very well decorated and setup.  i love that it feels nice but still down to earth.  the owners did a nice job.  

the food was really really good.  we had the piquillo peppers with warm goat cheese that set things right, the seafood stew which was very flavorful and the rack of lamb which was cooked perfectly medium rare with no hint of gaminess.  

very great experience and the prices weren't astronomical. a really great dinner that was worth it.
author: shar d.

description:
Worked 2 blocks from this place and had NO idea it was there. A big fan of the sit down restaurant, Piperade, and so happy to know it is an option.

- Had a great sandwich and salad.
- As others have said, if you're in a hurry, you'll have to wait.
- Super friendly staff.
- Kinda pricey for how much food you get.
author: Mark M.

description: This hidden jewel is Highly recommended.  I was quite shocked at the food experience and recommend this restaurant.
author: Mark F.

description: the lamb was amazing.  also a lot of parking in this neighborhood and it was easy to get reservations on a friday night!
author: Chantel B.

description:
Ate for the first time at Piperade and had a good experience.  Let me caveat this as it was a work dinner, so I was not picking up the tab.  I rated it only 3 stars with respect to the value one gets for the price.  It's mostly known as a lunch spot, I'm guessing by its location, but that means it's easy to park and get a table at dinner.  It wasn't empty last night, but it was definitely on the slower side.

We ordered a wonderful bottle of rioja that was recommended by the server.  It went very nicely with the food.  I ordered a pork shank, which is the Monday night special.  It was mostly good, but it lacked a consistent seasoning.  The outside pieces had a good taste, and although it was juicy, the inside was definitely less flavorful.  One of my dining companions ordered the lamb chop/shoulder, which definitely looked good.  We shared several appetizers, which were all decent, but nothing to write home about.

The space is cozy and the service helpful.  Although it was interesting that the server talked us down from higher priced wines, which worked out since the bottle of rioja was the best part of the meal.

Overall, I probably would not go back if I was paying the bill, unless I was entertaining someone who really enjoys Basque food/wine.
author: Scott L.

description:
Food is expensive...but really delicious.

My old boss used to bring us here on special occasions (bdays, xmas dinner, promos, etc...) and it was always a treat.  PLUS she knew the owner so he kept the wine comin!  The NY steak is really tender and juicy...and the fries are nicely seasoned and MMMMMMMMMMM good.  Always great service, too.  Get there early if you want a seat at the bar as it's limited.  (5-5:30...I'd say...)  Also, the lighting is dim for during dinner time sooooo it'll enhance your appearance :)  bonus!

I miss being treated to expensive meals :(  wah...
author: Kat C.

description: Excellent food, but also an awesome space for a group event. Private room space is really nice for a group of 25-30. Was there last night and was really fun.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Maybe we hit an off night but everything was only so-so.  The waitress had to have been new or a substitute. She knew nothing about the food she was serving and actually seemed pretty unhappy about working. Not a smile or a pleasantry the entire meal. 
The food was good but not memorable.
I wanted to only give the restaurant 2 stars, but I forgot my purse and a waitress (not the one that waited on us) chased us down the street with it.  So, he third star is a freely.
author: Amy A.

description: Lamb was delicious.  The skin roast was slight crispy.  The inside was juicy.  The cod was standard.  The orange were no good. The recommended red wine took time to breathe, but ended up quite nice.  It's odd feeling to be seated next to a glass door.
author: Byron L.

description:
Outstanding. Our service was attentive without being annoying, the atmosphere was was pleasant without being pretentious. The food was excellent. My partner had the salmon, and I had the Lamb. Both were beautifully presented and as tasty as the best of anything we have ever had. The Lamb in particular was cooked *exactly* the way I prefer it, and the salmon was seared to perfection with a slightly crunchy exterior and a tender and moist interior that offered a surprisingly scrumptious texture sensation. Even the dessert was (dark chocolate) memorable. It also has, in my inexpert opinion, an excellent wine list. We decided on the Elizabeth Spencer Cabernet Sauvignot 2009.

Others have complained about the service. Ours was first rate. We never once waited very long for anything. This experience is as close the best dining experience I've had in the bay area. I will most certainly be back. I thought the prices were reasonable considering the service and the quality of the food.
author: Robert P.

description: I've been this place multiple times, mostly is because it's close by my office and it's just easy. I tried almost everything on the menu and everything just "meh" for me. Everything is pretty tasteless. The seafood blow, salmon, or halibut... all of them just "meh"... and the portion is small, not worth the price at all. The setting look nice and it is a good place for business lunch but the quality wasn't that great at all... sigh.....
author: Erica J.

description: Never before have I had a salmon as mouth watering as the salmon here. Seriously order it, your mouth will thank you.
author: Deborah B.

description: The people including our server were great. I love the spacious and comfortable atmosphere. The bread and olive oil are unusually good. The menu is good but the kitchen does not pay attention to specific requests. We requested no salt on the fries. They had salt (but were replaced when asked). I requested no salt on my Atlantic cod. It was salty and I could not eat it. They gave me a free Armagnac after dinner to compensate and it was wonderful. My husband and I loved the prawns basquaises and his roasted rack of lamb with Merguez sausage was perfect. (I had one of his chops and so did not go home hungry). The orange blossom beignets were light and a great end to the meal. I liked this restaurant so much that I am willing to give them another chance and return for another dinner in spite of the salt problem.
author: Lorinda S.

description:
I had dinner at Piperade where I had been meaning to pay a visit for some time.  The restaurant is quite isolated, but the décor and ambiance is nice.  We sat next to the large window looking out onto the street.  There is a nice little patio which would be quite lovely to enjoy your meal when the weather is nice, though the opportunity to dine outside comfortably without bundles of layers only occurs in San Francisco two months of the year!  I ordered the following items:

Appetizer:
- Poached foie gras with sea salt, black pepper and apple compote: served with toasted bread, this dish was great.  The ingredients came separately which allowed you to season each bite of foie gras to your own liking.  I think I especially enjoy the sweet salty combination and with a little bit of the kick from the black pepper, the combination was quite good.
- Garlic soup: I just had a spoonful of the soup and I didn't think it was that great!  I know it made it on the 7x7 list, which quite frankly, I don't understand.  But then again, I'm not huge on soup so maybe it's just me?  BUT my friend, who is a huge foodie also agreed with me.  Hmmm.

Main course:
- Roasted halibut: I thought this dish was also very delicious!  I'm a huge fish person and though I don't remember clearly what exactly I enjoyed about the dish, I remember feeling thoroughly satisfied.

Dessert:
- Almond and pear tartlet: very good!

We also ordered a nice bottle of wine.  Unfortunately I can't remember the details of our meal, but I definitely remember that I was impressed and thought to myself as I was walking out of the restaurant, that I would have to come back again.
author: Jessica T.

description: Delicious food, very intimate and romantic atmosphere. Came here for Valentine's day dinner last year and we had a wonderful night. Definitely would recommend, but make sure to make reservations ahead of time
author: Karina A.

description:
Love this place!  Never knew that they are also the same owners of Bocadillos.  I have eaten at Bocadillos before and loved the cuisine, but Bocadillos is more of a Spanish tapas and wine bar.  

I had a short day trip out to San Francisco and decided to eat at a nice restaurant and came across Piperade!  It's a very nice upscale restaurant and the chef was very friendly.  I had the lunch special prefix and it was fantastic!  Service was awesome and loved the atmosphere.  

I will definitely come back.
author: Nathalie B.

description:
My friends took me here for my birthday celebration (yay!) and I was pretty impressed. First, parking was NOT an issue at all (a major plus when dining in the city), and since we made reservations, we only had to wait about 5 minutes for them to get our table ready. 

Laura F. made the food selections - we ordered a bunch of small plates and entrees to share. My particular favorites were the mushroom tart for the small plates, and the duck for the entree. They also had selection of desserts which we shared and they were all yummy. 

This place changes their menu every so often, so I'm definitely game for coming back again!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Love this little gem of a take out restaurant! the food is consistently good, (Chicken Mandarin salad is absolutely scrumptious!) 

On the downside, lines are always long, and the service is a bit slow, so if you're in a rush to get from a meeting to meeting during your lunch hour, find another place. (plus, if you don't go, that makes the line shorter for me! hehehe ;) )
author: Yasmine F.

description: the chef/owner is brusque and unfriendly and has been each time i have dined here.  i won't be returning.
author: Cindy M.

description:
The most memorable moment here was watching the executive chef greet customers with light chit chat.  He even helped out by bring our check to the table.  At a high end restaurant like this, we did not expect such humble actions which are very special.
We think the Seafood stew is the best, most flavorful dish we've had so far. I had the lamb which had a perfect crust and was cooked to a nice medium. I believe my boyfriend had the Halibut which was good but not special. The applet tart was delicious last time with the caramel sauce. we tried the beignet which we weren't so fond of though really enjoyed the dry cappucino we had with it. Must say, the beignets I think about over and over are at Epic Roasthouse.
Must say that the foie grois is gamey so I'd also pass on that next time.
Overall, really lovely and we would return for the Seafood stew with lots of the yummy warm bread!
author: Quan T.

description:
I had one of the best meals I've had all year at Piperade, in mid-December 2007. 

The food was absolutely delicious, and quite memorable. It was the holiday season, and even on a Thursday night, the dining room was jam-packed with people. 

My companion and I started the meal off with the garlic soup with rock shrimp, bacon and egg. It had a savory piquency that was quite memorable. A refreshing, zesty beginning to a great meal.

Next came my pick for my favorite dish of the evening, if not the entire year: Salt-cured cod (bacalao) with lemon creme fraiche, oysters and caviar. Words cannot describe the sensory pleasure this dish brought: The thin cod fillets were fork-soft, flavorful and ice-cold, as were the tender, plump little oysters on top (my favorite part of the dish). I still remember biting through one of those little oysters atop a piece of rustic bread, topped with some of the creme fraiche - absolute heaven.

A close second was the cold poached foie gras with membrillo paste. Personally, I much prefer hot foie gras to cold. Foie is so meltingly tender and succulent when served hot, but when cold, all the fats seize up and what was once tender becomes firm. (Sort of like what happens when you cook a chicken, then refrigerate it, allowing all the fat to become solid as a rubber ball). Still, of course the foie tasted lovely smeared on the crusty bread, particularly paired with the very sweet, complex-tasting membrillo paste. 

The entree was less unusual, but still delicious: I think it was a rare duck tenderloin, well seasoned and perfectly cooked. 

If we had dessert, I can't remember it now; nevertheless, the meal was really one to remember.
author: Suzie Q.

description:
I love Piperade.  The garlic soup with rock shrimp rocks!!  The tapas menu is outstanding and my favorite is the terrine but I will also gobble up the cheese platter in a heartbeat.  For a main course I usually order the steak and I'm never disappointed.  Always cooked to perfection and I love the fries. 
The reason this gets four stars is the service has occasionally been less than stellar.  Not the last time I was there so maybe Gerald has tightened up on that.
author: Karen C.

description:
Excellent duck breast, as well as the bread with cold butter.  The dark chocolate cake with creme fraiche was good.

The restaurant ambiance was cute.  Service was fairly attentive and fast.
author: Niniane W.

description:
My friend Tina celebrated her birthday here and I was part of the task force to find a restaurant that could handle a table for 12. Finding a restaurant that's open on a Monday and that can hold such a large group without charging a fixed price is almost impossible. I finally found the perfect restaurant, Piperade. Piperade gets MAJOR props for being so incredibly nice and accommodating. When I first made reservations, it was only going to be a group of 10. When I had to change the reservation to 12 people last minute, they were incredibly flexible. I even asked for a "nicer" table since we were celebrating Tina's birthday and they made sure to give us a gorgeous, round table at the center of the restaurant. Piperade is a smaller, intimate restaurant that serves Basque food, influenced by Spanish and French regions.

So I need to preface this review and mention that I was not feeling well at all during this meal. I was fighting a cold and was super congested. It affected my sense of taste. As a result, I think my food was less flavorful. Nonetheless, there were a couple of standout dishes at Piperade. I loved the calamari "a la plancha" and the piperade. The calamari was cooked very well (didn't have a tough, rubbery consistency) and I was loving the slightly tangy sauce on top. I had never had piperade before so I can't vouch for it's authenticity, but I can vouch for its tastiness! Piperade is a vegetarian stew with onions, green peppers and tomatoes and the restaurant topped it with bacon and a poached egg. It reminded me of ratatouille with a spicier kick. Out of all the desserts we tried, my favorite was the apple tart. The crust was flaky and buttery like a puff pastry and the apples and cream/custard were delightful. The caramel on top was the icing on the cake. I didn't want to share.

My dungeness crab txangurro had a healthy amount of crab in it, but it tasted a little bland. My cod was cooked well, but I kind of wish there was more sauce or a broth to bring the dish all together. The dish almost seemed too simple. The orange blossom beignets failed to impress me too. I'm not a big fan of floral-flavored things (I hate rose water and lavender) so the orange blossom was not my cup of tea. I also wished that the beignets were a little lighter and had a creamy sauce like a creme anglaise to dip it in. Oh man, Grand Marnier creme anglaise would have been a life-changing addition.

Overall, the ambiance was warm and inviting with wooden tables and really comfortable chairs. Seriously, those chairs were a lifesaver because I was feeling so uncomfortable otherwise. I would totally recommend Piperade if you're looking for a restaurant that can handle larger groups. And, parking is easy too! Glad we got to celebrate Tina's birthday in style!

Read more reviews and see lots of photos on my blog: http://rbjello.wordpress.com/2012/02/15/a-basque-feast-at-piperade/
author: Jackie T.

description:
Took a group of 8  colleagues here for lunch today, and was severely disappointed overall.  

There were some pluses- the small plate dishes (calamari especially) and some of the entrees were pretty good- one of my colleagues had the seafood stew-like dish and really liked it.

However, the negatives more than overwhelmed the positives:

Service was atrocious:  Waitress was snarky in response to a simple question about which dish she would recommend.  She also whined about us ordering drinks from the bar ("I have to make them myself").  No drinks including water were ever refilled.

Food was very slow:  A one hour lunch took almost two!!  Small plates took 20 mins, entrees another 30 mins.  Drinks did not come out until after the small plates were done.

Some dishes were shockingly bad:  I ordered a burger medium and was served up a completely charred (black and burned) patty which was so overcooked that the dry meat was literally crumbly.  No self respecting kitchen would have actually served this abomination, especially after a 30 minute wait!!  Instead of not charging for the burger, this terrible restaurant didn't charge for one of the drinks!!  Obviously their disgraceful preparation did not concern these people too much.

Stay away!!
author: S H.

description:
Amazing service, great upscale charming atmosphere, very good food!

Crab Salad- a large tower of lightly dressed fresh dungeness crab salad- diced apples, cucumbers and red peppers. Light and refreshing, full of flavor, so glad they didn't drown the delicate crab in dressing.

Mussel Salad: Simple mussels (de-shelled) with frisee and a light vinaigrette, some mini croutons. Good but not mind-blowing. 

Rock Cod with Spinach: A fillet of rock cod with a little red vinegar sauce on a bed of sauteed spinach, vinegar...a lil too acidic, too much vinegar. Rock cod was cooked well though.

Sea Bass, Vanilla Brown Butter Foam?, Brussel Sprouts, Pancetta: Sea bass was cooked perfectly, brussel sprouts were full of flavor and pancetta added nice bite. Maybe a little too much vanilla in the foam/sauce but overall pretty good dish.

Duck Breast, Potatoes: Nice sweet and savory sauce, duck was tender, potatoes simple but flavorful. Very good overall, would have preferred slightly more rare duck but that's just my preference.

Lamb Chop: Perfectly cooked, juicy. 

Their desserts were REALLY GOOD, definitely not an afterthought!

Flan: delicious!! Best flan I've ever had...I'm not a huge flan fan and this one blew me away, it was creamy and had a wonderful caramelized sauce.

Almond Cake- dense, full of almond flavor and a little liquor maybe? Super yummy.

Chocolate Cake- rich, dense, fudgy, with a yummy cream on top that tasted more complex than a plain whipped cream..perhaps some marscarpone or creme fraiche.

Orange Blossom Beignets: Though they are known for these, I thought they tasted too perfumey, like when you spray your floral perfume and then accidentally get some of the mist in your mouth :( The texture was good, just too floral.

Cheese Course- yummy fig cake, cheeses were all very good especially the manchego.

There service is awesome, very attentive, quick and friendly, and not uptight. 

The ambiance is wonderful: charming and elegant...something about this place just feels happy and comfortable, and even though it's an upscale dining establishment it doesn't feel stuffy at all. The lighting is bright and cheery and there's a celebratory ambiance. Great for a special occasion.
author: amy k.

description:
We ate at Piperade for my birthday dinner and it was a cute find amidst blocks of warehouses. The service was very attentive and accomadating - they rearranged our entire table so that we could have more room with 9 people instead of 10! 

The food was tasty but a bit overpriced. Among the 10 people of my party, we tried most the main dishes of the menu. For appetizers, the garlic soup and the mushroom pizza tart were the best and most flavorful. The garlic soup wasn't overly garlicy and the mushrooms on the tart were amazing. As for entrees, I had the salmon w/ summer corn. It was pretty straightforward - however the nectarines atop the salmon were a nice surprise. For dessert, the french apple tart w/ caramel was delicious. Small & simple, but a nice close to the meal. Also, the citrus beignets were refreshing and melted in your mouth. They even gave us an extra bowl!

Overall this place was a nice find for a dinner restaurant. The food was simple yet full of flavor. The ambiance was homey and comfortable, not too loud and not too quite. I'd like to try this place for lunch next time.
author: Brittany J.

description:
The perfect salad is: Fresh.  Gourmet.  Healthy.

I have now sampled every salad on Piperade take out menu.  Including daily specials.

Fresh? Check.
Gourmet? Check.
Healthy? Minus 2 checks.

Chicken Avocado Salad is a delicious piece of what looks to be panko fried breadcrumb chicken topped by fresh leaves and avocado with a heavily oily balsamic type dressing (albeit served on side).

Friday's Quinoa special contains about 4  times the serving size quinoa should be and vinaigrette seriously lacks in the vinegar department.

Most are typically heavily topped with some form of fried bread and are pre boxed so you can't pre-order a cheese-less or fried  topping-less alternative.

All in all, the food here is delicious (great selection of yogurt, cottage cheese, fresh fruit...), just don't come here looking for a healthy salad.

The 2 running this window do a fantastic job in keeping the line moving and efforts of friendly banter flowing.
author: Gabrielle J.

description: Our waiter fully  described a seafood stew special which I ordered and the squab arrived at my place. The special had been changed and he was uninformed. So then we had to wait for the regular stew to be prepared. In the meantime our waiter left to take care of another party. Fortunately we got our food in time to eat  to get to the Eureka Theater. Neither of the red wines by the glass were very good. Open too long, perhaps. I will go back since I think/hope it was just a fluke.
author: Lucille S.

description:
The steak: a healthy cut cooked-to-order rare perfectly. Topped with a some shallots and a pepper which i felt enhanced the flavor and gave you something other to taste than steak, although you really didn't need to as the steak was awesome. My girlfriend felt the peppers were unnecessary though.

The calamari: it's 8 or 9 bucks, and you get about 8 pieces of calamari. At first i thought "Jip!" and then i tried some. I wouldn't be surprised if they cooked just those 8 pieces by themselves with full attention. Not only were they the most unique tasting calamari I had ever had, but it was obvious they had had plenty of attention and effort put into them. Mmmm, tentacles.

I tried some of the Garlic Soup, which my girlfriend and I are still trying to think about how they pulled it off; The lamb chops, really nice and tender and with a smooth sauce that tops the whole thing off; and something who's name escapes me that seemed like a Basque version of cioppino that I really kind of wished that i had ordered.

It's all about taste here, not portions, but at the same time the portions are actually not bad at all. You'll walk away full but not bloated. One of my favorite places.
author: Spencer T.

description:
I had the pleasure of dining at Piperade with a friend recently.

In all, it was just the perfect evening out. The ambiance of the place is chic yet warm, and the aroma that fills the dining room was simply intoxicating.
After a glass of txakolina at the bar while waiting for the table to be set, we were seated for a memorable feast.

First was the cold poached foie gras with blue berry compote. It was beautiful in its simplicity: the crisp toast, the lushness of the foie, and the sweet acidity of the compote blended very well.

Then came the soup. It was unpretentiously called chicken, bacon and white beans soup, which is exactly what it was. But the execution!!!! It's not often that I'd just slurp the broth alone: never mind the bits of smoky bacon and perfectly cooked beans, I was in heaven just with the broth. 

This is one area where so many restaurants fall short: the quality of the stock. Stock is the foundation , and without a proper foundation, no matter how you engineer the edifice, it will fall down. Here, it's bolted directly to the bedrock.

The main course was duck confit, with lentils. This rustic food with its humble origins deserves loving preparation, and the chef delivers. From the crisp, crusty skin to the melt-in-your-mouth-but-not-falling-apart meat, I was in heaven. It was accompanied by lentils, with more bits of bacon or jamon, pearl onions, and probably a good amount of piment d'espelette that lent distinctive, fruity character. It formed an effective counterpoint .  In short, enjoying the whole dish was like listening to a J.S.Bach fugue.

Being a fan of aged Spanish wine, I brought my own bottle: good 25 years older than most on the wine list. However, the wine list here is quite extensive, and wines are very carefully chosen to accompany the food without overwhelming the palate. There are some top-shelf stuff like Krug champagne and various vintages of Opus 1, but I found them to be priced very reasonably. I would not hesitate to order any of the wine from their list.

I came away thrilled by the experience. I can't wait to return, and bring more friends to this jewel.
author: Anonymous M.

description: Their menu is great and I suggest sharing some appetizers.  Had the duck and it was delicious.
author: Eivind S.

description:
I used to go here for special occasions when I worked nearby. Haven't been around for a few years. So, decided to treat a friend to a birthday lunch here yesterday.  Never been disappointed before and they were just as good yesterday.  

I love that it is not in the bustling market or Soma area, making metered parking easy to find.  The calamari appetizer had an intensely flavored dressing.  Beef crudo was yummy with the diced sweet apple and jalapeno kick.  (I think it was missing just a sprinkle of sea salt to enhance the taste and we could've used just a bit more jalapeno. I'm sure they would've provided those if I asked for it, but I didn't want to interrupt the nice conversation I was enjoying with my friend.)  We said we were sharing the halibut and they served it already split onto two plates.  The halibut was the most perfectly cooked fish I have ever had!  It came piping hot, after we took our time sharing the two appetizers.  I don't know how they timed it so perfectly.  It was moist and tender, from the first bite to the last.  If I didn't know that halibut is a deep sea fish and must have traveled some time to get here, I would've thought it to be freshly caught 10 minutes ago.

When I made the reservation online, I asked for a nice table for my friend's birthday and we got a window table.  Our server was great and explained everything I asked about.  We ordered the milk chocolate hazelnut cake for dessert.  It came with a candle on top.  That was a nice touch.

This is my secret special occasion place.  Most people who don't work/live in that part of town doesn't know about this place.  I don't really want to tell others about it.  I wrote this review to thank the restaurant and our waiter for a great lunch.  Every dish is made with quality ingredients, treated with unique and sophisticated flavors that doesn't follow the pack doing the latest trendy thing.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Service is HORRIBLE! 
We had a Voucher and were treated like some kind of "low-lives"/tourists with no money! I was outraged at the wait staff question "you have a voucher?" BEFORE we were even asked if we would like water or anything else to drink.
The whole dinner experience was bad and it took FOREVER!
The duck dish was bad, overcooked, dry and hard. 
Lamb and steak were cooked per our instructions and were good.
The deserts: orange blossoms - too sugary, tasted like donut holes from a cheap donut shop; chocolate/hazelnut cake was very sweet as well, so was the yogurt cake. 
Parking across the street was available so, at least, we could leave fast.
author: Karen K.

description:
Had high expectations for this place and while it was good, it was not what we expected. This is classic basque cooking, not to be confused with Tapa's. 

As a result, a lot of the dishes, while unique and fun, didn't match expectations. Also, the plethora of ham and egg items wasn't what we were in the mode for. However, the cream of mushroom herb soup and the garlic soup with ham croutons was excellent! Also highly recommend the mussel salad if you are a mussels fan. 

Service I must say was great, as was the atmosphere. Overall, this is a place to check off your list but perhaps not a repeat destination.
author: Andy B.

description: Service could be better. Staff is not approachable at all.  Food is decent. The hostess gave us the impression that reservations are a must. The waiter didn't even greet us- the first thing he said is " what would you like?"; however, on the other hand if your appearance is older- then you get better treatment. This was observed.  I won't be returning here.
author: Karinna O.

description:
3 for food, 4 for service. I went here because I got a new job (yay!) I got a table right away and started conversing with the chaps on the next table. As my expected companion had texted 5 minutes after I sat down to look at the menu that she wouldn't make it (not the restaurant's fault, but just trying to make her feel bad and change her ways). I ordered the goat cheese appetiser, which was decidedly small for restaurants in this country. For my entree, I ordered the sea bass, for dessert the chocolate cake, and a glass of Tempranillo. The latter, I thoroughly enjoyed.

Per the service, the waiter, Daniel, came by asking me if I was done twice unnecessarily and failed to come by when I'd cleaned my plate. Odd that, I would think that an empty plate would  serve as a signal to the waiter to come by and offer, well, something -- the cheque perheps? 

Speaking of the cheque, it was almost $70 with tip. Bit steep for SF, but in line to what I've paid at home in London, for smaller servings. 

Like Joyce H. says, there is a patio outside, which I wasn't offered as a place to sit. On the other hand, it was almost 10pm by the time I arrived.
author: Hasan D.

description:
I go here for lunch far more often than I should - but I'm lazy and it's in the alley across from my office. Their sandwiches totally deliver. My favorite is the turkey, Brie, and cranberry - not usually a fan of turkey breast, but the combo is irresistible. All sandwiches come with a small green salad, which definitely makes the $7-$8 range worth it for me.

Their signature Mr. Williams' fried chicken sandwich is a treat, but it's kind of greasy so I don't have it too often. Same goes for when it's in salad form. I forget where they get their cookies from, but they're giant, delicious, and make me feel like a total fatty. Quite the treat.

The guy at the register seems like a genuinely nice dude. Has started asking me how my day's going. They've recently set up their ordering, paying, and waiting process so it's easier to follow, so even long lines go by rather quickly.
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
Starters
Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese - 5 stars!
Mushroom open face pie - 4 stars - excellent!
Calamari - good but outshined by other starters.
Main Dish
Lamb basquaise chops - tender and deliscious! Medium rare with some veggies - 5 stars!
Dessert
Orange blossom beignets - puffy with a hint of citrus, very good
Chocolate cake amaxti - surprisingly good. Not just a chocolate cake, had a nice wafer crunch hiding it -- mmm!

Piparo has a great wine list - tried at least 3 reds. Chef was in house and came over to our table of 7 and was happy to chat it up with us and give us his fave picks of food and wine. Friendly staff, nice setting, great food! Will go again.
author: Mel H.

description: Generally good food, cool waiter, stereotypical presumptuous hostess (almost expected her to call someone "Dahling").   The foie gras was a let down, but the seafood stew was excellent.  I would like to try more of the menu, especially if I could go on a night when there was a different host.  Wine was really good, but pricey.  There were a variety of people eating there, and none of them seemed to be tourists.  Decor was cool and relaxing, and it was dim but there was enough light to read the menu and see what was on your plate.
author: Don W.

description:
I had relatively low expectations of a basque restaurant and was truly and wonderfully surprised by the quality of the food and the wine selection. The desserts left nothing to be desired. The chef was amicable and fun, the staff a little slow but nice. The ambiance was warm and cozy and not too loud where we sat. In fact, we had a delightful banter as we shared everything on each plate. Stand outs were tne lamb plate and the well balanced fava bean salad.
Nice surprise!
author: Stefano B.

description:
hm. I wonder when I'll ever look old enough to be respected in fancy restaurants like this. Eating at a restaurant like this that reminds me of how much one's appearance determines the level and quality of service one receives. 

In any case, my friend and I came here for our monthly blackboard eats dinner saturday night. There is really nothing to complain about the food in my opinion. We shared one entree, the saturday night entree of a veal stew, which was kindly split by the kitchen for us. We had the mussels, the cheese and ham terrine and the dungness crab salad for small plates. All were delicious though my friend found bits of shell in the dungness crab and I thought the mussels were occasionally gritty. 

I had a glass of urxi, which was a slightly fizzy white wine from the basque region. 

As to the service, it wasn't horrible, not at all. It was just disconcerting to be treated dismissively by the waiter. When I as pondering the wines I asked a question and which he answered, then he turned away before I could ask anything else and walked away which was just strange. However, our water glasses were always full, dirty plates were cleared fairly quickly and they asked us if we wanted more bread so I suppose this speaks well of the busboys. 

In any case, this is not a place to go for the casual meal unless you're old enough to have an expense account.  I definitely couldn't have afforded it without the coupon. We actually tried to make a lunch reservation, which isn't served on the weekends, but our schedules weren't working out. 

In sum, good food, decent portions (nothing too generous), street parking, excellent service if you look old - fine otherwise. I think that's all one would want to know. I'm not really knowledgeable enough to comment on the wine.
author: Andrea L.

description: Six words for Piperade To-Go: Good foods and friendly vibes, to-go.
author: Stephen Y.

description: We had been wanting to try this restaurant for awhile, based on some favorable reviews from friends and my parents. It is wise to make a reservation; the restaurant was packed on the week-night that we chose to go. My husband, our infant daughter and my parents were seated immediately at the only available table as soon as we arrived at the time of our reservation. The service was excellent and they helped allocate space for my daughter's stroller. The food was truly the star of the evening! We were collectively blown away by the repast. We shared a bottle of wine from the basque country as well as appetizers: calamari and cheese selection. I ordered a soup that was so good, we bought the restaurant's cookbook that evening (I just happened to notice it by the hostess in the front of the restaurant) so that I could mimic it back in Montreal (which I did just two nights after arriving home). The garlic soup with rock shrimp was perhaps the best part of my meal - if you go and you love the 'stinking rose' as much as I do, then it is a must! My husband and mother both ordered the duck entrée and my father and I both ordered the signature dish, the piperadé. Everything just sang in our mouths and tummies. Maybe because the chef accidentally made an extra by mistake, maybe because our server truly was wonderful, regardless, without provocation, a dessert magically appeared before us on the house. It was the traditional Basque donuts and they were just perfect with our after dinner espressos.  This was the most memorable dinner during our trip to San Francisco.
author: Laura R.

description:
What a friendly restaurant with easy parking all around. The manager greeted us with a smile the moment we entered, the lovely waitress welcomed us and the owner chef mingled and received our compliments humbly. Our table ordered a variety of thursday night's menu : the Cornish hen, the duck and the fish & seafood  stew. 
Whilst waiting for the mains we were served with some delicious bread and olive oil.
I dug into the crab salad which was heavenly. I had the stew and had to ask for more bread to scoop up every drop of the truly magnificently prepared dish that is one of the best I've tasted : delicately flavoured with saffron, the perfect amount of seasoning with succulent pieces of fish, scallop and  topped with a giant prawn.  
Brilliant food & service. Love the centre piece  hanging made of empty wine bottles. The red and black colours of the painting really adds to the warm ambience. A real gem of a place that offers excellent food, wine, service, and an exciting buzz which at the same time allows you to hold a conversation. Memorable. Thank you:)
author: Natalie B.

description: My girlfriend's father is a basque immigrant and she has lived in Basque Country for several months at a time. We knew from reading the menu that this place had a much more modern feel than the traditional family-style Basque restaurants in the Central Valley or Inland Empire areas of Southern California. We enjoyed every aspect of Piperade, from the food to service and ambiance.  My Basque red wine went well with the meal. We started with piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese and accented with raisins golden raisins and nuts. The sweetness of the peppers paired extremely well with thin slices of Serrano ham. My entree of roasted rack of lamb was exquisite, with a date sauce that reminded me of North African influences. The apple tart with caramel sauce was a nice finish to an exquisite meal.
author: Matthew D.

description:
My girlfriends and I headed here for a night out with out the guys. We decided on ordering a few of the Tipiaks and ordered bowls of soup and desert and some cocktails.

Tipiaks (small plates) ordered:
Calamari a la plancha with fennel olive, caper and coriander: whole small calamari grilled, the dish was very pretty but lacked some seasoning. The calamari was cooked perfectly.

Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts and golden raisins: very good, balanced flavors, beautiful dish

Fois gras with black pepper, salt and pineapple compote: creamy and went well with the pineapple compote

Open face mushroom pie: crowd favorite of the night. It was scrumptious on a lovely puff pastry with herbs and chantrelles. All three of us loved this dish.

Also ordered:
Mushroom and leek soup: it was nothing to really write about, again lacked some depth and seasoning.

Garlic soup with rock shrimp, egg, bacon and bread: this was very interesting and very good. Broth like soup that was not overpowering in flavor. There was no skimping on the shirmp or egg or bacon for that matter in this dish. Absolutely recommended.

Dessert: Touron mouse cake with roasted almonds: the mousse was light and fluffy and the almonds were candided wtih nice crunch and sweetness. This dish actually reminded us of a bowl of Frosted flakes from a taste aspect. Different. Good.

Drinks:
Cava sparkling wine: yummy

Cockails from their cocktail list:
Jasmine infused vodka martini: Very good, like a lemon drop with out the sour and not overly sweet

Margarita:Not impressed, my friend actually didnt finish it and switched over to the Martini

Staff: friendly and attentive.Also had a cab waiting for us by the time our check arrived.

Overall, its a nice quiet atmosphere, romantic setting if  you are looking for a date night. It was good but the food wasn't memorable.
author: Sandra M.

description:
The food was excellent, but the service was shockingly poor for a restaurant of this quality.  We did have a late reservation, which may play a role, but we felt that the gentleman server was very short with us, as if he wanted to rush out out of there (the hostess was also very short with us).  Nobody was mean in any way, but we felt that a restaurant at this level would treat its customers with much more care and friendliness.   Additionally we learned later that a friend attempted to get us something special for dessert (phoned in a request earlier), but the server forgot to give it to us.

We don't think we will be back because of the low level of relationship building by the server and hostess.  We have higher expectations.  That said, the food was excellent as the interior is gorgeous.
author: Jon S.

description:
Met with a few friends on a Thursday night - the place was bustling around 7:30pm.  Service is great - prompt and completely unobtrusive; the tables were always clean with new silverware/dishes and the wine glasses were always filled and no chit-chat (love that).

I read the mixed reviews on the garlic soup and we decided to try it out.  It was really meh...  what's the big deal.  It tastes like salted cod soup with egg white.  Why is it garlic soup?  I would have to say "pass" on this soup.

The mushroom tarte was exceptional.  Really delicious.  

The non-descript foie gras appetizer wasn't even finished by our party of 6 (and most of us are foie gras eaters). 

The cheese place - not interesting at all.

The steak entree was meh... okay

The halibut on a bed of spinach is really good.  So good we ordered two.

The desserts I would say in general are a skip.  The flan was meh (have had much better), the chocolate cake thing was okay, and the apple tart was very very SKIP.

All in all the food was 3-star and service was 5-star.
author: Madison W.

description: I was sick and their soup was just what I needed.  The food was just as solid as I remembered it, including the mushroom tart, salad, fries, and that garlic soup.
author: jane d.

description:
Piperade is good!

i suggest you people to go. its in a quieter neighborhood but still business seems good. Darkly lit dinning room, and the crazy chandeliers catch your eye when you walk in. 

i had a small plate calamari which i liked a lot. had a great citrusy flavor without being overwhelming or bitter. My large plate was the chicken which was extremely flavorful, but the down point was that it was a bit overcooked and dry. My friend did get the piperade which was really good too. i'd recommend it. Lastly i had the lemon curd for dessert. It was good, but they should work on the name. right? curd just doesnt seem appetizing. But i digress. i say its a place to AT LEAST try once. 

GO GO GO! what are you waiting for?
author: Patrick A.

description: Piperade is right by my office, but this was my first time eating there. I placed an order for pick up and it was ready as soon as I got there. The place was packed with lunchtime visitors from the nearby offices. I ordered the Tuesday special which is calamari in ink sauce. It was delicious. I ordered it without the rice and just got extra salad. I chose to do the prix fix instead of a la carte: for only an additional $3 I got a salad and dessert. I will definitely be visiting this place again for a nice dinner. It reminds me of when I was studying abroad in Spain.
author: Alycia N.

description:
Wow, this is truly a gem in the after hours wasteland that is the Ad hub of FiDi.

Took a client from Wisconsin here a couple weeks ago, looking to entertain with a trendy sort of small plates meal that you can only find in SF.  Given that our table tried just about every item on the menu, I'm pretty enthused about finally being able to properly review this place.  


On the top tier: 

- Dungeness crab salad: Cold, crisp, juicy like only a crab can be. Perfection.

- Calamari "a la plancha": I'm not even a calamari fan and I liked this dish.  Not breaded and deep fried like the abominations they have everywhere else.  You can really taste the quality of the squid here.

- Marinated mussel salad: Excellent taste to this dish. Especially for seafood lovers.

- Wild mushroom tart: Delicious mix of umami here - all on top of the most buttery, rich crust you'll ever taste.

- Almond and pear tartlet with creme fraiche: The perfect amount of sweetness, with a slightly tart whipped topping.  After a spectacular meal, I just couldn't believe the desserts matched up.


Just a skoach from the top:

- Fresh goat's milk cheese and ham terrine: Delicious, rich dish.

- Butter lettuce salad: A little plain compared to the other stunners on the menu, but a nice start with the perfect, crisp acidity.

- Cold poached foie gras with pepper, sea salt and pineapple and vanilla compote: Really nice foie - I just couldn't get down with the vanilla scented fruit.

- Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese: I liked it, but it wasn't anything outstanding.

- Artisanal cheese plate: You all know how much I love cheese, but it's pretty much the same anywhere you go.

- Duck confit: Not a big fan of duck (except the extra crispy, extra fatty kind) so I'm of no help here.

Gateau basque: What a way to end a meal.

- Chocolate cake "amatxi" with creme fraiche:  So dark and decadent.  And there's that creme fraiche again...

There were seriously no dishes that I didn't enjoy here.  I'm truly impressed with Piperade.  It's the perfect spot to take your foodie friends that like to share.  I'll definitely be back to finish off the big plates!
author: Virginia L.

description:
Came here for the first time this past Friday with a group of friends. We really went big - champagne, wine, port, etc. We shared a bunch of the tapas/small plates - all delicious. Crab, mussel salad (yum!) and foie gras...all very, very, very good. 
I was between the steak and the lamb chops...so I asked our server what she recommended and she said the lamb was their most popular main dish..so I trusted her (mind you, I REALLY wanted steak). The lamb did NOT disappoint! Hello delicious! The sauce was absolutely tasty, the onion and small potato's, perfect. If I could have, I would have liked the plate - eh...but likely, not the most classy thing to do at a restaurant of this caliber! 

I do not remember what others ordered because I was so concentrated on my delicious lamb chops -however, everyone loved their meal! The dessert was good, so long as you get the beignets. We also shared some chocolate dessert that was not as good, oddly enough. The beignets were delicious. An absolute must order!
