I really enjoyed our dinner, we had a great server, nice ambiance and I'd love to go back again!
author: Isabel M. L.

description:
Used the Travelzoo deal.  SO worth it!  This is one restaurant where EVERY course was very, very tasty and memorable.
LOVED the:
-crab/grapefruit salad
-ham & cheese turine
-duck
-halibut
-apple tart
-Chocolate/hazelnut 

Will return.  
Bonus:  Abundance of parking.  It was also a quick walk to the America's cup Pavillion for a concert!
author: Julie S.

description:
Overall, a solid dining experience in all areas (food, service, atmosphere), but there were certain aspects that were just too lackluster to give it a complimentary four stars.

First, we waited 30 minutes for our table even though we had a reservation.  What's the point of making a reservation in the first place?  By the time we were seated and we got our drink orders in, it was past 10 PM.

I know Basque food pretty well and this wasn't anything remotely close to Basque food.  Using some Spanish spice on a standard fish dish does not qualify it as a Basque dish.  That being said, the food was still good and well-prepared, but it wasn't what we came here for.

The atmosphere of this place is pretty sterile as well and not very warm.  You would think that it would be outfitted with Basque decor, instead it just has a very contemporary, minimalist, and bland look to it.  It felt like it was lacking an identity.
author: Mike B.

description: I will come back here for a proper meal as my first visit was a bit marred by a late start and a not-so-hungry companion. The general atmosphere of this restaurant seems to be fancy, not rowdy, the waiters play a great role in maintaining a sense of high quality about the restaurant. I just don't have enough information right now to give any more detailed a review.
author: Shang S.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday evening around 8PM.  There was plenty of street parking so that was really nice.  When we got to the restaurant and took a look around all of the diners were white and middle aged.  The men were dressed in slacks and Khaki's and button down shirts and the women were in cocktail dresses or shirts.  A little stuffy but classy.  So here was what I ordered:

Small plates:
Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts and golden raisins:  two peppers served warm.  the cheese was super creamy and went well with the sweetness and texture of the raisins.   very enjoyable.

Calamari "a la plancha" with fennel, olive caper and coriander salpicon:  a salpicon is a diced mixture of various ingredients.  the calamari was savory and very tender.   i was scooping the salpicon up with the wonderful warm bread that they served...

Entree
Lamb chops with gigante beans: the lamb were cooked to perfection.  I must admit that it was a little salty but that did not stop me from cleaning my plate.

My friend had the duck dish and he said it was wonderful.

So the food was delightful and the service is very good.  I must say the restaurant's decor is nice but it didn't give off that trendy vibe.  It semed like kind of place to take your republican parents visiting from the Northeast.  I am not sure if this changes during the weekend.   Piderade is worth the trek for the food though.
author: Thang H.

description:
I've always had great service here - not sure what everyone is complaining about...

...just get there early.

Can't find better food around the Levi Plaza area.  And it's reasonably priced considering the quality.
author: Christine K.

description: I arrived here with my dad at 6:30 on a Saturday evening, and we were promptly seated.  We started off with a glass of txakoli wine and a plate of serrano ham.  Fortunately for me, Saturday's special dish was axoa, a stew of veal and potatoes which I had when I was vacationing in the Basque part of southwest France.  The veal was so tender it practically melted in my mouth; I have not had meat this good in a long time. Dessert was gateau basque for my dad and flan for me, which completed a very sumptuous meal.  Service was attentive, prompt and friendly.  Will definitely be back! Also, it is noteworthy to mention that there aren't many other restaurants in the immediate vicinity of Piperade on Battery Street so finding parking was really easy.
author: Yoshi O.

description:
Love the Mr Williams, and the staff that works the window.  I like that they have tons of healthy, creative options if I were to go here everyday.

The wait is a bit disagreeable if I've been foolish enough to forget a jacket and it happens to be windy in the alley.
author: Hilary C.

description: This has been our favorite restaurant for several years; comfortable, delicious food, excellent wine. But, last night they let us down: the piperade with serrano ham was overcooked and instead of thin, delicate ham, it was accompanied by a fried strip (aka bacon). Most upsetting, their truly exceptional lamb chops with date sauce and lamb sausage has been replaced with chops  accompanied by an aoili and extremely uninteresting baked garbanzos and  baked fennel. Their gem green salad was no better than I make at home. Perfectly good but nowhere near the exceptional meal we've come to expect from Piperade. Better than the average restaurant but we were very disappointed. First time I can't give 5 stars.
author: Alison D.

description:
#15 out of Top 100.  I think we're quitting  our mission to eat at all 100 restaurants in one year before we turn into blimps.

Lamb chops made me feel very heavy and full for hours on end.  A gamier tasting chop then the usual.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Stopping by after work for a few drinks turned into, several hours later, a full-blown meal.  Funny how that happens.  But because the head chef (who, I'll admit, is friends with someone in my party) hung out with us and gave a very personal touch to the experience, I have a very favorable memory of Piperade.

From start to finish it was a nice culinary tour.  Pre-dinner drinks (strong but good manhattans), fries and olives to snack on at the bar, apps (moved to a table now), main courses and dessert.  The only reason my review is not 5 stars is that my main course, lamb chops, was slightly overcooked and drier than I would have liked.  Of course, I still ate every bite which either means I was getting pretty drunk (quite likely) by then...or that I'm unable to stand up for myself.  I hope for everyone's sake that it is the former.  Whatever, the manhattans were strong.
author: Jon M.

description: The atmosphere and the food were wonderful. Three of us celebrated our January birthdays with sparkling wine and and a nice lunch. We shared the mushroom tart and the beignets, which were delicious. Seafood stew, Mr. Williams chicken sandwich, and scallops were our entrees and completed the meal.
author: Maria Perno G.

description: This is for the travelzoo deal.  You think you will be paying less but you will actually pay almost full price for everything.  The travelzoo deal is $69 for 2 apps, 2 entrees, and 2 desserts.  2 apps average $15 each = $30, 2 entrees average $30 per entree = $60,  2 desserts $9 each = $18, and 2 glasses of "wine" with meal is $12 each = $24.  $30 + 60 + 18 + 24 = 132.  The deal excludes tip and tax which is on the total bill of $132.  Tax was like $12 and it was taxed again when the bill came out for the tax on the travelzoo deal.  Hilarious.  The gratuity says 18% on the total bill.  So 18% of $132 = $23.76.  The waiter swiped my card and wrote in $30 in the tip.  WTF?  Fuckers can't do math here.  Service here was slow and inattentive .  I don't mind tipping on good service but when the food came out nothing was explained it was just dropped off and the waiter bounced.  It takes me 1 hour to make $7 so I need to make my money count.  The food except for the dessert was amazing.  Service and this bill thing was shit.
author: Fatty A.

description: Dined on a Friday night at 8 pm. We arrived on the dot and we were escorted to the table with a smile. The crowd was mostly 40+.  Starting with calamari was warm and tasty. I loved the brussels sprouts slaw with pickled herring. The sautéed serano ham with poached egg was just okay, not what we expected, a bit of a let down really (too much red pepper sauce).  The sole was a very healthy portion, good though a bit lackluster over a bed of spinach. It was a treat to have a bottle of txakoli and reminisce of past trips times in Basque Country.  Pommes frites were outstanding and so was the service.
author: K K.

description:
I had a nice business lunch here recently.  The space was bright and lively, the service was  well paced but never rushed, our waiters answered our questions quickly and accurately, and the food was largely good.  One very bad bowl of soup dropped this from a 4 to a 3 star review.

I had the garlic soup and the piperade.  The piperade was delicious -- sweet peppers and onions with chewy shards of ham and topped with a perfectly-poached egg and sauced with a subtle sherry vinegar.  It was a cold day and this wonderful added a splash of color,  a taste of summer and a lot of warmth.  I sopped up the sauce with the crusty, chewy country house bread.

Sadly, my garlic soup was a mess.  The predominant taste was salt, with little garlic to be tasted and too few bread crumbs.  The worst part was the egg, which was so overcooked into a rubbery mess.  For a menu standard, this was a surprising mess.

My companions had the pequillo peppers with goat cheese (a success), a butter leaf salad (fine for what it was), and the black cod special with leeks.  I tasted none of the dishes, but they got good reviews.

I will come back, but I won't order that soup again.
author: Scatterbrained D.

description:
Basque (not French or Spanish)
Very tasty house bread and wonderful olive oil
Reasonably priced international wine list e.g. Grgich Hills Fume Blanc
Lots of appetizers: great presentation of calamari, haricot vert (seem a little expensive)
Delicious char and fantastic lamp chops
Wonderful desserts e.g., chocolate cake, rocher, and orange beignets
Very casual food service
On street parking
author: Rosquete B.

description: I'm all about the Mandarin Chicken Salad and snacks. Other than that everything I've had here is just ok.
author: T S.

description: The food was great. Service excellent! The only thing that I felt really disturbing was the reception: After entering the restaurant and eager to be seated, the employee, who was obviously not busy, would not raise her head from the ipad for at least 10 seconds before greeting us. A restaurant of this class should do better.
author: Kazuyoshi F.

description:
The four of us had dinner at Piperade on Saturday night.  Reservations were for 8:30 p.m.  We arrived at 8:20 and told we would have to wait for a table and wait we did.  We waited over 40 minutes before being seated.  What's the point of a reservation if you still have to wait 40 minutes (that was not including the 10 minutes we arrived early).  Not only that, but once we were seated it took an incredibly long time to have someone come and take our order.

While the service/seating left a lot to be desired, the food was absolutely wonderful. Two of us had the petrale sole, one the seafood stew and the one the veal stew, and it was all great.  I also had the wild mushroom tart and it was to die for.    I would go back in a heartbeat for the food, but would only go if I could get in the first seating.
author: Liz B.

description: Decor amazing . Food okay. Ordered the cheese platter , server did not explain what cheese was what nor did he explain the quince in the center of the plate which I taught was strawberry . Service was terrible , server didn't give me a chance to taste my $18 glass of wine just poured. Defiantly will not be back here.
author: lisa w.

description:
Everything was great--the food and the service.  It was a little loud, but I knew that prior to my visit; this was my first visit.  

I definitely will go back!
author: Kendall Austin S.

description:
4.5 stars

I found my way over to this wonderful little restaurant after a friend forwarded to me this article: http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

The restaurant reminds of so many cozy little places in NYC I've been to. The ambiance is romantic yet comfortable for a group of kids that came with some grown-ups to celebrate a birthday. A beautiful, tasteful wine bottle chandelier hangs from the ceiling that does not scream "look at me!" the way so much restaurant lighting does. The exposed beams and dark wood floor exemplified the aesthetic of the rustic Spanish-Basque menu well.

The hubby and I decided to chance it and walked it without a reservation on a Saturday night. We were greeted at the door by a very nice hostess who offered us a table, even though she was saving it for a 730p reservation. Having exactly 1 hour and 15 minutes to dine, we didn't dillydally with our decisions. Our server and waitstaff didn't dillydally either as they gave us brisk, concise yet efficient service. 

After taking our order, the bread, that was absolutely to die for came out. Complimented by the even more impressive olive oil, we had to stop ourselves from eating all the bread. I noticed no salt and pepper were available at the table, which I thought was a gutsy move that showed that Chef Hirigoyen really encouraged his customers to trust his flavoring. WIth no salt or pepper, we were also able to taste the wonderful olive oil in its true, barest state. Wow, I might never put salt in olive oil again.

We both ordered the garlic soup (on the 7X7 list) to start. The soup was indeed a simple yet complex clear-broth soup. My tastebuds were amazed to find how well seasoned the soup was given it's bare, yet simple home-cooked look. I concluded that I had never had anything like it. My hubby ordered the lamb chops and I had the seafood and shellfish stew.  Both dishes were excellent, well-portioned and presented, and left both of us with exactly enough room for a cup of coffee afterwards.

However, the clock read 730p as we both sopped up the last bits of sauce from our dishes with the two pieces of bread we wisely saved. We paid for our dinner and thanked the hostess for her kindness. No dessert but we were glad to have another reason to return as we walked out with warm, happy bellies.
author: Dawn L.

description:
This is a beautiful, warm restaurant with a seemingly mostly older crowd. The service was good.

The food was disappointingly bland and meh.  We had garlic soup, cornish hen, steak, apple tart (the caramel was burnt, ugh).

This place is waaay overated imho.
author: N F.

description:
The Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die
53. Garlic soup at Piperade
(http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die)

I'm glad my friend told me about that while in the restaurant. I must've read the menu 10 times through before he told me and made my choice. The soup had rock shrimp, bread and eggs. I dont enjoy shrimps, but i'll eat it. The soup was more salty than garlic-y. There was one spoon where I actually was able to taste the garlic. I found myself dumping a bunch of the free bread into the soup to alleviate the saltiness, and i'm usually pretty good with salty foods. I think if the chef wasnt so heavy handed with the salt, the soup would've been pretty good, on the lighter side. Slightly reminiscent of chinese soup.

As far as the experience, I dont like being in fancy-smancy restaurants in general. For what it was, service was really nice--they were patient with our party of 18, especially when we were holding the table up for another large party. I felt pretty uncomfortable being there simply because it was obviously I didnt fit into their demographic of upper class diners.

I think I'm too much of a casual eater for this place--I really didnt need someone to unfold my napkin for me. That should've set something off in my head.

On the bright side, PLENTY of parking spaces in front of and around the restaurant. I was surprised since it was so close to the embarcadero, but its probably far enough from north beach to not attract a bazillion cars.
author: Rena Y.

description: Everything was delicious. The entrees are purposefully not huge so plan to have several small plates ("pintxos") beforehand. There is a wide variety of great pintxos so be sure to mix it up. Extensive list of good wines as well.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
As other reviewers have reported, great food despite the off-the-beaten path location.  The upside is that there is TONS of parking.

Calamari appetizer was excellent and different.  Cheese plate was delicious.  Great wine options; the waiter made two great by-the-glass recommendations.  I enjoyed the rockfish (main entrée) but my husband did not enjoy his dish.  We both found the dessert (basque gâteau) different and delicious (although we found the side of cherries cloyingly sweet).

The space is very cozy and they have not changed the interior from its previous incarnation (when it was called Pastiche, which was also run by the current owners).

I have to disagree with the reviewer from 1/2/2010 who found the service lacking -- we had a very good experience.
author: Marnie S.

description: if you want a place near levi's plaza to have a nice lunch, a glass of great wine, and be civilized - this is it. Management is polite and accomodating and remembers you always.  Food is a bit unique, and somewhat heavy - but always a nice experience. Try the stuffed piquillo peppers and the Piperade for true basque experience.  Did I mention the desserts?
author: Nora F.

description: absolutely loved this place! The food was incredible, the crowd was not pretentious and there was easy street parking! can't ask for more :)
author: Cam N.

description:
What happened to the service? 
I'm not sure what is going on but I have been going to Piperade for years and have to agree with some other reviewers, the service had been deteriorating recently (with one notable exceptional waitress). Like another recent reviewer, we arrived late but on time for our reservation) and there were two large parties there.  We were seated right away but had to wait for ages for menus. Eventually our server showed and took our cocktail order.  She then disappeared for a long time and then came back with the drinks which had been sitting on the bar for a long time,  I was tempted to go to the bar and pick them up myself! She took our food order. We wanted to order some wine and get our water topped up, but again our server was MIA. We tried to flag down another server but he ignored us. Again the restaurant wasn't particulaly busy. Food is as great as ever but service has gone down hill.
author: Paul C.

description: I liked Piperade, but was not completely blown away by my dinner here.  The food was good, but not amazing.  I've never had Basque food, so I can't really say if it was authentic, but all mushroom tart and the seafood/shellfish soup I had for dinner were flavorful and fresh.  Service was pretty good, but lagged at times (it was hard to flag our server to make drink orders after we had made our dinner orders).  The ambiance is very nice inside, although it is a bit cramped.
author: Michelle C.

description: Nice dinner spot with both individual tables and communal layout.  Had the 2007 Vina Cartin Albarino which matched great with my seafood.  Service was a bit on the sluggish side, but prices were reasonable.
author: Eric F.

description:
So what was it?

Was it that I was in with my friends that hat had an Irish accent?

We were your latest table and we told you that we would be when we called in.

We made it clear that we ware industry.

And your food was excellent.

And your service was embarrassing for me to take my friends to your establishment.

I only dropped U$ 200 + a U$40.00 tip.

And you embarrassed me.  Food was really good, your servers were lazy asses.

The server never explained the four cheeses on the cheese plate, nor could he when he was questioned about them.  Much less the Quince Jelly that he needed to go back and ask the kitchen about.

Nor did anyone ask us ONCE how our food was.  Nor did anyone ask us if we needed anything.

Never been before, but will never go again to Piperade.  Thanks, but when I leave Manhattan, I'll try to research and do better next time.
Sincerely,
NFS
author: Neil S.

description: Tried this pace for a birthday dinner and was pleasantly surprised with my experience. I hadn't ever heard of this place since it's a bit tucked away in an area of downtown I do not frequent. The restaurant decor is very nice casual, elegant. The food and service was good. Not counting the two bottles of champagne we had here, the food can be a bit pricey when ordering many small dishes to share, but other than that I believe this is a great dining spot for a weekend dinner.
author: Kent W.

description: After an epic FAIL of a would-have-been-free Italian wine tasting, Nikki G. and I meander down Battery. Walkerby man sees us looking at the menu and says "...It's gooood." We go in and, DELISH. Great friendly and attentive staff. Enjoyed some tasty glasses of Basque white wine with beautifully executed calimari with bread-dipping-good sauce. Definitely coming back for a full lunch or dinner sometime.
author: Kelly N.

description: Great food and great time with my wife.  Halibut and sea bass were Delish.  Server a little hard to understand but did an excellent job.   Was a wonderful experience for both of us and we will return.   Thanks piperade staff
author: R C.

description: Great food, great service, nice atmosphere. Had the fried manchego, chilled mussel salad, piperade, and braised seafood. Everything was fresh, perfectly seasoned, nice portion sizes and very memorable.
author: Karen B.

description: Great place. I Would recommend the rack of lamb. Order it cooked medium. There is a nice bar as well. The only odd thing is that they don't serve sangria.
author: Abhi M.

description: Excellent!  Food was wonderful with a beautiful presentation.  Went on a Saturday and tried the veal cheeks.  Amazing!!!  Tried the crab cakes for appetizer and they were lovely.  The desserts were delicious as well.  Wonderful atmosphere and Jean, the waiter was outstanding.  Couldn't have been any better!
author: Patti A.

description: The dungeness crab is amazing! Also try the Apple pie crisp...its like a yummy fancy toaster strudel!!!!
author: Jasmine S.

description: I was impressed by the food here! I came by for a work dinner and all of the dishes were good - especially the foie gras appetizer! I had the lamb dish for my main entree which was really flavorful. The place isn't very big so I would recommend reservations. It wasn't outstanding but definitely better than expected. Parking is also easy to find here.
author: Leily P.

description:
First off, Steven, our waiter, was awesome. He was attentive, honest, and he totally put up with our group of 6 girls. You rock! I'd definitely come back again. Everyone's food was delicious and nicely presented. I'll start from the beginning. :)

Bread - huge basket full of sliced sourdough (?) bread. The olive oil was full of flavor and really robust. I think I ate 4 slices and sopped up at least 2 TBS of olive oil.

Garlic soup - had very high expectations, as everyone was raving about this soup. It smelled garlicky, but didn't actually taste garlicky. I liked the bits of bacon in it, and thought the shrimp and egg bits were delicious. In itself though, I thought it tasted like wonton soup. Almost all the girls who ordered this put in pepper to taste. Pretty filling though, and still good. Shouldn't have been that hyped though!

Roasted pork - YUM. The meat is quite tender. At first bite though, I did think it was slightly dry. but then I ate another bite with the cabbage, and WOW. My mouth was in heaven. The pickled cabbage was perfectly sweet/sour, and complimented the pork very well. I finished everything. I want more now...

Orange blossom beignets - a very unique spin on beignets! The aroma of orange blossom really came through, but didn't overwhelm the taste buds. I didn't feel like I was eating perfume, so that was an A+. It was quite a delightful treat.

Chocolate cake "amatxi" - delicious. Great flavor and consistency. Reminded me of the insides of a slightly overcooked molten lava cake...so still dense and moist, but not runny. The creme fraiche that accompanied it paired very well with the rich chocolate cake. The cake disappeared within 4 mins. I got to eat the last bite. i win! :)
author: Carol L.

description:
came here twice for lunch, and not for the food, which is whatever.

the workers are what make this place. if you're having a downer day at work or something, come here. they'll cheer you up in about 2 minutes.

that's all.
author: Shawn C.

description: The vibrant flavors and entrees here are not often emulated in the Bay Area. Both times I have been here, I was impressed with the quality of the entrees, ingredients, presentation, and service. The roasted lamb (chop, shoulder, and sausage) entree with cumin-date relish, braised fennel, and potato is outstanding (if you like lamb). The fish/seafood stew (which is akin to a lighter version of cioppino) is also fresh and flavorful, and well-portioned. If you have room for dessert, the caramel custard "koka" is perfectly prepared and executed.
author: Chris T.

description: Great food with an awesome friendly staff.  My new favorite place to eat when in the City...
author: Julie W.

description:
So Piperade and their people ruined my life.

They happen to run my company's cafeteria.  Yeah, we're ALL class.  What of it?

Needless to say, I rarely eat there cause they charge like $18 dollars for a hard boiled egg.  But when I do decide to throw my money to the wind and my ass to the morbidly obese, the food is fantastic.  

Hard day today.  I just polished off a three million dollar salad with pecans, ripe avocado, mandarin orange slices, grilled chicken breast, slices of rich parmesan cheese and a lovely vinaigrette.

It was hard, but I stayed away from those sneaky snacker Greek Yogurt cups.

So this one time I walk in to get a snack, and they are out of the little hummus cups that I usually make mouth sex to.  I ask the counter lady when they might get some more.  She says she doesn't know and points me in the direction of the Greek Yogurt Cup.  I am like, sure.  Greek Yogurt.  Whatever.  I'll take it.

I get back to my desk, and sure enough I have been fucked royally.  The Greek Yogurt is the thickest most insanely delicious thing I have ever put in my mouth.  Ever.  It's like eating a whole cup of sour cream. 

2.5 seconds later, I need more.  That's right.  I got ANOTHER one.  All the while thinking, "It's YOGURT! What harm can it possibly do?", and also giving major props to Zeus or Aphrodite or Chlamydia for sprinkling some their big phat Greek wedding magic into healthy food to make it taste like straight butter covered butter.

You might have already come to the punch line of this stupid, tedious little story, but I'm blonde, so I'll take you all the way through the painful details.

Cut to Casa G****berg about a month later.  No wisdom teeth.  Moms asks me what I want to gum on.

Ummm, greek yogurt of course.  The most amazing, delicious, ridiculous shit ever.

So she brings it to me.  Sho nuff, it tastes different.  Not as thick.  Not as creamy.  Not as sour cream, buttery.  So I am like, "WTF?".   

Turns out what the lunch ladies have been shoveling in my yogurt hole weighs in at about 25 grams of fat and 300 calories per serving.  Can anyone say Big Mac?  Like, I could have been eating fried bananas covered in peanut butter and fudge sauce this WHOLE MOTHER FUCKING TIME?  

So, I came to work very enraged and wrote a little note for their suggestion box, that went a little something like this:

Dear Lunch People, 

The greek yogurt is fantastic.  And why wouldn't it be?  IT'S MADE OF FAT.  CHUNKY, PEARLESCENT, WHITE FAT HARVESTED FROM GREEK BABIES.

YOU SUCK.  I HATE YOU.

- Rachel

PS.  Can you please think of adding a Vegetable Cup to the menu?
author: Rachel G.

description:
It took some poor service at the newly opened Quince to make me realize that I had done a disservice to Piperade in not yelping them prior to this.

We are neighbors of theirs and stop in fairly regularly to eat at the bar.  The food is excellent and Jonathon the barkeep treats us with respect even if we are eating at the bar rather than at a table.

I love the cozy space and the understated elegance of the surroundings.  I can't recommend Piperade enough for those of you traveling to our neighborhood.  Its an excellent spot to wait out the post 4th of July, or Blue Angels traffic or to enjoy a meal prior to some time in North Beach.  Heck, I'd eat there before Teatro Zinzani and then leave that food for the busboys.  Its that good.
author: Joe N.

description:
I'll keep this review at 4 stars, although I am VERY tempted to lower it to 3 stars... My first experience was more like a 4.5, so I'll knock down to 3.5 and round up.  

As a person who has had the "opportunity" to work in a restaurant as a Server, I have a LOT of patience toward restaurant personnel, BUT I also value good service tremendously.  

We came for the 2nd time in a one week period to celebrate a great friend's birthday.  We were a group of 9 and we spent a LOT of money, as you can imagine.  Service-wise, the experience was NIGHT and DAY from the previous experience.  Our server hardly seemed to care about how we were doing/ our experience, etc.  Very shocking, especially in this economy.  Lady, there are a thousand people out there who would kill for your job about now... just saying.

I won't say the service was terrible, just negligent.  She seemed pretty nonchalant: water glasses were not refilled.  She never poured wine from the bottle, we had to do so ourselves....  Now, I admit it can be annoying when a waiter seems to practically ram the wine down your throat so that you'll buy more bottles, hence a larger bill, BUT at such a large table, where conversation was flowing, it's not so easy to halt the conversation, yell to the person on the other side to pass the wine... that's when it's useful for the server to step in and assist.  Not once did she refill a wine glass.  As we were waiting for our desserts, we realized that we still had 1/2 a bottle of wine leftover and the lushes in the group (including me of course!) had to start chugging!

I made a BIG mistake and ordered the Rockfish (minus 1 star) -- quite boring and bland.  Basic basic boring white fish served over steamed spinach.  In fact, I think that I enjoyed the spinach more than the fish!  But I'll take 1/2 the blame because the description on the menu wasn't all that... don't know WHAT possessed me to order it, to be honest.

My husband, however, ordered the Lamb Chop entree (plus multiple stars!!!)  OMG.... that is the winning dish for sure.  Hands down the BEST thing on the menu (besides the beignets, but I'll get into that in a moment).  Super tender, served med-rare, meaty, tasty, YUM!!!  It is served with soft roasted potatoes, soft roasted onion and a mini-lamb sausage as well.  I want to go back right now and get that dish!  LOVE it.

As for dessert, we had been raving about the beignets all night (since we had enjoyed them just a few days prior).... I SWEAR folks at the tables around us MUST have heard us rave, because as we are going around the table ordering, they RAN OUT!!!!  So, two of us got to order the Beignets but by the time our lovely server got around to my hubby and I, they were all out.  OMG!!!  I could have cried.  We ended up ordering the Flan, which was also delicious.  But we bartered 3/4 of the dish for 1 beignet!!!  It was worth it too....  Oh, by the way, we had to ASK for coffee, aren't they supposed to ask by default?
author: Sheila D.

description: Warm and friendly atmosphere. Delightful employees and amazing service. The food we ate... perfect! Top quality and prepared to perfection. A bit pricey...
author: Jan J.

description:
So this year my friends didn't want to try and surprise me because they usually ruin it before dinner happens.  This time, they asked me to give them a few options for restaurants to choose from that could hold a good amount of people.  Piperade was one of the places I've always wanted to come and I'm glad I did!

Before even entering the building, there was surprisingly a lot of parking near the area.  That's a plus!  Walked in to a calm, cool environment with a dark, yet chill decor.  There weren't too many people there so it was quiet, which is nice because I could talk to everyone that was there.  They easily accommodated our group of 16ish people.

They had a small menu, but everything on it looked great!  I decided to go with the Veal which was delicious.  It was very tender and just melted in my mouth.  I'll have to come back to try the other dishes like the duck, and sea bass.  I did get a chance to try some of the garlic soup and rock shrimp.  I liked it, but it didn't really wow me.  It was unique and I could see why it would be on the 7x7 list.  I don't know if I would order it on my own, but I'm glad I tried it.

Service was very pleasant and courteous.  It felt a little rushed, but we were supposed to be out of there after 2 hours anyways.  Can't blame them for that.  I'm still surprised they handled a group that size so well.

I'm a fan!
author: Tom Y.

description: Piperade is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  It is so consistently great.  The ambience is very soothing, and the noise level is not at bomb level.  The food, cocktails, and service are always excellent.  We had the butter lettuce salad, haricots verts salad, rack of lamb, and halibut last night.  All were first rate.  I will always return to Piperade when I want  a great meal.
author: Katy L.

description:
I am doing a review of the Piperade I know, the one that serves delish sandwiches and fresh salads from a window on the side of the building! Everyday the people that work in the Levi's Plaza area flock to the window to see what the lunch special is of the day! 

The hot food is always "cooked-to-order" even at lunch! The couple minutes wait is worth it. You also get a couple sprigs of lettuce on the side, which compliments all the meat and bread you are about to inhale. Good variety of chips and drinks too that you can add to your meal.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Delightful place.  It doesn't seem all that Basque to me, but I'm no expert.  I loved the namesake piperade dish, with the serrano, and caramelized peppers, tomatoes, and onions with a poached egg on top.  It's almost as good as sizzling pork sisig!  The highlight of the meal was a haricot vert and fig salad that was the perfect combination of texture, temperature, and taste.  Amanda had a wonderful halibut and IQ's pork tenderloin was moist and perfectly cooked, although I wasn't crazy about the flavor combinations in the pork dish.  

I especially love the beautiful, warm, intimate dining room.  We did not see the chef making table rounds as other reviewers note, and that may explain the spotty service.  Bar service was friendly and fast, but the table service was cool bordering on frosty.  I have to give extra kudos to the hostess who, having accepted a late reservation with the understanding we'd be at the communal table, nonetheless found a nice corner table for us that made our party of four much more comfortable.  The big square communal table might work for either very large groups or groups of two, but a group of four would find the conversational logistics tough.

We will definitely be back.
author: Kevin S.

description: The bar tender was a little too chatty for my taste (i was on a date), but the food was delish and it had great ambiance.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Primary disclosure: my girl and I have been cooking Spanish food for many months now - every weekend, twice a weekend. Became slightly obsessed with it, actually. Penelope Casas, I think I love you. I've said, quite seriously, that I could eat in the Spanish style for the rest of my life and never be dissatisfied. It's one of those 'last meal' kind of questions. Last lifetime cuisine? Spanish contends. That noted, I might have reached my Spanish ceiling. With this in mind, we come to Piperade - overall, excellent, exceptional perhaps, but nothing we could not or did not do ourselves. We tried as much as we could and drank Viognier the entire meal long.

We started with small plates and made our way to one big plate - it was far too much food.

Calamari 'a la plancha' with fennel, olive, caper, and coriander salpicon ($12): Probably my favorite because I find it hard to resist perfectly cooked squid - a touch salty, mind you, but intentionally so and explosively flavored.

House cured bacalao with oyster tartare and lemon creme fraiche ($13): Nice, also salty (it's thinly sliced salt cured cod!), but very sound - oysters a nice contrast and the creme fraiche a needed cut against the salt of the bacalao.

Grande white bean salad with boquerones, fresh herbs, and crushed egg ($11): Fantastic, actually. But this is also why I opened with my disclosure. This is a classic Spanish dish. Not much to it if you have the best ingredients - simple simple simple - but miraculous in its simplicity. The Spaniards love egg (and ham), olive oil (it's like oxygen), boquerones are one of my 5 favorite foodstuffs (they change all the time), and the white beans were heirloom-good. If you have never tried heirloom beans, give them a go - they are notable.

Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts, and golden raisins ($13): Another delicious dish. Spanish food has enlightened me to the divinity of the properly prepared red pepper. Before we started cooking Spanish, red pepper of any sort never appealed to me. Piquillo peppers? Nom nom nom. Stuffed and roasted with goat cheese, pine nuts, and golden raisins? So obvious, right? Indeed. You cannot go wrong. But this is the genius of Spanish cooking my friends.

Thinly sliced serrano ham ($16): Quite possibly my favorite foodstuff, ever - I have dirty dreams about serrano ham. I do not know why, I could be mad, but I find serrano significantly superior to prosciutto - deeper, subtler, less salty, more complex, more fulfilling, more luscious - my palate slides softly into an ecstatic delirium. Rightfully, they do nothing to the serrano - I do not like it heated or cooked (it loses its life force). Why is this not my favorite small plate? Well, that's a lot of $ for a small plate of thinly sliced cured ham. So I reward the imagination of the calamari a la plancha - however, if I could take only one to my grave, it's serrano by a mile. And smokes. And wine.

Garlic soup with rock shrimp, bacon, bread, and egg ($9): Easily the most disappointing dish - not bad, not great, just adequate - no rich garlic essence, average little shrimp, bits of so-so bacon, a nice bread cube, an egg-drop kind of egg, and a far too salty broth.

Finally, the big plates all looked interesting but, as noted many times now, we've done a lot of Spanish cooking and wanted something slightly more special. So we went with the Friday night Basque classic. I preferred other Basque classics on the menu, but you only have one choice each night. Which takes us to...

...Albacore 'marmitako' with saffron potato stew ($26): Good. The tuna reminded me why I prefer my tuna on the raw side. Thick tuna muscle, cooked fully, loses flavor, loses the lushness of its fat maybe - and so maybe more olive oil and a pinch of salt would have improved the fish. The saffron potato stew was classically Spanish with julienned red peppers (which I would have preferred skinned) - sound, classic, good. That's about it. We were way too full to finish and boxed it for home. It heated up just fine for lunch. 

To close as I began, if we did not cook so much Spanish food, every dish we had (with the exception of the garlic soup) would have been more impressive - as is, still a sound 4 stars. Service, ambiance, excellent.
author: Brski B.

description:
I've always liked Basque food, but I've always thought about it as old people food. Most of the Basque restaurants I'd been to had delicious food, but were staffed by smelly middle aged dudes.

Not Piperade. First of all, the wait staff is extremely friendly and attractive.

I've learned that when a restaurant has an item on the menu that shares a name with the restaurant you're supposed to have that.

And so it was.

Piperade is a pretty simple concept. Suateed vegetables in a light broth with Serrano ham, topped with a poached egg. Simple and delicious.
author: Jason R.

description: Such a cute place for lunch. It's away from all the crowd by the embarcadero, so it makes it a quiet nice lunch place. I got the burger, which was tasty. The meat was very juicy and it was soaking through the bun. I enjoyed it very much.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Dee-li-cious, very reasonable and suitable for many occasions(i.e. quiet enough for a business meeting or comfortable enough for a long, leisurely lunch later in the week.) 

I haven't tried dinner, but I recommend the pre fixe menu option for lunch. The menu changes daily and is a lot of food for lunch  - just skip breakfast, and plan for a long run or lite dinner -but you'll be happy once your first course arrives, I promise. Yum-my! 

Service is not too shabby either, and the host at lunch is super sweet, and very observant to your special requests made via Opentable.com which surprised me. 

I say try it...you have nothing to loose.
author: Sam C.

description:
Best Basque restaurant I've ever eaten. Okay, it was the only Basque restaurant I've ever eaten in but that doesn't diminish my enthusiasm for the food. It was some of the simplest, best, food I've eaten.

I was dining alone and sat at the bar. Rather than order an entree I ordered three apps: fava bean, treviso, basil and mint salad ; cold poached foie gras; and thinly sliced serrano ham. Small plates with intense flavors.
author: Chris L.

description:
Quality of food was quite superb; however, cocktails didn't impress me.

Ambience is warm and staff is quite friendly. It is a nice place to hang out after work for wine and dine - no doubt.

Fava Bean and Treviso Salad - Love this salad plate. It was well-balanced and flavorful like an orchestra of food.

Piquillo Peppers Stuffed with Goat Cheese - It is not spicy, but it has a strong and rich goat cheese taste to back it up. It is quite heavy that I do not recommend finishing this dish by yourself.

Cold Poached Fois Gras - This is as rich as the piquillo peppers with goat cheese, if not heavier, and it is smooth like butter. It's great dish, but not a must-eat.

Fried cheese - This is an awesome dish and surprises my taste bud.  A recommendation from me!

Piperade with Sauteed Serrano Ham and Poached Egg - It is not up to my expectation partly because I heard how amazing Serrano ham is.  Made with fresh ingredients, but it's not on top of my list.

Lamb Chop and Sausages - I have a more favorable memory on this dish than the Piperade because I am a fan of lamb.

Roasted Halibut - Although not particularly impressive, there is nothing disappointing on this dish.

Conclusion:

This is my first time at a Basque restaurant. I really enjoyed tipiak, more than handiak. Recommend for after-hour hangout to share bottle of wine and small bites.
author: Edmund L.

description:
If you own a business and you offer a half price meal through Bloomspot the idea is to attract new customers to come try you out, right?  But then the customer that comes with the certificate is treated like a second class citizen all night by the waiter.  So you just gave away food at half price AND you turned your potential new customer into a walking advertisement for why NEVER to patronize your business.  NOT VERY SMART!
The food was amazing, the host seemed pleasant and accommodating, the bartender had ZERO personality (go to Foreign Cinema and see how the lady behind the bar greets people i.e with a smile and makes you feel at home!), and the best the waiter could do was grunt at us: "another drink?" (it was too much effort to speak a full sentence to the certificate bearing patrons (which by the way we did tip on the full coupon value plus drinks. despite total crappy attitude which is my bad!!)  He almost ruined the whole experience, luckily the food was great and some staff were warm as we were leaving the restaurant..........?????
We have so many amazing food choices in a city like SF, hopefully they do a little staff training.......................
author: Dana H.

description: I ate here with Dine About Town (DAT) in January, and had a choice of any appetizer, entree, and dessert for $20. Overall, I was very underwhelmed.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Piperade is a must-go-to place and is one of the best places to eat in sf, but why do you ask?

the foie gras is superb - i've not had better in sf - presentation is perfect and flavors are rich and mesh well with the accompaniments

service is informative and polite and perfect

after eating numerous entrees, i've only not liked the bouibaisse - but I'm not a huge fan of that dish to begin with

The gateau basque is also superb and i can't ever not order it for dessert 

not a noisey venue so conversation battles are not an issue - the wine list is also appropriately chosen for the cuisine

not a "hip" scene, but food is more important that that
author: Jerome, Jerome T.

description:
We had our annual dinner with dear friends that we see all to little of, at this restaurant. Piperade made the evening a special one with their delicious food, ambiance and service. One of our friends was especially excited to see sweetbreads on the menu and he said they were excellent. Being vegetarian, I didn't really want any details but I thought I would pass on his review.
   Salads had a nice attention to fresh ingredients that made them incredibly tasteful. As for all the entrees at the table on a scale of 1-10 they all scored between a 7-10. Piperade is a great place to enjoy delicious food and wonderful friends.
author: Stella N.

description:
Having lived in San Sebastian for a bit and loving everything I ate there, I was excited for some Basque food in SF.  Piperade delivered.

The highlights for me were the peppers stuffed with goat cheese and the steak.  Sampled some other plates at the table and thought everything was good.  Wine list was solid.

More than anything, though, it is a good relaxed place.  Good service without being stuffy, pretentious, or annoying.  Interesting location close enough to North Beach to stroll over afterwards but out of the hustle and bustle.  A few bottles of wine into the evening we realized it was past 11.  Left happy, full and relaxed.  Will be back...
author: Brad C.

description:
We ordered almost every small platter, and some entrees. A few were really good, most were meh, a couple were really not.

The service was spotty. But, I am not one to begrudge a restaurant on its service. I am there for the food right? All could have been forgiven if not for one fatal mistake.  They messed up their signature dish...the piperade...and when I called the waiter out on it he says "This is the way we serve it." Eww...

Oh how the mighty have fallen. Maybe at one point this place deserved to be on Bauer's top 100 restaurants in SF...no longer. We spent close to 200 dollars, and had 1 completely inedible entree, 2-4 boring dishes, and maybe 1-2 truly delicious things. 

Recommend: If you insist on going...
- The mushroom tart was awesome. Extremely tasty flaky crust...a great savory dish.
- The foie gras was pretty good. It was served with a compote that overpowered the foie gras slightly, but was interesting

Avoid: Oh...so many things...
- Saffron potatoes (just a cold plate of blah)
- Mussels on a bread salad (not delicious like the bread salad at Zuni)
- the piperade (served with a completely cooked poached egg, by a waiter with no shame...hah)

One final note: most people dining at this place are like 50-70 yrs old...kind of creates a sort of "Retired Wall Street" feel. Just good to know, in case you wanted a place with a hip ambiance.
author: Rondeep C.

description: Had a wonderful meal and experience last night using the Travelzoo voucher.  Service was attentive and polite, and the food was delicious.  Minor complaint is that my steak was overcooked (ordered medium rare, but came out as a medium), but my companion's salmon was wonderful.  Don't miss the calamari and piquillo peppers appetizer.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
Without question, this was a five star experience.

My husband and I had a reservation at 8:30PM and were running a few minutes late.  The hostess thanked us for the call and let us know there would not be a problem.  

Upon arrival we were seated promptly in a window seat.  The restaurant has a warm feeling and my stomach had a very hungry feeling so we got to ordering right away.

Sparkling water was brought to our table upon request and we each ordered a glass of rose - delicious, dry, and a gorgeous ruby color.  

We each ordered the Prix Fixe menu and were not disappointed.  I tacked on the Haricot Vert salad which was delicious and the perfect mix of mint and amazingly fresh flavors.  As a starter it tantalized the palate. My first course was the soup of the day - lentil bean, I believe.  It was hearty and warm, perfect for the all-too-typical freezing San Francisco summer weather outside.  My husband had the green salad.  

We both ordered the pork which was of the fall-off-the-bone-and-into-our-mouths variety.  This all sat atop a bed of cabbage which was equally enjoyable.

For dessert my husband had the Gateau and I the Orange Blossom Beignets.  They disappeared shortly after arrival, not surprisingly.  

Since we'd let the restaurant know this was a special occasion (hubby and my last date before the new baby arrives) I believe they surprised us with a sparkling muscat after dinner.  It was so SMOOTH!  I forgot to ask what bottle it was, regretfully.  I guess I'll just have to return!  

Woe is me.  Finding another San Francisco favorite yet seven years too late.  I'll have to make up for lost time!
author: Leslie A.

description: A restaurant you must try! Our family did and loved the small plates we all shared. We had the cold foie gras, oysters and bacalao....yummy!
author: Grace R.

description:
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G

Seriously!

I loved Piperade! 

Things i loved:

1) The outside seating area-- loved the big faux clock and candle lit tables
2) Hostess was very nice and accomodating
3) Seafood stew of sorts.. YUM
4) DUCK entree was by far my favorite-- lamb was good.. but didn't compare to the duck (in my opinion)
5) Chocolate cake :D
6) Very nicely priced bottles of wine.. very surprising

As a few people stated, I wasn't a huge fan of the cocktails we had. . both were so so. I did enjoy the bar area however. The greenbean salad that everyone raved about didn't amaze me. 

Can't wait to come back!!!
author: Sarah W.

description: Food is great...so is the service, but I suggest you come here for the dessert...which deserves 10 STARS
author: Martin C.

description: Good food and wine... well composed wine list.  Serrano ham is great... as was the Bokish Abarino.  However our server was not competent.  He knew little of the food, nor especiaily the wines, and failed to attend us properly.  Apparently aware of our special occasion, he never mentioned it... nor even put a candle on either of our desserts.... this is not the kind of place where you expect to ask for water or pour your own wine, but we did.  When I asked if we should have been given olive oil or butter to go with the bread, he said... ''oh, you didn't''.  He ruined the experience for me.
author: Skip G.

description:
2/27/2008
That bacalao dish was FANTASTIC!  The calamari, the piquillo peppers, and the fish ttoro soup were all really good too, but that bacalao dish completely knocked our socks off!  The chef/owner and his staff were all so friendly and nice to top it off.

9/6/2007
went to a wine and food event tonight and piperade was there as a vendor serving some food.  they didn't have a banner up or anything identifying them but the food spoke for itself.
author: Pelle Y.

description: Food is not so great for the price.  This place is not up to par with other restaurants in this price range.  Dishes are not prepared that well.  Service and environment are fine.
author: Joe B.

description: I eat lunch here, probably every day. It's hidden down Icehouse alleyway in the center of all things Pottery barn/Williams Sonoma headquarters off of Battery on Union. You HAVE to make sure you arrive between 11:45-12:30 or else it will be sold out. I absolutely love their salads and sandwiches. Their soup is pretty great too. I would reccomend the quesidellas if you're over the whole soup/salad/sandwich thing. Definitely a lunch stable to hit if you're in the Levi's plaza area.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Delicious. 
Impeccable, friendly and warm service.
Great space, not too small, not cavernous. Just inviting and comfortable.

We had the green beans with perfect blondes (walnuts) peaches and shallots. OMG this was the best "salad" I have ever had in my life ever. The beans were tossed in a dressing (was that walnut oil giving it the nutty-ish flavor??) which managed to be SUPER flavorful but very light at the same time. 

I had the steak and my date had the special sweetbreads. Both dishes were perfectly executed, delicious and tender. We had the cornmeal cake with strawberries for dessert. YUM!  Our server was  gracious and had a lovely Basque accent. We'll be back! Thanks for a great dinner, Piperade!
author: Kandy P.

description:
a great place to dine

i am very fortunate to have been visiting the city with a friend that is pretty knowledgeable on places to eat there. this was one of the spots he said i had to try and he was right.

we passed on an appetizer because we wanted to be sure we had room for a dessert.

for dinner, i had the lamb which came with 3 different cuts. chop, loin, and braised shoulder. all cuts were good with my favorite being the shoulder. it had the best flavor out of the 3 since it was slow cooked in wine. the loin on the other hand was a bit too mild for me. when ordering lamb, i want that slightly gamey flavor but instead the loin was more like a mild beef. the dish came with a side of beans which had a nice tangy flavor. seemed like it had saffron in it and was my favorite part of the entree

my friend had NY strip which came with potatoes. perfectly seasoned and done. his steak had a really good flavor.

for dessert i had the chocolate cake. warm and gooey and accompanied with creme friache. excellent. when i commented to our server that the creme fraiche had a great flavor, she brought out a small cup of it for me. very sweet of her.

i'll definitely go back the next time i'm visiting
author: Mark Y.

description: The roast chicken was really dry, small, and unappetizing. The appetizers were mediocre and not really my kind of food. Tureen of sheep's milk on the menu sounds totally disgusting, glad no one at the table ordered it.
author: KellyMoi M.

description: Lovely place.  Beautiful food, great tastes and attentive service.  The dining room is quiet enough for conversation and on a Tuesday night there was parking right outside.  I'll be back!
author: Sarah L.

description: The food was excellent and fairly priced.  We had some large and small dishes and everything was wonderful as well as the wine list.  Try the tomato tartlet, stuffed peppers...everything.  And for dessert the apple tart was to die for.  Excellent atmosphere, not to loud and parking available on the weekends
author: Roberta L.

description: During the lunch hour they open up a little cafe window out back with premade sandwhiches and salads. They've got a few great sandwhiches and soups, but i was quite unhappy to discover the smelly fish scent coming from my caesar salad was anchovies buried underneath the lettuce. Next time i hope they put that on the menu so fish phobic people like me don't scream in the office.
author: Nikki M.

description:
eh. not. impressed. at. all.
came here last nite with some co-workers and was very disappointed with the dining experience. 

1. we had reservations but apparently it is for a table outside with heated lamps. normally that would be ok but there were 2 other folks outside just smoking. and then their LOUD friends came to visit them. our own table conversation was overshadowed by these obnoxious folks. when we asked our waiter to kindly "do something about it", he didn't even acknowledge our feedback. gee, thanks.

2. the bus boy (yes not our waiter) brought out our entrees but didn't seem to know what i ordered. first he handed me a plate of meat. "um what is this? i didn't order the duck." try again. "uhhh wait this is all vegetables. i didn't order this either." strike two. "yes, that's mine, it's the halibut right?" 

3. i wasn't pleased with the appetizers that our waiter recommended. the calamari was intimidating. the proscuitto was too salty. the asparagus was bland.

4. again the chocolate flourless cake that our waiter suggested was my least favorite of the desserts. i did like the chocolate with hazelnut mousse cake though.

one of my co-workers said that the lunch is better. maybe i'll try this place for lunch but i won't be coming back for dinner anytime soon.
author: Helen Y.

description: A friend of mine asked for restaurant recommendations and it took me forever to remember the name of Piperade.  A little out of the way, but really delicious, and different.  Definitely worth a try.
author: Kristen S.

description: Lovely and comfortable sophisticated dining.  Gorgeous ambiance and gracious service.  A true delight.
author: Diane G.

description:
How much do I love this place?

For the warmth of the cozy space -- all rustic hewn woods and low ceilings... the last time I visited on a Monday for lunch there was an explosion of vibrant red tulips in a large glass bowl in the center of the room... gorgeous.

It was so nice to see Chef in his own restaurant, actually working the front of the house!  He greeted us, poured our champagne choice, made us feel very welcome.

The food -- fantabulous.  I'd been dreaming of going here for their sweetbreads alone (alas, this is considered a Basque speciality and is only served Mondays).  The menu is essentially split into categories of small plates and large, with a small selection of sides.  The fries are addicting.  One can't stop.  I love their Baccalao carpaccio with 4 perfect, sea-subtle oysters and creme fraiche.  Gerald Hirigoyen is a genius.

We had a lovely and gracious server -- Sandra -- who was extremely helpful in recommending a Basque wine. It was perfect for our meal, and very reasonably priced.

And then, the coup de grace -- we received a call 3 days later from a staffmember (Anthony) saying that he believed one of our party (my fiance) had left a Canon 17-40mm lens when we dined there Monday!  We were very grateful as it was an expensive lens and appreciated the time they took to track us down and call.
author: Claudine C.

description:
4.75!!
deeelish!!
clean, modern atmosphere. service is excellent. good location. and even if all of these weren't true, and the food was served in a dark dingy alley atop old dirty trash can lids i would still devour it and give em a stellar rating!!! i would def recommend the butter lettuce salad, the crab and mango stack, the pommes frites, the creamy and heavy potato au gratin and the amazing cherry and heirloom tomato tart w a balsamic reduction!! ohh and they make a pretty mean arnold palmer!!
author: Kaylan S.

description:
Piperade has been on my want-to-try list for awhile now since a) I love Bocadillo, its sister restaurant, and b) I adooooore Spanish tapas and Basque cuisine. I spent two weeks eating my way through Spain recently (think seared foie gras pintxos, black pudding, creamy discs of goat cheese, fried calamari sandwiches, deep fried chorizitos, grilled padron peppers, creme catalans topped perfectly charred sugar, arroz negro with seafood, etc.) so the bar was set extremely high. 

Piperade is great - on a relatively quiet part of Battery Street, the exposed brick dining room is warm and inviting, service is efficient, and the tapas portions are just right. We tried the grilled calamari in a tangy but savory tomato sauce, bacalao tartare with raw oysters and aioli, garlic soup with shrimp and croutons, and the crabmeat tower with veggies and microgreens. On an SF restaurant scale of 1-10, I give it a 7, which is pretty high considering the quantity and quality of good food in this city. However, as I said before, the bar for Spanish/Basque tapas is set extremely high, and ultimately, Piperade failed to wow me.
author: Deb I.

description: Great atmosphere, great food. I enjoyed the intimate, sophisticated feel of the place. It was quiet enough that I could actually hear my dinner companions, but still lively and fun. I had the asparagus appetizer and the chicken entree with chick peas. Others had the garlic soup and the sea bass. We shared the beignet dessert. Everything was excellent.
author: Andrew L.

description:
The best Basque food may be in America may be in Boise, but the best in San Francisco is Piperade.

I dined here for dinner with several others and we were all impressed with the food.

To start, I had a bowl of the corn chowder, which was wonderful. It was not too creamy or too watery. I then I had the steak, which was prepared just as I would want it, with some unusual spices that added to the taste.

The atmosphere is cool as well. It is dark, friendly, and has a sophisticated flair to the room.

It is in the Jackson Square area. So, in the evening, there should be street parking or a lot.

It is great for a special occasion, small to medium groups, as well as delicious food.
author: Christopher W.

description:
You might as well walk another block to the Il Fornaio cafe, which is just as disorganized but the staff are friendly, and they seldom run out of anything. The alley folks are primarily notable for their rudeness and lack of enough change to get through the lunch rush.

I do find myself there sometimes when I am feeling uber-lazy, but usually end up picking bad lettuce out of the salad and lamenting later on twitter that I have been weak and eaten "alley food" again. They get 1 star for convenience and 1 star for pretty good food - I do wish they'd figure out that friendly service would get them a lot further.
author: Cyn S.

description:
Great meal here, with Rob D. actually, who reviewed earlier below.

Room is really something special, warm lighting and rich textures everywhere. Great service from the moment we arrived.

We did Tapas and wine, all of it was very good. Cheese plate and Serrano ham are a must, as was the white beans with anchovies and the garlic soup. Solid wine list with emphasis on the obscure, finished with a nice Muscat.

This is just a great restaurant, food, decor and service all A's.
author: Michael T.

description:
4.5 Stars

My husband & I ate here early on a Tuesday night, but by the time we left, the restaurant was packed!  We were also by far, the youngest couple there!

The food & the service was excellent.  We started out splitting the haricots verts with figs & walnuts salad, which was light & refreshing.  My husband got the halibut while I tried the duck.  Both were delectable.  It's really hard to not overcook duck, but my dish was moist & not overpowered by the cherries.  We wrapped up by splitting the apple tart with vanilla ice cream, which I'm sure is not a traditional Basque dessert.  If it wouldn't have been completely inappropriate, we would have licked our dishes clean!

Bonus points for splitting the appetizer & dessert for us before they came out (we didn't request it) & for not charging us extra for splitting items.  Also, we were charged for two appetizers instead of one & our server quickly corrected that as well.

Definitely on my list of restaurants to revisit in the near future!
author: Jenny M.

description:
I love the Basque countrry, and Piperade is Basque and I love Piperade. My expectations are high and M. Hirigoyen does not disappoint. It has a great unified mood -- the layout, lighting, bar, menu, service all just seem to work together. I was looking for a place to take the wife to dinner and called about 5 nice places. Piperade won for the most professional reservation line. (Cortez, you're last). 

The vibe is international, if not Basque -- our hostess was Brazilian and the waiter Polish -- but it worked. Delicious starter of salt cod followed by exquisite lamb and a toothsome Irouleguy red. 

But what it's really about is the consistent experience from start to finish we were treated consistently and well. And that's what a nice dinner out is all about.
author: jim b.

description:
alright alright.

so i guess i better update my review.

i used to HATE this place and avoid it at all cost, but now i find myself there almost every day.

the service and food has gotten IMMENSELY better. the regular employees here are always super nice and attentive and get me in and out pretty quick. no longer is there the rude chick that works there and it makes me SUPER happy. 

i usually get the fiesta salad, but all of them are SUPER SUPER good!

yay, alley coffee!
author: Ameigh F.

description:
We ate at the humungo communal table :)  Love the dining room and vibe -- very quaint. 

Try try try try the SEAFOOD STEW!!  @_@  So good it makes my eyes pop!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I love this place.  

Been once--loved it--been wanting to return for 2 years and the cute husband surprised me for my bday.  

And what a happy birthday it was!  
Happy garlic soup with rock shrimp, bacon, bread and egg-day to me!  
Happy foie gras with quince paste-day to me!  
Happy roasted pork tenderloin confit with braised cabbage and figs-day to me!  
Happy gateau basque cakeday to me!

Ahhhh... my new favorite restaurant with my favorite husband, great way to start my new year.
author: Allison V.

description:
Named after their signature dish, this restaurant provides a sophisticated take on the more rustic style of Basque food. The room's interior was appealing - lots of wood and brick - and the low ceiling had subtle sound-deadening materials that enhanced conversation at the table. After a few minutes wait, we were quickly seated and
attended to by a pleasant waitress.

Appetizer: a selection of four cheeses, with two of them having Spanish origins. However, the best were the creamy French-styled brie and the mild blue from Oregon.

Main course: lamb chop, lamb sausage with grilled fennel and roasted new potatoes. Lamb chop was quite good, but nothing spectacular; the accompanying sausage contained paprika and other spices, but tasted more like mutton than lamb; fennel was a nice side, as were the small new potatoes.

Beer: instead of wine I chose a Stella Artois draft beer, for a change, and enjoyed this pilsener.

Service: good throughout the evening.

Parking: plentiful street parking available, as the commercial area is largely deserted at night.

Overall, an interesting restaurant that offers an unusual menu based on a classic cuisine, in an inviting atmosphere.
author: Keith L.

description:
Must order: 
- artisan foie gras sauteed with Monterey squid, grapes and verjus
- bistro steak w/ caramelized shallots, gascon fries and portobellos

* they also had a special duck confit which was equally superb
author: Katie K.

description: Great service, great atmosphere, great food.  Came here for a business lunch, and everyone was blown away.  Make sure you get the seasonal mushroom tartlet with thyme and garlic.  Do not miss out on this.  I got the sole with spinach-- it was tender and perfectly flaky.  A couple of my colleagues had the basque burger with caramelized onions and said it was one of the best burgers they'd ever had.  That's saying something.  Keep doing what you do, Piperade.  Next time, I want to try dinner!
author: Alice Y.

description: Going through the reviews after eating here I am convinced the 4 star rating is due to a bunch of "plants" fake reviews from people associated with the restaurant. Service- sucked. Once our waiter found out we had a travel zoo voucher, with a mandatory gratuity we barely saw him. My water glass was constantly empty and we were forced to stay about 20 min longer than I wanted to BC I couldn't track him down to deliver the check. Food- meh. Stuffed pepper was good. Really good. The Dungeness crab was weird. Tasted more like tuna. Entrees were just bad. New York steak was super chewy. Only ate half. My salmon was undercooked and over buttered. Barely touched it. I didn't even have the energy to complain. It was so damn hot in there and they sat us under some kind of goddamn flood light. I was sweating like a hooker in church. The saving grace and only thing from keeping this above zero stars...the deserts. I had apple tart. Friggin bomb. My gf got the chocolate cake. Really good too. Either way, glad I tried this place. Because I was always curious and now I know to stay far away. The price is too high. The food and service too crappy to ever consider going back. Much better basque influenced restaurants within walking distance.
author: Sean K.

description: Lamb chops and fried goat cheese were unreal.
author: Dan K.

description:
Their Foie Gras sauteed with grapes, squid, etc is perfect.  This and a little Sauternes can save your soul... or perhaps damn it.

I can recommend many things on the menu but if you can take the hedonism then you must try this dish above all the others.

There is something that makes me wonder if gluttony really is a sin when I eat good foie gras.  There's a depth of depravity that adds the perfect depth and rich taste to this  slippery toe tingling evil meat.  Then the grapes burst in your mouth and the squid resists ever so slightly in your teeth, you have put one more brick in the road to food fetish hell.

I have cravings in the dead of night for Piperade's take on this dish, in all its richness and sweet glory.  I may be damned but I don't care.

*
Piperade is consistent, a little loud in that nice SF everyone talking at once over food and wine sort of way.  Great service, interesting shape to the space.  There is something that feels like trend here and something that keeps me from utterly relaxing, so 4 stars. But don't let that or thoughts of angry geese keep you away forever.
author: ChubbyBunny I.

description:
This Basque restaurant is a treat, and it makes me miss the food in San Francisco big time.  The restaurant is elegantly decorated with lots of dark wood.  The tapas were all very creative -- we had the warm sheep milk's cheese and ham terrine with aged sherry, as well as the house-cured bacalao (cod) with oyster tartare and lemon creme fraiche.  I had the seared lamb chops with lamb sausage, potatoes, and something else dreamy.  All of the food was paired with a restrained and elegant 2006 Syrah from Copain.  Dessert was the lemon curd with warm cherries.  The food was elegantly plated, the service was impeccable, and although this is certainly a treat, it won't entirely break the bank.

A certain destination when I come back to SF.
author: Rachel S.

description: Great food. Pricey but I left feeling satisfied. The staff didn't know much about the wines on the list, though. I would recommend the seafood stew. Delicious!
author: Bonnie G.

description:
Although certainly not the least expensive Basque/Spanish/Tapas place in town, definitely worth a try!

We had the goat cheese stuffed peppers- Amazing!
The dungeonous crab salad is one of the better ones in town!
While the Calamari were good and had a strong flavor of capers, the serving seemed quite small- try La Ciccia- perfection!

The entrees were good, but both seemed like the vegetables were overcooked and had lost some of their zest.
Piperade- Serrano ham with peppers and mixed veggies- good, but not worth a special trip.
Cod with Fennel and vegetables- More noteable, although the fennel was overcooked and had lost it's unique flavor and texture.

Drinks were STRONG!

Dessert- Gateau Basque was worth the trip alone- excellent!

Service was a little slow at times, and I did get a glass of sour sherry, which was replaced with a better one afterwards... some time later... Pet peeves.

All in all a great experience, although clearly the best value is the entree prix fixe with soup, salad and dessert for under $40, our meal was easily twice that per person by the time we were out the door.
author: J B.

description:
An interesting twist to basque...had some great flavors to the crab salad and their chicken was quite good but for some reason the fish had some trouble being cooked right.  I think it was too thick that they either didn't want to overcook but it ended up being undercooked 2 times...but the chef was definitely nice to come out and make sure everything was fine and even gave us some fries to eat while waiting for our fish to be cooked again.  For those of you who enjoy mingling with others, they have a communal table where you can share experiences or if you are adventurous share some food....; P

C u at the next tables......
author: Mee-stique K.

description: Elegant but down to earth. Great food but on the high end of pricing. Worth it though. Treat yourself and any out of town guest. Good times. Pleasant people working there too.
author: Mark R.

description:
The food here was outstanding and the prices seemed extremely reasonable for the food and atmosphere quality.  Still, it seemed like something was off about our meal.  

The group I was with ordered several dishes to share and asked for them to be brought out as they were ready (instead of specifically asking for one or two at a time).  Fifteen minutes after we ordered they brought out all seven of the dishes at the same time--leaving the table extremely crowded and making it difficult to pace ourselves when eating the food (since several of the dishes started getting cold as they sat there).  Even if the food all took the exact same amount of time to cook, it seemed like a poor decision by our server, the kitchen, or whoever makes those decisions, to not spread it out a little bit.   

If my review were divided, it would have three stars for service and five for the food and atmosphere.
author: Katie S.

description:
I've never dined inside, but have too often frequented the take out window in the "alley". I recommend the Mandarin Orange Chicken Salad w/ Avacado and Pecans. Its just the right size for lunch, but still leaves room for one of their amazing, extra-large cookies. I devoured a chocolate chip with some kind of cherry flavoring mixed in...

Update: the chicken quesadillas aren't bad either, especially with the guacamole...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Being vegetarian, a Basque restaurant is not my top choice.  But I'll tell ya... I really enjoyed Piperade.  I got the goat cheese stuffed pepper appetizer.  It was delicious.  The warm cheese had pine nuts in it, and raisins sprinkled on top.  Wonderful.  I also got a vegetable plate which was also very good.  Then, the most important part, dessert.  If you like hazelnut, get the chocolate hazelnut rocher.  It has a crispy bottom layer and to quote my husband, "it's like a glorified Nestle's Crunch bar".  It was sooooooo good.

Two people in my party got the salmon and devoured it.  So, I assume that was good!

The service was great.  Everyone was warm and friendly.

The restaurant has a nice, rustic decor.  

Unfortunately, I think because of its location, it got quiet by 10:30.  So this is definitely just a dinner spot, then move on.
author: Elena I.

description:
I am giving this place three stars as I think the food is great, however I think that the place is 50/50 on service.  I say 50/50 as there are two people who work the window.  One individual, the tall guy (don't know his name) is always friendly and asks how my day is going and gives great service.  The other individual, I think her name Star is not a "star" at all.  She is very rude when you ask her questions about something on the menu and I always feel like she is in a bad mood.  She is only nice to customers that she wants to be nice to.

I highly recommend this place for lunch and I really like the food, especially some of the newer items (Cuban, black and blue sandwiches) and the soups are great.  I just try and get in and out quickly because of the 50% chance I might experience bad service.
author: Kathy S.

description:
Piperade is one of the first restaurants I went to after moving here in 2005 and it remains one of my favorites.  The interior is upscale yet warm and cozy - love the classic warm tones and white tableclothes.  The service has been impeccable during every visit, which is a huge plus!!  No attitude here, even when you arrive by bike, sweaty with your bike helmet accidently crashing into a table when you walk in.  Not that that was me... 

Oh god, and the FOOD.  My favorites include the goat cheese stuffed piquillo peppers, the braised shellfish stew, lobster and ANY of the fish dishes (steamed pacific snapper and monkfish were amazing).  The mussel and bread salad is the only dish that was a bit underwhelming, but everything else is fantastic. The location is not extremely convenient for anyone who doesn't live/work near downtown, but it's certainly worth going out of your way.
author: Leona K.

description:
I really enjoyed this place but felt that the food was a tad overpriced.  For two of us with wine and three courses the bill was way over 170 dollars.
We had a great waiter (turns out he was from Holland and was familiar with our favorite microbrewry bar there  the Arensnest)
I loved my first course the goat cheesed filled peppers with golden raisins and pine nuts and my main of Piperade was good.  My husband had the expensive squid in its own ink dish and then my dessert was great   but way overpriced....eight dollars for dessert.   anyhow the area was depressing, lots of for rent signs all over the jackson square area and it seemed that the economy is not doing so well there now that Myth has  closed.  Area was really dead.
author: Susanne C.

description:
YUM!! first of all, their olive oil!! is SO delicious! where did they get their olive oil? I had so much bread that I was stuffed before my entree.

3 girls shared 2 appetizers and 2 entrees.  Portions for appetizers are small (~$14/dish), entrees are normal ($20-30/dish).  For appetizers, we had dungeness crab (shredded crab meat with basil, chopped peppers, mango) and Piquillos peppers (stuffed with goat cheese, pine nuts, raisins), which were EXCELLENT.  Full of flavor! Entrees were not as impressive, though - we had chicken (with crushed pistachios on top, and mushrooms on the side) and rockfish laid on spinach bed. Chicken was rather dry.  Fish was very tender, but flavor was nothing special.
