I recommend getting a bunch of appetizers to share instead of getting entrees.  Oh, their pomme frites are very good, too.  The whole meal came out to be ~$30pp, which isn't bad at all.  Cute cozy decor, slightly older crowd tonight.  I'd definitely come back here again.
author: Jen K.

description:
I'm so glad that I got to eat here.  All the food was amazingly good.  I came here for dinner and got a wild mushroom open faced pie, duck with a huckleberry sauce, and a gateau basque with preserved cherrys.  All if the fool had just the right amount of flavor and it was very pleasing and pretty light.  I highly recommend the wild mushroom pie for an appetizer.

Be sure to make reservations in advance (meaning at least a day before) unless you don't mind eating before 6 or after 8.  Parking is very easy to find and is deceptive if you think the restaurant will be empty because of easy parking.

All in all, I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Randall H.

description:
Came here on a Friday night with a group of six.  We started off with several appetizers including some sheep cheese and ham, foie gras, and some other pizzete dish with olives, mangoes, and red peppers.  Everything was very tasty.  

We ordered some red wine (don't know much about wines), but the wine selectiion seems to be very good.  Went well with the new york steak I ordered.  The steak itself was very good, cooked with carmalized onions on top, which added a lot of flavor, the portabello mushrooms on the side were also very good.  For dessert, I got the kefir cheese yogurt with asian pear and honey.  This was the best part of the meal, slightly tart and cheesy, and good with my coffee.  Oh yeah, the atmosphere is very relaxed and cozy.  Very nice setting.  Pricey, but overall recommended.
author: J T.

description:
We had the best meal here!  The service was attentive without being intrusive and our waiter was funny and wry.  But the food, oh the food.  Really sublime! Each dish was composed of complementary flavors and textures and colors; the execution of every dish we had was beautiful. I savored every bite.
I also love the atmosphere, the low ceiling and open room.  It feels intimate, but not loud.  This was a completely satisfying meal on every level.
author: Sio O.

description: I took my fiancé there for her birthday dinner with a group of friends.  We had a great time and really enjoyed our food.  I had the lamb shanks, she had the duck, another friend had the salmon, and another the piperade.  My biggest surprise was the quality of the wine list and how well our waiter recommended wines for each dish.  He was spot on!  Our table was ready right when we got there, service was excellent and never "on top of us", but always available and well timed.  They brought out a candle with desert and of course our waiter was French so my fiancé got to chat with him as she is fluent.  The only knock is that it's a bit pricey for what it is compared to other SF locales.  But all in all well worthwhile with interesting and well prepared dishes.
author: Sam S.

description:
I noticed Piperade on one of my routine trips to Houston's, and sat at the bar to give it a shot.
The restaurant is spacious, the bartenders pour great drinks and everything I tried on the menu was outstanding. 
The chicken was cooked perfectly, moist and well seasoned. 
The lamb chop was the I best ever tasted.
My only complaint was that the 'small plates' menu was not that interesting.
author: Jason N.

description:
Fantastic Basque food, great (and VERY reasonable) wine list, good atmosphere. Great place.
Read my full review at: http://sibilous.blogspot.com/2004_03_01_sibilous_archive.html#107914512908325276
author: Don H.

description:
When I eventually found this intimate spot - there's NOTHING going on in this part of town except the sound of your footsteps and the occasional tumbling of weeds - I really enjoyed my night. Piperade has a really nice ambience - check out the cool bottle chandelier in the center of the room, the cozy lighting and the bar that is oh so worth bellying up to. My fellow diner started with a lemon drop martini, perfectly poured and oh so pretty; I opted for a greyhound, stiff but not unreasonably so. 

Dinner itself was pretty durn tasty. I began with a dungeness crab and mango salad concoction which was superb - appropriately fishy, succulent, not overly rich thanks to the mango's fruity acidity. My buddy opted for whole prawns with garlic, parsley and lemon, which was truly epic in its portion size. There must have been 7 or 8 of the suckers lined up on the plate. I would have been quite happy with those two apps and dessert to be honest. 

We both had fish dishes for mains. I was a little disappointed in mine - I don't recall what kind of fish it was, but it was about the same size as my app, overpowering cumin and served with a vegetable that just didn't do anything for it. My friend had the sea bass, on the other hand, which was pretty wondrous.

The most interesting thing about the experience was that the waiter actively steered us away from a more expensive wine to a lighter pinot after we had ordered our food, because he felt the wine we'd picked out might overpower the cuisine. I thought that was quite refreshing. 

I would definitely dine here again - prices were reasonable and overall the experience was quite pleasant. I'd just steer clear of anything too cumin-laden (and that's coming from a cumin lover, so be warned...)
author: Leela S.

description:
I LOVE getting lunch here. The food is excellent, there's always a few people in line (but not too many), and the folks behind the counter are nice. Plus, if you've got a book or a friend with you, you can go sit out at Levi's Plaza and just chill while you eat. 

While I've only had about 3 or 4 of the items they serve, everything that I see coming from behind the counter looks and smells great. Personally, I recommend (in the this order) the Turkey and Brie, the Chicken and Avocado, and the Ham and Cheese. I think I'm pretty dead-on with my choices too... because that seems to be the order in which they run out of these items.

Which alas, brings me to why I can only give Piperade To-Go three stars. If you don' t get there early, there's a pretty good chance you aren't going to get your top choice. I consider myself lucky to get there when they still have Turkey and Brie, the only reason I've tried the Ham and Cheese is because they ran out of my top two choices, and today when I got there at 1:30, I was met with, "We only have soup." 

I'm sure there is a well-constructed supply and demand reason for all this. And I'll keep going back because I do love the lunch. But I don' t know - maybe I'm just old-fashioned - I always thought "having the food" was sort of a basic principle in the lunch biz...
author: Ben R.

description:
Awesome awesome! from the minute we got there , celebrating my son 's birthday, and is complicated,we enjoy all our dishes ,simply esquisite,the calamari oulala!!and the lamb chop,and everything....
Thank you ,thank you what a great meal
Sebastien Oxner
author: jean sebastien o.

description:
3.5 stars

Tried the garlic soup - I have to say, I wasn't completely blown away. I thought it was just ok.

The goods: Cocktails, stuffed piquillo peppers and braised seafood stew.

The just oks: Saffron seafood stew (it was the Friday Basque classic dish - forgot the exact name) and service. Perhaps it was bc my girlfriend and I can look young at times (which, believe me, I am NOT complaining about - I'd rather get carded than not), but it was a trial to actually flag the waiter down and be served...whereas our neighbors did not have the same problem at. all.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
I don't mean to exaggerate but I have never had a bad meal here.  Of course, that being said, my next meal there will be less than stellar eh??  DANG!!! But I have to tell the truth!!!

I just went there a few weeks ago and was a little upset that my favorite garlic prawns are no longer on the menu.  However, I did find many new dishes that would take its place.   Chef Gerard really knows how to handle seafood.  You will rarely go wrong with his fish dishes but don't limit yourself to that.  He REALLY knows how to make an amazing melt in your mouth Daube (aka stew).  The last time I was there, the lamb chops were perfectly seasoned and perfectly seared and just oooooh... sooooooo... gooooood!

As for the desserts - you cannot go wrong with the apricot and almond tart, cornmeal cake with fruit, and orange blossom beignets (for a great fried kick!).
author: H. Q.

description:
Definitely one of the best meals I've had in SF!

I'm not an expert on Basque cuisine by any means, so I can't comment on authenticity. But I am a lover of a great meal and a great dining experience, from which Piperade excelled on both.

Super friendly waiter, nice ambiance and amazing food. What else could you ask for? Also plus points for being in an easy to park area on the weekends.
author: Jon N.

description:
Truly a wonderful experience.

I was lucky enough to be invited by one of the chefs to dine here and I was assured that I would not be disappointed.

I absolutely love, love, love the lamb dishes here.  The crab cake is tasty and does not include an overwhelming amount of fillers (breadcrumbs) that other establishments seem to put in their crab cakes.  

The atmosphere is warm and intimate.

I would definitely recommend this place to celebrate any special occasion with your significant other.
author: Curt L.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant. I've been here at least five times, with parties from 2 to 10 people, and the service has always been perfect and the food has always been excellent. 

Last night, we had a perfect dinner. For apps: an excellent tomato tartlet and yummy piquillo peppers. For entrees, we had the awesome duck, the awesome halibut, and the excellent pork. Even the fries are good, skinny and crisp. For dessert, the aromatic orange blossom beignets are my favorite and the turron cake is hubby's favorite. 

We've always found street parking easily. I wouldn't feel comfortable here in less than business casual, but I have seen plenty of people dressed more casually than that. They also have an excellent wine list (I recommend the Miura pinot for those of you that are clueless).
author: Marina N.

description:
FOOD: THREE STARS (* * *)
While I generally enjoyed such appetizers as the cheese plate, piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese and the butter lettuce salad with herbs, I was slightly disappointed with the halibut.  I found it to be cooked well, with a slight crust on the outside and a rich flavor throughout, however I felt the portion to be very small for $26, and I found the presentation to be lacking (general mish-mash of beige and white with some afterthought peas thrown on top for whatever reason).  It came with artichokes, which were a decent complement, but also with a slew of runny hazelnut butter sauce and peas (like we ate when we were children), which I felt degraded the meal.  As for the dessert, the caramel custard was perfect, with an excellent portion size and a perfect sweetness without being over-the-top.

ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS (* * *)
The restaurant is beautiful and the chandelier made of bottles was rustic without being too kitschy.  The noise level was perfect for a business dinner or date, and overall the experience struck the perfect balance between romance/formal and relaxed/casual.  The bathroom was adequate for a restaurant of this caliber.  I found the service to be generally good and consistent, but it did sometimes border on pretentious--one instance of requesting a few extra spoons for the appetizers was met with "you have spoons on your table."  Tsk tsk.

VALUE: TWO STARS (* * *)
I found it to be overpriced, certainly for the entrees (ranging from about $17 to the steak at $30), considering the portion sizes.  The appetizers were also slightly expensive given their sizes and lack of culinary sophistication (butter lettuce salad, anyone?).  Their prices ranged from $8 to $16.  All desserts were $8, and well worth it, given their taste and presentation.

Average of
FOOD: THREE STARS
ENVIRONMENT/SERVICE: THREE STARS
VALUE: THREE STARS
================
AVERAGED GRAND TOTAL: THREE STARS

Would I recommend it to others?
No.  For the money, I feel you can certainly get better food elsewhere in the city.  If you need an easy client dinner spot and this is close by, go for it, you won't be disappointed, but you will not "thrill the pants" off of anyone, either.

Would I return?
No.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Great experience here. we had a group of 9 so they gave us this huge round table in the middle of the room with sweet cushy chairs. service was on the ball with getting drink orders, wine bottles and food orders. I didnt feel like we waited at all. 
the food was great too! we had a bunch of garlic soups, goat cheese stuffed pequillo peppers and calamari, all of which were great!
i had the snapper entree which was delicious and tasted the duck confit and lamb dishes, which were winners too! 
great ambiance, great service, great food, check this place out
author: Rich B.

description: I went to Piperade last year for my former company's holiday party and the food was fantastic. It was my first time trying Basque cuisine. We ate everything family style which is always fun. The calamari was amazing and so was the sea bass. They have plenty of great apps too.
author: Michael C.

description:
We recently had a fantastic meal at Piperade. Every dish made me more and more happy. The wine list had an excellent selection of interesting wines in all price ranges. The service was spot on and unassuming.

I will certainly be going back to this restaurant and would recommend it to anyone wanting to discover Basque cuisine.
author: Rachel B.

description: I had a really delicious lunch here today, starting with a pile of fresh butter lettuce and herbs, then a rich, plentiful seafood stew, and finishing off with orange blossom beignets / coffee. The service was excellent as well. I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a more upscale dining experience in this part of town.
author: Sebastian T.

description:
Wow. The Cobb Salad is one of the best I've ever had! Loaded with goodness: cubes of turkey, crumbled blue cheese, avocado, lots of bacon with a side of amazing ranch sauce. Also had a bite of the Mandarin Chicken Avocado Salad which was equally tasty. I love the fact that it's just a window in the back of an alley - way to cut down costs but still remain fresh/cute/popular. 

Great lunch spot!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Used to love this place.  Kitchen has gotten careless.  Several courses so  much salt as to be inedible - and I tend to like salt.  Service lackluster.
author: Lucille D.

description: a meal the other night hit all the right notes. Each dish was well prepared, served well, with gracious care by a kind woman. Not one thing was off. Especially good were the calamari, the lamb and the turron!
author: D L.

description:
My roommate and I ate there on 7/13/06. Excellent food! But, the wait was BAD.

We started with the piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese topped with mango salsa and also split the crab salad txangurro with apple and curry. For our entrees we split the duck confit which came with tasty lentils and was a daily special and the marinated lamb chops with thyme. We pretty much scraped each plate clean. Dessert was orange blossom beignets, very different...the orange blossom was very fragrant in taste if that makes sense, at times overpowering, but still very good.

We arrived early for our 7:30 reservation, but were not seated until close to 8. It would have been nice to receive a complimentary appetizer or glass of wine for our wait, but we were given nothing. Those types of things can easily erase a sour taste in my mouth (figuratively, not literally). 

So, all in all, I LOVED Piperade's food, but they should have been a little more accomodating for making us wait. I definitely understand they can't control how long an earlier party decides to stay, but some concessions should be made.
author: Dariana R.

description:
The BF took me here for my birthday and we had a grand old time. The waiter recommended a great (and surprisingly inexpensive) bottle of wine, and the rest of the service was generally good.

Our appetizers and main courses were fab. The the goat cheese stuffed piquillo peppers were particularly memorable.

My only complaint was the desert - stone cold apple tart with a very chewy crust. Not up to par with the rest of the experience - but hey, I did get a birthday candle and a little sing song.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
I think this would be a great place for anyone who enjoys meat and seafood, but for the vegetarians out there, there isn't much fare. 

Literally.

But the appetizer selection is reasonable and the cheeses are all imported. You can definitely try some interesting cheeses that come from Spain that aren't usually available even in gourmet markets.

Just as a note, I don't know if this is the case with other people's experiences, but the waitress didn't really "wait" on us, and she wasn't attentive at all.
author: G J J.

description: I've been meaning to write this review for a while, and what I want to say hasn't changed. I love this restaurant. The food is delicious and I believe it is a very clever combination of Basque style cooking blended into the Northern California marketplace. The wine list gives nice weight to Spain and there are interesting choices from the Basque region which to me is de rigueur when eating here. Another major plus is that many members of the service staff have been there for a long time and that is a true sign of a well run establishment. Bonus: parking at night in the neighborhood is generally easy!
author: David S.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner with some friends. We had:

SEAFOOD STEW-YUMMO!! especially good with their bread
LAMB- juicy and tender
DUCK- cooked pretty well

Lastly, my boyfriend bought a fruit tart from La Farine to the restaurant and the box opening fee was a whopping $24.00 friggin dollars. That's more that the tart itself ($22.00)!!! This is one reason why I only gave this place 3 stars. The other is that  portion sizes were a tad on the small side...=( and it's not like i'm a big girl either....haha
author: Irene L.

description:
Piperade is my favorite restaurant in the city.  It is elegant but not pretentious.  Classy but not stuffy.  An all-around delightful experience that I like to share with family or close friends on special occasions.  

The wine list is excellent, and becomes even better with a recommendation from your server.  The food is just...delicious.  From stuffed piquillo peppers to manchego gratin to the apple tartlet - I was in heaven.  I love the classic yet rustic decor, and the overall feeling that not only are you having an enjoyable time dining, but so is everyone around you.  

Piperade is what its all about.  Five stars.
author: Kristin K.

description:
So first up - I've had some good dinners here before, but nothing memorable, I personally think they are too expensive for the food they serve.

Had to take some friends from out of town out last night, and since they are right by my office, why not? Rainy Monday night, friend with in-laws in tow... seemed like a great idea. 

Food was ok, no one said anything bad about the food, but then again no one said anything great about it either. I personally have had much better duck (NOPA, but be warned, they will skew your duck experience forever). 

The real kicker was when it came to paying for our food - and we divvied up the bill and I was signing for my share - our lovely waiter noticed I hadn't included a tip. As I was about to sign my copy, he loudly proclaims (while tapping my check with his finger) "Service is NOT included". 

Now, I know its not easy being a waiter, but doing something like that, totally uncalled for. Especially since I then had to explain to him that someone else was leaving the tip for the whole table on his check. 

Mortified. Definitely not coming back. Never been treated so poorly at any restaurant in my life.
author: Jane H.

description:
This restaurant is located across the street from my wife's office and around the corner from a friend's.  When we planned an after work get-together, this seemed like the obvious choice.

We also wanted to go on a Spanish food hiatus in advance of our trip to Spain (lunch at El Bulli) in August.  This place seemed like it would offer up a great last meal, and they did not disappoint.  I'm more accustomed to tapas, so the bulk of the menu was uncharted territory for me.  Strap in for the post-mortem on our meal.

The table started with the cold foie gras.  It was served with salt, pepper and a compote of fruit (quince?).  This is a simple but delicious dish that wouldn't be well served by a more complicated preparation.

My wife had the piperade, a thick soup akin to French Onion Soup, but based on red peppers.   There's also some serrano ham & perfectly poached egg thrown in for good measure, and it is, again, simple but delicious. I had the Thursday special which was a confit of duck leg served over green lentils.  Again, this is a simple dish that is as rich and textured as you would want it to be without obscuring the umami.

The table also shared an order of fries that I regretted ordering as they were not done to my taste.  They were cut larger than I prefer and rather bland.  We also shared 2 desserts, but they were unremarkable.

The service was fine - nothing stood out good or bad.  In hindsight, I think that this is probably a very good thing.  The wine list is impressive.  We frequent a number of tapas places in the city and I know most of the reds that are in the rotation.  Piperade didn't have any of the usual suspects and it was fun to get acquainted with something new.

Parking is relatively easy on Battery, and if you don't find a spot there's a lot a block away on Embarcadero.
author: Michael F.

description:
Just thinking about Piperade makes me smile. I have been here several times and it is the one restaurant in memory that I can say has surpassed my expectations every single time. Their stuffed piquillo pepper appetizer is phenomenal and I could probably eat it every day without my love for it ever diminishing. Their entrees have always been exceptional- simply prepared and perfect. Our last meal there ended with a superb orange blossom beignet dessert that I've been craving ever since. 

I have always been happy with the service. The wait staff probably errs on leaving you alone more than some may be comfortable with, but I'm rather easily irritated by waiters who are constantly asking if I need anything. The decor is rustic and welcoming and exactly the kind of space that makes eating enjoyable.

I will certainly return here again with high expectations. One of my favorite simple restaurants in the city.
author: Sarah K.

description:
A must go and go back place!

Missing the most its turron mousse cake with roasted almond! A most delicious chewy nougat cake!!

Of course, its garlic soup, asparagus salad, warm cheese milk salad ( a baked cheese) and its Piperade with sauteed Serrano ham and poached egg (stewed pepper, onion slices in light tomato sauce).  Delicious and healthy!

Interior design has a NY feel (wood ceiling, brick wall, patio), atmosphere is good and the waiter (could be the same dutchman) service is great as well!
author: Ile F.

description: I had the extreme pleasure of dining here with a small group and had the food experience of the year.  This place is amazing, anything on the menu will blow your mind.  This is definitely a special occasion restaurant, take your out of towners here for a fancy, classy meal or treat yourself evey so often.  If you haven't Piperaded, then you truly haven't lived.
author: April C.

description:
Well, I gave up entrees for New Years 2006 (because I find them boring. Appetizers rule.) so I can't comment on the restaurant from that perspective, but I *CAN* say that the ham and cheese terrine is just about the best thing I've ever eaten.  Get one of your own, because food that good is guarenteed to ruin a relationship.

I vote it best appetizer in San Francisco.  Except for the Poketini at Roy's.  And the steak tartare at Bix.  Ok, they all rock.  Why on earth do people eat entrees?
author: Ioanna S.

description:
Great wine bottle chandelier in the middle of the room!

Piquillo Peppers.... fabulous!
Calamari..... fablous!
Mushroom pie.... good.
Lamb... fabulous, fabulous, fabulous!  
(OK, I admit, I almost chewed the meat off the bone... then I remembered that I was sitting in a nice restaurant... whew, caught myself)

My friends and I dined here for a birthday celebration.  We haven't had such good food and laughs in a long time.
author: Grace S.

description: Unfortunately, I was called "sweetie" three times by the cashier today and this is just not forgivable. Also, the menu is pretty limited and about half of it is cold, pre-made sandwiches. My favorites are the Mr. Williams (chicken sandwich) and the turkey brie and cranberry, both of which come with a wee salad inside the box.
author: Polina F.

description: Fantastic.  Very cozy place with great food that's not to heavy.  very fair price as well.
author: Matt B.

description:
I grew up eating Basque cuisine, and I don't know, Piperade didn't really fit the bill of what I had been expecting. 

Basque restaurants are kind of hard to find, so I was excited about Piperade! I had been expecting a foodie's delight, more of a familial cuisine and environment (larger portions, moms, kids, grandmas, etc.), agricultural atmosphere (because Basque people are that way! My family's favorite Basque restaurant was in Chino, CA- cow country!). I wasn't expecting something cheap- a hamburger heaven, or a place with coloring menus for kids, but I was thinking it would be a little different. 

Piperade had good food, but the experience was rather unmemorable, and was not the Basque restaurant I had wanted so desperately to replicate in San Francisco.

My BF has a seafood AND nut allergy and he was limited to 2 items on their menu (other than salad)... who wants to go to a Basque restaurant and eat salad? I got the lamb, he got the steak and fries. (safe and boring, but he had no other choice.) 

I'd seen Piperade on "Check Please Bay Area" and had been dying to go, and it was awhile before I could get a reservation. In fact, despite our reservation, we ended up standing, waiting. I can comment that that fact was a little awkward because they do not have a foyer or waiting area. They had an extensive wine list, and the place itself was very beautiful with its wooden beams and large windows, but in a location that was out of the way from the hustle of Broadway, but close enough.

Though intimate and refined, I still left a bit disappointed. Piperade is part of a group that also includes Bocadillos, so maybe I should try that before I give up on Basque SF. We'll see.
author: Glansande J.

description:
Sorry to write a negative review about a restaurant that used to be one of my favorites.  Dined there last night and while it was good, it has lost some of the edge that put it into the top echelon. First, let's wash the windows. My wife and I sat next to the windows and they had not been cleaned for awhile -- that is always a bad sign.  My lentle soup was luke warm and a relatively small dish for the price. It was good but not as much flavor as I am used to from Piperade -- and it was only warm.  
The service was O.K. but not a lot of enthusiasm -- you like that extra effort. The main waiter is good but looks like he is ready to retire -- too  many nights.  The back up waiter was good but had a personality problem. He had a bad habit of looking the other way when he brought something -- as if he wanted to avoid you like the plague or if you had bad breath or something. The main course was good, it was the sauteed serano ham with a poached egg.  Good but for $20, a bit over priced.  The dessert was excellent. The wine from Northern Spain, white, was excellent, but at $45 was one of the lowest priced on the menu -- so the wines are expensive and no deals. 

Sad part, is we maybe will not return.  Too much competition at better prices. But the truth is we will return because we love this restaurant and have so many great memories.
author: Bill L.

description:
Piperade is quickly become my go-to restaurant for special occassions and entertaining out-of-town visitors. The restaurant itself is beautiful, the food is consistently good, and the staff is wonderful. 

I would highly recommend the goat cheese and ham appetizer. It's a great combination of flavors and has an interesting texture -- it's crispy and sort of melty at the same time. My only complaint is that it wasn't large enough. 

For entrees, you can't go wrong with the steak or the lamb. I hear the seafood is very good but I'm not much of a fish fan. I went here with a friend one evening who ordered the duck at the waitress' recommendation even though he rarely, if ever, likes duck and he thought it was perfect. The meats here are often cooked just right so it's a great place to try new things.
author: Asheley W.

description: I love this place, especially their olive oil.  The olive oil tasted so refreshing, and olivy.  The food was interesting too.  Will be back!!
author: Elena L.

description:
I was impressed with my visit to Piperade! Very low key, relaxing atmosphere (I loved the wine bottle chandelier). They also had quite a simple menu, but I think a place like this focuses on a few dishes just to make sure they're done right.

I settled on an order of the lamb chops, which I really liked, but a lot of other options seemed very appetizing, such as the chicken, duck, and sea bass. If I had a bit more money, I wouldn't mind coming here more often.

Credit to their staff for getting the food out very quickly for a large group (I noticed this since my dinner last night was ungodly slow) and for being very patient in our inability to get orders out quickly/leave the table quickly. Politeness goes a long way in my book!
author: Roland C.

description:
The food is fantastic. I would hesitate to place it in any one food category - A. Basque? B. French? C. Mediterranean? D. None of the above? E.) All of the above? Stunningly simple in preparation, yet incredibly flavorful, Piperade's food is consistently remarkable. Literally, it is worthy of comment.

However - and this is, unfortunately, an emphatic however - the service is often terrible. Not just inefficient or distracted or perhaps new on the job. Downright rude. The last time I was there, the server was so surly that it effected-dominated-ruined our entire table conversation. After all, she virtually threw a glass of wine at a friend of mine who had done nothing more than remind the server when she brought the first round of drinks that one glass, hers, had been forgotten.

I've never experienced anything like it. And I wish I never had, because I still crave the halibut...
author: sarah h.

description: Been going there for years - client lunches and dinners, late glass of wine with girlfriends. When I came across a bloomspot deal - you don't have to ask me twice!:). The restaurant was full for a Tuesday night, I wonder why they even ran that deal...anyway, great food, quick and pleasant service. I would always recommend Piperade.
author: P I.

description:
we came here out of the pouring rain, completely drenched.  five stars for being under a roof.

the french fries here are amazing.  yes, i am not sophisticated.  suck it.

the garlic soup with rock shrimp and bacon was really good.  my dining companion had the split pea soup with blue cheese.  i don't even like blue cheese, but the soup was good.  i used the Acme bread they gave us to sop up the rest of her bowl of soup.  it was pretty awesome because the waitress took one look at her completely clean plate, and said, "bravo!"  the french can even make calling you a pig feel like a compliment!  needless to say, i let the waitress believe that i was the dainty eater of the group.  hehehe.

we had the crab appetizer too, which was good.

service was really good.  atmosphere was nice, although the crowd seemed to be older businessmen?  or something like that...

unfortunately we had a super late dinner, and wasn't terribly hungry, so we didn't have more food, nor did we have dessert.  nevertheless, if our experience that evening is any indication, a full meal there would probably be really good.  i will definitely go back at some point...
author: Miss P.

description: Hosted a special celebration here for 20+ people. Excellent food and service. Waitstaff and employees were all friendly, kind. The separate private party room is both warm and modern with great lighting and natural element effects. Basque reqion wine is showcased, and it was well-paired with the food. The event planner (Stephanie) was very responsive, and I always felt things were in control with her help. The chef/owner came out to met us as we reviewed the menu selections, and he seemed to be present in all good ways the night of the event. We were well taken care of, wined and dined, and it's no exaggeration that EVERY guest raved about the food. This is notable as a few guests are foodies or professionals who've seen a lot of these group events. Most people had the delicious lamb, some the steak, and a few the risotto. The apps were heavenly grilled calamari, the shredded crab, tomatoes, those famous stuffed peppers. All nicely presented. I brought table centerpieces and keepsake items; the staff was great in helping me pack them neatly back before the end of evening.
author: Na m.

description:
Love the cozy, simple, elegant interior and atmosphere, but the food wasn't too impressive. We decided to get a variety of small plates.

- House cured Bacalao: salty, fresh, oysters were good
- Piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese: must be a fan of creamy goat cheese, but not bad
- Wild mushrooms: looked like a mini mushroom pizza, nicely sautéed mushrooms, but the crust wasn't that great tasting
- Calamari: a bit on the rubbery side, too many toppings/flavors going on that didn't quite go well together

Overall, I really liked the atmosphere, but the food was a bit disappointing. Service was excellent. I will probably come back to try their entrees.
author: Linda C.

description:
I've been to Piperade many times and had a great experience each and every time. I've tried much of the menu, lamb chops, piperade, rabbit stew, halibut, garlic soup, ham and sheep's milk cheese terrine, etc and found all of the dishes to be enjoyable, comforting and made with the highest quality ingredients.  From picon punch to caramel "koka" our meals are always excellent.

Both my BF and I have Basque grandparents and both of us have taken our parents here with great results. My father says the piperade reminds him of how his mother made it and my BF's mother who is the toughest critic of all has had nothing but praise for our meals there. Without sounding overly sentimental, my boyfriend and I learn something new about our Basque heritage every time we share a meal with our families here. 

Piperade has a menu that manages to be sophisticated and homey and service that is crisp and professional yet never pretentious. One of my favorites in the city, bar none.
author: stephanie c.

description:
The atmosphere is charming with lots of wood, windows and mellow lighting.  The waiters are very personable and attentive.  The wine was very good.

We started with the Warm sheep's milk and ham terrine.  It was tasty. I had the Bistro steak with caramelized shallots, gascon fries and portobellos for dinner.  The steak was cooked properly (medium rare) and a good texture, but completely flavorless. It tasted like they cooked it with no seasoning at all. The caramelized shallots did not mask the lack of flavor either.  
My date had the Orange blossom beignets for desert and they were fabulous.  If I dine here again, perhaps I will try the small plates.
author: PictureGirl F.

description: This was just the right restaurant for our anniversary dinner which was followed by a short Uber ride to Beach Blanket Babylon. We dressed up for the occasion, and the warm, romantic atmosphere was perfect. We were glad for our reservation but would have been happy to sit at the bar had there been a wait, or on a warmer evening, outside in the comfortable and very inviting sofas in the patio area. Most diners were in elegantly casual attire, others formal, but everyone seemed to be there for a special meal. And that's what we got: excellent, attentive service from a waiter who had a deep knowledge of the wine list and menu, and an imaginative, fresh, beautifully presented dinner. We ordered the seared sea scallop with parsnip purée and shaved apple appetizer as well as the frisée salad with goat cheese stuffed piquillo peppers. Three fat and tender scallops were positively popping with flavor, balanced by the cool and tangy apple. We were tempted to order a second, despite the generous portion. The frisée salad was equally delicious--the goat cheese melted like butter in the warm vinaigrette, in savory contrast to the crunch of the salad. My husband ordered the Duck Confit over braised green lentils for his entree. He found it rich, and artfully prepared--moist and hearty but delicately flavored. I had the fish special--a black cod over a leek and potato "stew." The fish was light and not overpowered by the leeks--crisply seared on top, flaky beneath, but overall this dish was the least impressive and blandest of our selections. I unfortunately couldn't persuade my husband to try a dessert so after much difficulty deciding, I chose the "Dark Chocolate Cake Amatxi". This was definitely the grand finale: warm, moist, dark chocolate cake with dark chocolate garnish and a truly marvelous, tangy creme fraische. We'll be back!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Elegant and exquisite are the first things that come to mind. As one enters you're greeted by a very attentive hostess. The wait staff is friendly and helpful.

The namesake Piperade was mildly spicy but a wonderful contrast of taste with the ham and peppers.

The lamb chop was perfectly cooked. The flavor was sealed in a crisp layer which kept it perfectly juicy. The meat was tender and the sauce had me dipping bread on the plate to get another taste. If you must have only one thing there do yourself a favor and don't miss this masterpiece of culinary art.

Finishing with the incredibly delicious soft "melt in your mouth" Gateau Basque capped off a delightful meal at a place which did not disappoint. Coming from New York I'm not easily impressed by too many restaurants but this place was special.

The quiet atmosphere allows one to carry on a conversation, regardless of whether or not your mouth actually stops craving the food, and the lighting made one feel as if they were able to kick back at any minute. 

Oh and have a reservation because it fills up quick.
author: Chris P.

description: I go every year for my birthday and the food is consistently well prepared, fresh, and presented with panache. I like the stuffed peppers (piquillos) with goat cheese and the great Basque specialties. The service is attentive without being invasive and the atmosphere is great. Everytime my family comes to town, and particularly those who have never been there, join us for a fantastic meal!
author: Else T.

description:
I'm not sure why I had really high expectations for this place but the restaurant and the food just did not meet me there.  

Apps: plate of artisan cheeses - I liked two of the four cheeses (I believe they were the ones from Basque region but definitely not the blue cheese) although the pieces were quite small and the presentation was awful.  Granted cheese is a little odd to present but still.  It looked like four tiny pieces on a big plate.  calamari - Interesting form of calamari.  When I think calamari I think fried and battered squid.  This was not fried and not battered.  In fact it looked like the type of squid I would never really want to eat but did.  It was delicious.  And the best thing on the table I had that day.

Meal: fish - I can't seem to remember which fish dish it was but it had beans and mussels, unfortunately this was partially my fault as I failed to read what else was in the dish and it happened to be two things I don't quite enjoy.  Nonetheless I ate the fish, although I must say that the fish alone was not tasty.  I suppose you should eat it altogether but overall my poor choice did not make me very satisfied.

The restaurant here had an ok ambience.  It was definitely filled and our server did an acceptable job (not too annoying where you just want to be left alone, but never forgot you were there).  I'm not sure if I would ever go back though, I'm too scared that my food choice will leave me disappointed again.
author: Yosie G.

description:
This is our favorite neighborhood restaurant.

Love sitting at the bar for a casual dinner. A small cozy space that's so inviting. My favorite meal is to begin with the butter lettuce salad and the warm piquillo peppers and then move onto the chicken for my entree.  Jonathan keeps the Txakolina flowing.
author: melissa n.

description: Seriously amazing. The lamb chops were so juicy. I love me some lamb. Also, I loved the foie gras. I mean I love any foie gras, but it was particularly amazing. I would go back again and again. Willie Brown was dining there at the same time too! =)
author: Jemma L.

description:
What a disappointment...  My husband and I also had an expired Travel Zoo voucher ($69 for 2 champagne, 2 app, 2 entrees, 2 desserts) that they extended, and the waiter seemed to be fine with it.  I had high expectations with Piperade being so popular for lunch and dinner alike, and rave reviews about the food.  

Waiter brought our champagne right away and took our order once we figured out what we wanted.  Kind of a weird menu, none of it was really blowing up our skirts, but we managed to choose a nice variety that we could share.  The ham and cheese terrine was gross, way too salty.  The endive salad was delish (1 star for that).  Hubby ordered steak medium rare...it was crusty on the outside and raw inside...the waiter was not gracious at all about it and said 'yeah, that's medium rare, guess you want medium' and took it away.  Whatev.  My salmon was amazing (the other star) but a very small portion.  After I had finished my salmon, the new steak arrived and was ok...not the best steak by far (I'd go to Harris' or somewhere else for better).  The desserts were fine, but small, and again were an odd selection that didn't quite hit the spot for us.  We were never asked if we wanted coffee or tea.  Water glasses were filled by host regularly, food was brought out by someone completely different, and dishes taken away quickly by yet again someone different.  Bread and olive oil were yummy.

Again, really disappointing for the price -- even with the voucher they add on another $12 for something (who knows what), regular tax, and an 18% tip, which was not deserved.  I'm a former waitress and a generous tipper, but even 15% would have been pushing it.  For such a high end establishment I expect exemplary service and excellent food...I would NEVER pay full price for anything here.

Oh well, now we know...
author: SFmama O.

description: I guess I am the black sheep here by saying Piperade was "all right". Meaning that I can make these dishes at home. The whole prawns with garlic was weak sauce. The seafood stew was meh. Mousse with almonds tasted like a Trader's Joe boxed dessert. Spanish tapas? Really? Wow.
author: Betty N.

description: This is my 3rd visit to Piperade and I'm a huge fan of the atmosphere.  I love the bar, the lighting and décor, and the service is pretty good.  What I'm having problems with is the food.  Don't get me wrong ,it's fine, but just not great.  I started with the warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine....really salty and the salad it rested on was kinda soggy.  Next I had the Piperade - Serrano ham with a poached egg on top resting on a HEAP of sauteed peppers and onions....way too many.  It was ok and probably my fault for not questioning it before ordering it.  For dessert I had the apple tart....really disappointing...soggy and tasteless.  Here's what really got me at this visit. ..my husband also ordered a three course meal and two of the three items ordered were delivered wrong...completely wrong items.  In addition, when the bill came it too was wrong.....I was exhausted by the time I left after having to call the waiter over to fix all the problems.  Oh, and never an "I'm sorry".  Don't get it.  I will probably go back, but I'm a little disgruntled.
author: Joanna M.

description: We also used the travelzoo coupon and didn't have any problem with the service, the food was fantastic, especially the lamb and steak.  Our only problem was with the really unfriendly bartender, who really looked at you like he wanted you to go away.  I ordered two drinks and before he made them, a lady that obviously knew him, pushed in and asked for a drink and he served her straight away...   but this won't put us off going back as the food is fab.
author: Kat J.

description:
this place was just alright. i came here with my family and each of us found something on the menu to eat, but my sister's soup came cold, the cheese plate was fine, but not all that interesting, and neither my dad nor my fiancee found the piperade stew all that inspiring. however, the mushroom tart appetizer was really good, and my garlic shrimp soup was delicious. 

we probably wouldn't go back though, cause we found that we tried everything on the menu that we were actually interested in eating in one sitting.
author: Whitney G.

description:
Excellent selection of wine and beautiful presentation of food. The waitress was beyond accommodating and knowledgeable in regards to the menu and cooking style. I had the stuffed peppers as my small plate, moving on to the roasted duck for the entree and finishing with the chocolate and hazelnut dessert. The chef, who we commended after the meal, did an excellent job with the flavors and pairing of foods. 

The only negative was the atmosphere, which I found not quite cozy enough. Otherwise, well done!
author: Stephanie J.

description:
The atmosphere and food here are both wonderful.  The lighting and decor are perfection.  The sI like oft brick walls, a common table, and simple white table cloths with Basque colored accents are tasteful.  I like this restaurant for its unique flavors and attention to detail.  I tried a Basque wine here that was admittedly different, but perfect for the food.  I tried to make a version of Gerald Hirogynen's pancetta and egg soup, which was splendid, and my version completely flopped.  I found the recipe in the Chronicle and I have to say, get the real version at the restaurant.  Many times I go to a restaurant and say 'I could make this at home.'  I definitely couldn't make anything here.

The foie gras and the beignets are lovely.

This is an exquisite restaurant that is not overdone, and is an originality in a sea of pan Asia, California cuisine.
author: apple r.

description:
Gerald Hirigoyen is a true chef.  Meaning he checks on the guests, makes sure they're doing okay -- and will let you receive a fax from his upstairs office if asked, as I did.  I also liked the bartender, who without hesitation said, "Don't get the Basque wine" when I asked about it.  I think he said it'll make you go blind or have a headache or a seizure.

The food here is Spanish-like: savory, spicy, with liberal use of red peppers and garlic, which I enjoy.  The wines are big and red, and Gerald changs the menu regularly.  The food is very inventive, and I loved the calamari stuffed with the peppers, as well as the foie gras.  They are familiar, but done in fresh yet traditional way that really works.  

Rustic, bright atmosphere.  I want to bring a big, happy group for that large center table.  It's food you'd expect to see in the Mission, but the crowd is older, and that's okay as well.  Not as sexy, dark or intimate as other spots, but the food will work wonders for you and yours if you need to make points.
author: ed y.

description:
I celebrated an early Valentine's here, and I can also see this being a good restaurant to take your parents out to.  The atmosphere is cozy and warm, the crowd was mostly older people.  I tend to gravitate to trendy, "happening" restaurants, but I was happy on this occasion to be able to hold a conversation without yelling over music or a loud crowd.

I loved the lamb chop and the warm, gooey chocolate cake.  The steamed rock fish was also good, but a little underwhelming compared to the lamb.

Overall nothing particularly memorable or outstanding, but still a very pleasant restaurant.
author: S L.

description:
As my own private protest of John Burton's absurd bill proposing a ban on the production and sale of foie gras in the State of California, I made it a point to order the "artisan foie gras sauted with Monterey squid, grapes and verjus." And it was good, so fuck you, John Burton. You can go cram your anti-duck-gullet-cramming bill down someone else's gullet, because mine was full of rich, buttery, seared foie gras. The grapes were a nice touch in lieu of a more traditional fruit accompaniment and the calamari was wonderul -- "it's like two appetizers in one," said S. Three, if you want to count the verjus, which actually sat up and asked us to sop it up with bread.

We also got the "bacalao fritters," which were my attempt to dull the pain of not seeing a brandade on the menu. Bad idea. Even though bacalao is fun as all get out, it's probably too dry and fibrous to be successfully batter-fried. Or maybe not. It seemed like they were aiming for a hush puppies batter-fried style and I generally don't like hush puppies.

In terms of main courses, I got the "pork daube with fall vegetable ragout": soft, thick chunks of braised pork with vegetables I actually really enjoyed -- they tasted as if they had been stewed along with the pork. Hearty and decidedly unfancy, but I'm always a sucker for braised meats.

Bemoaning that we were there on the wrong night for the rabbit special, S. went with that night's special, which was a veal "stew" composed of veal that she described as "like butter," served with potatoes and some other mish-mash that I didn't pay much attention to, as I was too busy marvelling at how the veal was so soft and buttery, I literally didn't have to chew it. It was a masticatory revolution.

Dessert was a flan-ish custard with a more substantial texture that reminded me of pumpkin pie. Also, a little pile of orange-blossom-flavored beignets. I'm not sure how they did it, but the beignets were so orange-blossomy that I didn't miss the fact that they were served with nothing but a sprinkling of powdered sugar. The only problem was that they got way too soft way too quickly, so we decided that the best thing to do was to stuff the beignets with the custard. Kind of odd, kind of fun, and rather good.
author: Chester Y.

description:
4 stars for the food
2 stars for the service, ambiance and hostess

You should go to this restaurant if you want yummy frenchy/spanishy Basque food especially. I'll start with the cons and work my way into the good stuff

so first thing, the address on yelp.com is incorrect, the address is actually 1015 battery between Union and Green streets. I think it's listed as between pacific and Broadway which through us for a loop so i had to call the restaurant for the address which i explained to the woman who wanted to put me on hold (seriously, i work in customer service, it would have taken 2 seconds to tell me) so I walked the 4 blocks to the restaurant until the hostess was back on the line...didn't need the address anymore, but still...annoying.

Ok, so we step in and instantly i felt two things;
1. i was the youngest the person in the room (I'm nearly 30)
2. the old white man's republican convention was at La Piperade

My boyfriend (who is French and doesn't know proper terminology) said it was pretentious...the point is, it was stuffy.

After we got the stare down from the hostess who couldn't answer simple questions on the phone, we were seated...

We had a nice table at the end of the restaurant  near the bathrooms, and kitchen...yay! Our server was nice, the bf insisted she was related to the chef...she only spoke French to us,assuming we both spoke French. not a problem, it's a beautiful language...

We ordered:
Appetizers: 
Oyster tartare with lemon creme fraiche 
foie gras with peach compote

1 star for the tartare...just not my thing, WAY too fishy and the lemon...um, no. fyi, my bf LOVED this...he says it's really French.
5 stars for the foie gras-buttery, smooth, delicious and paired with my fav...something sweet. Dash a little salt on top and WOW!!

Entrees:
5 stars for the garlic roasted salmon
5 stars for the pacific snapper with spinach

both really great entrees...I had the snapper...it was light and delicious. A warm vinagrette smothered on and around it...really good stuff. The roasted salmon was beautiful on top of a creamy risotto side..really nice, not what you expect form looking at the creamy brown sauce. very recommended.

Desserts: 5 stars...anything you get. Thank you to the pastry chef.

And there you go. La Piperade.
author: nina B.

description: The restaurant is located within a relatively quiet commercial district. It's not hard for people to just walk pass by without knowing its existance. Food was great and service was attentive. Will go back again for sure.
author: Stef L.

description:
Very intimate atmosphere with an old SOMA feel.

The whole wheat bread was excellent.

Cream of artichoke soup was kind of bland and much too watery for me. I like my soups thick with pieces of things otherwise it tastes too much like baby food.

Blue-nosed sea bass was good & served with some green stuff that looked like a cross between asparagus & broccoli (apparently called brocollini).

Snapper was good (not great) had too much cayenne pepper on it, overpowered the actual taste of the fish and was served with A LOT of spinach (the spinach was really good)!

The chicken was ok, but could have been more tender. The mushrooms that were served with it were really good.

The desserts were my favorite part: a Basque cake with cherries (and almond flavoring) & an almond cake with pear and cream fraiche.

The atmosphere definitely made the restaurant. Piperade is forgettable, but better than a bad memory! I would definitely go back for the atmosphere.
author: Elaine S.

description:
This is my second time.  Love the isolated location and great Basque food.  Have yet been to a better Basque restaurant.

Went there for a small wedding party.  Had the dungeness crab salad with mangos and then piperade for the main course.  The food was homely yet one could distinctly feel that the it was prepared at the hand of a scholar.  Basque food sits at the perfect nexus between the delicate preparation of French food and the spiciness and excitement of Spanish cuisine.

The only negative to the restaurant is that the room is somewhat small and the tables are tightly packed for this "loud" restaurant.  Those who want to experience Basque food should go somewhere else and then come here to taste the contrast.
author: Laurence H.

description:
The lobster salad was excellent.   Best part about the restaurant however the is the space, very cozy and inviting.  I probably wouldn't go back in the near future, for the price we have had more amazing meals, their sister restuarant was a little more tast-Il Canto

Okay..have to revise this, ended going here again w/in  weeks...friends set up a dinner.  This one blew my socks of a bit more.  We split about 8 apps..each of them tasty, the only one I would not order again was the foie gras, not big into the cold slab of it, like my grilled.  The monkfish was what really made me want to come back for more.  We'll be putting it into our rotation.
author: Brye L.

description:
My porn habit is out of control lately and I haven't been leaving the house or my room for that matter. But it was time for a break. TiTs and Ass could wait for a couple hours. Watching porn is strenuous activity. One must consume a proper meal as to not bonk out in mid porno session.

It was a Tuesday night and the crowd was a bit older than I expected. The table next to us was full of lawyers having an "I can be louder and more pretentious that you can." contest. Although annoying, strangely captivating. Maybe my need to eavesdrop is just really that bad. Anyways, our server must've been smokin' crystal or somethin, he would never fully stop when he talked to us he kept trying to take our plates while we still had food on them. He was like the little kid who cant sit still. But he did suggest a nice pinot.

We started with foie gras torchon which was served with pear puree, sea salt and cracked peppercorns. It was ok, but the pear puree was too sweet.
Next we had braised oxtail wrapped in cabbage served in broth.  Pretty slammin'. Dippin the bread in the jus was mmm mmm tasty.
First entree halibut with clams in a light broth. This was pretty dope. Fish was light flaky and moist. Broth was light and flavored with clams.
Second entree was a lamb extravaganza. There were a couple of very nice cuts from a rack of lamb and a pile of roasted lamb shoulder. Served with a vegetable relish or something like that. It was kinda mixed together. Not gamy at all. 
Dessert Apple tart and corncake with creme fraiche. Pretty standard stuff not great, but very good.  The Macallan neat was a nice finale. 
Overall a nice dinner. Pretty costly tho. I'll be back, when i need another break.
author: Michael S.

description:
Terrible service, delicious food. Should be five stars, but it's three simply because of general lameness. Why such poor treatment of customers when serving such tasty bites? Dishes were brought out at the wrong time, drink refills weren't offered, huge time lags between courses occurred...

That said, I did love the grilled calamari. And the butter lettuce salad, simple, fresh, and tasty. And the stuffed piquillo pepper. J's steak was delicious as well. My cocktail was nothing special, but it wasn't bad, either. We didn't try the desserts, as we just wanted to get away from the people who couldn't care less about making our dinner enjoyable.
author: Tara M.

description:
My first eating basque food.  We arrived around 7pm and the restaurant was still not crowded. Be sure you make reservations! It started getting busy around 8pm. 

 We got the calamari dish for appetizer. It was pretty tasty.

Seabass and Halibut entrees were ordered. I guess I was disappointed with the flavors with my dish. Very soft and bland? I guess that's what you call stew dishes right?

Anyways, dessert was good. It was  a dark chocolate, crispy wafer dish.

Good, attentive service.  

Not sure if I will be back next time
author: Jboogie L.

description: Love this place. The bar is a great place for a pop after work but the real treat is the dining room. Lunch or dinner, Piperade rocks it. It's a basque menu that leans French. The seafood is always terrific and there's always a special that has been spectacular every time I've been there. One of the best places to eat in a city replete with great eateries.
author: Kevin E.

description:
I was taken out to dinner, so I can't really comment on the cost, but I can sure tell you about the food.  We shared a bunch of small plates. Dungeoness crab salad, butter lettuce salad, haricots verts with figs and walnuts, piqudillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese and golden rasins....all of which were quite tasty although not terribly exotic. I would expect to see any of that on a typical SF menu. However the last dish we got was SO FANTASTIC. Calamari with black olives, toasted almonds and parsley (I think that was the green on it). Wow. Perfectly cooked...and I even ate the little chopped up tentacles which I usually don't care for. 

We were seated in probably the one poor table in the place, situated between the out-door of the kitchen and the bar, so anyone walking out of the kitchen to behind the bar passed us, as well as anyone heading to the bathroom. But anyone looking for nice ambience would do well there. It's a homey looking place and on nice days it looked like there were a few tables out front.
author: Emily L.

description:
Piperade is what happens when you tart up regional cooking. 

Instead of tasting like Basque food, it tasted like practically any other 'California Cuisine' restaurant. I've been to the Basque country and the  restaurant should be called 'Barely Basque'.

Sure, the presentation was lovely (1/2 star), but  the appetizers and entrees were bland bland bland. What it lacked in actual taste was made up in the salt used in the dishes. The garlic soup tasted more like salt water to gargle with--totally lacked flavor. 

Another 1/2 star for the rustic decor.

I am giving it an additional star because the gateau Basque was actually good. Minus a star because the beignets were cold and should have been at least warm.

I was pretty disappointed with the whole experience. It used to be a fairly decent restaurant with authentic Basque dishes. 

The restaurant is definitely over-hyped.
author: Akasha A.

description:
I came here for a late dinner one Saturday night and was happily satisfied with the quality of the food and service. We ordered the piquillo pepper appetizer and the fact that I even remember what it was called is a testament to its tastiness. The crab salad was also very fresh, as was the sea bass. 

We closed out the restaurant and never felt rushed to leave. A very relaxing evening overall filled with good food.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I loved this place. Last December I went there for the first time. The boss & I always pick some fabulous new (to us) restaurant to try for a long Holiday lunch. This year it was Piperade. We chose small plates - a mussel and frisee salad, gigante bean salad, potato gratin, selection of cheeses and jamon serrano. 

The first thing about which I must rave - olive oil that is the best I have ever tasted. We wanted to order some but ultimately found out they weren't going to be able to import it anymore. Such a shame because it was luscious. It wasn't too peppery or too green, perfectly balanced, fruity and mellow. YUM!! 

The bread was delicious, rather rustic and with terrific texture. Everything else was absolutely excellent. Sadly I can't remember the name of the ny-the-glass Spanish White wine we had. But it was crisp and fruity and a perfect match to everything we ate.

The service was lovely, the ambience was warm and very welcoming. All in all - a terrific experience.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
This is a late review. Went to Piperade for our first time in May, 2013. One of the best SF dining experiences we've had in a while. We'll return. Have tired of the newer SF restaurants with great food, but are so noisy it's hard to have a conversation. 
Service - Excellent, there when needed, unobtrusive, good menu info. Seated on time.
Vibe - Décor open, inviting, not stuffy. Everyone looked like they were enjoying themselves. Mixed age crowd, on the older side, with some 20's-30s. Probably in part due to cost. Our 24 and 27 year old sons who live in SF loved it and commented on how calm Piperade felt. And yes, we could hear one another, but not  conversations from other tables.
Price - Higher, but worth it. 
Food - Consistently excellent. Bread - fresh from Acme, yum. Dungeness Crab Tangurro and another appetizer with ham was delectable, though that portion seemed small. Cornish Hen - moist, flavorful. Seafood & Shellfish Stew - excellent, wasn't sure about the mussels' texture/maybe because was the first time had them. Pacific Snapper with spinach - so light seemed to melt in your mouth (good!). New York Steak - tender, just right. Dark chocolate cake with crème fraiche - one bite and everyone dove in for more, delicious.
Parking - Easy street parking at no charge, because business people gone for the day.
Reservations - Uses SeatMe, not Open Table, so you won't get OT points. Doesn't matter.
author: A. D.

description:
I went to a wine supplier lunch here yesterday, and it was my first time experiencing Piperade (although I have dined at Bocadillos once before). 

I ordered the txangurro crab app to start. It was a composed salad of dungeness crab meat (in a tall cylinder form), with brunoised mango and roasted red pepper around the bottom. I didn't taste much of the alleged basil accompaniment, and I had to repeatedly salt the crab meat as well so I ended up giving away a lot of it to the other diners. I was a bigger fan of everyone else's starters: the warm white bean salad (although I didn't try any of the anchovy or egg accompaniments) and especially the mushroom pie - this was basically a seasonal mushroom tart with creme fraiche. It had the most amazing savory flavor tempered by the creamy goodness - I will be back for that!

My seafood & shellfish stew entree was just okay. There was a giant head-on prawn, several tentacly (rubbery) baby octopi, a couple scallops, and some thoroughly overcooked fish chunks (salmon? whitefish? not sure). The flavors of the broth also needed to be more developed, and I was looking for a toasted bread slice smeared with romesco or something. I thought it would be a Basque interpretation of cioppino or bouillabaisse, but I was so disappointed. Once again, everyone else's dishes were great. Clearly, I need to order differently next time. The sea bass entree came with some of the best brussels sprouts ever - they were almost blackened and were braised with bacon - plus there was some buttery froth all around the plate. The burger looked a little unwieldy but tasted good, with just the right amount of cheese (Ossau Iraty, a sharp little Basque cheese). I only tried one fry and it was kinda limp, but the spicy ketchup was great on the burger. The duck confit Plat du Jour looked very good as well, nice crispy skin and plated with green lentils, but she didn't want to share.

The desserts were all-around fantastic though: the traditional Gateau Basque was a little slice of heaven - almond cake served with a cherry compote - and the Rocher dessert is a must-try (although a little hard to eat since it is semi-frozen and there are whole hazelnuts on the top). I would definitely come back to try the orange blossom beignets and the roasted pineapple clafoutis.

I am giving three stars because of the general under-seasoning of my dishes, plus the extremely slow service. Our waitress was a lovely little Basque woman, but we were not on Basque time! It took almost half an hour to get our orders in, and while the food/desserts came rather quickly, espresso/the check/etc did NOT. Our companions had to call their next appt to cancel because we were there for so long. We arrived at 12:30 and left at about 2:45!

Get a more attentive server and the salt shaker in the rotation and I would give 5 stars. Until my next visit...
author: Stephanie S.

description: There isn't much for me to add here that hasn't been written already.  The atmosphere was warm and cozy; our waiter was attentive; the lamb chops were nice and juicy.  I'd definitely come back.
author: peter w.

description: I gotta say, I am addicted to the chicken, mandarin & avocado salad. The price is totally reasonable and the food is delicious. We don't have many lunch choices and I am SO glad I was introduced to Piperade to Go by my co-worker.
author: Jessie H.

description:
Hmmm.. after reading so much about this place we went last night.. they couldn't get us in until 9:30 but we were okay with that.. now here's the deal.. i have been in the restaurant biz for years. I have been a waiter and a maitre d and a manager so I know all about service and how it should be..
So the hostess see's our heavy coats and doesn't offer to take them.. she tells us our table will be ready in a couple of minutes...we sit at the bar and i return the coats  to her. The bartender is cool.. the drinks good. The place is beautiful.. we're looking forward to our dinner.. the joint is jumping.
So 9;30 comes and goes..9'45..9;55.. finally i get up and ask the hostess when our table will be ready.. she says two minutes.. no apologies nothing.. 10 minutes later our table is ready.. we're not worried.. we're having a nice time but that seemed a little tacky.. and still no apology....

Then the server hits us really fast with a drink order.. my arse had barely touched the seat.... big NO NO in my book.. clearly he wants to get us out and though the food was good (not great!- it still didn't come close to any meal we've had at chez panisse cafe)the rush of the food and the poor service tainted our experience and unless someone can convice us otherwise we won't be going go back any time soon.
author: Stevie D.

description:
I don't know how Basque it was (was very Californian/French/New American), but the food was great!  Then again, Piperade claims to infuse only a "taste of Basque."  Halibut with cream/corn sauce entree was recommended by the waiter and I was skeptical since the description didn't sound appealing but it turned out fantastic, not too heavy and fish was perfectly cooked.  Chocolate cake and apple tart with caramel sauce desserts also excellent, especially the apple tart...I could've eaten another one.

Ambiance was cozy, pleasant.  The crowd was mainly late-30s and up.  Parking within a block was easy at night since Piperade's in the financial district mainly by offices which are closed at night.
author: Chris P.

description:
The precision and attention to detail that are usually Piperade hallmarks were conspicuously missing during my last meal here.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt since I've had many an outstanding dinner at Piperade and hopefully last night was just an anomaly (the place was packed and there was a party of 12-14 people so the staff was overtaxed).

We started with the crab, mango, and pepper salad and the cold-poached foie.  The crab was anemic - severely lacking in flavor and refrigerator cold  (bland and too finely shredded, making the dish texturally boring), accompanied by precise dices of just-ripe mango and overpowering pickled peppers.  The foie was of inferior quality and the terrine was haphazardly made, breaking into pieces when cut into.  The  vanilla-infused compote was its saving grace.

We then had the duck with sunchokes, onions, and balsamic reduction and the lamb trio (chop, shoulder, and loin).  The duck was our one unadulterated highlight - beautifully cooked and well-accompanied, very mellow and delicious.  

But the lamb...oh, where to start.  The portion was comically oversized, with easily a pound of protein on the plate.  When I cut into the chop, it was rubbery and grossly overcooked.  Our server was very attentive and considerate in immediately noticing the problem without my prompting and taking the plate back to the kitchen.  She returned just a few minutes later with a new chop.  I wanted to let it rest so the juices got a chance to recirculate and cut into the shoulder to find it dry and below room temperature.  The loin was likewise lukewarm and completely devoid of any lamb flavor, as was the chop.  They were accompanied by mushy and bland gigante beans.  Again, our server really took care of us when I told her it was not to my liking, sending the plate back and removing the charge from the bill, as well as offering another entree free of charge.

I got the seafood stew, with perfectly cooked and delicious clams that had a compelling iodine and brine flavor.  The remaining fish was a bit overcooked and unremarkable.

Desserts were a marked improvement, we got the beignets and the kefir yogurt with asian pear and honey.  The beignets were room temperature and doughy but the flavor was good.  The yogurt, however, was spectacular - tangy and creamy; well accented with the crisp fruit and sweet honey.  The kitchen could have ramped up the presentation though, as the yogurt was simply ladled onto the plate.  A simple piping bag would have greatly enhanced the visual appeal of the dish.

I've had too many stellar meals at Piperade to be seriously bothered by this miss-step and will certainly be back, expecting the greatness that I know chef Hirigoyen can deliver.
author: Yan G.

description:
This is one of those place that is way too convenient for me to not go all the time. Lucky for me, the food is pretty good (when they have it :P ) 

Which brings me to my peeve about this place - they run out of stuff ALL THE TIME. If I'm feeling like its a Piperade day, I try and plan to take an early lunch in order to avoid the inevitable "No more___(insert food I wanted to eat that day here)___". I literally stand in the long long line, willing all the people in front of me not to order what I was hoping to order that day just so I could get a better shot at it. When I do get it though, its generally really good. Their salads are very filling and the sandwiches are tasty.

If I'm feeling like a lunch time gamble then I go here.
author: Tara O.

description:
Piperade gets 2 stars for service and 4 stars for food, so an average of 3. 

My friend and I had a 12 person group joint birthday dinner at Piperade in late Jan 2009, and our waiter had attitude. Overall he seemed annoyed by the large party and not very friendly or helpful with suggestions. I would expect friendlier service for a top 100 Bay Area restaurant. 

Several dishes were very good, notably the sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine. My friends loved the lamb chops and stews, though I can't speak for them personally. There were a few mediocre dishes: my grilled swordfish was boring with little flavor, and the artisanal cheeses were nothing special. 

Overall the small dishes were more interesting and tasty than the large dishes. Piperade isn't good for large groups, and don't expect very friendly service.
author: Tu T.

description:
This is officially the first time I have "yelped".  It is not because I am not a foodie, because beleive me, I have eated at some of the best restos in the world.  But, "Piperade" is definitely worth taking the time to brag about.  

Basically, this restaurant literally brought me back to my days living in Barcelona, Spain.  The food is not simply "Spanish" but Basque food- the Northernest part of Spain that touches the French border and is the culinary center of the world.  The Basque region is where the term "tapa" comes from.  I had such an incredible culinary experience there, that I had to try this restaurant as soon as I heard about it.  

The first impression was the inviting ambience.  Warm colors, romantic lighting, jovial energy.  The second impression was the hospitable chef and owner, who actually met us at the hostess table.  The third impression was the sweet, authentic and energetic waitress- who is actually from the Basque region.  Finally, last but not least, was the incredible food- cooked to perfection and basked in the most incredible flavors.  

When I return on date night, as opposed to with my family (as I did here), I will likely order the same memorable meal:

- Calamari "a la plancha"- asian pears, lemon confit (calamari that is grilled vs. fried, very unusual.  Sauce is amaaazing)
- Flava bean salad (season for just two months)
- Lamb shank + shoulder + sausage.  (served wtih potatoes that were cooked to perfection)

I am looking forward to attending "TAPAS" wine tasting tomorrow where the sister restaurant Bocadillos will be serving food.

Abrazos!

K
author: Kara W.

description: Went to their take out window for lunch a few times and I've got to say their food is pretty good. I am in love with their Cobb Salad, fresh plentiful ingredients and homemade croutons (not the typical ones from the box). The portion was pretty large as well. I've also tried their very popular Mr. Williams sandwich and was awesome as well.  Most of the items are probably $7+ but considering the location and quality of the food it is well worth the price. I will definitely be coming back!
author: Bunnie L.

description: Piperade is always a great treat for me. I go there about once a week and order the same pacific snapper w garlic vinaigrette and spinach. For dessert I have the orange blossom beignets that are light, sweet and consistently fresh.
author: Sheila C.

description:
I'm fussy.  I don't enjoy Spanish food, nor Catalan food, so I approached Basque food with trepidation.  I had visions of too much oil and too much luke warm mush.  But I was very pleasantly surprised with nearly everything (4 small plates between two).  Probably the only disappointment was the wine, recommended by the waitress, totally unpronounceable, full of xs and zs, and rather sweet and bland.

Decor and atmosphere was upscale but relaxed and definitely improved by the overt transvestite propping up the bar.

Recommended!
author: Norman B.

description:
I understand service has been a major complaint about Piperade in the past, and perhaps it is an issue more at dinner if the restaurant is trying to turn the tables faster. But for lunch, service was unrushed and extremely pleasant. One the table for shared starters was a tartare of bacalao and oysters, a garlic soup, and a French onion soup. The garlic soup was easily the favorite, but I convinced everyone to leave some as I knew I wanted to take some home for a late-night snack. This was all consumed with a Tablas Creek Roussanne which worked quite well.

K chose as his entree lamb chops served with Manchego potato gratin and I opted for rarely-seen veal cheeks with fava beans and cepes. Our guest was dieting and opted for a butter lettuce salad. Both our entrees were astonishingly good but the veal cheeks, undoubtedly a sous vide preparation, melted in the mouth. We had as a second pairing a Guelbenzu blend that consisted of a cab-sauv/tempranillo blend which worked quite well.

Being a business meeting, more time was needed for negotiations and dessert was ordered... a cheese plate and port for K, a Gateau Basque for me, and our guest (then realizing how great the food was and foregoing the diet) ordered an apple tart. At one point during the discussion, I mentioned in passing to our guest that K and I were experimenting with making cheese but were struggling with finding goat's milk that is not ultra-pasteurized. While clearing plates and overhearing this remark, our server brought a large hunk of goat's milk cheese from Petaluma for us to try. It was a simple gesture, done without largesse and was well-appreciated.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Again another restaurant that gave me happy feelings!  The food and wine was excellent!  The decor was up to par with its trendy competitors.  A great place to take a girl for her bday!  ;-)
