Again, I must confess.  I'm bias with my review since I was taken out there for my bday as a client luncheon and my sales rep knew the owner, so we were probably take care of above and beyond!  Still I hope to revisit this gem again soon!
author: Alice T.

description: Ok food.  Amazing service and not a bad wine list.  Had their warm sheeps cheese & ham terrine as one of the appetizers...sounds yummy but sadly was just OK.
author: Rebecca W B.

description: I have to say, I was disappointed with my overall experience, especially as I work in the area and have been passing by for months and dying to try.  The menu looked fantastic, it's a beautiful venue, and they have a ton of servers on the floor so was excited for a nice experience. Upon arriving, we told our server we were grabbing just a quick, small bite as we had somewhere to be.  Clearly she didn't understand the "quick" part as she didn't return for our drink orders for 10 minutes.  We ordered the mussels, a sheeps cheese and ham terrine appetizer and sauteed sole to split.  When we got our first two starters, we were super confused - the mussels were actually a cold salad - and very fishy at that.  I was sad that our server didn't explain that this was actually different than most traditional mussels - at a place as nice as this, I would expect more guidance.  Same went for the terrine - you actually couldn't see the cheese, it was extremely light and in between the superfine ham slices...so really was like a salty ham slice with slight crusting of cheese.  It was good...but again, not at all what I expected and way too salty for me.  Most disappointing was the fact that our server never came back to check on us to ask us how it was.  I would have liked to let her know that it would be helpful to know beforehand as I honestly couldn't eat the salad (too fishy) and would have like to know the other options.  Finally, the sole came, which they split for us and while it was good if I took a bit with all ingredients (garlic and sauteed spinach were divine), the fish itself was, well, fishy.  Again, since runners brought out our dishes and she never came back until the bill, there was no opportunity for feedback to our server, even when the bill came.  It should always be a question in any restaurant about the satisfaction of the taste of the food - so needless to say in such a nice place, she soured the experience for me.  I really want to like this place, but after spending $80 for a meal to my disliking with no question of my satisfaction, I will definitely have to spend my money elsewhere.
author: Betsy C.

description: Excellent food, the mushroom tart and squid dish are wonderful, the cod and lamb are always delicious; the chocolate cake delightful. Also, quieter and more intimate atmosphere where you can talk to your neighbors.
author: Jm G.

description: Excellent. Calamari and Red Bell Peppers for appetizers. Very yummy. I had the bass with brussels sprouts, which were perfectly cooked and seasoned. Would love to go back to try out the other dishes.
author: Susanna L.

description: Food was good. Not great, but certainly good. On the plus side the tomato tort and the mussels were very good. On the minus the steamed fish was too "fishy" smelling, and the wine list is not up to the calibre I'd expect.  Not bad at all, but wouldn't rush back.
author: Josh B.

description:
Our first experience with Piperade was a home run.  My daughter had passed by the restaurant several times on her way to work and wanted to try it so we dropped in on a Thursday evening without reservations.  What a beautiful spot!  People were dining on the patio area.  We were greeted warmly and efficiently, and seated inside the restaurant which is beautiful, warm and inviting.

As we were seated, we received water and warm, crusty bread.  Service was spectacular.  Our server was very knowledgeable, picked up on the nuances of each of her guests, helped with indecision and was thoroughly effective in her role.  Two out of four of us ordered specialty cocktails and they were delicious.  The other two martinis were perfectly prepared.  We ordered appetizers, salads, soup, and two entrees to share.  One entree was the salmon, and it was heavenly.  The other was a steak dish and, again, out of this world.  We had a garlic soup that was very yummy, but the soup of the day (although I cannot remember what it was) amazed us!  

The wine list is diverse and interesting, and we were assisted with selecting a Malbec (from Argentina) that was fantastic and extremely reasonably priced.  We followed up with a couple of glasses of Spanish Tempranillo that was superb.

Dessert was fantastic as well - we ordered a flourless chocolate cake to share, but our server also brought out a sumptious fruit tart as a bonus.

It was such a pleasurable experience - fresh ingredients, beautifully prepared, and great ambiance.  We'll be back.
author: Casey N.

description:
Positives: the place is nice, the food is very good, and the waiter we had was friendly and polite. The Calamari is the best I've ever had and I loved the pork chops. Both my wife and I thought the food was really good and the desert was excellent. Finally, parking is easy to find on the street. 

Negatives: the portions are small. I ordered pork chops and this dish was $28 and I got two very small pork chops, and some vegetables. For $28 I thought they might be a little bit bigger or maybe a third chop. 

Also we ordered wine by the glass since I did not want to drink alot and just wanted one glass. However even though the waiter suggested a good wine, he probably poured me and my wife about 1/5 of a glass.  I felt I got ripped off, it was like paying $11at a wine tasting and getting a small pour of one varietal. This was very disappointing. 

Do yourself a favor if you don't want to drink alot but would like a normal glass of wine for you and your date order the half bottle so you get a decent glass. This was really annoying.
author: Greg D.

description: Let me say That I have never eaten at this restaurant. I had a Bloomspot  Certificate. It will expire next week. When I called, you have to call for a reservation,mentioned the certificate they are completely booked up until next Tuesday after 8:30pm. This is on a weekday. They do not appear to want Bloomspots business.The certificate is expired.I have tried previously to make a reservation same problem. Best to contact restaurants for reservations before purchasing certificates. Problem these restaurants request Cert # beforehand. Perhaps if this restaurant gets more bad reviews from these problems they might change their attitude.
author: jay d.

description:
I've been here twice recently and was very happy with the experience.  I also enjoyed this place when it was Pastis, but I think I like Piperade better.

At our most recent visit we had a fantastic foie gras and calamari appetizer which was marred only slightly by a couple pieces of the calamari that were chewy.  Since were already having a cruelty-full dinner, we opted for the veal cheeks with nectarines as one of the main courses.  They were fantastic.  We also had the garlic soup with rock shrimp and bacon, which had enough garlic in it to keep head colds and vampires away for the next year (I consider that a good thing).

If you go on a Tuesday, be sure to try the calamari in ink sauce.  I'm planning on making my next visit on a Monday, so I can try the sweetbreads.
author: Sam L.

description:
I went here for a business lunch and I was impressed with the space, the service and the food.  It's pretty solid all the way around and there is good attention to detail in all aspects of the experience.  

It's kind of out of the way, but was super convenient for my meeting.

I would recommend it...

The square table in the middle would be great for a group of 8-10.
author: Tony A.

description:
I love this place. The only gripe is how to pronounce it, i think you pronounce it in the following manner:

pipp  err odd

The interior decor is cool, very homey, with lots of rustic wood style. 
A good wine list, with a capable staff that wasn't too stuffy. But is it basque? I say more basque-ish. I think i had the duck, and it wasn't oily like duck can be sometimes. The appetizers were superb, sorry i can't be more detail-minded, but it was at least a year ago, when I went...
author: wayne s.

description: The 4 stars is for the service but over-all, the food only deserve 3 stars.  Personally if I was to choose Basque, I would have gone to Fringalle or Spanish Tapas, then Bocadillos.  The food was so-so ok, nothing stands out.
author: elle n.

description: Was expecting outstanding and only found so so.  While eating we were discussing other restaurants with greater food.  I only ate half my rack of lamb and they did not bring my doggie bag and since I was talking I forgot it also, so I feel like half my money went down the drain.  My friends wine glass had sludge in the bottom of the glass and the waiter said that was the way that wine was--!!
author: Lorene N.

description:
Always a good meal
* traditional, rustic french-basque
* good for individual or sharing, family-style
* save room for dessert :)
* warm, open atmosphere
* full bar/wine list
* attentive service
* a primary Gerald Hirogoyen restaurant
author: susan f.

description:
A spate of recent, bad reviews leaves me a bit sad.  This place has been the site of some of my most sublime dining experiences in the City.  The ambiance is so mellow and warm - the place is like a gastronomic down comforter.

The food has been simply fantastic every time I've been there.  Great variety of ingredients with preparations that are decidedly unlike anything else you'll get on the Barbary Coast.  On one occasion the halibut was a touch overdone for my girlfriend's taste, but she likes it damned near raw.  On another, the piquillo peppers weren't quite right.  But generally speaking the food has really been first rate.  

What's really shocking to me have been the comments regarding service.  We've had different waiters or waitresses each time there (we've been there 4 times now), and all have been delightful.  Good knowledge of the fare, good ability to recommend appropriate wine pairings, etc.  Polite.  Prompt.  Not overbearing.  It's just really sad to think the service could be degenerating to such a degree.

I'll post an updated review in a few weeks - planning on dining there just after the 4th of July - in the meantime, I'll rate it as I remember it having been in October of 2007.
author: Forrest C.

description:
EXCELLENT SERVICE and Great food. Our waitress Virginia was very helpful and friendly.
Must have the lamb chops and the chocolate dessert.
Will do back
author: nit p.

description: Tasty food, nice portions, relaxed atmosphere, delicious cocktails.  Nothing blew me away but everything was really good.  A good place to relax, get a nice meal, and spend time with friends.  Plus the Basque words were fun to learn and try to pronounce.
author: A L.

description:
Since Valentine's day itself is usually laden with nervous, needy food seekers and harassed waitstaff,  Mr. H and I typically go a few days before, or after the actual day itself for our cupid day food exploits. This year we chose to go to Piperade the day after Valentine's. It was scrumptious. It was lovely. We'll go again. 
It's located in an interesting space on Battery street, and although we sat inside there was a lovely little patio space outside that would be ideal if the weather in SF was cooperative, or if you are bravely bundled (they have patio heaters!)
The interior is dimly  but artfully, lit and has the perfect mixture of exposed urban brick and reclaimed wood floor that says "I'm having a laid back yet swanky dining experience tonight". 
I started out the evening with the Biarritz cocktail, it's mixture of Jasmine infused vodka, citrus, and a little sugar was refreshing without being cloying. 
Since we were little piglets and literally everything on the menu sounded tasty we opted for two starters and an ala carte main course.
Mr. H started with the Calamari. It was perfection with it's light dousing of vinaigrette and almonds. I got the open faced mushroom pie. scrumptious. Then came Mr. H's garlic soup and for me, the goat cheese and ham terrine. The soup looked almost like a Chinese egg drop soup when it arrived, a slightly clearish broth with recognizable egg and shrimp. But the taste was utterly unlike eggdrop,  deep and redolent of roasted garlic. My terrine was one of the clear winners of the evening. You know how when you were a kid and your mom made the most perfect grilled cheese sandwich in the world and the most perfect part of that perfect sandwich was the small, lacy rim of crispy cheese that had melted and oozed out of its bready home onto the griddle and cooked itself to golden perfection? Well this terrine is a 3" by 3" by 1/2" piece of that married to smoky ham and kissed with a little sherry. By that time I'd moved on to a glass of Tannat and it was perfect with the cheesy goodness, and later with the sweetbreads I ordered. The generous portion was lovingly cooked and tender in it's madeira braise with some carrot and spinach. Mr. H had the Sea Bass which was tasty, tender and juicy.
We finished up with a piece of Gateau Basque (it only seemed right!) and apple tart. Both were good, although the Basque and it's side of glacied cherries were the winner for me. I'll definitely be back for the chilled mussel and bread salad and the orange blossom beignets.
For a dining experience of that caliber we expected to spend somewhat more than we actually did, so we were more than pleased all around.
author: Joyce H.

description: I'd have to agree with Yee-Shing Y., they have a killer cobb salad here.  They don't skimp on the ingredients.  They give you a side of blue cheese dressing, but I don't put it in the salad or a very small amount because the salad itself has enough flavor with all of the crumbled blue cheese and bacon.  Not the healthiest salad, but it's worth it once in a while.  Plan on sharing it with a friend because it's a pretty big.  You don't want to save it for overnight because overnight salad just tastes bad.
author: Lucky M.

description:
First time back in a couple of years. Overall very good food/atmosphere.

For appy I had the piquillo peppers stuffed w/goat cheese and golden raisins on the side. I was going to share it but my friend decided he didn't like goat cheese so much, so I ate both...a bit too much so better to share this appy.

My friend had the special broccoli cream soup. Took a spoonful which was nice but at the end he commented that it was too bland & needed either salt (none on table) or pepper (none offered by waiter).

For entree I had the NY steak but don't order it if you had the piquillo peppers for appy because it is topped with them too. Even though you could take them off, the flavor of it was overkill by the end of the meal.

For dessert I had the chocolate flourless cake which was pretty yummy, although my friend tasted it & said it tasted like cake frosting (but hey, Iike frosting more than I like cake).

Good food, just read the menu carefully.
author: D L.

description: Crab salad and calamari (aka crackamari), need I say more?  This place never fails to deliver excellent food.  Love the cozy, small space.  Parking for dinner is always easy, because the area becomes deserted after business hours after all the 9-5ers have gone home.  Definitely a San Francisco staple!
author: Carolyn D.

description:
This is the best in San Francisco, my favorite.

It has a cozy, romantic atmosphere. The staff is on top of everything. The food is unreal and good value.  You can find parking. You can walk to & from North Beach or the pier.

Tip: You have to try the ham and cheese terrine.
author: Joe C.

description:
This is on my top ten list, mostly due to the ham and cheese terrine.  Unfortunately, it is only served as a small appetizer for about $5 a bite, but it is the best $5 bite you will have.  I only wish I could order a whole plate of this as an entree, but maybe "all things in moderation" wisely applies here, due to fat and cholesterol limits.  Servers can be snooty.  Our server never looked us in the eye, as if intentional.  I felt like saying "excuse me sir, down here!  We had a reservation and were passed over by at least 5 parties who came 5 to 15 minutes after us, each time the waitress saying "your next, I promise!"  Kudos to the busboy, who was really working his ass off while contiually being chastized and yelled at for apparently no reason at all.  He really makes the place run.

The food is very, very good.  Service is hit or miss depending how important you appear to be.  I love the location, easy to park and great for walking afterwards.  They also sell the restaurant cookbook there for $35.  Being the cheapskate I am, I passed on that but wish I had it now.

The other fun thing about this place is taking people who have not been.  When they hear "basque food", they usually think of cheap steak and greassy french fries, and they are pleasantly surprised on how good the food is, albeit at a high price.  Desserts fall a tad short by comparison, but otherwise the food is superb.  Nice wine selection.
author: Greg R.

description:
I had delicious food here, the foie gras was amazing, thanks for force  feeding! the Halibut cooked perfect (on the small side) was just really good. the molten chocolate cake wasn't to sweet, interesting wine list, the attentive service from a charming "frenchasian" waitress was a plus.
if only the waitress had gone under the table this would be a 5 stars!
author: verstonku a.

description: I love this place. It's a quintessential SF spot. Exposed brick, nice 8 top for groups and a great big bar. Basque region is a combo of Spanish and French regions leaning towards Spanish. Nice fresh ingredients with authentic preparation. The food is good, kind of comfy Spanish food. Would never turn down a night here, special SF spot!
author: Tom W.

description: First of all, great drinks.  The food is excellent.  The Basque Cake was better - though I wish they would leave off that tart fruit sauce.  The cake is great on its own.  The service was good.  I will definitely eat here again.
author: N F.

description: Had an amazing meal here. The food was delicious and fresh. The atmosphere was minimalistic but cool without trying to be. The whole place definitely had a fresh vibe to it. Negative is that, while the vibe is fresh, this place isn't bursting with personality the way, say, Zare would be. So come here when you want an upscale but mellow experience.
author: Shreya C.

description: So sad.  I haven't been here in a few years, and went with a group of 6 for lunch today.  We were all geared up for a fabulous meal, but we were decidedly underwhelmed.  We started with a cheese plate and the serrano ham. The cheese was good, but the serrano ham was not as flavorful as I had remembered.  We got a smattering of main plates among us -- the arctic char (tasted a bit fishy, according to my friend), the piperade (ok, but the entire dish seemed under-seasoned), the tuna sandwich and the snapper. None of the dishes seemed very inspired, and we all left less-than-impressed.  Sigh. Maybe I'll wait a few years before giving this place another shot.
author: Bess K.

description: Very cozy and romantic setting. The experience was lovely but it wasn't one of those memorable meals that would have me coming back here. The fact that I can't even remember what I ate is an indication that the food was probably not that GREAT....but at least I don't remember it being bad. It doesn't look like they get much use of the patio space that they have in the front because SF is just so damn cold! I guess if you wear your snowboarding gear you would be ok sitting out there. That, or you could just throw back a few and let the alcohol keep you warm!
author: Jennalyn M.

description:
i *was* going to give piperade four stars, but as i was thinking about it in the shower, i don't think i'm a fan of it. it's not BAD, but it's not like i'd make it a point to come here again.

the space itself is great--large yet small, intimate but still open. the service is on par with what i would expect from this type of restaurant. 

the food, however, was only meh. for an appetizer, i had the sheep's cheese and ham terrine. it made for a nice starter but it was overly salty--not sure if it came from the cheese or the ham, or maybe a combination of both. 

i then had the lamb, which came with a sausage (lamb sausage?) and fingerling potatoes. nom nom -- loved the potatoes, the lamb was pretty good but not great. i ordered it medium-rare but it came out a bit too red for my taste. my mom had the seafood stew and enjoyed that a lot, but my dad got the cod (or was it sole?) and said it was overcooked. 

the desserts, however, were excellent. i had the gateau basque. nice and thick and almond-y. mmm! my mom got the turron mousse cake on the recommendation of the waiter but didn't like it (but my dad and i did, although to my palate it ended up bland after eating the almond-overload that is the gateau basque). dad had the almond and pear tartlet and enjoyed it.

so yeah. in summary, the food is good, not great. slightly overrated, imho. glad i tried it, but yeah, not worth another drive from the east bay.
author: Jonathan K.

description: Went for a business lunch: great pinchos, nice entrees and an outstanding turron-flavored desert. Also, first-rate service.
author: cicciolini e.

description: Very tasty varied and filling. Good service and quiet enough so you can hear, good lighting so you can see. calamari to die for, garlic soup very interesting, duck with pear melted in the mouth, desserts - the Basque gateau with cherries is a winner and the orange blossoms beinets.
author: Josephine G.

description:
Alphabet Soup- P Dinner

Piperade was the chosen restaurant for "P" dinner in our monthly installment of restaurant club.  Between the 8 of us, we ordered most of the apps, entrees, and desserts, so we had a good overview of the menu.  The overall impression was that Piperade is a beautiful space with great ambiance, decor, and an open, yet intimate atmosphere.  The service was superb-- I dare say better than most restaurants in range.  The menu is solid and includes traditional ingredients interpreted with a modern flair. The translation from menu description to plate falls just a wee bit short of expectation, however.  The house specialty (piperade) was flavorful, but the unanimous impression was that it would be better as a breakfast dish.  The seabass and snapper were dry and rather small portions at $26 each.  The chicken and steak were good but not outstanding.  The desserts were all amazing, and I agree with the reviewer that declared "the desserts are much better than the main courses."

I can't wait to come back on a warm summer evening for a glass of wine and small plates on the open patio.  This is a great spot to take family visiting from out of town or an intimate dinner pour deux.
author: Geri-Ayn G.

description:
I went to Piperade for the first time a few years ago, and had a wonderful experience - I thought the food and service were top notch. I was really looking forward to going again, and bringing my good friends who were visiting from out of town. Unfortunately, seems things have changed since I was there last. Our server really did not have it together - I had to flag her down for just about everything we needed. We waited for quite a while before I could get her attention to take our order, and then she brought out the entrees before we had received our appetizers. She also brought us the wrong bottle of wine, and was just generally inattentive - I expected much higher quality service from a restaurant of this caliber. Also, the food was good, but not stellar. I had the arctic char with broccoli rabe and chorizo - it was much too salty, and I couldn't finish it (and I generally like things on the saltier side). I was disappointed with the experience this time, and had wished I chosen a different restaurant to bring my friends. 

I agree with another reviewer - my rating is teetering between 2 and 3 stars.
author: Alicia A.

description:
I am, no doubt, one of the most annoying non-Basque people in San Francisco to take out to a Basque restaurant. I try -- I really do -- but as someone who has spent a few months in the Basque Country, as someone who has literally seen almost every Basque movie to come out in the last twenty years, as someone who wrote a thesis on narrative representations of trauma and their implications on the construction of Basque national identity in the films of Julio Medem, as someone who spent three years taking Basque language courses... Well, I'm an overly-critical prick who expects all things Basque to be nothing less than completely authentic while simultaneously avoiding falling into easy stereotypes of Basqueness. Which, if you think about it, is totally impossible.

Of course, I realize that the authenticity factor is not the only axis upon which food is measured. The other one, of course, is the chichi factor. Cuisine can be completely authentic but still be disregarded by those who consider themselves epicureans simply because it lacks the appropriate chichi-ness. These people are, I would argue, fuckheads. Take, for instance, the Harvard professor I met at a conference in Milwaukee who I overheard say immediately after delivering a keynote address on how academics need to relate better to, respect more, and listen more carefully to, the general NASCAR-loving population of our country in order to have progressive change -- while drinking a martini in the hotel's top-floor martini bar that had a needlessly French name despite it being, you know, in the middle of Milwaukee -- that there are only two "worthwhile cuisines -- cuisines, period -- in the world: the French, and the Chinese."

Obviously, Mr. Harvard Professor -- would-be savior of the palates of the underprivileged -- has never drank a gas station slurpee, eaten samosas sold by a street vendor in a sketchy alley, or devoured fried tortillas covered in cinnamon and sugar and washed them down with a jug of pulque at a country hut outside of Cuernavaca.

I've been to plenty of Basque restaurants, from tavernas in villages outside of Donostia to completely disgusting steak-houses-in-disguises next to truck stops in the San Joaquin Valley. As far as authenticity, Piperade falls somewhere in between. As far as chichi, well: it tries to bill itself as "French" Basque cuisine, when there really isn't much difference between French and Spanish Basque food, since it's a tiny-ass region to begin with; its menu says, "West Coast Basque" and we all know that that is a euphemism for "California Fusion Yuppy Basque"; they have many items on their menu that include mango; and many of the menu listings include the French name for the dish instead of the Basque name. So, yeah, it's up there.

Chock full o' chichi, I must admit, is not necessarily a bad thing. It resulted in, I'm sure, such a carefully constructed combination of fresh herbs, perfect golden raisins, ridiculously smooth and tangy goat cheese, and their placement inside of a just-ripe-enough piquillo pepper. It resulted in, no doubt, perfectly seared scallops. And, to be sure, it resulted in a fluffy mousse approximation of the oh-so-Spanish turron. In fact, I could have even dealt with a tad more chichi in my "cod donostia"  -- the Basque-iest of Basque dishes -- which was completely uninteresting and maybe even a bit overcooked.

But despite the inherent snobbishness of their attempt to Frenchify Basque food, Piperade's fusion approach is, in some ways, representative of the only possible solution to the nationalist violence that has plagued the Basque Country for so many years. Basque food is as dear to many Basques as it is to the rest of the world. Old Basque men in berets attend secret Men-only cooking society meetings where they trade -- and guard -- traditional recipes. They will argue that it is the best cuisine in the world, that they invented many French dishes long before the French. However, as important as the preservation of this tiny culture is, too much emphasis on authenticity only creates the kinds of perceptions of difference -- between Basques and Spaniards or French, for instance -- that have fueled both the terrorist organization ETA to commit violence against the Spanish as well as against Basques who do not support its cause and the conservative Spanish government to commit violence against and suspend the civil liberties of many Basques. Yes, I know that the chef at Piperade probably had no political message in mind when he added a slice of mango to a traditional Basque dish. Still, it's as good a place as any to start.
author: Ben P.

description:
Pretty good stuff. Decent prices/portions, relatively high quality, quick service. 

It would be nice if there were prices on the menu board - I really can't come up with any reason to not have prices, and it's really annoying.

A lot of reviews here complain about rude service, and maybe the crew is not incredibly customer-focused or attentive to detail, but I don't think anyone is trying to be a dick on purpose, and it's just a sandwich shack - the stakes are not high.
author: Wangston P.

description: Very reasonable prices for the quantity and quality of food. We had chicken with pistachios and apricots surrounded by shittake jus, tender squid with capers, a great port and a rich chocolate dessert. My mouth is watering as I think about it!
author: Shannon R.

description: It's Pip-erade not Piper-ade.  Sigh.  It just gets harder to pronounce things as I age. Besides the light flickering on and off above our table, it was a completely enjoyable dinner.  The size of the restaurant was perfect - not too small, not too large.  Noise level never got too loud, even as the evening wore on.  Very cool, laissez faire waiter but we never wanted for anything. I'm still thinking about the small plate calamari - so that was the memorable dish of the night for me.  Foie gras - very earthy and strong on the duckiness.  Halibut & duck main dishes were lightly infused with sweet fruit flavors and colors of nectarines and blackberries.  Lovely.  Especially liked the colorful little mini squashes accompanying the halibut.  Besides the foie-gras, the other heavy dish of the night was the potato gratin - heavily decadent but also good if your arteries can take it. Hazelnut rock for dessert was interesting - liked the moussey part better than the rocky part.  As always, it's fun to dine with Curly & Larry.
author: Peg S.

description: Came on a warm Monday, it was pretty busy. Love, love, love the decor. Parking was super easy. Food...so good! Tried the lamb..perfect...petrale sole, perfect...turron mousse dessert...wish I could eat one everyday at every meal! Staff was really friendly.
author: Olivia A.

description: Love this place.  Fine innovative food in a super comfortable setting.  Chef Hirogoyan sets the tone with his great rendition of modern Basque cu sine.  Everything is full of flavor and the mix of seasonings fresh ingredients is subtle and well balanced creating a fantastic food experience. The vibe is low key and light and the staff provides excellent service.  Don't miss the mushroom tart and the poached sea bass.  All the food is excellent and the prices are quiet fair for an award winning food experience.
author: david b.

description: I wish this was closer to my work place so I could come here more frequently.  It was worth walking around the rest of the afternoon with my teeth stained just to eat the squid dish with squid ink.
author: Ernest S.

description: I liked the interior, and the food was interesting.   I had a good fig salad and haricots verts to start, and my halibut was good.   Nothing really slayed me but it was a business lunch, and I couldn't taste too broadly across the menu at lunch.  I would try it again.   Expensive for a lunch, especially these days.
author: Laurel B.

description: A really pleasant space, with great service and delicious food.  There is a good selection of wine by the glass and we also got a bottle of a 2001 La Rioja Alta that was truly memorable.  We shared a selection of small plates: haricots vert, Dungeness crab, "bacalao" (deserves the quotation marks, it's a very good dish but it's not bacalao), stuffed piquillo peppers.  Although it's on the menu only as a dinner-sized portion, we asked them to bring us two small versions of the piperade, which was delicious comfort food in the best sense.  Some dessert wines and we were totally satisfied.  What a pleasure!
author: Laura H.

description: If a deft hand in the kitchen, a warm personality, and a genuine concern that his guests are enjoying themselves are the makings of a 'celebrity' chef, then Gerald Hirigoyen qualifies. It's not unusual to see him out front, schmoozing with dinners and graciously accepting their deserved compliments. The simple but stunning space, with its wooden beams, bold, colorful paintings, and subdued lighting, is a pleasant setting for the cuisine, a creative blend of his French Basque origins and contemporary California touches. The menu is divided into small and big plates; the former include options like garlic-spiced prawns, warm sheep's-milk cheese-and-ham terrine, white bean salad with eggs, chives, and anchovies, and garlic soup with rock shrimp, bacon, bread, and egg. Among the more substantial offerings, all priced below $20 - are piperade (a traditional dish of melted onions, peppers, tomatoes, and garlic) served with sauteed Serrano ham and poached egg, blue nose sea bass with brussel sprouts, and beast of chicken with roasted butternut squash. Each day Monday through Friday, a different Basque specialty - such as sauteed calamari in ink sauce or braised rabbit with prunes - is featured. Orange blossom beignets and kefir cheese yogurt with honey and caramelized nuts are irresistible desserts. Hirigoyen's culinary empire includes Piperade Cafe in Icehouse Alley (between Union  & Green and Sansome & Battery ), with a wide range of high quality take-out soups, salads, sandwiches, pastries, and coffee drinks, and the more informal Bocadillos, a sandwich-soup-and-tapas bar.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Despite what other yelpers said about poor service, especially with a Travelzoo coupon, my experience was vastly different.  Great service, period.  Friendly, smiling, checking back, etc.  As for the food, it was all superior.  I had the lamb chops, my wife the bouillabaisse.  Both excellent.  I had the calamari appetizer, my wife had the butter lettuce.  Both excellent.  I had the orange blossom flavored "thingies", my wife had the chocolate pudding/cake.  Both excellent.  We ordered an additional bottle of wine because the one glass provided wasn't enough for the full dinner.  Well priced, good wine. As for the Travelzoo pricing package, I didn't find it onerous at all.  Without the extra bottle of wine, we would have paid an additional $40 or so, so it would have been about $120.00 total with TZ.  Where else in SF can you get a terrific 3 course dinner, 2 glasses of wine, tax, tip etc. for $120?  If we'd paid full price, yes it would have been more, but still a good value considering the quality of the food, the ambience and the service.  So, all in all, go.....you should try it.  You'll like it, full price or discounted.
author: Ron B.

description: And the winner of my new favorite restaurant in the city goes to... Man, this place is unbelievably good. From the warm lighting and thick, wooden beams to the delicious bottles of Candella that are oh so hard to find, this is some excellent Basque cuisine. Inventive food that you just cannot find anywhere like the sheep's milk and ham terrine (small plate) or the seared ono (large plate). It all was delicious and the atmosphere would have made up for any shortcomings, had there been any. Piperade is great for a date or small group, romantic yet casual... I can't wait to go back.
author: Michael E.

description: A fantastic location and a wickedly charming establishment translates into my favorite top ten for Ladies who Lunch!
author: Yelper A.

description: This was one of the better dining experiences I've had in SF.  The food was good all around.  I had the lamb chops and they were the best chops I've had in the city.  The portions were smaller than I would have wanted but they were perfectly seasoned.  Our party tried 6 or 7 dishes and not one of them was disappointing.  After a so-so meal at Zarzuela, I was pleasantly surprised by the flavors of this Spanish restaurant.
author: John N.

description: My wife and I picked this restaurant based on very positive Yelp feedback, and because it is Basque cuisine, and we wanted to try something different.  Basque is not French or Spanish, but its own distinct style of food.  We had 2 cocktails (Basquerak and Donostia), and some Voss still water as far as beverages go.  The Basquerak is similar to a Sazarac - not sweet and made with bitters.  I had the Donostia, which is gin based, and also not sweet.  Both of these drinks are very good and strong , but to be savored slowly.   The appetizers (Ttipiak)  are small plates, similar to tapas, so we went for three of them: piquillo peppers,  calamari "a la Plancha", and the marinated mussel salad.  All three were outstanding.  For entrees, we had the steamed pacific rockfish with bed of spinach, and the chicken breast, roasted gernika peppers, white beans, and chorizo.  The gernika peppers are mild and very flavorful, and complements the chicken breast and white beans well.  The restaurant feels warm and comfortable, and the service is excellent.  For desert we had the gateau basque (marzipan cake with cherry preserves) and gateau warm chocolate cake - both were mind blowing.
author: John H.

description:
One very excellent business lunch!

I'm a lover of good food, regardless of how authentic it is, and Piperade was no disappointment.

For appetizers we got the following:
Warm piquillo peppers with goat cheese, California raisins and moscatel vinaigrette
-The goat cheese was warm, creamy and the proper degree of tangy; the raisins added a hint of sweetness that complemented the cheese and the pepper was the perfect envelope to pull all the flavors together
Dungeness crab salad "tangurro" with apple, curry, and piment d'Espelette
-It didn't hurt that it was dungeness crab season - this was the best crab salad I've had - it did not smell like fish at all, was creamy (which usually a gross consistency to have with fish, in my opinion), and had whole, nice big chunks of crab.
Chilled mussel and bread salad with red wine vinagrette
-Not usually a fan of mussels, but these mussels were big, full of flavor (like an ocean in your mouth) and the bread salad complemented the texture of the mussel.
Thinly sliced Serrano ham
-The ham was wonderful, thinly sliced, airy pieces of meat that melted in your mouth (it also was excellent with any leftover goat cheese from the first appetizer).

For lunch I had the Steamed Pacific Snapper with Fried Garlic Vinaigrette.  The snapper was perfect - flaky and again, no fishy smell.  The slices of garlic were perfectly pan fried and echoed of Goodfellas.  The meal was on a dish of spinach that even a child would eat - delicious, eloquently sauteed with a hint of garlic.

The service was excellent - all the wait staff was easy to talk to, ask questions, very quick on asking if you needed anything.  For lack of a better word, they were well "trained."

Regarding prices, I'm not really sure, since it was a business lunch, it looked a bit pricey, but there are affordable entrees on the menu for under $15 and all the appetizers are around $7.  This is only for lunch, not sure how dinner works, but I definitnely recommend Piperade for an elegant lunch, if you feel like treating yourself, or if you need to entertain a client.
author: Meghana A.

description: Delicious food, warm atmosphere, welcoming, old world service.  The nightly specials are particularly good, and the Piperade burger, available at lunch, is the best burger in the city. Great chese plate.
author: Kelli K.

description: James ordered for both of us, and if you know James, that meant a lot of food.  The waiter had the kind of charm that made you think that perhaps he was making up for some deep professional insecurity, and maybe that French accent wasn't real.  Like maybe he was just making up his wine pairing suggestions.  But then, soon after our food came and the wine to match, magic happened.  The kind of gustatory exquisiteness and perfect service that you know you won't remember any better than you remember that girl your sophomore year who turned out to be the best kisser of your life -- but you didn't know it then -- you thought something better would come along, and then it didn't.    Well, I might have a better evening at a restaurant.  But I might not.
author: Adam E.

description: I live on the East Coast, I am from the French Basque country. Every time I am in SF, I make sure to have a meal at Piperade. The food is excellent and the whole experience takes me back home. I only wished I could come to Piperade more often.
author: Emmanuel H.

description:
ooo lala, i just can't get enough of this Basque restaurant...I've been to one other Basque restaurant (in South San Francisco) that was just as good, however the ambiance at Piperade closes the deal. 

i've been here several times for lunch and dinner and just can't get enough! The food even managed to impress my picky boyfriend who has only praised the cooking of his beloved Momma. 

My favourite dishes are the oxtail, rabbit, piperade, cheese tray... just to name a few. I wasn't crazy about the croquettes, didn't really do much for me. It's near the Levi's Plaza so you'll find a lot of Williams Sonoma & Levi's execs hanging out... it's also got a nice (smaller) outdoor area for when the weather cooperates.
author: Nenette Y.

description: I went there for a business lunch with a large party. As I work in the advertising quad on Battery, it is hard to find a good spot. It is definitely a business crowd inside. We tried different appetizers and I ordered a sea bass for entree. Food was cooked perfectly and the presentation was beautiful! However, the restaurant is a little bit crowded and your elbows will be bumped from time to time.
author: Yi-Bing Z.

description: I've heard my friends rave about the place and finally got to check it out. Piperade's definitely one of those places where when you compare the price of the dishes to the actual size and quality, it's a great deal.  We ordered the sheep's milk terrine , the pork (oh so tender), monkfish, and peppers stuffed with goat cheese, sundried raisins and pinenuts ...everything was fabulous and recommended...portions surprisingly generous.  Along with the great meal came wonderful service....Chef Gerald was often making sure everyone was having a good time in the dining room ....which is very romantic and cozy (the dining room, not Chef...although he seems like he can be a true romantic).  Didn't try the dessert but it wouldn't be a shame if you skipped the cheese plate.  All in all I loved the place.
author: Tanger T.

description: I'm really mixed on Piperade, so I'll err on the side of being generous.  The food is delish - we literally mopped up our plate with the foie gras - and the wine selection quite generous.  However, I ate the lamb chops and ended up puking when I got home.  It might have been because Karen ordered it RARE, and it did taste good, so I don't put the blame on the kitchen.  Would definitely go back... but probably stay away from the lamb :-)
author: Serena Y.

description: Awesome food, ambiance, and service. I had the garlic, egg, and bread soup ... amazing!
author: Richard D.

description: The food here was excellent and even though our group was chatty and took forever to order, the waiter was very patient and gave excellent suggestions. His wine suggestion was the best and went very well with my crab salad.
author: Teju A.

description:
kaixo!

tucked away in a nondescript area somewhere between the embarcadero and the financial district, you will find piperade. once you find the entrance, you will enter into a warm and comfortable environment. authentic basque art hangs on the walls and authentic basque cuisine awaits you (i brought a friend from bilbao...trust me!) 

i recommend the piquillo peppers stuffed with goat cheese and raisins followed by the piperade: serrano ham with a poached egg and tomatoes. also, the txakolina wine from....the basque.  for dessert, the chocolate cake with creme fraiche.

merezi du hemen jan egitea. 
lau izarrak!
author: eric g.

description: If you don't like tapas, then don't talk to me. If you do, then Piperade is one of the best options in the city. The location leaves something to be desired if you're looking for a "hot spot" part of town, although it's not too long of a walk to Bubble Lounge and North Beach.
author: Mike G.

description: I took my friend here for her belated bday celebration.  The food was really good, we nibbled on the cheese platter, our main course which was Pacific Snapper & Halibut were tasty, so was our apple tart dessert.  I was so happy that there was a lot of parking in this area that along is a gem...
author: Michelle M.

description:
went here for a first date.
now we are in love.
food was amazing. 
service was exceptional.
ambiance was to die for. 
we were the youngest people there. (late 20's) but i liked it that way. everyone there i felt knew what they were getting into.
the veal was so amazing.
author: Tim B.

description: Dropped by the restaurant after reading reviews on Yelp and was excited to find a place serving beignets!  Unfortunately, the food was very disappointing, given the price.  The stuffed pepper and calamari were not flavorful.  The seafood stew and sole were too salty.  The only good dish was the mushroom tart.  And the beignet, which I was looking forward to all night, was undercooked.  Given the great number of restaurants in SF, I rather drop my $$$ somewhere else.
author: John L.

description:
My son's birthday--a very special day--so we chose Piperade to celebrate with his best friend and me. BF, Alex is from France so selected a very nice Pouilly Fuisse to accompany our Calamari "a la Plancha." Deliciously spiced. Then on to the Warm Sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine--perfectly crisped on the outside and wonderfully rich in flavor. We opened an old French wine that we brought which gradually opened up into a lovely wine with a lot of family memories. The young woman waiting on us was very sweet and fun, jousting in French with Alex. She recommended the Mushroom tarte and we also got the cold, poached Foie Gras. The tarte was savory with a great pastry crust and the Foie Gras was creamy and melt in your mouth good (not a crumb was left of either).
We asked Chef/Owner Gerald Hirigoyen to recommend a wine to go with our main dishes. He chose a Temperanillo from Lodi which was big and fruity, but not overwhelming for the dishes we had. The guys had the Lamb-which comes with just right pink inside lamb chops, lamb sausage and whatever else there was I never found out as their plates were clean by the time I looked up from my Piperade!
We whiled away the hours, talking, savoring the wine and enjoying a day when work and hectic schedules were forgotten for awhile. Eventually, we were the only patrons, but were not hurried or made to feel like we should leave. Got around to dessert and decided on Beignets and coffee. The pleasant atmosphere and the chance for a leisurely lunch was such a gift for all of us, we left re-connected with each other and happily full.
author: Dyann E.

description: Piperade was my first experience at Basque food.  It's traditional, right?  Their salads are awesome, and so is their bread.  And the piperade.  Ooh and their snapper and halibut.  I think my mouth is watering just thinking about it.  Great atmosphere, friendly service, and best of all, great lunch company.  Too bad it's so far from work, or I'd come more often.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The steak here is awesome. Definitely good atmosphere for an after-work dinner or drink. This place gives you a very personable feel, and the waiters are very professional and personable.

The chocolate cake dessert was also the best I've eaten in quite a while.
author: Linda Y.

description:
i haven't visited many nice restaurants in my life, so this place was quite the gem for me.  i was lovin this to the max.

the appetizers were all delicious, esp the cheese and calamari. oh and those stuffed peppers...mmm

i tried a little bit of everyone's main course and the best was definetely the steak.. by far. surprising, yes.  the halibut was the 2nd best; very light and tasty.

i love spots like this
author: Victor B.

description:
Piperade is brought to you by chef Gerald Hirigoyen, who also owns nearby Bocadillos.  There aren't many Basque restaurants in the Bay Area, so it's a good thing that Piperade and Bocadillos are here to represent.

Food:  3 stars.  
The restaurant has a regular menu and classic Basque dishes served on different nights.  We chose from the regular menu as the restaurant had already run out of the dish of the day (atlantic cod "porrusalda").  This would be a running theme throughout the night.  For appetizers, we had the garlic soup, warm sheep's milk cheese, calamari "a la plancha" and dungeness crab salad "txangurro."  The garlic soup with rock shrimp, bacon, bread and egg was definitely garlicky and too tepid.  The calamari "a la plancha" with fennel, olive, caper and coriander salpicon was the least appealing of the appetizers - the texture was good (not too chewy), but there was not enough flavor.  The Dungeness crab salad "txangurro" with basil, roaster pepper and mango was also a little on the bland side.  I wonder where they got the crab, considering the recent shortage due to the oil spill... The best dish among the appetizers is the warm sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine with aged sherry, which was a little salty (probably due to the ham), but REALLLLLY GOOOD.  It's fried and crispy and orrrrgasmic.  Next were the entrees.  Like the cod special, the sea bass was also unavailable.  Fortunately, we had plenty of good things to still choose from.  The piperade, which is a stew similar to ratatouille, but prepared with onion, sweet peppers, and tomatoes sauted in olive oil, was a standout.  It had crispy sauteed Serrano ham and poached egg on top.  The ham totally makes the dish.  We also had the steamed pacific snapper with spinach and crunchy fried garlic vinaigrette.  The ingredients melded well together, but they didn't do a good job of fileting and cleaning the fish, as we found some random small bones and scales in the fish.  The lamb basquaise chop, shoulder and loin with "zikiro" vinaigrette was tender and juicy, but just a bit too hearty with the gigante beans that accompanied it - and I do mean gigante.  The savory filet of duck with salsifis, quince and peppercorns was by far the best dish...I'd order it again and again.  Desserts were a bit on the average side.  In keeping with the night's theme, the popular orange blossom beignets were out.  The caramel custard "koka" is basically a glorfied name for flan, but not really that spectacular.  The chocolate cake with creme fraiche was just okay.
 
Service:  3 stars.  Although our waiter was really friendly at times, we mostly couldn't understand him - it must have been his Basque accent.  Service seemed slow at times, especially to take our order and to take care of the bill.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The decor is simple and modern, accented by a huge wine rack chandelier with empty bottles hanging over the largest table (I'm glad it wasn't hanging over my table - hello, earthquake).  To describe the atmosphere as convivial is correct.  My table was practically in the center of the room, and the large parties neighboring both sides of my table were loud and merry (one table was a little on the geeky side, where some guy laughed like Keith Carradine's character from Revenge of the Nerds).  Lining the walls are intimate two-person tables, where most of the patrons appeared undisturbed by the loud people in the middle.  The crowd runs the full gamut from nerds to preppies to cougars and more (yes, all were present that night).

Hits:   Filet of duck, piperade, warm sheep's milk cheese, plenty of parking at night.

Misses:  Calamari "a la plancha", running out of too many dishes, the revenge of the nerds.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Bocadillos, Iluna Basque
author: Keith C.

description:
I was brought here for my welcome lunch by my new office in SF, and I have to say it was a great way to start my dining adventures in the Bay area!

Everyone was happy with their dishes (we were a group of 9), though the service I would grade only as "ok."  I realize it's hard with a big group though, so I didn't mark the stars down for it.

The fish is consistently good, the beignets are divine.  The atmosphere is comfortable and the decor attractive.  You can easily pull together a meal out of the appetizers (which are a strong suit, IMHO).
author: Jen G.

description: This place has been around for a few years now and is going strong - and it should be. Excellent food, service and atmosphere. Lamb chops are maybe even as good as Kokkari Estatorio's (OK, different style, but on a par). I can't remember what else we had, except it was all really tasty. I really liked the ambience - it was warm and cozy and classy and it made me feel as if I were somewhere else - not that you need to feel anywhere else when in SF!
author: Dana B.

description: I used to work in this area, and at lunch I would consider it a treat to get the steak salad from their to-go window at Icehouse Alley. YUM. A good lot of very flavorful steak sits on that salad. Not sure when the window closes. Check site.
author: Mar M.

description: Piperade is great. The food is pretty satisfactory. Good place for lunch with co-workers or clients. Waiters don't bug you once every 5 minutes when you're trying to speak with clients. They have a smart hunch when to approach your table for service, and don't abondon you. Prices are a little high for lunch, but service is wonderful. Table covers are always bright white with even cloth runners. Nice location, in the waterfront district.
author: Food L.

description:
Somehow I fell in love with Piperade. The atomsphere is romantic and warm. The decor is masculine without being overbearing or overly noticable. The staff is friendly and extremely knowledgeable. The proximity to my job is unbeatable. Hoping across the street for an expertly mixed manhattan or a well selected half-bottle of wine (well, you have to make the visit worthwhile don't you?) is so convenient. 
So this was my second visit. On this visit I had reservations for dinner with a friend. And we seriously needed to catch up. So away we went - yakking up a storm from the moment I walked in the door. So the only negative thing I'm going to say here - the waiter did not seem amused by our rapid-fire conversation. On the contrary he seemed determined to make me feel bad about it. I was not up for that. I ignored him once I realized he was irritated with our lack of attention to him. The service - was fine. Water glasses filled, wine attended to, food explained -  all adequately. Enough about him. I hope he doesn't wait on me next time. 
The food was delicious. I ordered the piquillo peppers stuffed w/ goat cheese - oozing with melty goat cheese. Fantastic. I ordered a half bottle of a pinot noir for myself - reasonably priced and delicious as well. My companion ordered the calamari "a la plancha" - offered me a bite - and thank god for generosity! Another great dish - fresh, refreshing, just the right size. I ordered the New York steak and was extremely pleased. Cooked to perfection - with wonderful gascon fries and caramelized shallots. 
My first visit a month or so prior - I sat at the bar with a friend. I ordered a manhattan on the rocks. The bartender was so personable - the cocktail was perfection. I really like this bar. We ate at the bar that night and I have to say I will be doing that many more times. 
This is a beautiful dining experience - worth every penny you may spend. This establishment is seriously devoted to making your experience within its 4 walls worth the effort of the visit. I hope they save a seat at the bar for me......this Wednesday.
author: Tom R.

description: I definitely can't knock this place, but I don't know if I'd ever go back because I'm picky and not sure basque food is my style.  But it's a beautiful dining room with very well-formed dishes.  The chef is quite amazing.  It's mostly small plates (lots of meat - beware veggies!) but they were all pretty tasty.  Nothing sticks out as memorable (I went a year ago or so) but I would recommend it to anyone, especially if they like french food.
author: Annie F.

description: Fabulous. I have eaten here a bunch and love it every time. It's a great respite from the heavy French choices in the city and if you are a seafood lover they have the best sea bass I have had in the city. The seafood stew was also nice and spicy (which the owner was nice enough to come over and point out to our table after we ordered).  The service was attentive and managed to walk that nice line between in-your-face and always-there-when-you-need-them. There are rumors that Piperade made Gourmet's top restaurants in the country (comes out this summer) so get in before it becomes impossible!
author: Catherine K.

description: One of my favorites. Excellent and interesting food, interesting and excellent wine list!  Love to sit at the bar and eat a few small plates. I have never been disappointed. I have recommended the restaurant to many and have been thanked for the recommendation by all. Enjoy!
author: Josh N.

description:
i had a beautiful weeknight dinner here with my grams and her sugar daddy. piperade is comfortable, inviting, and un-intimidating. the space is a good manageable size and the low beamed ceilings are a cozy change from the airy impersonal spaces that many restaurants favor. there is a nice background of conversation but nothing deafening. the staff was friendly and helpful yet not intrusive. chef Hirigoyen even spent some time stopping by tables, saying hello to diners. i like the man - he has a cleverness down in his eyes and a quick genuine smile and was super charming, even after my grandmother brusquely demanded a coffee from him without realizing who he was...

over all the food was satisfying and interesting. the flavors were assertive and complex without being overdone or confused. the bread was very nice - and there are pitchers of strong grassy olive oil on each table for dipping. the basket was bountiful to start with and was refilled quickly each time we worked our way through it.

there were minor flaws, things to tweak here and there. the verjus sauce for my pistachio crusted chicken was perfect - thick and sweet but with a slight tangy edge that prevented it from being cloying - but the meat itself was a little dry and scratchy around the edges; the lamb dish suffered from the same problem. the cheese platter was utterly uninspiring which is unfortunate since basque country is rich with gorgeous cheeses. the cornmeal cake i had for desert was very disappointing - dry and coarse - and it could have also used a little more than the conservative dab of creme fraiche served under it. but the apple compote served on top of it was tart and fantastic.

basking in the after dinner glow i felt warm and well sated.
author: g t.

description: I'll have to withhold a fifth-star until I've had dinner here, but the lunchtime vibe is wonderful -- simple starters (small plates could make a meal) and great ambiance make this a delicious alternative to the Houston's monopoly over the Levi's Plaza crowd.
author: Andrew S.

description: I do not know if it really delicious, but in class our professor need to discuss one restaurant, so.....
author: Tiffany Z.

description: We had the lunch special which comes with soup or salad, a main dish, and DESSERT. Soup was delish, the seafood stew was a little cold but very flavorful, and the beignets were so scrumptious, light, and tasty. Total came out to about $30 a person. I was really digging the olive oil and balsamic that came with the bread. This place has an old European castle feel to it. I'd come back.
author: Claire C.

description: I have had a change of heart, I was there last night, and I had the calamari, which were delicious.  i also had the sea bass, and the brussel sprouts, which was amazing.  I give this spot  a good rating, yet a few draw backs. A- skip the crab salad, as although it was a ton of crab, it was not so great, pseudo mayoy. And also don't sit near the door as it is freezing.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Oh. My. God.    In the good way. 
I took my food and wine snob client here for lunch.   Starting with the service and the ambiance, we were impressed.   When an addition to our reservation showed up, there was no hemming and hawing - just another place setting and chair brought over and set up.   The tables were spaced so that we weren't on top of our neighbors and could talk business freely without worry about who might over hear our super-secret plans to take over the w... uh, well, our industry stuff...
We ordered a bottle of white bordeaux that was wonderfully balanced.  I love when a client will have wine witih lunch!!!   We ordered a few apps - mussel salad (yum), calamari (yum), cheese plate,  and peppers with a yummy cheese and raisin filling.   
When we ordered our entrees, one of our party asked which was better - the Snapper or the Sea Bass.  Our server said, "you're asking the wrong guy!"   and we quickly realized that it was Chef Gerald Hirigoyen himself who was taking our orders. 
Entrees were amazing.  I had the seafood stew (yes, I'm predictable like that) and we all enjoyed our entrees - lamb, snapper, sea bass and NY whatever it was (I can't recognize meat at all, but I hear it was delicious!) 
The food came out efficiently enough that we had time to enjoy capuccinos and dessert.   I ordered the orange beignets so that I could eat one and send the remainder away....but I ended up eating two.  They were delicious!   
Fabulous lunch - can't wait to try dinner here!
author: Maria C.

description:
i had the pacific snapper with sauteed spinach. [confirmed: i really love spinach!] usually with seafood, you get small portions, but this was not small. although, i did assume that i will finish my plate in no time with still room to spare. but by the last couple bites, i was ready to quit, surprisingly. [yes, i finished it.]

it was a group of us so we got to order a few good desserts:

*apple tart with vanilla ice cream- you'll need a knift to cut the tart, for sure. this was soooo good. apple tarts are not usually in my top choices for dessert, but this is what i WILL order next time i come here.
*turron moussecake with almonds- i love almonds, especially when they're roasted. this fluffy ensemble is light and creamy. deelish.
*caramel custard "koka"- flan. it's light texture and it melts in your mouth instantly. [i'm melting...]
author: Rosalee C.

description: I seriously try to NOT go here more than once a week. I go here too often. My co-workers and I have started to call it the "Pipehole" for simplicity.  It's the closest good spot to grab a quick bite for lunch. I love the Mr Williams chicken sandwich. The service is pretty quick, even when there's a long line. Prices are moderate and comparable to other lunch places in the area. Def. a good spot for lunch. (Piperade the restaurant is also very good!)
author: Evelyn C.

description: There 12 doller tuna with roasted peppers and onion marmalade is off the hook.
author: Prescott T.

description:
Went to piperade for a holiday get together, party of six all in the restaurant
business.  We had great service, great food, great wine.  Try the piperade with sauteed serrano ham and poached egg. Also the mushroom tart as well as the calamari excellent.  The potatoes au gratin and the fries were wonderful.   The lamb chops and steaks were cooked to perfection a rare feat.  We weren't able to stay for dessert (we had tickets to the phantom) but on a previous visit we had the apple tart, amazing.
author: patty m.

description:
3.5 stars. For the all press this place gets, one would expect quite a bit more. Not considering the hype, this is a good place with a nice rustic ambiance, feels very warm and inviting, although at times it's down right cold and dark on those dreary winter days. The food is good, but there's certainly inconsistency as another reviewer mentions. Sometimes the same dish is too salty, sometimes not at all. I don't feel the Basque flavors come through the way they should. Perhaps it's our produce? To me, it's more like eating good California cuisine with a Basque theme. What really is 4 stars about this place is the desserts. Their orange blossom beignets are awesome! 
You can often find the exec chef greeting patrons. In fact you're more likely to see him outside the kitchen than inside. Prices are high, even for lunch, and even if you want a sandwich you have to get extra sides, which are pricey, but very very good (especially the fries). Their MR Williams is a classic Chicken Avocado sandwich which is done really well. 
------
Piperade to-go is the little to-go window open at lunchtime at Williams Sonoma Corp building. It offers some good lunch options such as sandwiches and soups (they also have Mr Williams here). Their sandwiches are a little cheaper than what you pay in the restaurant, but the quality is also worse, although some would reason that it's still better than getting something for the same price as the deli. It seems they sometimes use the restaurants leftovers for the to-go boxes, especially for the side salad. Once there were fruit flies in the mixed greens that came with the sandwich. Gross. They do have some yummy cookies, yogurt & honey, spring rolls, fancy sodas, available at the to-go window. The line gets really long right at lunch, so get there early.
author: B C.

description: Piperade is probably my favorite restaurant in SF.  We have gone there for several important celebrations  ( including the first time I met my in-laws) and they have never let us down.  Food, service, wine list everything is amazing, and the atmosphere is a great mix of friendly/special.  I highly recommend the ham and cheese terrine, the beignets (sp?) and the Basque wines .
author: cynthia a.

description: I finally was able to have dinner here and it was worth the wait!  My friend lives right on the Embarcadero, so we walked there.  It was perfect weather last night and we were all seated in about 15 minutes with no reservations. We started out with a bunch of small plates: fava bean and treviso salad, Calamari with fennel and the piquillo peppers(delish). I had the roasted halibut which was the most beautifully prepared fish I have had in a very long time.  My other friends ordered snapper, salmon and the lamp chop.  All looked amazing and the lamp was done perfectly.  We had 2 bottles of wine which were so lovely, they paired with our food to the tee.  We passed on dessert as we had to make reservations for drinks elsewhere.  The waitstaff were beyond helpful and very attentive.  I will be looking forward to going back maybe for lunch very soon.
author: A M.

description:
I came here with a large group of girls for a birthday dinner and I will say that the ambience is great. (FYI - it is a bit of an older crowd)  It's warm and inviting and would be a great date spot too.  

However, the service was extremely disappointing.  Our server  forgot to take our dinner order for quite some time and one of us had to send back a drink.  Then, they never came around to refill our drink orders or offer us a dessert menu.  The food was, for the most part, pretty tasty, with the exception of the halibut which was really overcooked.  I would also recommend the small plates over the larger entrees.  

The most disappointing part of the evening was when our server pointed out several times that tip was NOT included and then stood over us while we counted out cash for the bill and practically grabbed the check out of my hand.

Although the food was good, I wouldn't run back due to the service.  There are a lot better places in the city.
author: Jamie S.

description:
Great food in a great environment.  The bacalao with oyster flavor was great as was the basque seafood stew.  I liked the special squid dish on Tuesday with squid ink.  The crab salad tower was also nice.  Cocktails and service were good.  

However, if there was a 4.5 category I would choose that.  In spite of a great experience that I will go back to, it wasn't really extraordinary, just very good.
author: Richard P.

description: I only been there 2 times and i love that place very quiet service was good and the food was delicious.
author: Mani N.

description:
The food here is good, but not amazing- more french (the chef is french) than basque, I would say. 

 The service is great- I was the first person to arrive (20 minutes early) out of a party of 12 and the chef personally came over to chat with me and helped me choose a glass of wine. The ambiance is nice, not over the top. The basque cake for dessert was simple and delicious.
author: katie m.

description:
I am on a business trip in San Francisco.  The night before last, friends and I went to Piperade.  We were very excited to go, as my husband and friends had a great dining experience at Piperade this past winter.  I wish I could say that I was that lucky.  My experience was nothing short of AWFUL.

I'll begin with the food.  It was okay.  The asparagus salad was tasty, but the flan's consistency was too crumbly and the flavor too sharp for the smoothness of the dressing.  My halibut was fine, but not stellar.  The potatoes gratin were PHENOMENAL.  This was the very best item on the table.  (Hence the 1 star.)

Now I'll write about the service.  It was BY FAR the WORST SERVICE I have ever experienced in my life.  The waiter took 30 minutes to take our order.  He never asked if we wanted wine.  (An obvious up sell that he could have benefited from.)  There was a dirty wine bottle from the previous guests right next to one of my dining companions.  It remained there for the entire meal.  After the food was LITERALLY DROPPED in front of us, we ate.  Most of us felt the food was, "eh".  

After we were finished with our entrees, the dirty dishes and EMPTY water glasses sat for about 20 minutes.  (Our water glasses were NEVER refilled.)

Our waiter finally DROPPED a few dessert menus.  We were all so frustrated by our experience thus far that we were praying for a delicious dessert to sweeten a pretty bad experience.   Unfortunately, it took our waiter 20 more minutes to ask what we wanted for dessert.  (Still with empty water glasses and dirty cocktail glasses.)  We took a pass on dessert completely.

One of my dining companions needed to use the restroom...  It was completely FILTHY.  There was actually wet vomit sitting in and around the toilet.

We left a 10% tip.  I've never done that before.

I doubt I will ever try Piperade again.  It's a shame.  They lost several real "foodies".
author: pam w.

description: This is the ultimate high-end tapas eatery, consistently good on every visit, with attentive but not intrusive service.  The wine list is excellent, the small plates perfect for sharing, and delectible presentation.  And just when I thought I couldn't possibly have dessert, voila! the most beautiful tart, chocolate pudding-like cake, among other treats successfully tempted.  Not for the calorie conscious and not intended to be -- indulge!
author: Paul Y.

description:
a long awaited experience, turn out ho-hum ... along with the service ho-hum ... the cheese platter appetizer was poorly selected and presented, the entrees:  the lamb and black cod was expertly prepared but oddly paired with missed-matched accompaniments; namely fennel and beans; however the sauce for the fish was pure sex!  the service was for those regulars and not for newcomers, how sad in these challenging times ...

did not have our reservations, and seated in the deuce next to the emergency fire exit, that should have been the time to continue on thru that door and skip the dinner-of-what-i-hoped-for ...
author: tim y.

description: Incredible Basque food. The blue cheese and potato soup, the crab and mango salad, the fish, the chocolate cake, the orange blossom beignets - you must go. Just don't order the stuffed calamari. Go to Iluna Basque for that.
author: Vena V.

description: Friends took me there for my birthday.  Food, service and wine recommendations were spot on.  Awsome waiter!!!  (Younger guy with the goat.)  We were there for three hours and never felt rushed. Will definately be going back there.  Best dining experience in a long time.
author: John C.

description: I took my boyfriend here for his birthday dinner. Neither of us had been before. I have to say it was once of the best meals I've had in SF. The service and atmosphere was fantastic as well. They were able to seat us at a table where we could sit next to each other and the chef/owner Gerald came over to talk to us on a couple of occasions.
author: Andrea G.

description: WOW! Now I know why SF is the foodie Capital of the U.S.!   Lived in LA for the past 20 years and never found a Basque place within reasonable driving distance.  Now I have a place that's not only in town , but with OUTSTANDING food.  Can't sing enough praises about his place -- and as to some of the negative reviews about service, I have NO idea what that's about cuz we were waited on hand and foot!  Can't wait to come back!
author: Lee Y.

description:
brought my lady here for her birthday.  i had heard over a year ago how great this place was so my expectations were already high.

i have noticed lately that it is getting harder and harder to "wow" me with food.  perhaps my taste buds have been overstimulated since moving back to the bay area.  the best places i find seem to be the ones that take simple ingredients and really wow you with the prep.  not the case here.   the food was good, but honestly didn't seem like anything i couldn't prepare better for myself at home. 

it's a great date place, the decor is old school and the place feels very classy.  solid food, good wine selection, but i just wasn't all that impressed.
author: Steven C.

description: In my imaginary world, this place would be called Pooperade.  The food was not so great.  The only good thing we had was the cherry tart appetizer.  Our duck was undercooked, our lamb was dried out, and the calamari special was just not very tasty.  Even the desserts were pretty ho hum.  Total tab was over $230 for 3 people (including an average bottle of wine).  I was pretty disappointed.  Should have gone down the street to Kokkari instead.
author: Cindy W.

description: My friend and I were in the Financial District and wandering around looking for a restaurant. Piperade had just opened back then and we decided to give it a try. Obviously, we didn't have a reservation, but were offered seating at the bar or the communal dining table in the middle of the cozy restaurant. This table was HUGE!! The two of us sat at one end and had an amazing, delicious meal that neither of us expected. At one point, the chef came out and inquired about our meal and how we liked the restaurant. Unlike many SF establishments, there's no showiness or glitz involved at Piperade. It's just that and the wonderful Basque cuisine that makes this restaurant a stand-out and one worth visiting again and again.
author: Kittenheel S.

description: Piperade - another top 100 for the SF Chronicle and another must check out. Some websites note it as spanish/tapas, other says French, it's more like French tapas. We started off with the crab salad and endive/escarole salad with serrano ham. Both were really good. Well seasoned and not too heavy on the dressing. Both went very well with the sauvignon blanc. We tried out the monkfish which was firm but succulent.  Next time would definitely go back to try more of the meat dishes. We did save room for dessert and the creme caramel was the absolute best I have ever had in a long time. It was sweet and creamy with a hint of vanilla bean. The caramel sauce was so decadent I would have licked it off with my finger.
author: Josephine H.

description: No better Basque cuisine to be had outside of San Sebastian.  Many accolades to Chef Tom Snyder
author: Madama M.

description: My favorite fine dining in SF.  Piquillo peppers are so good and so is all the food, especially the deserts!
author: Danielle B.

description: The dipping oil for the bread was nutty and absolutely mouthwatering.  It was difficult to refrain from eating too much bread because the oil was so delicious!  I felt the garlic soup starter was too salty for my taste, but my dining partner enjoyed it.  We both loved the duck and the lamb main courses.  The orange blossom beignets were very unique.  I would have loved more attentive service because we often had to flag down the servers, but the food and ambiance were solid.  This is a great special occasion restaurant which I will definitely visit again!
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description:
In hindsight not sure it rates 5 stars. But I was HUNGRY and the food was definitely tasty.  And expensive. We went on a Wednesday night. Wanted to try for a few years. Dining companion had been there several years ago and still remembered it = must be pretty good.
Decided on several small plates.  Garlic soup, special of asparagus soup, mussel salad, white bean salad, sheep milk cheese terrine, mushroom pie.  
That garlic soup is delicious. Straight up. Reminds me of some kind of Chinese soup. Probably due to egg floating in it. Really garlicky, bacon, egg, and perfectly cooked rock shrimp. Not rubbery at all. How do they do that in a boiling soup? I would order that anywhere over and over again. Did not share it, though that was original plan.
Asparagus soup. Eh. not my thing. Companion liked it.
Mussel salad- well, i mistakenly thought we were getting steamed mussels. My fault for not reading. Still, it was really good, though seeing mussels out of shell struck me as odd. Didn't stop me from gobbling it up.  White bean salad very tasty. Not a whole lot different than something I'd get at maybe Whole foods. Well, maybe a bit better. Also wiped plate clean.
Mushroom pie kinda disappointed me. Was barely warn, crust not so much that of tart (i.e. shortening and flour), but more like flaky pastry that's toughened or sat around too long. Tasted ok, but not exciting. The Terrine was also not what I anticipated. I thought it would be melted cheese in a casserole, as I'd had at  a few Spanish places. Nope.
