It's layered cheese and ham that appeared to be pan-fried. I love salt but this was WAY too salty for me. My friend loved it. Thought it was the best thing we had. I enjoyed small bits of it atop the mushroom pie. It was just way too salty (and quite greasy) for me.
Though we were both really full , especially after eating 2 baskets of bread (did I mention we were hungry?), we still got dessert. From these reviews it seems most are comped a couple glasses of the sparkling dessert wine. We were as well. Very nice, not too sweet but just right. I got the hazelnut chocolate Rocher mousse and he got the caramel custard. Both were very tasty. I prefer chocolate and I like Ferrero Rocher chocolates, so the crust made of what seemed to be melted Rocher was really lovely.
We were both stuffed afterwards, and both very happy with dinner. Service and food was exceptionally good. All in all I guess it does warrant 5 stars.
author: Allucaneat G.

description: the food was great,wine selections wonderful and ambiance nice but the server could be a little "warmer" and attentive.no oil on the table with bread,wasnt that friendly......too bad,especially it was our 5 yr anniversary and we finally got a babysitter!!!
author: Aubrey P.

description: I took the fiancée here for her birthday and it certainly impressed. The brick interior is warm and inviting and the tables are not placed on top of one another, meaning you don't have to listen to the conversation at the next table over. We started the evening off with drinks at the bar, where a friendly French bartender served me up a 'don-OSTIA' as he called it (nunca mejor dicho -- I was definitely feeling it's effects by the time we sat down) -- ginger, juniper, agave and a lemon twist. Very nice and very potent. We started off with the famed stuffed piquillo peppers and though there were only two of them, they did not disappoint. For our main course, I ordered the New York steak and the finacée, the duck. The waitress suggested a spot-on Bordeaux to accompany. Both mains were very good, though not outstanding. I preferred the duck and my fiancée, the steak (grass is always greener on the other side of the table...), though we both agreed the best part of either dish was the mushrooms that accompanied my steak. Dessert surprisingly stole the show. Rarely, if ever, does something as glorified on Yelp as the orange beigneta has been, live up to the impossible expectations over-zealous yelpers set for it. I must admit, these little doughy puff-balls exceeded even the most hyperbolic reviews. I felt their light orange perfume in my mouth the rest of the evening and woke up this morning thinking about them...My advice, IF they happen to serve these little gems in the morning, would be to check this place out for brunch and get a massive café creme to accompany a half dozen orange beignetas. In short, we'll be back...soon.
author: Matthew Z.

description: Piperade is definitely a restaurant to return to.  I've only had lunch there, but look forward to going for dinner soon.  Their to-go window on the back side of the restaurant has delicious lunch and breakfast options (a bit pricey, but worth it)
author: Heather C.

description: food was good but servers arent the friendliet
author: Jared A.

description: My second time to Piperade. The first time, a couple of years back, was very good. This time, it was stupendous. My wife had the piquillo pepper app and the salmon with morels and corn. Holy crap! Both of those were outstanding - especially the salmon. I had the white bean with boquerones (anchovies) app and the chicken with chorizo jus, which were also excellent. However, my wife's salmon ranks as one of the best dishes I've had in my life. Great service, with excellent recommendations for matching wines rounding out the great meal. The chocolate Biarritz was also great. A fantastic and memorable meal!
author: Jose d.

description: it sucks because i really can't give a very detailed review.  unfortunately, the drinks part of "dinner and drinks" kind of screwed that up!  BUT i do remember the important things!   the food was fantastic and different (i've had little exposure to basque food) and the service was excellent... soo there's no doubt that i will be back.  loved the space too, the low ceilings and wood paneling made it feel very warm and inviting inside.
author: Yvette H.

description: Basque food keeps calling me back. You will find Chef Girard at the door most of the days. Great atmosphere and food. Love the crab salad, calamari in its ink with rice, the steamed snapper, almond mousse dessert, list goes on and on...YUMMY!
author: Angela H.

description: I actually wasn't that impressed with Piperade.  Was expecting more from this restaurant based on reviews I've read and the reputation.  Maybe it was an off night.  The ambiance is very nice and cozy.  The staff was attentive.  Certain dishes were tasty, but of the three or four dishes we ordered, only one (the lamb) was exceptional.  For the price, this was disappointing.
author: Dave L.

description: We sat at the wonderful square table in the center of the restaurant...great ambience and sumptious Basque food. Love the sauteed calamari in ink sauce "Txipiroa"!!!! Excellent!
author: Yan M.

description: I so much wanted to love this place. I'm a big fan of Chef Gerald Hirigoyen and Fringale and have been wanting to try this place for the longest time. Unfortunately it did not live up to expectations. From the luke warm service, to the luke warm food, to the luke warm hostess who kept eyeing us wanting us to leave so she can seat another couple, it just was not a very enjoyable experience. I gave it 3 stars because of the great wine selection.
author: Reza E.

description:
Like going back to Spain - but maybe even better in terms of the food...
Wow - went here after choosing 4 places on yelp to try to get it on short notice during a business trip.  They didn't have a table, but said "we can save you a few seats at the bar..." - which they did (how many restaurants will actually do that?!)
Chummy little place - nice atmosphere - was pretty packed on a Thursday night.
Food was FANTASTIC - everything from the olives to the bread to the 3 starters we tried (Calamari - best flavor of any you ever had, Fava Bean and mint salad (WOW!), stuffed Piquillo Peppers (mmmmmmmm), to the entrees (Seared duck breast with cherries and sunchokes (Oh MY), Salmon with Lentils etc (moiiiisst).
I spend a lot of time in West LA with all the good restaurants there (and a non-limiting expense account), but this place beats most of the LA restaurants plus just a super friendly vibe you NEVER find in LA!   Am from Seattle - felt more like Seattle quality service, ambience, and food.  Great stuff!
author: Chris D.

description: I came here for a friend's b-day on a Friday night. This was my first foray with Basque food and didn't know quite what to expect. From the appetizers all the way to desert, every dish was deliciously prepared. Everybody in my party just kept raving about their dishes and about how much better this meal was compared to Bix (see previous entry).
author: Sandy Y.

description: Consistent and tasty...well worth the trip to the random location!  Also, if you have a big group (8-10 people) try to get the wonderful square table in the center of the room...it's a great spot!  Try the Foie gras and the apple tart...HOLY MOLY!!!
author: Sarah D.

description: I think everyone's said it all already (the good things)...I really do like this place.  I've eaten there for dinner and lunch several times & never had anything I didn't like.  The service is always perfectly courteous and professional.  Cozy vibe.  I definitely recommend it.  (And parking should be easy most of the time too!)
author: Kerry L.

description: Piperade's heaven.  The service and food was great!  Decor's way cute. Too bad the my friend's frish had bones left in her dish and as a result, she started choking.  The Chef and manager came to apologize profusely, offered her a bowl of rice and more water to hopefully get the bones down. We ended up receiving 4 complimentary desserts (there were only three of us!).  Gave 4 stars because the food was soooo good, too bad for the fish bones.
author: Mare C.

description: Bleh, the entire experience was not worth what I paid.  I've been here before but didn't realize it until my boyfriend and I walked through the door.  I turned to my boyfriend and said, "I've been here already."  Then he said the most prophetic thing, "You must not have liked it if you didn't remember you came here already."  Except for the crab cake appetizer, which was really smooth and tasty, the rest of the meal was average, nothing spectacular.  I don't recommend it.
author: C L.

description: Almost perfect.  Went last year.  (I know, I know, tardy as usual.)  My meal was perfect.  Decor a wee bit mature for me still (30 something going on 25), otherwise would be a cinco.
author: Isa L.

description: I had the braised seafood and shellfish stew in a red pepper sauce, thanks to a yelp review that I found while I was dining. You get a taste of everything from clams, scallops and fish in a tasty sauce that resembles tomato soup. You must not skimp on the dessert since they do serve very fine sweets. We had the Orange Blossom Beignets, Chocolate Cake, Flan and Turron Mouse Cake. The Beignets and Chocolate Cake are good enough to try again! The bill was quite steep but at the end I felt that it was well deserved. The ambience and gourmet spanish food makes this quite an experience to go out and try.
author: Dave Y.

description:
I really like the ambiance of this restaurant.  It has a warm feeling to it.

We did not have reservations and the hostess indicated that she could seat us at the only open table if we were gone by 7:30.  We really appreciated it.

The olive oil was fantastic.  It was really robust.  

My husband had fish served on spinach and he indicated it was one of the best he had ever had.  

I had the cheese and serrano ham appetitizer as my main dish.  The selection of cheeses was very nice.  The ham was not as good as you would find in Spain which was a bit disappointing.

Once the waitress finally focused on us the service was good.  However, we sat for about 15 minutes before she even came over to us which was surprising since they wanted us out of there in a little over an hour.

Overall, it was a good experience.
author: Karen B.

description: This review is for the food only.  My second time to Piperade.  The food is quite good; the waiter we had might get a 1/2 star.  Older, lethargic guy who spent more time schmoozing with what was probably the "regulars" than on his tables.  Probably won't go back.
author: Deanne D.

description: This restaurant is one of my favorites! I am addicted to the piquillo peppers with the goat cheese topped with pine nuts and raisins. Oh My! They are truly delicious! This menu is always up to my expectations. The service is always super friendly. It is a pretty small restaurant but the location is awesome.
author: Lauren P.

description: Food is alright, nothing spectacular that would make me remember. Their lunch express in back of the building is pretty good though.
author: ji k.

description:
Outstanding food, great service, warm ambiance.
Best place in SF for an upscale business dinner or when your parents are in town.
author: Thomas K.

description: Tasty Basque food and chef, Girald Hirogoyen is very friendly and hospitable. They serve some terrific wines, especially those by winemaker, Emmanuel Kemiji. North Waterfront location is warm and cozy. They used to have a hostess there who was stunningly beautiful. Her name is Mimi or something like that. She's a "friend" of Girald's but she doesn't work there anymore. Too bad!!!!
author: Mike B.

description: This was a really good restaurant-- first time I've officially tried Basque cuisine. Not sure how authentic it was, but definitely delicious. I ordered the veal cheeks, which tasted kinda like ox tail-- but obviously with more meet. The flavor was great and the portion was sufficient. I think the price was midlevel high, but it wasn't all that bad. Loved the giant table we sat around though-- very homey--although dark as can be on the inside....must have been for atmosphere.
author: Jessy M.

description: Awesome food and service!  Loved our waiter, an older gentleman with a wry sense of humor.  He suggested a great bottle of slightly effervescent white wine for our meal.  For small plates, we had the butter lettuce salad, red peppers stuffed with cheese, and a white fish tartar that was covered with caviar, creme fraiche and oysters.  We split the salmon (large plate), which was cooked perfectly.  The warm chocolate cake dessert was smothered in creme fraiche.  Just a perfect meal!
author: brewgirl b.

description:
My fiance and I had her best friend and best friend's boyfriend up for the weekend and had reservations at Piperade.  After a quick drink at Slanted Door, we cabbed over and were told that we would have a 'short' wait until our table was ready for our 9:30 reservations.  We took a seat at the bar and perused the wine list.  The standard bar drinks were pretty fair, though the pours were kind of weak.  I hate it when a bartender just assumes the left over change is for him and just keeps it.  This is what this place's bartender did.  I would have given it all to him anyways, but they lose half a star for that because the entitlement pisses me off.  

Finally, after 30 minutes, our 'short' wait was over and we were seated (another half star off).  The restaurant was slowly emptying, but we didn't care because we got a delicious Spanish wine and some apps.  The calamari was WAY too acidic, but was still ok.  When the entres came out, we were really excited.  I got the braised pork with figs, and it was among the best food I have had.  The sauce was rich, and the bites of cabbage, fig and tenderloin were ridiculous in the levels of flavor.  My fiance got the chicken.  I usually hate it when she gets chicken because it is just so plain, but they did a great job.  It just melted in my mouth.  The fiance's best friend got the sea bass, and I was really impressed.  I love seafood, but for some reason rarely get it at nice restaurants.  It was perfectly cooked, and had real delicate flavors.  The last dish was a Salmon, and it was just as good as any of the other dishes.  The presentation was a bit lacking compared to the others, but might have been the best balanced taste-wise.

For desert, we had the chocolate cake.  It was fairly standard and forgettable.  However, for some reason they kept trying to give us the beignets which we didn't order.  We sent them back once, but since they were closing, they just decided to give it to us.  They were sooooo good.  Not New Orleans good, but REALLY good still.

Aside from the bartender, the service was average to above average.  Not enthusiastic by any stretch of the imagination, but polite, prompt and wasn't intrusive.  I would definitely recommend this place for semi-romantic dates or group dates.  It is a bit pricey (about $50 each with a bottle of wine, but not included other drinks).
author: Daniel M.

description: I have been going to Piperade as long as it's been around, and have never walked out of there disappointed. I had a large birthday party there, the service is above and beyond.. Miriam is my fav server she is always welcoming and on top of everything and who could ask for more then John behind the bar! Gerald is one of the top chefs in this city, Don't know what I'd do if they weren't there!
author: Honest in SF H.

description: Excellent Basque cuisine for a nice or more casual occasion.  Loved it the first 2 times we went.  Last time the service and food wasn't quite as good, we'll call it an off night, reason I'm giving 4 instead of 5 stars.
author: F G.

description: Need I say more than 5/5. This place is a great date, friends in town or pre-show spot to catch dinnner.  Great wine selection.
author: Yaz J.

description: I think that maybe if we had ordered differently, I would have given more stars.  A couple of the items we had were really wonderful while others were just okay.  We started with the cherry tomato tart which was by far the best thing we ate.  It is served warm with a flaky layer of pastry topped with incredibly sweet tomatoes, basil, and garlic.  Sounds so simple but it was really special.  They also split it for us and put it on separate plates which was a nice touch.  We also had the sheep's milk cheese and ham terrine which was layer after layer of salty and crunchy ham and cheese served over a frisee and apple salad.  Might be too salty for some but for a salt lover like me, it was quite delicious.  We then ordered a large plate to share and opted for the halibut.  I think this is where we didn't make the right choice.  While the halibut was good (seemed to be poached with garlic and almonds on top and served over wilted spinach), it didn't "wow" and was something that could probably be made fairly easily at home.  For dessert, we had the cornmeal cake with blackberry compote after hearing such great things about it on "Check, Please".  This was another mediocre dish and I get the sense that some of their other desserts are really show stealers.  The service was excellent and I loved the atmosphere of the restaurant and while some of the dishes didn't live up to my grand expectations, I would definitely return to try some new things (and maybe have that tomato tart again).
author: Carrie L.

description: Chicken Mandarin Avocado Salad is to die for!  I've tried to recreate it at home but I just can't seem to get it right...you win this time Piperade, but I'll figure it out someday!  Oooooh and they have the best Gingerale in town!
author: Sue K.

description: We had an amazing dinner there. It was a sudden dinner and we were able to get an early reservation. The food from top to bottom was excellent. And the service was friendly and spot on. It is one of my favorite places to eat.
author: Alek C.

description: Lovely dining room, good wine list, ordinary food, poor service.  I wouldn't go back.
author: Ken W.

description: This was my first Basque meal experience.  Not the 'typical' Spanish meal....they had light bites, but not a full tapas menu.  The waiter was quick to inform me that Sangria was not available.  I was dining with a party of 8, so we ordered 5-6 txiki (pronounced cheeky and meaning small, as in small portions).  While I'm no expert on Basque cuisine or preparation, I was struck by combinations which sound really awkward but tasted really good (calamari + mint + cantaloupe) and (goat cheese + pistachio+ raisins).  The atmosphere is definitely appropriate for a date or special occasion but formal is not required.  For my entree, I opted for the dish which is the namesake of the place.  Piperade is a nice blen of vegetables (primarily peppers, tomatoes and onions) which is garnished with a poached egg and 2 strips of Serrano ham.  The meal comes with a price tag, but the variety and creativity of the final product make for a good value.  If you want the fresh taste without the pricet ag, try to suggest Piperade for your next office outing.  ;)
author: Ron G.

description: 3 of us went for dinner.  Made reservations in advance but had to wait 20 minutes for a table.  I had the piperade entree - traditional Basque "stew" which includes famous Serrano ham and a poached egg on top.  It was very good!  Dessert was decadent - can't go wrong here.  Great bar.
author: Janice P.

description:
Piperade is certainly one of the top restaurants in the city. The food is consistently excellent. We had two excellent meals there, excellent and not that expensive for a place of this calibre. 

 Its been a while since I have visited but thought a shout out yelp was deserved. As others have said of all my dining forays in S.F Piperade is one of the few I have been to more than once.
author: Arun R.

description: My wife and I went there on our trip to the bay area...  I was so looking forward to it as I had heard so much about it..  I will say the food was really really good.. BUT  !!! THE service sucked!!!!!!!!  Our waiter was the rudest person on the planet.   I have been in the restaurant business for 22 of my 37 years on this planet so I know the rules.   We ordered apps, wine with apps, entrees, wine with entrees,  dessert, after dinner drinks.. Still we were treated like pariahs.  To top it off, they lost my credit card bringing it back to the table.  I ended up having to cancel it..  So go if you want good food, but the service blew bad.  I would not go there again due to it.
author: james b.

description:
Went here on Sat 11/24. Overall I gave it 3 stars because I am a serious 'foody' and I believe there are other restaurants in the city in this price range that are better. The ambiance is very quaint and romantic. I love the small, intimate atmosphere that is evident as soon as you walk in. The food overall was above average in my opinion with the Piperade, Lamp Chop, Steak and Pork Tenderloin being the big hits at the table. The wine selection was below average with very few California wines being represented on the menu. I understand this is Basque cuisine so the importance of representing European wines is not being understated in this review, but being that we are less than an hour away from Napa/ Sonoma I would have liked to have seen a better selection of local wines. There are very few Wines By the Glass options available. 

The big negatives for all of us were the sea food dishes. Each was very 'fishy' and the Bacalao was the most 'unique' of them all. It's undoubtedly an acquired taste and none of us were too enthused after the first bite. By the same token the Halibut, Red Snapper and Crab salad very similar to the Bacalao in terms of them being rather 'fishy' in smell and taste

The dessert selections were okay - the Cheese Yogurt is unique and worth a try if you're open to trying a more tart/sour dessert versus your traditional chocolate cake type ending.

The last comment is that as one of the last tables to finish our meal it was clear the folks at Piperade were ready to see us leave. They 'hovered' for the last 30 minutes of our meal and that was most infuriating.....irritating....and surprising.....

All in all 3 stars.....for 5 people the tab was around 400 bucks not including tip.....
author: Anon Y.

description: I went there with my co-workers for lunch, a 3-course pre-fixe menu, with soup or salad as starter, a main entree and a free choice of dessert which I think is the best part in the lunch. You really have to leave room for the dessert.  I really enjoy the food there, but I just don't like the price for the pre-fixe lunch keep increasing.
author: Emily C.

description: Cute place, very odd and deserted location, but hey, that means plenty of parking on a Friday night! This is almost as rare in SF as a restaurant with no vegetarian options. Serrano ham appetizer was delicious, both of us had fish and it was prepared just perfectly, not at all overcooked. My fish was served on a bed of spinach and covered with a brown garlic and slightly vinegary sauce, my friend's was in a green parsely sauce with root veggies. Skip the orange-blossom beingets for dessert; they were lukewarm and uninspired. But otherwise a spectacular meal, including the glass of a Spanish rose that was extra yum plus.
author: Liboo K.

description:
Very good.  I had the dungeness crab salad and tomato tartlet?  Fresh tomatoes!  The crab was good, very rich.  And they have a nice ecclectic list of wines, especially by the glass.  Some very unique varietals, but don't be afraid to ask your server for some explanations.
Oh, and I sat on their patio, very comfortable!
author: Megan C.

description: I went to the restaurant on a Wed. night and the food was great. The service was not really that nice; the restaurant was full but it is not an excuse. The food was served on time and the server was very professional but if you are looking for some personalize service, this is not the place to go. The server will do his job but will not take the time to do more. But the food was very excellent and even on a Wed. night it was full so it is a must try for the food but do not expect too much from the service.
author: Noellie G.

description:
Not a bad dinner but nothing special either. We started with the piquillo peppers stufffed with goat cheese and golden raisins. The sweetness of the raisins went quite well with the goat cheese and the peppers. I had the lamb basquaise chop/shoulder/loin and my dining partner had the piperade. The lamb shoulder and chop were quite good. The loin was a little raw even for my taste but tender nonetheless. The presentation really wasn't much to write home about and it was pretty much all meat on the plate except for a few beans. My friend's piperade looked pretty weird and it wasn't much of a presentation either.

We had a very nice 2005 Bodegas Verdutuev Volver Tempranillo for around $40. Given that it's a $12 wine on the street that's quite the markup.

Deserts were quite good. We tried the Gateau basque and the and the chocolate cake.

Service was efficient but a little gruff and impersonal. Some confusion about who was our waiter was also a little weird.

So like I said, not a bad experience but for almost $150 for 2 (including tip, tax, a bottle of wine, 1 appetizer, 2 entrees, and 2 dessert) definitely felt overpriced and not worth the trouble. Really no reason to go back.
author: Pablo P.

description: I dined here two to three times and always have had a wonderful experience.  On one occasion, I didnt have a reservation, and though it was at least a 30minute wait, I enjoyed having a drink at the bar and the hostess was always kind.  The dishes are creative - the salad appetizer with persimmon, or the squid. I had the piperade twice and enjoyed it both times.  I think the deserts have always been my favorite.  I enjoy the quaintness and snugness of the restaurant with the decor that really does remind me of the basque regions of france and spain.  Customer service is always wonderful.  I think most importantly for me, it always feels like a good value for the creativity and taste.
author: Jane D.

description:
Wednesday, May 2, 2007
5pmish 
Sat at the Bar - Tall, White Bartender - not very pleasant but we arrived a little early (they were not completely set up).  However, still no excuse for poor service.  He was extremely unfriendly, bad facial expressions, body language, etc.  Thought he might just be having a bad day....until.....two beautiful ladies with nice breasts showed up and sat down.  Boy, did that perk him up (literally).  He was over the top friendly to them and then came back to our section and totally changed his tune.  His attitude was so cold you could see your breath.  Hit changed to scalding hot when re-entered the ladies section and then changed back to freezing cold around us.  Now, I'm saying that he is homophobic - but he definitely is!!!!!
Totally shocked by this and I wasn't alone  - there were three other people with me and we all had the same experience.  First time to this establishment and most likely the last.  If you're straight - you will probably have a great time - if you're gay - better go somewhere and spend your money.  Speaking of money...I should not have left him a tip but felt compelled to leave him at least 10+% - however, he made that perfectly clear with his body language and facial expressions that it was NOT acceptable.  He's lucky he received anything - pissing off a gay person is like a women scorned!
Good luck!
author: R A.

description:
Wonderful place, great food, great service. 

I have been to Bocadillos several times and liked it, and was glad to hear that they also owned a 'proper' (no tapas, this!) restaurant like this. Dinner at Piperade was a very enjoyable experience overall. 

As wonderful as the food was (I had the piquillo pepper + goat cheese and the lamb chops), the service won the night for me. Very personable, low key, and normal - striking the right balance between being attentive and leaving me alone when I needed to be (a positive contrast with another popular-restaurant-that-shall-not-be-named where the waitress congratulated me on having pronounced the wine correctly, as if she were somewhat shocked that I did). Am going back very soon.
author: Srinivasan P.

description:
I've been here twice.
Felt TOTALLY out of place though.
1st time deserves 4 stars.
I had the Lamb and Chocolate flourless cake.
DELICIOUS!
Portions are pretty tiny, so I ordered something protein-packed so I'd be full.
Prices are really HIGH for the amount of found served.

2nd time deserves 2 stars.
UGH.
The 30 Dollar New York Steak was TERRIBLE.
My mother saw them cleaning the kitchen, so they fried the steaks-instead of putting them on a grill.
Awful flavor anyway, I couldn't eat more than two bites.
But the dessert was delicious, and thats why this place gets 2 stars rather than 1.
I had every chocolate [only 2 things anyway] dessert on the menu, and they are great.
author: Kathleen T.

description: It is difficult to give a restaurant 5 stars, but this restaurant was outstanding in every category.  The service was impeccable and friendly with great wine recommendations; the food was delicious.  The server  was knowledgeable of the different wines as well as the food.  There were four of us, each ordered a different appetizer and entre - one lamb chops, one halibut, another chicken, and another duck.  Each was cooked to perfection.  We took out of town guests and they were amazed by the fine service, food, and ambiance.  We dine out at least twice a week and seldom do I write a review, but this restaurant was special.
author: D. S.

description: A long time ago, a bartender at Piperade made up a cocktail just for me, the Autumntini and hot damn, I felt pretty special, having a cocktail designed to my exact tastes and named after me at such a great restaurant. I used to send friends there just so they could order Autumntinis. They were all the rage! That was back in the day when I lived a life of leisure, leaving the house only to lunch with friends and shop. Those days are over and this working girl has to work, indeed. My money's well spend at Piperade. I love the piquillo peppers, garlic soup, and seared tuna salad. They also make up a mean cheese plate. I am a huge fan of the restaurant's interior and comfortable, mellow vibe. It's a delightful place for lunch or dinner and service is always great. There's no more Autumntini, but the restaurant is pretty wonderful regardless. When tables are hard to come by, the bar is an equally good option and the bartenders are always a delight. And the word Piperade is just so darn fun to say.
author: Autumn K.

description:
had a great meal at piperade last night!  i won a gift certificate there in a silent auction about 6 months ago and finally went with a friend for dinner.  i loved it - cute atmosphere, and the food of course was delicious.  we shared everything - 2 small plates, 2 large plates, and desserts.  yes - we were hungry and making the most of the GC.  our small plates - dungeness crab salad and stuffed peppers - were both great.  for our large plates, we got the duck confit and the red snapper.  the duck was the special - they have traditional basque favorites that rotate every night which i thought was a nice touch.  i couldnt resist getting that dish.  both plates were great i thought, i think the snapper was my favorite thing that we got.  we also ordered the machego potato gratin side dish which was awesome, and a great complement to our other dishes which only came with vegetables.  
desserts were amazing - we couldnt pick 1 so we got 2... the orange beignets and the chocolate cake.  both were soooo good, glad we got 2! i was really impressed and will definitely go back again!!
author: Carolyn B.

description: My favorite restaurant in all of SF. I had my 30th birthday party here in January 2003, and the 8 of us took over the square sheepherder's table in the center of the restaurant. Chef Gerald Hirigoyen used to own Fringale, and now along with Bocadillos, serves amazing Basque food at the former Pastis. And plenty of parking on the street too! When we arrived, we hung out at the bar while we waited for our table, and a few us had the sublime Chateau L'Hermitage Costieres de Nimes, an off-dry white with a subtle note of honey that I have not been able to find anywhere else. It's become my favorite wine. Among the 8 of us, we had the ham and sheep's milk cheese terrine, the garlic soup with rock shrimp, the braised seafood stew, the rack of pork, the squid with grapes and foie gras, and the gateau basque. I came back in January 2005 when Piperade participated in Dine About Town. I had a perfect meal, with a cute Slovak waiter. The waiters wear jeans here, and that can prove to be a bonus. :) But come for the food, everything else is just extra. Love this place!
author: Hao L.

description: It's not often that I find myself craving Basque food; but a few days ago the urge hit me.  So I found Piperade on Battery near the Financial District.  Wow!  Piperade is Basque+++.  First of all the location's charming and the interior has a nice unpretentious loft-like feel.  The staff was friendly, attentive and helpful.   Nevertheless, it is the meal that matters most.  To start I had an amazing warm cheese and ham dish that was so good I ordered a second round.  It was warm, mild sheep's milk cheese accented with ham and aged sherry.  At this point I was in an absolute feeding frenzy.  For a main dish I enjoyed steamed snapper with spinach.  This dish had a light background of garlic vinaigrette that pulled the spinach and snapper together into blissfully mellow Basque wonderment.  Lastly I enjoyed three light and warm orange blossom beignets.  The place is great.  Service is somewhat slow but that's what you get in restaurants where preparing great food that makes people happy remains the prime directive.
author: Hale J.

description: Don't be afraid to try out this Basque restaurant. You won't find dishes that you can't pronounce, only great food that you'll want to rave about. Between three people we split the mixed baby lettuce, the thinly sliced serrano ham, the artisan foie gras, the white and green asparagus, the lamb chops, and chocolate cake. We weren't sure if it'd be enough for us, but you knew that it was after the last bite of the dessert was devoured. However, the service wasn't that great. You won't have difficulty getting what you want when you want it, you'll just get it with a bit of attitude from the snooty waiters and the icy hostess. They just perpetuate the ridiculous French maitre'd stereotype, which normally isn't true, so just take them with a grain of grey salt. It's tucked away at the end of Battery street, intersecting at Green, so you'll almost miss it if you're not paying attention. All in all a romantic little restaurant worth checking out.
author: Jenny R.

description: Piperade has quite a reputation in San Francisco but I must say that I was a little underwhelmed by my experience there recently. The restaurant is lovely and the staff is attentive and courteous but I found both my appetizer and my entree under seasoned and lacking in depth of flavor. I started with the garlic soup which I had expected to be more creamy but was actually somewhat similar to the egg drop soup you get at Chinese restaurants. It had some bland rock shrimp in it and really the overwhelming taste was salty. I could see what they were going for in the soup though and it was disappointing to me that it didn't quite come together. For my entree I had the piperade which was also good but was hampered by the fact that it was served to me way too hot and again the overwhelming flavor profile was salt. I didn't taste enough of the vegetables and it felt like they had not been allowed to cook enough to develop the flavors and let them meld together into something wonderful. I'm really bummed about my less than stellar experience but am willing to give Piperade another shot.
author: Cathy T.

description: I love foods whose names have a lot of X's; as time goes by, it appears that there are less and less dishes with consonant-laden, tongue-twister Basque names at Piperade.  I wish they would re-inject the menu with Basque pride again; it added a dimension to the experience to see dishes spelled out in their native language.  The atmosphere at Piperade is warm, inviting, and elegantly rustic and the service is attentive and friendly.  The food is usually impeccably executed, but sometimes inconsistent.  One time I had very excellent sauteed sweetbreads and beef cheek daube, and on another visit, I had an overly salted terrine with serrano ham and the rabbit entree was too salty too.  I like the modular menu that allows you to order many small plates to get a breadth of Basque cookery or go for a more standard appetizer-entree sequence.  If you are comfortable with variety meats, the sweetbreads in various incarnations is highly recommended.
author: maiko h.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 3 stars waiter / 1 star bar manager

It's been a long time since I've been truly impressed when eating out. The food I sampled here was superb. I came away satisfied with a curiosity of how I could recreate the dishes rather than the feeling that I could have done the same, if not better. 

- Bread - generous Acme? whole wheat sourdough levain w. excellent olive oil. 
- Appetizer - Cold poached foie gras w. quince compote - accompanied by a sprinkled streak of sea salt & ground pepper; served w. thin toasted wheat bread. The sweet-tart quince (texture of applesauce) and crunchiness of the salt paired w. the fatty duck wonderfully. The waiter automatically split our appetizer into 2 portions without prompting. Very good, silky, smooth, the flavor of duck was delicate, not the least bit strong.
- Seared duck breast w. sunchokes, cippolini & huckleberry sauce - Wow. incredible. Thick duck medallions perfectly medium rare came w. its crispy skin. Surprisingly the tart huckleberry sauce accompanied it so well. The sunchokes (jerusalem artichokes / potato like tubers) were thin shaved and stirfried until crispy. More assertive flavor than potato, I kept digging under my duck to unearth more sunchokes. Wonderfully harmonious dish. The only dissent came from the fresh italian parsley sprinkled over the chokes & onions, green flavor was a bit overpowering. 
- Lamb chops w. potato confit, fennel & some sort of relish - lamb came in thick portions, also very well cooked, great flavor. I appreciated the deviation from typical rosemary or mint seasonings. This one used a light cumin seasoning. great lamb. The potatoes were well-cooked, perhaps needed a bit more salt (i'm not a huge fan of potatoes), fennel was braised, not much flavoring beyond its own slight licorice taste, a little bland. 
- Dessert - Orange blossom beignets - very light, airy, almost like a soft choux batter. Moist inside, well dusted w. powdered sugar (dough was not too sweet). Also not particularly drawn to orange blossom essence but this was not overwhelming.
- Coffee - flavorful, not bitter. excellently paired w. dessert

Bar manager was extremely rude & put-offish. Waiter was nice, attentive, and professional. 

Friday night w. reservations, the place was packed.
The dining area is an unusual angular shaped open space with wooden floors and warm lighting. There's a nifty recycled wine bottle chandelier centerpiece over a large round family table. 

In summary: 
Very good food, well prepared. Different from the conventional French style of preparation or Spanish flavors. I'm interested in trying a fish dish sometime.
author: A. T.

description: i love everything about this place!  last night we had a dinner here thanks to my lovely boss. parking was perfect at 8:30, right in front of the restaurant. lights low, great service (although he had a very thick accent, he was smiling and having fun with us). and when we go out, we loove to try everything. for me, i had to try this garlic soup. it was more of a egg drop soup, with rock shrimp, bacon. it was aboslutely amazing. im not usually a soup person, but the garlic was rich, not over powering but was the main focus on the soup, and plus for them for not having any cream in it. three others at the table got the dungeness crab with mango, roasted red pepper. i ate half of my co-workers it was so yum!! oh and another must try is the sheep milk cheese & ham terrine with aged sherry. i also practically ate the entire plate. Going into entrees, since we normally don't have meat at the house, the NY steak was WOW. med-rare, perfect, caramelized shallots, scrumptious. everyone got a little piece and raved about it. For the table we got the side of fries, which had to have been deep fried in beef fat, you seriously couldn't get enough! And to the even MORE amazing parts of dinner...DESSERT. *insert drool here*. we needed to try alot, so we ordered eight different ones and just shared. too much to write every single one, but hands down, my favorite ended up being the Gateau Basque with cherry preserve! i tasted heaven and it was great.
author: Abigail W.

description: took my brother there for his birthday , very elegant place , the whole setting and meal and presentation was perfect waitress was very profesional made the experience even better this is the kind of place u wanta take an important guest from out of town to , it will make u look good ;)
author: NAEL K.

description: hearty,distinctively flavored basque cuisine.warm and cozy without being cramped, the chef usually makes an appearance to greet his patrons.fantastic service.( must try dish:pacific red snapper).
author: aj s.

description: This is my first review.  I had to let people know about this place. I went there for a first date on a recomendation from a friend.  Huge disapointment!!   After being seated to a table with a fork and a huge kerral of dryed food in it ( which I never got back) The service was and food was not what I was expecting.  The cappacio was not good at all.  I had the crab salad that was nothing special.  In fairness my Halibut dish was good the orzo was tasty more than the fish.  My date I could tell was really disapointed.  He ordered lamb.  I tasted it and it sucked.  The waiter said it was going to be braised med rare.  Hello Braised and med rare and two totally different things.  It accually come to the table med.   Our finished plates sad forever on our table on all three courses.  Then the bussboy was resetting a table next to us.  He shook out the tablecloth so a dust cloud of cotten balls fell into both our wine glasses.  I would really give then one and a  half stars because the orzo was really  good.
author: cecilia g.

description: OMG. I don't even know what I ordered... I basically took the recommendations of my knowledgeable, slightly-accented waiter and everything was AMAZING. The food was so fresh and well-seasoned. The serving sizes were well proportioned and the ambiance was not too trendy (which I prefer). Despite the great reviews, I didn't have many expectations walking in but all-in-all, it was one of the better surprise dining experiences I've had in the city. In particular, the Serrano ham was off the hook and the caramel custard dessert to die for!
author: C K.

description: tried  just two dishes (expected to try more) and the crab first course seemed like it was made from the canned crab one gets at trader Joes, or it was made a day or two in advance and kept in fridge. The grilled sheep's cheese ham thing was good but a little like home food.
author: bob o.

description: i wasn't too enthused when my holiday lunch for work was to be at piperade.  i had previously been to the estabilishment when it was pastis and wasn't super wowed by it.  i was pleasantly surprised by the array of apps.  the foie gras was delicious.  the dungeness crab salad was nicely mixed apple and mango.  the serrano ham also steller.  for my entree, i had the ny steak.  about half our party ordered it and we all cleaned our plates.  for dessert, i had the chocolate cake with creme fraiche.  it was heavenly and by far the best in comparison to the beingets and turron mousse cake.  only bummer was that the waitress forgot our coffee with our desserts.
author: Sharlene C.

description: Best Basque food in SF - hands down.  Consistently good - you can never order wrong from the menu here.  And very romantic/charming venue.  Perfect for a Saturday night out.
author: Lisa K.

description: I really enjoyed this place. We ate there last night. Good wine selection and good food. The lamb, duck, and seafood stew were delicious, and that was the most jamon serrano i have ever seen. The service did mess up our drink orders twice, but were extremely prompt to respond and pretty funny about it to boot. I will definitely be back.
author: Bennett C.

description: I want to give them 4 stars for food, but I simply cannot because their service was so terrible the other night.  Monday night - reservations at 8 pm - the place was pretty full - so we weren't seated until 8:30 pm.  Normally, I appreciate the European way of dining leisurely, but I wasn't in the mood for it since it was a "school night."  The waiter didn't take our order until 9 pm, and we kept having to remind him about refilling our water.  Service was nice, but so slow that I was exhausted by dessert time.  I have to admit that the food was excellent - the fig and haricot vert salad was perfectly dressed with a walnut oil vinagrette, and the steak was delicious!  The fruit tart was divine;  the orange beignets were okay, not great.  I did love that the environment was pretty lively, especially on a Monday night.  I just hope that I can go back on another night when I have the energy and time for a leisurely late night meal.
author: Christina S.

description: nice atmosphere good service. wouldnt come here on my own dollar or on my own time i must say. The food was ok, nothing special. their bread and cheese is good and they do have some of the best desserts i have ever tried . get the chocolate cake thing with a crunchy bottom, or the chocolate with white moose on it. their meals and appetizers werent great and the portions were small.
author: Wats C.

description: perhaps my favorite restaurant in the city.  the food is f-a-n-t-a-s-t-i-c !!!  Great place for lunch (went there twice last summer) ... dynamite dinner tonight -- great location.  wow.  given the 1/2 star option, i'd mark it down to 4 1/2 stars as it's a wee bit expensive (my hand cramped as i signed la cuenta) ... 3 apps., 3 dins, 2 bottles of wine ($35/per average [basque white/red]) + 3 glasses of 20yr port = $310.  i'll be back (either w/ a bigger budget or a more discriminating appetite).
author: Gavin M.

description: Haven't much exposure to Basque, but definitely enjoyed Piperade on my visits.  Unlike many other establishments in the city which gets over-San Franciscanized (take that, Pat Riley and your three-peat patent), Piperade doesn't conform to the "this is how you do ______ in California" style.  Rather, it retains what makes it successful.
author: Benson J.

description: I am only giving this 3 stars. The food was good (the Piperade entree didn't really rock my world, even after all the good words) but the garlic soup appetizer was really great. I had this and the Piperade, which were both light dishes, so i guess overall it was a healthy dinner. I docked it stars because the customer service i thought was a bit snitty. I didn't like our waiter much - he seemed to have an attitude and not once, did he ever offer to refill my husband's soda. We even put the empty glass right at the edge of the table - still didn't get the hint. There's an asian guy who serves the bread and brings out the dishes; don't think he speaks english. got our entrees mixed up, and he came by once to take away dishes, and as was clearing the table i asked him for some fresh black pepper. He just started walking away so i said excuse me! He turned to look at me and continued walking away. i thought he would call our waiter over, but didn't. so i had to flag our waiter for fresh black pepper. He came over, did some turns and rapidly walked away, as if i had really inconvenienced him. He didn't bother to even ask my mom and husband if they would like any. So food was good, mediocre, condescending service enough to keep me from another visit anytime soon, or by choice.
author: Chris C.

description: Went here for valentines day and the decorations were pretty ridiculous: tons of helium balloons with the ribbons hanging down (into the food, tangling up the poor bus boys!) - if you've seen the Sex and the City movie it was just like when Miranda and Carrie go to dinner on valentines day - which I'm pretty sure was designed to be a joke and no real restaurant should ever do that.  I was a bit disappointed they had a prix fixe menu.  There were only one or two things on the prix fixe menu that were actually on the regular menu so I can't really comment on the standard menu items - what we had was ok.  Apps were a salad with truffle vinaigrette that didn't taste at all like truffles but was fairly tasty anyway, and chestnut and celery root soup that was pretty good, mostly because it had a ton of heavy cream in it I think.  For our main course we had steak that was pretty standard and lamb chops that were the same. The standout of the whole night was definitely the flourless chocolate torte for dessert.  I did like that the prix fixe included a glass of cava though!  I would like to go back and try their regular menu of small plates.
author: Erin L.

description: Ooh..a treat when you can afford it.  I went for lunch once and got the Lobster salad and the Veal cheeks...both to die for!!  The veal cheeks especially were like butter..so tender and delicious!  A meal that I will never forget.
author: M M.

description: I met a friend for lunch here today. Our food was very good but nothing incredible. Our server vanished for a good portion of the meal, luckily reappearing when we were ready to get the check but it would have been nice if she checked in a bit more so I didn't have to ask other servers to refill my glass of water. I'm not a demanding diner, so this place is fine in my book. Nothing bad, nothing amazing. Pretty good.
author: Nicole R.

description: The food is uniformly good, which is what you'd expect in a small restaurant where the owner/chef is present and clearly vigilant.  I don't understand the quibbles about the service on these pages, since on the two occasions I've eaten here, the service has been correct and professional in the French manner.  (I really don't want to know my waiter's name or  the source for every ingredient.)
author: John C.

description: My wife had seen a rave review of this restuarant on the Check Please television show so when her birthday came along I asked where she wanted to go and she replied Piperade.  Now I'm not familiar with Basque food but I'm always willing to try a new cuisine. The resturant is located in the 1000 block of Battery which in the evening offers lots of free parking close by so that was definately a plus. The resturant is set in what looks like an old factory - with it's old unreinforced brick masonary look giving it an old world feel.  When we were seated for our 7:30 reservation the place was crowded, and , like another reviewer mentioned, not a lot of young people under 30 there.  Our waiter was very helpful and the wine list was truly impressive.  The small dishes were superb.  We ordered the Garlic Soup which I found to be delicious, but then again I love garlic.  My companion was not so enthused with it. The heirloom tomato, herbs, and watermelon dish was a feast for the taste buds and definatley a must here as was the braised calimari in tomato sauce.  In fact according to a friend that dines here often, you can't go wrong with any of the small dishes.  Our dining experience went south, however, when I ordered the Basque Special which was Duck.with lentils and mango I believe.  The lentils and friuity sauce was wonderful but it couldn't save the bird which was so over cooked that I've had ducks that have been hanging in the windows of Chinatown for a week that were more tender and moist.  The leg and thigh portion was so dry and tastless and was helped little by the fruity sauce. I guess it was my bad that I didn't return it but I tried to struggle on with the dish.  On the other hand the Angus beef with carmalized onions was incredible. The deserts were only so so as well as the flan I had was rather ordinary.  Outside the washroom, which was as hot as a sauna, framed clippings and magazine covers heralding  this resturant. lined the walls.  My trip here was just a little less enthusiastic. Our waiter, it should be mentioned,  was attentive throughout and if I ever go back here I would stick to small dishes exclusively as I saw others at the surrounding tables do.
author: Nick C.
